HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Weakens Against Yen But Gains a Bit on the Mark

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar ended weaker against the yen but modestly higher against the mark yesterday amid growing doubts about Europe's plan to establish a single currency by 1999.
 Talk of a delay in the timetable for a single currency spread through the market after Prime Minister Romano Prodi of Italy said in a television interview that Germany might ask that the start of the monetary union be rescheduled. 
 Although the German Finance Ministry later denied any plans to change the starting date, Mr. Prodi's comments weighed heavily on the market, sweeping the mark higher against the currencies of many of its European neighbors, particularly the Italian lira.
 The lira fell to its lowest level against the mark in more than three months, rising above 1,000 a mark despite talk that the Bank of Italy was actively selling marks for lire in an effort to defend the currency.
 "The market is clearly concerned about the timing to monetary union," said Dennis Pettit, foreign exchange manager at the Long Term Credit Bank of Japan.
The mark tends to benefit at the expense of other European currencies when doubts about the planned single currency arise because it has less to gain from the project.
 While traders bought the mark against other European currencies yesterday, they sold the German currency against the yen, which benefited from renewed hopes for a recovery in the Japanese economy.
 The governor of the Bank of Japan, Yasuo Matsushita, said in a speech yesterday that Japan's economy was gradually recovering.
 Buying of yen pushed the mark to its lowest level against the Japanese currency in eight months and led the dollar lower against the yen.
 In late trading in New York, the dollar fell to 120.22 yen from 120.69 yen on Thursday and rose to 1.6903 marks from 1.6875 marks. The British pound rosed to $1.6295 from $1.6258.
Currency traders said they remained optimistic about the dollar despite yesterday's mixed showing.
 In other trading, the Mexican peso ended higher against the dollar after the United States recertified Mexico as an ally in the war on drugs.
 The peso edged up to 12.5945 cents, from 12.5786 cents on Thursday.

HEADLINE: Compromise May Be in Works on Acquisition by Staples

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28

 BODY:
Federal antitrust regulators have canceled a meeting planned for Saturday to review -- and possibly block -- Staples Inc.'s proposed acquisition of Office Depot Inc., officials said today.
The delay indicates that senior Federal Trade Commission officials are searching for a compromise to allow the $3.4 billion deal to go forward in spite of strong misgivings at the staff level about the economic wisdom of the combination of the two top office supply retailers. 
 The combination would create an office supply colossus with 1,100 stores and $10.7 billion in annual sales.
Company officials and lawyers for the regulatory agency have conducted a week of intensive discussions over whether, and in what form, the merger should be permitted.
People close to the negotiations said that the F.T.C. staff was concerned that domination of the office supply superstore business by two huge chains would make it virtually impossible for a new competitor to enter the market. Regulators are looking at the office supply market city by city to see how the proposed merger would affect competition and pricing.
Several analysts suggested that regulators might permit the deal if Staples agrees to spin off several dozen stores in cities where the two chains' outlets overlap and if it pledges to keep consumer prices down.
No date has been set for the five-member commission to weigh whether to permit the merger or to challenge it in court.
Agency officials said that the proposed merger presented some of the thorniest antitrust questions they had wrestled with in the last four years. Office supply superstores are a new and evolving business and there is little precedent for the combination of the No. 1 and No. 2 companies in a fast-changing three-player industry.
If the deal goes through, the new company's only remaining competitor in the specialized office supply supermarket business would be Officemax Inc., with about 500 stores and $3.3 billion in annual sales.
The two companies today agreed to extend their merger agreement until May 31 in hopes that a settlement can be reached with the Federal agency. The Staples stock offer for Office Depot was to have expired today.
Staples executives have argued before the agency -- as well as in an expensive nationwide advertising campaign -- that the merger would yield cost efficiencies and lower consumer prices.
The chairman of Staples, Thomas Stemberg, has said that the new entity would control only 5 percent of the office supply market, competing in a highly fragmented environment with catalogue operations, warehouse clubs, local stationers and large general retailers like Wal-Mart Stores.
But some F.T.C. staff lawyers and consumer advocates contend the merger would be anticompetitive and allow the new entity to raise prices with impunity.
Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, and Bart Naylor, an official of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, met with F.T.C. staff members earlier this week to lobby against the deal.
"Three competitors are better than two, and they are three giants," Mr. Nader said in an interview after his meeting. "Competition creates price efficiency for consumers."
Mr. Nader said that a study conducted by his Consumer Project on Technology had demonstrated that prices were lower in markets where Staples and Office Depot compete head to head.
The survey showed that thermal fax paper costs as much as $26.99 a roll in locations with no superstore competition and as little as $13.99 where Staples and Office Depot stores were close neighbors.
But a top Staples executive dismissed the Nader study as "statistical hogwash" based on a one-item sample and "sixth-grade analysis."

HEADLINE: Growth Rate In 4th Quarter Cut to 3.9%

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28

 BODY:
The economy grew at an annual rate of 3.9 percent in the fourth quarter, slower than the 4.7 percent estimated originally, the Commerce Department said today. A measure of inflation remained at a 30-year low.
The department attributed the downward revision in the growth of gross domestic product to an unexpected liquidation of inventories at retailers and other businesses. Farm inventories were also smaller than previously estimated, export growth was slower and military spending was lower. 
 Analysts had expected, on average, growth to be revised downward only to a 4.2 percent pace. In the third quarter, the economy grew at an annual rate of 2.1 percent.
The 3.9 percent rate "is still a pretty strong number," said Tony Riley, an economist at A. Gary Shilling & Company in Springfield, N.J.
Dan Seto, an economist at Nikko Securities Company International, said the inventory revision "gives us weaker growth but suggests there is more room for it" in the first part of the year as those inventories are replaced.
In all of 1996, gross domestic product, which measures the nation's output of goods and services but does not include income from abroad, grew 2.4 percent, down from the 2.5 percent reported previously but up from 1995's 2 percent expansion.
In a separate report today, the National Association of Realtors said home resales rose 2.1 percent in January. Analysts had expected the report to show no change in the month. A third economic report, from the Chicago Purchasing Management Association, showed the February index of manufacturing rising to 56.2 from 55.9 last month, a sign of improving manufacturing strength in the region.
"It really says that we are looking at decent strength on all fronts," Richard Berner, chief economist at the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh, said of the data.
In the current quarter, which ends March 31, growth will probably run at a healthy annual pace of 2 to 3 percent. The Federal Reserve's chairman, Alan Greenspan, said this week in his twice-yearly report about the economy that prospects "in general are quite favorable," although he suggested the Fed might soon raise interest rates to guard against inflation.
The Government issues three calculations of each quarter's gross domestic product as information becomes available to its economists. The final revision will be issued March 28.
On the inflation front, the price deflator, a measure of price increases that is watched by Wall Street, grew at an unrevised 1.4 percent pace in the fourth quarter. That was the lowest reading since the first quarter of 1967, a Government spokesman said.
The price deflator measures the magnitude of price increases and detects whether higher costs drive consumers away from a product.
The price index for gross domestic purchases, which tracks the price of all goods purchased in the country, including imports, grew at a 2.5 percent rate in the fourth quarter, the same as previously reported.
The G.D.P. chain-weighted index, which tracks changes in the price of all goods and services made in the United States, increased at an unrevised 1.8 percent rate.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Real Economic Growth"
Annual rate of change in the value of the gross domestic product, bases on seasonally and inflation-adjusted figures for the quarter. (Source: Commerce Department)

HEADLINE: Japan's Road to Deep Deficit Is Paved With Public Works

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: SHINTOKU, Japan

 BODY:
When the national and local governments built a $4 million "agricultural airport" in this small town in northern Japan, they said it would allow local farmers to get higher prices for their vegetables by flying them to market while still fresh instead of sending them by truck, a three-day trip.
What the officials overlooked was that each flight would cost more than $4,000 but could carry no more than $3,000 in vegetables. Moreover, since the planes are too small to make it all the way to Tokyo or Osaka, trucks are sometimes still needed for part of the journey, and shipping time is cut by only one day. Last year, only 10 flights took off from the airport, and taxpayers are wondering if their money was well spent. 
 "It may be good for a children's playground," said Kayoko Omiyo, the wife of a farmer. The town government is indeed thinking of turning the runway over for in-line skating, and cross-country skiing in the winter, to make greater use of the site.
With their nation facing a severe budget deficit, people in Japan are starting to object to the spending for public works projects that have played an outsized role in Japan's economy and political system. The questioning is part of a broader reassessment of public spending policy and of Japan's once-admired bureaucracy, both of which are now being seen as riddled with waste and corruption.
Japan spends more on public construction, about $300 billion, than the Pentagon spends on defense. Critics call Japan "doken kokka," the "construction state," a reference not only to the magnitude of the activity but also to the cozy relationships between contractors and Government officials that keeps pork-barrel projects coming. Public works have also long been a sore point in trade with the United States, as American companies seeking a share of the huge projects have complained of a bidding system that locks them out of contracts.
"The construction state is in some respects akin to the military-industrial complex in cold-war America (or the Soviet Union), sucking in the country's wealth, consuming it inefficiently, growing like a cancer and bequeathing both fiscal crisis and environmental devastation," Gavan McCormack, a professor of Japanese history at Australia National University, wrote in "The Emptiness of Japanese Affluence," a recent book.
In the last few years, public works spending has been stepped up even more to stimulate a languid economy. Everywhere you look, roads are being paved or dug up, rivers dammed, bays filled to make new land, and domed arenas erected. Projects range from the $7.6 billion Akashi Straits Bridge, which is being built near Kobe and which will be the longest bridge in the world, to the art museum for the small town of Ono, completed in 1993, which displays only reproductions because there was no money to buy art.
The statistics alone are staggering. Japan uses as much cement each year as the United States, despite having only half the population and only 4 percent of the land area. Japan's construction industry, with 500,000 companies and 6.6 million workers, accounts for 10 percent of the country's employment compared with 5 to 7 percent in other advanced nations. Public works spending in Japan amounts to about 6.6 percent of gross domestic product compared with 1.6 percent in the United States and 2 to 3 percent for Western European nations, according to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.
But now the Cabinet has formed a task force to cut public construction expenses. Citizens have begun to question Government extravagance in public buildings. And environmentalists have started fighting the construction binge that has left only 3 of Japan's 113 major rivers flowing freely and only 45 percent of the coastline of the four main islands in a natural state.
The press is having a field day digging up white elephants, like the pier at Fukui, a port to which ships rarely come, that is called a "10 billion yen fishing hole" by local residents. The pier, sitting empty except for fishermen, actually cost 30 billion yen, or $250 million.
A fiscal crisis is driving Japan's reassessment. After years of lecturing the United States to reduce its Federal budget deficit, Japan has developed a deficit of its own that is far worse proportionately than Washington's.
In 1996, Japan's central and local budget deficits amounted to 7 percent of gross domestic product, the highest among the Group of Seven major industrial countries. The figure for the United States is less than 2 percent. Some 22 percent of next year's budget will be spent on interest payments on the accumulated debt -- more than on education, science and the military combined.
"Japan holds a time bomb that is expected to explode in a few years, and the bomb gets bigger every year," an advisory committee to the Ministry of Finance said in a recent report.
The deficit results from several years of a weak economy, which forced the Government to cut taxes and to increase spending to prime the pump. Since 1992, the Government has announced stimulus packages worth $560 billion, with much of it spent on public works. The budgets included $50 billion in 1995 alone for relief and reconstruction after the Kobe earthquake.
Despite such infusions, the economy still has not fully recovered. Some economists say the public works stimulus is losing its effectiveness, though others say it kept the economy from a deeper recession.
Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto has suggested that the Government might review a pledge to spend more than $5 trillion on public works from 1995 to 2004. The promise was made in response to demands by the United States that Japan stimulate domestic spending to increase imports.
Critics also label spending for agriculture as wasteful, including $50 billion the Government committed to spend over six years to compensate farmers for the partial opening of the rice market to imports. Takigawa, a town in northern Japan, is building a hot springs resort using agricultural promotion funds, justifying it on the grounds that a shop on the premises will sell local produce.
But cutting back on public works is proving to be difficult. Those expecting sharp cutbacks next year were outraged that the proposed budget included $10 billion for extensions of bullet train lines that analysts expect to prove uneconomical.
Too much fiscal tightness could plunge the still-fragile economy into recession. Japan is already planning to raise taxes this year to fight the deficit and the United States is cautioning Japan not to restrict spending too much.
But a bigger reason is that pork-barrel politics is deeply ingrained. Politicians push for big projects for their districts, not only to satisfy voters but because construction companies have long been among the biggest contributors to the Liberal Democratic Party. The party has governed Japan for most of the post-World War II period and is now back in power after a three-year hiatus. Ministries also fight any diminution of their budgets.
Bribery of public officials to win contracts is common. So is bid-rigging, in part because bidding on many projects is open only to designated companies, shutting out foreign firms, among others. Those factors have helped make construction costs in Japan at least 30 to 40 percent higher than in the United States.
Government officials contend, and many citizens agree, that Japan needs to improve its infrastructure . The war leveled large parts of the country, and Japan has emphasized developing industry over improvements that would have been considered consumer amenities.
Half of Japan's population lives in homes that are not connected to sewage systems. And Japan has only 4,000 miles of expressways compared with 5,500 in France and 7,000 in Germany. Most of its highways are only two lanes in each direction and are clogged.
"Japan is still a developing country compared with Western Europe and the United States," said Yasuo Mitsuie, a Ministry of Construction official.
But critics say that politics drives projects to take on a life of their own, even if the need for them disappears.
"The construction itself is the purpose," said Hirofumi Uzawa, a retired University of Tokyo economics professor.
There are some signs of change. In a rare move, the Ministry of Construction has canceled plans for four dams -- of 300 being built or planned. The Ministry of Agriculture is reviewing its agricultural airport program because the four that have been completed have been failures.
But the construction state will not die easily. Indeed, a project to top all others is now being planned -- to move the nation's capital out of Tokyo by the year 2010.
To reduce the congestion and concentration of power in Tokyo, a new capital city of 600,000 people is to be built. The initial cost estimate is more than $100 billion, but it is likely to cost much more.

HEADLINE: A Rational Way to Reduce the Deficit

 BODY:
The Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, has bravely called for a commission to fix -- more accurately, lower -- the Government's measure of inflation, the first step toward reducing Social Security payments to the elderly and raising personal income taxes. Revising that yardstick, the Consumer Price Index, would knock perhaps $1 trillion off the deficit over 12 years and spread the burden of the budget cuts across the population.
But President Clinton and most Congressional leaders -- with the notable exception of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York -- have refused to take on the elderly and other beneficiaries of an overly generous inflation gauge until Mr. Lott made the first move. The Senate minority leader, Tom Daschle, embraced the proposal. The White House expressed lukewarm acceptance. 
 A panel of economists reported last year to Congress that the gauge was probably off by about one percentage point a year. The panel estimated that if Congress adjusted its benefit and tax schedules accordingly, it could reduce the deficit by about a third, or $60 billion, by 2002. The correction would reduce Social Security benefits by an average of $100 next year, and raise taxes by about the same amount for a family earning $50,000.
To fix the problem, Congress need not tamper with the actual computation of the index, which is produced by a professional, nonpartisan staff at the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Instead it could forthrightly acknowledge that the official measure is exaggerated, that a reliable measure is not yet available and that it will make a reasonable correction for the purposes of adjusting Federal spending and tax programs. But because the exact size of the correction is uncertain, Congress should exempt disability benefits and other payments to the poor.
Adjusting the Consumer Price Index is a better way to balance the budget than big cuts to public investments and other valuable Federal programs.

HEADLINE: Ford Files for Initial Hertz Offering

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich.. Feb. 28

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company, aiming to unlock more of the value tied up in its nonautomotive assets, said today that it planned to sell less than 20 percent of its Hertz Corporation car rental unit in an initial public offering.
Ford said the offering, which had been long expected, will involve newly issued shares of Hertz common stock. A registration statement for the offering was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington. 
 The transaction will mark the end of Ford's three-year ownership of 100 percent of Hertz, which claims to be the world's largest car rental concern.
Ford first invested in the car rental giant, which is based in Park Ridge, N.J., in 1987 to gain a captive customer for its vehicles. The strategy, also pursued by General Motors and Chrysler, allowed the auto maker to keep its factories running during the early 1990's recession, but barely used rental cars soon lured buyers away from new cars.
Analysts said today that Hertz as a whole was worth up to $3 billion, meaning that Ford could gain up to $600 million in cash in the 20 percent offering.

HEADLINE: Long Bond Unchanged in Mixed Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, as end-of-month buying partly offset investors' concern that the Federal Reserve would raise short-term interest rates to keep the economy from overheating.
Traders said the morning release of economic reports showing a rise in home resales and manufacturing heightened the anxiety investors evidenced since Wednesday. The Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, said in Senate testimony then that the central bank could move pre-emptively to counter inflation without waiting for signs to appear. 
 The price of a 30-year Government bond was unchanged from Thursday at 9725/32 , to yield 6.80 percent, while the price of a two-year note fell 1/32 , to 9920/32 , to yield 6.08 percent.
"It's simple," said David Ader, managing analyst with Technical Data, Boston. "The market believes that Greenspan has told us he wants to tighten, and he doesn't need inflation to do it. He is willing to make a pre-emptive move, and we are still reeling from that pronouncement. I don't see a chance for this market to have much more than a short-lived bounce until, and unless, we get some very friendly data."
The National Association of Realtors reported that resales of homes rose 2.1 percent in January, a stark contrast to analysts' forecast of no change. And the Chicago Purchasing Management Association said its February index of manufacturing rose to 56.2 from 55.9 in January, a sign of improving manufacturing in the region, as the prices-paid component, which is viewed by some market participants as a measure of inflation, fell to 56 from 57.4.
"However," said Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber, "the vendor performance index of delivery lead times," which, he said, is one of Mr. Greenspan's favorite indicators, "jumped from 47.6 to 56 in the Chicago purchasing agents' survey."
He added, "The odds for Fed tightening will rise further if a similar vendor performance rise is reported in the overall N.A.P.M. survey to be released on Monday."
The Commerce Department said fourth-quarter gross domestic product grew at an annual rate of 3.9 percent last year, down from its original estimate of 4.7 percent. But the drop did little to comfort investors, since the revised number was still fairly strong. Analysts surveyed by Bloomberg News had forecast that G.D.P. would be revised down to 4.2 percent.
Despite the downward revision, analysts noted that some market participants saw within the report a drop in inventories, which could be a sign of strong first-quarter growth.
Elliott Platt, director of research at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said economic growth during the first two quarters of 1997 would be contingent upon trade. He said the trade deficit was unsustainably low in the fourth quarter of 1996.
The February employment report on Friday will help investors develop a view as to the outlook for a rate increase at the March 25 Federal Open Market Committee meeting.
The Fed has held the line on a rate adjustment since January 1996, even as the economy expanded because inflation has been benign. February nonfarm employment is expected to rise by 204,000, slowing from a 271,000 rise in January.

HEADLINE: Stocks Fall Again as Dow Drops 47.33

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
Stock prices fell for the third straight day yesterday, as many technology stocks continued to slump and investors became cautious in the wake of Alan Greenspan's warning about "excessive optimism" in the financial markets.
Since the Fed chairman testified before the Senate Banking Committee on Wednesday, the Dow Jones industrial average has lost 160.47 points, or 2.3 percent. Yesterday, the Dow was off 47.33 points, to 6,877.74. 
 "I think Greenspan just spooked the buyers," said Laszlo Birinyi, president of Birinyi Associates, a research firm in Greenwich, Conn. "We have seen the buyers become much more cautious, but there's not so much selling."
Mr. Birinyi said that despite the attention given Mr. Greenspan's warnings, the market has not lost much of its strength. Further, what it has lost recently has come as much from a faltering technology sector as from the Fed chairman's cautioning, he said.
For the week, the Dow was down 53.88 points. After zooming up 106.59 points on Monday and Tuesday, the Dow retreated to finish the week with its lowest close since Feb. 11 -- just two days before the Dow topped 7,000 for the first time.
The Nasdaq composite index fell 3.66 points yesterday to close at 1,309. For the month, the technology-heavy Nasdaq lost 5.1 percent. Yesterday, Microsoft and Intel made a comeback, but other technology shares -- particularly computer networking companies -- continued to falter. Microsoft was up 1 3/8, to 97 1/2, and Intel was up 29/64 , to 141 7/8. But Ascend Communications lost 4 3/4, to 52 1/4, and 3Com was down 157/64 , to 337/64 .
While the Dow has risen 6.6 percent this year, the Nasdaq has gained just 1.4 percent. Without some of its leading technology stocks, the Nasdaq has actually lost ground this year. The Russell 2000 index of small- capitalization stocks is down seven-tenths of 1 percent.
"There is this dichotomy in the marketplace," Ned Riley Jr., chief investment officer at BankBoston, said. "It's been more of a defensive market than an offensive market for the last seven months."
Mr. Riley said that investors believed that large-cap stocks were safer, particularly in the event of an economic downturn, while smaller stocks are considered more vulnerable. "One reason for the dichotomy is that the market is discounting a slower economy in 1997 than the Fed has forecast," he said.
In contrast to the troubles of stocks, gold has recently made a comeback. Some believe a rise in the price of gold is a sign of increasing expectations of inflation. Gold rose $4.10 an ounce yesterday, to $365.10 in New York. Since Feb. 13, the price has risen $22.
"With the bond market flat this year, I think gold has taken over as the lead daily indicator," Mr. Birinyi said. He noted that stocks had made some of their biggest losses this year on days when the price of gold had gained. And although the stock and bond markets have often moved in tandem this year, they have also frequently decoupled, he said. Yesterday, as stocks slid, the bond market was flat, with the benchmark 30-year Treasury holding steady at 6.80.
The biggest losers in the Dow 30 were General Electric, down 2 1/4, to 102 7/8; J. P. Morgan, off 2 1/8, to 105; and Merck, down 1 3/4, to 92 1/8. Merck has lost about $5, or 5.8 percent, since announcing on Tuesday that it would buy back about $5 billion worth of shares and increase its dividend.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks also fell, closing down 4.25, to 790.82, dragged down by declining energy and financial issues.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Ruler of Japan Ports Not Cowed by U.S.

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 28

 BODY:
When the United States imposed new trade sanctions against Japan this week, it was taking on not just the Japanese Government but also a far more formidable figure -- a little-known 83-year-old Japanese businessman who governs the nation's ports as if they were his own backyard.
Shiro Takashima, who has run Japan's ports for two decades, has created a system that is among the most tightly ruled, opaque operations in the world, and probably the most expensive. And Mr. Takashima, shows no signs of changing a thing. 
 Indeed, he has reportedly threatened to retaliate against Washington by banning all American ships from Japan.
Mr. Takashima is an oddity in the world at the end of the 20th century, an authoritarian traditionalist running modern container ports in one of the world's great trading nations. Japan had $689 billion in two-way trade last year, and Mr. Takashima controlled virtually every ship.
"You have to play by the rules in all aspects if you want to get anything done," said a United States official, who insisted on not being identified. "It goes to the balance of power on the wharf, and right now, it's a dictatorship. And there are lots of costs associated with that, and it's discriminatory to boot."
Japan's ports have always been run with a touch of xenophobia, ever since the nation virtually closed them to the outside for more than two centuries beginning in the early 1600's. Moreover, around the end of World War II, the ports became dominated by mobsters, and it has been hard for the ports to shed that shady image.
The latest dispute escalated sharply Wednesday when the United States said it would impose sanctions against Japanese shipping companies, in retaliation for Japan's failure to liberalize its port practices. Japan has angrily denounced the United States action and threatened to appeal to the World Trade Organization.
At the center of the dispute is Mr. Takashima, who runs his own stevedore company and is chairman of an influential association, the Japan Harbor Transportation Association. Mr. Takashima declined to make any comment. A fierce, imposing man who has spent most of his life in the business, Mr. Takashima oversees domestic as well as foreign shipping companies, shipping executives and analysts say.
"Whether you are a domestic shipper or a foreign one, your wish is the same: you want changes," said Jun Harada, a shipping analyst at Yamaichi Research Institute.
"Even executives from the listed companies can't feel that they can talk directly to him," he said. "He's such a mighty figure. People can't freely utter their views."
When shipping companies want to change their routes, adjust their port call schedules or switch ships, they must apply to the harbor association at least six weeks in advance. Such changes are usually allowed, but there is a great deal of uncertainty.
"If they are in a good mood, they will accept" your application, said Rudy Mack, head of the Japan Foreign Steamship Association. "There are no guidelines."
But when it comes to creating a new shipping alliance, or forming a new line, the process becomes more complicated. Moreover, to handle cargo at the docks, foreign shipping lines are assigned a stevedore, and shipping companies say that it is virtually impossible to get approval from the harbor association to change a stevedore.
The Sea-Land Service Inc. unit of the CSX Corporation, for instance, has been using the same stevedore company that the association assigned to it in 1968. Over the last year, shipping lines have cut the prices they charge by about one-third, but the cartel-like port practices in Japan have kept costs high.
"We as a carrier are interested in the modernization of port practices in Japan," said William J. Flynn, who runs Sea-Land in Japan. "It's regrettable that sanctions have to be issued to cause meaningful discussions on the modernization of port practices."
A couple of years ago Sankyu Inc., a large Japanese transport company, filed a complaint with Japan's Fair Trade Commission, contending that the harbor association's allocation practices violated antitrust laws. The association responded by putting pressure on Sankyu's clients and reportedly refused to approve Sankyu's terminal revamping plans.
In the end, Sankyu withdrew its complaint and is said to have apologized to the association.
The harbor association told American officials there would be "massive retaliation against U.S carriers," if sanctions are put in place in April, according to the United States Federal Maritime Commission's ruling on sanctions Wednesday. If the sanction effort is pursued, Mr. Takashima said he "will not let any U.S. ships come into Japanese ports," the ruling added.
As long as he runs the harbor association, Mr. Takashima is likely to exert a great deal of control, experts say, and the Ministry of Transportation has done little to make changes. Kazuhiko Umoto, an official at the port transport division of the Ministry of Transportation, acknowledges Mr. Takashima's influence.
Japanese shipping companies have mixed feelings about the sanctions. On the one hand, they do not want to pay the $100,000-a-ship penalties that Washington will impose.
Still, the Japanese companies say that they, too, want to liberalize port practices and that the most effective means might be "gaiatsu," or foreign pressure, like the threat of American sanctions.
About three-quarters of the value of Japan's worldwide trade moves in and out of its ports, producing $13 billion in annual revenues for Japanese shipping companies alone. But a port call in Japan for cargo ships, whether Japanese or American, costs two to three times what it does in the United States.
It is no surprise, then, that Japan is losing business to other Asian ports like Hong Kong; Pusan, South Korea, and Kaohsiung, Taiwan. Japan's share of cargo tonnage shipped in Asia dropped from 66.5 percent in 1975 to 19.2 percent in 1994.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: METS NOTEBOOK;
Wilson Makes Most of a Chance

BYLINE: By CLAIRE SMITH 

DATELINE: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Feb. 28

 BODY:
When Jay Payton, a candidate to play right field for the Mets, injured his right elbow Tuesday, Manager Bobby Valentine said that Payton's setback would not necessarily change the workload for Carl Everett and Alex Ochoa, the other top competitors for the position.
Valentine did say, however, that Payton's misfortune would create at-bats for outfielders considered long shots to make the club and that the opportunity was theirs to do with what they could. Today, Preston Wilson, the son of Mookie Wilson, the Mets' first base coach and former center fielder, took advantage. The long shot muscled an even longer shot for his first home run of the spring. 
 Yes, it came in an intrasquad game, off Mike Welch, a minor leaguer who otherwise threw well. Welch retired the final six batters he faced and struck out two of the final three.
But, for Wilson, the homer was something to cling to, a powerful statement made in the only at-bat by a player who has yet to advance past Class A ball.
Valentine was watching, and he said later that the home run showed him Wilson was capable of using his power, which he has shown rather impressively in batting practice, in games.
Yes, it was an intrasquad game, "but it was competition," Valentine said. "And it was not wind-aided; it was a legitimate blast." The ball cleared the fence in left-center field at St. Lucie County Stadium, where dead center is 410 feet from home plate.
Wilson said he got only about 95 percent of the ball. "It went more up than on the line," Wilson said. "But I guess it was enough."
Though he feels for Payton, his sidelined friend, Wilson said of this sliver of an opening: "You have to do it. It's a profession."
 
 
Exhibition Opener Today
 The Mets will begin the exhibition season Saturday against the Dodgers (Channel 9, 2 P.M.) with the following lineup: Lance Johnson, center field; Edgardo Alfonzo (2b), Bernard Gilkey (lf), John Olerud (1b), Butch Huskey (3b), Ochoa (rf), Tim Bogar (ss), Alberto Castillo (c). Bobby Jones will be the starting pitcher.
Players who were still missing because of nagging injuries and were not expected to play this weekend were catcher Todd Hundley (tight left hamstring), shortstop Rey Ordonez (sore right shoulder), second baseman Carlos Baerga (hyperextended right elbow) and Jay Payton (scar tissue irritation in his reconstructed right elbow).
Baerga said his elbow was back to about 85 percent and that adjustments in his swing have allowed him to sense more drive from his legs. "I've got more pop in the bat and I feel quicker," he said.
Hundley, who ended practice early Thursday when his hamstring tightened, today said "it's nothing." He added that he did not know when he would play. "Whenever I feel like it," he said, grinning.
"Todd's hamstring is still a little tight, but it has progressed," Bobby Valentine said.
Payton said that though his elbow was still sore, it had not bothered him to hit. Therefore, he hopes to get clearance Saturday to start facing live pitching again. As for throwing, he said, "That's a day-to-day thing right now."
 
 
Clark Is Steady as Ever
 Mark Clark, the Mets' steadiest starter of 1996, pitched in his typically steady, economical fashion today, throwing two and a third scoreless innings and allowing just one hit. He walked two. Valentine praised Clark's location and sinker, and said his slider was O.K. "Mark's pick-off move is greatly improved," he added.
Joe Crawford, a left-hander hoping to crack the rotation, matched Clark's outing, throwing two scoreless innings with one hit, one walk and a strikeout. "He was trying to work the inside part of the plate and did," said Valentine, who also praised Crawford's top pitch, his changeup.
"I threw strikes and, when I put a guy on, I showed that I could throw a changeup wherever and had some good, inside fastballs," said Crawford, who was very pleased with his outing.
 
 
Six Players Sign Deals
 The Mets signed six players to one-year contracts today but ended negotiations with the five other players left on the 40-man roster who are without deals.
The five unsigned players -- pitchers Paul Wilson, Bill Pulsipher, Jason Isringhausen and Juan Acevedo and outfielder Alex Ochoa -- have until Sunday to accept the club's offer or have their contracts renewed.
The players agreeing to one-year deals were infielders Rey Ordonez, Edgardo Alfonzo, Butch Huskey and Roberto Petagine, outfielder Carl Everett and catcher Alberto Castillo.

HEADLINE: Casino Hope Dashed, Catskills Resort Files for Bankruptcy

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 28

 BODY:
For years, it has been the gold standard of Catskills hotels, the sleek resort where Buddy Hackett and Alan King kibitzed, Muhammad Ali trained, and scores of Jewish singles met the loves of their lives.
But today, reeling from lagging patronage and the defeat of a state measure to permit gambling that it saw as its salvation, the Concord Resort Hotel announced that it had asked for protection against its creditors in a Chapter 11 bankruptcy petition filed in Federal Court here Thursday. The 1,200-room hotel, with its three golf courses, 41 tennis courts and two swimming pools, will stay open for business while the owners and creditors figure out a plan for repaying its mountain-sized debts. 
 The Chapter 11 filing by the Concord is a milestone in the declining fortunes of the Catskills, which in its heyday had 40 large hotels but now has no more than 6. A generational shift in vacation tastes toward destinations like Europe and the Hamptons and the weak economy of the late 1980's and early 1990's have buffeted even a hotel that seemed as invulnerable as the Concord.
S. Robert Parker, one of five siblings who own the hotel in Kiamesha Lake, said that the hotel had sustained a small decline in patronage in recent years but that the coup de grace was the defeat on Jan. 28 of a measure in Albany that would have permitted gambling in the Catskills and other sites in the state. Without a tourist lure like gambling, other hotel operators theorized, the Concord could not put together any financing for an effort to pay off its creditors or attract a buyer.
One creditor is Sullivan County, to which the Concord owes $8.7 million in property taxes and $258,000 in room taxes. Last week, the County Attorney wrote a two-page letter to the resort threatening to seize the hotel's property unless its room taxes were paid.
The Concord's court filing, which said the hotel had $56.9 million in assets and $26.6 million in liabilities, identified other creditors as Robert Towers Advertising in Manhattan and Howard J. Rubenstein Associates, a public relations firm, as well as a number of food vendors.
As the hotel's financial problems mounted, it seemed to have trouble maintaining the standard of luxury that lured vacationers and conventioneers. Carpets were frayed and tiled bathrooms needed new grouting. A major setback in recent months was the decision of the fire chiefs of New York State not to hold their annual convention at the Concord.
A lawyer handling the Chapter 11 petition for the hotel, Richard Braverman, said that the hotel still plans to refurbish to attract more customers and to this end had secured a $5 million loan from Lincoln Capital Mortgage of Cleveland.
One small wrinkle in the Concord's travails is that Donald J. Trump, who has a hankering for owning premier properties in any locale, briefly considered buying it. But Mr. Trump, who owns casinos in Atlantic City, ultimately helped defeat the gambling referendum in Albany.
Jonathan Drapkin, county manager of Sullivan County, said the hotel still had prospects for a healthy recovery like other companies that have entered Chapter 11, such as Macy's. He cited the hotel's proximity to New York City, its ability to host large conventions, its world-class golf courses, and its national reputation.
"Seeing the Concord file for Chapter 11 is not a good thing," he said. "Obviously the county is concerned because of the impact on jobs and the local economy."
The county, with 68,000 residents, had an unemployment rate of almost 6 percent, about average for the state. But such figures do not give a hint of how the county's fortunes have plunged since the 1960's, when the summer hotels made the streets of Monticello, Liberty and the other towns bustling centers of commerce and tourism.
The Concord, which employs 1,200 people during the summer, was started in 1937 by Mr. Parker's grandfather, Arthur Winarick, who took over a 60-room hotel from a woman who defaulted on a mortgage he gave her. In the postwar boom, the family began adding tall modern wings that contrasted sharply with quainter neighboring hotels. But the Concord essentially shared the same tried-and-tested Catskills formula of three voluminous meals a day, endless entertainment that invaded even the pools and plenty of rooms for pinochle and mah-jongg.
Soon the Concord drew performers like Judy Garland, Sammy Davis Jr., Maurice Chevalier, Barbra Streisand, Bill Cosby and Buddy Hackett. In recent decades, as many in its traditional clientele retired to Florida, the hotel tried to lure new patrons with singles weekends and a cuisine aimed at young Orthodox Jews. A hint of the tradition clinging to the Concord was evident two weeks ago when the comedian Alan King performed on Presidents Day weekend. Mr. King and his wife were joined by three couples with whom they had honeymooned 50 years before at the Concord.
Mr. Braverman, the Concord's lawyer, said, "What are the odds of four couples still alive, still being married to the same person 50 years later?"

HEADLINE: COURTING DONORS: POLITICAL MEMO;
Clinton Burnishes Image as Protector of Children, Not Hotelier

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28

 BODY:
For the second time this week, it was Vice President Al Gore's job today to introduce a youngster, who had the loftier task of introducing the President of the United States.
And once again President Clinton stepped to the microphone to present himself as the defender of children everywhere, projecting an image that his aides believe slices through the babble about campaign finance scandals and means much more to voters than who slept in the Lincoln Bedroom and at what cost. 
 At almost every public appearance, reporters fling questions at Mr. Clinton about campaign finance improprieties, and although he answers some, he also plugs away at his chosen topics: higher education, fighting drugs or, today, ending tobacco use among children and teen-agers.
A senior White House official said, "We know it plays out there," in referring to reports on those issues on local television and radio as well as by national news organizations.
The Administration is not overlooking many opportunities to push the President's themes -- or to burnish his image. On Monday, the White House plans to announce that Mr. Clinton and his wife, Hillary, will begin appearing on television in public service announcements promoting better parenting.
His preferred message appears to be getting through so far. It has also not hurt, some aides acknowledge, that the economy is strong. As new details of questionable campaign finance practices have trickled and then poured out in recent weeks, as the White House has reluctantly filled in some of its stories and rejiggered others, one thing that has stayed constant is Mr. Clinton's public approval ratings, which are among the highest of his Presidency.
But this week, some Republican pollsters reported signs of hope for their cause: The words "Lincoln Bedroom," and the notion that it was up for sale, was at last generating a response, they said.
Yet White House aides grit their teeth over the daily drumbeat in the press, urging reporters to examine Republican campaign finance practices and rattling off lists of Republican donors appointed to ambassadorships by President George Bush.
Mr. Clinton demonstrated his own concern about the issue this week by placing late-night telephone calls to Senate Democrats, asking that they not call for an independent counsel to look into his campaign finances.
"Clearly, he was upset with some of the statements that had been made," said Senator Bob Kerrey, a Nebraska Democrat who talked to the President on Sunday. Senator Kerrey said Mr. Clinton had urged him to remind other Democratic leaders that there was a legal mechanism for appointing an independent counsel. The calls were reported today in The Wall Street Journal.
But the public so far is not up in arms about slippery campaign finance practices.
"There's a disconnect between the way Washington sees this, and the way the American public sees it," said Andrew Kohut, a pollster who is the director of the Pew Research Center for the People and the Press.
That situation depresses some proponents of changes in the campaign finance system, who see it as a sign that they cannot count on rising public revulsion to propel restrictive finance legislation through Congress. But others argue that Congressional hearings will help generate enough political pressure to force change.
Paradoxically, in the view of some Clinton confidants, the sheer volume of reporting on the scandal is working against its potential power to bring about reform.
"There's a sort of numbness out there," an Administration official said, noting that even news organizations were sometimes not chasing one another's scoops. "They think you guys cover it like a sport, and they think that what we do is sport."
Even after new details of Mr. Clinton's close involvement in raising money were released on Tuesday, a poll by CNN, USA Today and Gallup on Wednesday found that most respondents said they believed that his behavior was typical of how the White House had been used by both parties.
Public anger has certainly not been great enough to stop Mr. Clinton from raising money. He has held two fund raisers in the last two weeks. At one, he called for legislation to outlaw a type of donation that he was soliciting.
On Thursday, Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary, left changing the campaign finance system out of a list of things he said "the President believes that the American people are interested in seeing progress on." Asked about the omission, Mr. McCurry said such changes were "a very high priority."
Referring to polls, he said that although changing the campaign finance system was "not indicated as a subject of high concern or interest on the part of the American people, it is a subject of high interest to the President himself."
Today, in the Roosevelt Room of the White House, Mr. Clinton stood before a group of children wearing bright-red T-shirts promoting the "campaign for tobacco-free kids." It was an image shown over and over today on CNN.
Mr. Clinton, speaking in mild, fatherly tones, said: "Most of us have an instinctive urge to protect our young people from danger. We make sure they bundle up before going out in the cold. We should wrap that same protective arm around them when it comes to resisting smoking and the advertising and marketing of cigarettes."
Concerns about children and smoking weigh more heavily on people's minds than campaign finance details, aides to Mr. Clinton say.
"We believe that the American people care more about college costs than coffees," said Rahm Emanuel, the senior adviser to Mr. Clinton. "They care more about the drug war than donor history, and they care more about standards than the stay-overs. And that's what we're going to continue to do, is to focus on the American people's agenda."
Aides to the President say that despite the preoccupation here with news about campaign finances, his comments and appearances filter through the Beltway. Even major news organizations give many of them prominent play. On Tuesday, "ABC Evening News" featured Mr. Clinton's presentation of his anti-drug plan ahead of a report on new documents revealing his intimate role in raising campaign money.
But Mr. Kohut's poll, taken last weekend, suggests a more complex picture. Over two-thirds of those who said they had recently heard something about Mr. Clinton said it related to a scandal. Yet, over all, 60 percent approved of the job he was doing. The poll's margin of sampling error was three percentage points.
Mr. Kohut summed up the public's attitude this way: "Their nerve endings are dulled if not dead to news of scandal about Bill Clinton. They feel the finance scandals are to be found on both sides of the aisle."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Clinton, at the White House announcing an anti-smoking program directed at children, uses such occasions to promote his favorite issues. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Japanese Fears Give Boost to Nationalists

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Edward J. Lincoln's "Japan Hasn't Really Failed" (Op-Ed, Feb. 22) fails to recognize Japan's serious political and economic paralysis. In the parliamentary election last fall, Japanese voters did not, as Mr. Lincoln claims, largely spurn the parties most eager to reform.
Amid the deepening distrust of bureaucrats and the lowest voter turnout ever recorded, Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of the Liberal Democrats won voters' grudging faith in his promise of fundamental reforms. 
 As Prime Minister Hashimoto's pledge has turned out to be another empty campaign promise, both Japanese and foreign investors have started selling Japanese yen, shares and bonds.
They do not share Mr. Lincoln's belief that Mr. Hashimoto and those corrupt bureaucrats will suddenly grow wise and selfless enough to guide Japan properly into the 21st century.
Nowhere is the Japanese public's rising fear for their future more vividly shown than in the rising influence of the ultra-right-wing nationalists.
In order to review the image of the former glory of Imperial Japan, they are successfully denying Japanese atrocities committed during World War II.
Unlike French ultranationalists who have to fight to influence local municipalities, Japanese ultra-nationalist deniers are already entrenched in politics, business, mass media and education circles.
Even belated United States disapproval of Japanese war crimes and their deniers would help Japan to reform to meet the best interests of the world.
 
YOSHI TSURUMI
New York, Feb. 23, 1997
 
The writer is a professor of international business, Baruch College.

HEADLINE: Japanese Fears Give Boost to Nationalists

To the Editor:
I take exception to just one point in Edward J. Lincoln's perceptive commentary on the Japanese economy and official efforts to revive it (Op-Ed, Feb. 22). Rather than Americans, it is the Japanese themselves who have become the most pessimistic about the prospects for their nation's economic recovery. 
 China is now at the epicenter of Asian economic growth. Yet many signs already point to a modest Japanese economic recovery -- followed, no doubt, by a renewed Japanese sense of economic strength and direction.
 
MARK MASON
New Haven, Feb. 24, 1997
 
The writer is an associate professor at the Yale School of Management.

And Bear in Mind
(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
 ASYLUM, by Patrick McGrath. (Random House, $22.) An elegant and restrained but sufficiently grisly Gothic, narrated by a complacent psychiatrist who assigns textbook pathologies to the dreadful things his patient does for love.
 
 THE BOY WHO WENT AWAY, by Eli Gottlieb. (St. Martin's, $21.95.) A touching coming-of-age novel whose adolescent narrator, a crackerjack at domestic intelligence work, compiles the facts about a family and its secret suffering.
 
 BRIAR ROSE, by Robert Coover. (Grove, $18.) A very complex novelist's intricate variations on "The Sleeping Beauty," treated with a kind of irreverent logic as sex and storytelling are seen as metaphors for each other.
 
 GLADSTONE: A Biography, by Roy Jenkins. (Random House, $35.) The long life (1809-98) of the toweringly righteous, frighteningly omniscient four-time liberal Prime Minister, by a British ex-minister who himself understands and can deliver the cut-and-thrust of speech and debate.
 
 GLASS, PAPER, BEANS: Revelations on the Nature and Value of Ordinary Things, by Leah Hager Cohen. (Currency/Doubleday, $22.95.) Informed, meticulous historical and economic reflections on a tumbler, a newspaper and a cup of coffee, and the evocative power of each.
 
 A HISTORY OF THE BREAST, by Marilyn Yalom. (Knopf, $29.95.) An enlightening examination of cultural, political and artistic attitudes through the ages toward personkind's most symbolically freighted body part.
 
 HUNGRY GHOSTS: Mao's Secret Famine, by Jasper Becker. (Free Press, $25.) A journalist's re-creation of the famine of 1959-61, in which perhaps 30 million Chinese perished because of the ignorance and obstinacy of their ideologically ensorcelled leaders. Gruesome details.
 
 JACKIE BY JOSIE, by Caroline Preston. (Scribner, $22.) An amiable first novel whose protagonist takes a job researching the life of Jacqueline Kennedy; soon, sure enough, her life starts running in ominous parallels with Jackie's.
 
 LIFE ITSELF: Exploring the Realm of the Living Cell, by Boyce Rensberger. (Oxford University, $30.) A science writer for The Washington Post guides the reader through the mechanisms of the cell, where biology's real tricks are performed.
 
 NIAGARA: A History of the Falls, by Pierre Berton. (Kodansha, $27.) A Canadian historian tells how this sublime natural wonder has been used and misused, admired and corrupted.
 
 1988, by Andrew McGahan. (St. Martin's, $22.95.) A refreshingly benign novel from Australia; its heroes, two young men plunging into the wilderness, meet nothing they can't handle and return to civilization without grave incident.

PUB-DATE: March 2, 1997

SECTION: Section 7; Page 13; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1815 words

HEADLINE: One Was a Multitude

BYLINE: By Alan Brinkley; Alan Brinkley, a professor of history at Columbia University, is the author most recently of "The End of Reform: New Deal Liberalism in Recession and War."

 BODY:

BAYARD RUSTIN: TROUBLES I'VE SEEN
 A Biography.
 By Jervis Anderson.
 Illustrated. 418 pp. New York:
 HarperCollins Publishers. $30. 
 BAYARD RUSTIN is probably best remembered today for his close association with Martin Luther King Jr. and for his part in organizing the 1963 March on Washington. But his role in the civil rights movement was only one of the many he played in his long and varied career. He was a major figure in the American pacifist movement and both a theorist and practitioner of nonviolence. He remained active in peace causes until his death. He was, at various times, a Communist, an anti-Communist Socialist and a well-connected activist within the Democratic Party. He was a champion of the American labor movement and a well-traveled advocate of human rights throughout the world. He was a talented musician who once considered a career as a professional singer and entertained audiences with his powerful tenor voice throughout his life. He was an avid collector of art and antiques. He was a self-educated scholar of philosophy and political theory. He was a black American. And he was a gay man.
Rustin juggled these multiple roles and multiple identities with remarkable agility and, on the surface at least, seldom exhibited any serious anxiety about the strains they must often have created for him. Indeed, the picture that emerges from Jervis Anderson's admiring portrait is of a man with an almost insouciant imperviousness to the many trials, assaults and frustrations he experienced as he moved through the public world. Rustin became an important force in many organizations and movements, but in most of them he also alienated or embarrassed the leadership and found himself obliged to move on. His life was dominated by his consistent commitment to work actively on behalf of peace and social justice, but it was also characterized by a restless instability. Few things could contain him for very long.
Mr. Anderson worked at the A. Philip Randolph Institute when Rustin was its executive director in the late 1960's, and he has been a staff writer at The New Yorker since 1968. "Bayard Rustin: Troubles I've Seen" reflects both experiences: a reverence for Rustin that Mr. Anderson evidently derived from his association with him, and a clean, straightforward prose style characteristic of the magazine for which he works. He provides the first thorough account of Rustin's life and career, and he suggests how Rustin became so eminent a figure without ever becoming a genuine leader. "He didn't lead so much as he influenced," The New York Times observed in an editorial when Rustin died in 1987. And he derived that influence from a combination of intelligence, magnetism and charm that Mr. Anderson effectively portrays.
Rustin was born in 1912 into a middle-class black family in West Chester, Pa. Not until he was an adolescent did he discover that the man and woman who had raised him were not his parents but his grandparents, and that his real mother was a woman he had always assumed was his older sister, who had given birth to him when she was 17 years old. His father was a young man from the neighborhood whom Bayard never knew. As with many other important personal issues in Rustin's life, Mr. Anderson offers few clues as to what effect this shocking discovery might have had on him. But he does note that Rustin went to some lengths to hide the facts of his birth from all but a few close friends.
The Rustins were Quakers, and Bayard grew up in and absorbed the political -- although never much of the religious -- ethos of his family's faith. He attended two colleges for a year each and, despite real academic gifts, left both under mysterious circumstances, perhaps related to his homosexuality. Not long after that, he gave up his ambitions to become a professional musician, began his long career as a political activist and moved to New York, where he lived through most of the rest of his life.
While taking courses at City College in the late 1930's, he became active in its Young Communist League, where he stood out as the only black person, as a talented organizer and as an epicure who introduced his comrades to good wines, cheeses and pates. Rustin was interested in the league largely because of its commitment to the racial struggles in the South. In 1941, when Moscow ordered the American Communist Party to abandon its civil rights commitments and focus on World War II, he left the organization.
He moved instead into the orbit of two great anti-Communist Socialists of the 1940's and 50's: A. Philip Randolph, the head of the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters and one of the pre-eminent black leaders of the era; and A. J. Muste, a leading pacifist and the head of the Fellowship of Reconciliation. Rustin helped Randolph organize a great march on Washington in the spring of 1941 -- and then angrily (if temporarily) broke with him when Randolph canceled the march in response to Franklin D. Roosevelt's executive order banning racial discrimination in war industries. Rustin then joined forces with Muste and became a major figure in the Fellowship of Reconciliation's peace campaigns during and after the war.
As a Quaker, Rustin easily won conscientious objector status. But true to the radical pacifism of Muste and his organization, he refused to report to the Civilian Public Service camp to which he was then assigned, because, he said, "I cannot voluntarily submit to an order stemming from the Selective Service Act." He spent nearly two and a half years in Federal prison as a result, the first of many imprisonments he experienced -- all but one of them for acts of conscience.
For the first eight years after the war, Rustin remained almost wholly within the Fellowship of Reconciliation and, as one of the organization's most popular and magnetic speakers, traveled widely on its behalf. But in 1953, while on a trip to California sponsored by the organization, he was arrested on a morals charge when he was found having sex with two young men in a parked car near his hotel. Rustin's associates had long known of his homosexuality and had quietly tolerated it. But the stern and at times self-righteous Muste could not forgive Rustin for a public scandal that might damage the fellowship, and he unceremoniously dismissed him from the organization.
It was a low point in Rustin's life -- and a moment that Mr. Anderson (who rarely offers much explanation of the critical ways in which Rustin's homosexuality surely affected him) handles gingerly. But Rustin's departure from the Fellowship of Reconciliation in fact helped him move in new and more visible directions. Three years later, after working for a while for another pacifist organization (one more tolerant of his personal life), he responded to the urgings of the novelist Lillian Smith and A. Philip Randolph and traveled to Montgomery, Ala., where he joined Martin Luther King Jr. in organizing the bus boycott that established King as a national figure. And for the next 10 years, he moved back and forth between the world of the civil rights movement and the world of peace activism, both movements then committed to the Gandhian ideas of nonviolence to which Rustin subscribed. His past followed him everywhere -- his youthful ties to the Communist Party, his wartime imprisonment, his arrest in California; Rustin often had to limit his public exposure to avoid discrediting King and others whom Southern white leaders (and the Federal Bureau of Investigation) were attempting to destroy. But his training in the peace movement, and his sophisticated understanding of philosophies of nonviolence and social witness, made him an influential and valued adviser to more visible figures still searching for the intellectual underpinnings of their efforts.
Rustin worked closely with King and the movement for nearly a decade and was particularly important in helping Randolph plan the 1963 March on Washington, the high-water mark of the nonviolent age of civil rights. But his relationship with King was never an easy one. In part, it was because his radical past and very likely, although no one ever said so, his homosexuality made the beleaguered leaders of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference uncomfortable as they struggled against the false accusations of Communism that the F.B.I. and others flung at them.
But Rustin's problems with King were also a result of Rustin's own relative conservatism in areas in which King was becoming more radical. He criticized King for denouncing the Vietnam War; Rustin opposed it too, but like many others he thought King was compromising his leadership of the civil rights struggle by linking the issues. He opposed King's plan to take the movement to Chicago in 1966, warning (correctly) that the prospects for success were dim. And he began to argue as early as 1967 that the "movement" phase of the civil rights struggle had lost its usefulness, that it was time for blacks to turn to politics (and to form coalitions with other progressive forces, most notably labor) to work for the economic reforms that should now be their most important goal.
In the late 60's, Rustin at last found in his leadership of the A. Philip Randolph Institute the secure institutional base he had always lacked. But at the same time, he was becoming increasingly at odds with his former colleagues in the movement. He was a strong critic of black nationalism and black power, a fervent believer in making political alliances with powerful groups dominated by whites, a defender of the Democratic Party and the labor movement, even an energetic supporter of Albert Shanker and the United Federation of Teachers in their bitter battle against the effort by black activists to win community control of public schools in New York. He remained in demand as a speaker and adviser throughout the 70's and 80's, and he served on many committees and boards. But while his life was no less active in those years than it had been in his youth, his influence was less profound. And when he died, even his admirers had some difficulty articulating exactly what had made him a significant figure in the nation's recent history.
But Rustin was a significant figure, perhaps more significant than Mr. Anderson's cautious biography makes clear. Not so much for the speeches he made, the organizations he assisted and the events he orchestrated, but for the way in which he, almost alone among the major figures of the civil rights movement, tried to articulate a set of ideas and theories to justify their efforts and shape their tactics. He was a man of ideas and a man of action, of "pragmatic idealism," as Vernon Jordan said in eulogy. And in an age of acrimony and division, he helped keep alive the fading vision of a broad, consensual coalition of the forces of change.

HEADLINE: Even Without Snow, Winter Means Travel

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
JUST plain winter, with or without snow, is enough to send people packing. So say those who sell winter travel packages.
"People may not be as desperate to get away this year, but winter is still winter and they want to go," reported Ina Rich, founder and chief executive officer of Rich World Wide Travel, with headquarters in Harrison, one of several travel agents interviewed. Even a week off in a short month like February, traditionally observed by most schools, had little negative impact on travel plans. 
 "Trips were shorter, four days instead of a week, and some parents even kept their kids out of school," said Allen Rich, a director of Rich World Wide Travel and Mrs. Rich's husband. "But there were very few cancellations in any of our offices."
Mr. Rich added, however, that "everything has a direct impact on the travel industry. Whatever affects the world, weather, political unrest, the stock market, we feel it. Right now the public's perception of the economy is that it is stable and times are good. And that upbeat outlook shows up in increased business for us."
Rich World Wide Travel employs 148 people in 6 retail offices in Harrison, Somers, Chappaqua and Pearl River and 2 offices in Manhattan. The company also operates 12 corporate in-house ticketing offices. Rich, which ranks among the 100 largest independent travel agencies in the country, evolved from the Riches' early careers as tour operators.
"Back in the 50's, we were a young married couple, teachers who ran summer teen tours all over the world," Mr. Rich recalled. "My wife, who wanted to stay home after our first child was born, opened a travel agency in Scarsdale in 1968. She gets the credit for building the business. I joined her in 1980, and now with our two sons-in-law in with us, we have a real family enterprise."
Given their own family structure, it is not surprising that when speaking about trends in travel, the Riches say the multigeneration vacation is hot.
"We've taken a number of three-generation vacations ourselves," Mrs. Rich said. "And the family market is very strong." "Instead of throwing the big party, our clients are celebrating important anniversaries and birthdays with their children and grandchildren on location. Bermuda, an easy flight from New York, is one popular destination. Resorts and cruise ships are others. Cruises are an excellent buy. There are a lot of bargains around. And a cruise lends itself to a three-generation vacation because it offers something for everyone. It's also the easiest way travel, with a minimum of packing and unpacking."
The renewed interest in golf has led to another trend, the golf tour, Mr. Rich said. "Lately, we've been sending more clients out on golf tours than ever," he said. "They favor resorts in the South and the West and in Bermuda. And spring bookings, beginning in May, for golf tours in Scotland and Ireland are heavy."
At Pied Piper Tours in Chappaqua, Kay Mullane, the owner, said that last winter's snows changed business sharply. "We run bus trips for older adults, and we always were busy year round," Ms. Mullane said. "But we were faced with so many weather-related cancellations last year that we reorganized our business, and this year cut out winter trips entirely. We hope to make up for it by scheduling more spring and summer overnight tours to our most popular destinations like Williamsburg, Cape Cod and the Allegheny Mountains."
Joel Dash of Dash Travel in Mount Vernon has been in the travel business for 39 years. And rarely, he said, in all those years have there been the travel bargains that there are now.
"Bargains that have a negative impact on the profits of travel agencies," he said. "When we book a cruise that cost $2,000 last year and is going for $1,000 this year, a cut in profits results."
By the same token, he said, consumers are profiting.
"How can you beat $349 for a seven-day, all-inclusive Carnival cruise from Miami to San Juan?" he said. "And more than a half a dozen mega cruise ships, those carrying approximately 3,200 passengers, are coming on line in the next couple of years. The Carnival line has three; Royal Caribbean has two. If these ships are to go out anywhere near capacity, I think the policy of offering deep discounts will continue."
Today's consumers are hunting for bargains in all other types of travel, he added.
"They are very price sensitive and savvy," he said. "They read the ads and quote the prices of airline promotions. Right now, there are many travel deals around at unbelievable prices."
One example, he said, is Alitalia's promotional fare of $279, which has stimulated winter tourism to Italy.
"People who have never been to Europe are passing up Florida for sightseeing," Mr. Dash said. But the best buy around, he said, "is Air Moroc's $899 package to Morocco, which includes everything: air, meals and hotel. They use Club Valtur, which is the Italian version of Club Med and very luxurious."
Asked to describe the pace of business at Briarcliff Travel Service in Briarcliff, Lenisse Goldberg said: "It's running off the walls, we're so busy. We're also an American Express Agency, so we draw our clients from all parts of the county. Our advance bookings are well ahead of last year with the volume of leisure travel up."
Ms. Goldberg said the increase in travel reflects the general feeling that the economy is strong. "I think the early bookings are an indication," she said. "People are confident enough to plan ahead."
And the excellent travel buys on the market are a strong contributing factor, Ms. Goldberg added: "We're selling well-priced packages to Asia and Europe. Greece is a popular summer destination. Disney is No. 1 for families and honeymooners, although Hawaii, after losing ground, is back in favor for honeymoons."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Allen and Ina Rich, in the offices of their agency, Rich World Wide Travel in Harrison. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Air Fare Specials Served Up on the Web

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
THE growing use of the Internet for selling air fares has been compared to a revolution, supposedly as important as the dawn of the jet age in the late 1950's and airline deregulation in 1978.
Calling the trend a revolution may be an overstatement, but it has evolved rapidly, with many domestic airlines using the Internet's potential by offering discounts to computer users. For the airlines, the Internet offers an inexpensive way to advertise fares to fill seats that generally go unsold for weekend travel. And there appears to be a big appetite for such discounts -- several airlines have signed up tens of thousands of subscribers within the last year. 
 Each week, the airlines that offer such fares -- including American, Northwest, Continental and USAir -- send out discounts for travel between certain cities to subscribers via electronic mail or post them on their World Wide Web computer sites.
The fares, which are typically about 75 percent less than 21-day advance purchase fares, are intended for spur-of-the-moment travel, as they are good only for the coming weekend. The airlines say they generally change the list of cities each week. Although every airline's rules vary slightly, the fares are typically posted every Wednesday, and require leaving on a Friday or Saturday, returning on a Sunday, Monday or Tuesday.
American Airlines, for example, offered round-trip fares during the first weekend of February that ranged from about $69 to $189. A round-trip between Dallas and La Guardia Airport in New York was $179; a New York to Boston round-trip ticket was $89. American also offers international fares, such as a $249 round-trip between New York and London. The international fares are sent out on Mondays for departures on Thursday or Friday, and return flights the following Monday or Tuesday.
Not everyone is applauding the trend. Donald L. Pevsner, an attorney who describes himself as a consumer advocate on many aviation issues, filed a petition in January with the United States Department of Transportation. He said that the Internet-only fares represent "invidious discrimination" by airlines against consumers, like him, who do not own a computer. Mr. Pevsner said that when he calls an airline and requests its lowest available fare for a particular route and is not told about the Internet deals, that is discriminatory.
"The computer is a tool," Mr. Pevsner said in an interview. "It is not supposed to be some unfair edge."
The airline industry counters that use of the Internet is simply another way of distributing its product. The Transportation Department has not yet ruled on Mr. Pevsner's request. USAir, however, said that if travelers call a toll-free number, (888) 359-3728,, and tell the airline which cities they are interested in flying between, the agent will check whether any of its discounts on the Internet are available. Travelers who have specific cities in mind can also ask agents at Continental's toll-free number, (800) 525-0280, whether any Internet fares are available that week. At American and Northwest, the fares are only for those who learn about them through the Internet.
Some of the largest airlines, including Delta and United, do not yet offer Internet-only fares. United said it is developing a system that subscribers can customize so that they receive special fares only for certain destinations.
For now, the growth of Internet fares has eclipsed another fledgling idea -- electronic auctions on the Internet, in which airlines receive bids for tickets. American Airlines held three such auctions last year. But a spokesman for American, Tim Smith, said the company found aspects of the auctions cumbersome. "It was definitely a learning process," he said.
Cathay Pacific Airways held several successful auctions last year. It is planning just one this year, though, because most of its flights to Hong Kong this year are already largely booked. Its auction for 1,000 seats in economy class for travel from September through November will be held this summer. Cathay Pacific also has 130,000 subscribers for its Internet-only fares, which have fewer restrictions than those offered by the United States airlines.
Although Internet fares appear to be a greater success for the moment than auctions, other companies say they are committed to the idea. A fledgling business called Electronic Travel Auction with the Web address http://www.etauction.com began offering a variety of travel packages in January. Its auctions generally run for 30 days, and people who place a bid (the seller sets a minimum bid) are sent electronic mail to inform them whether they are the new high bidder.
Mark Hawkins, president of the company, said the business has started relatively slowly, but that with the recent addition of partners like Hilton, interest should grow quickly. He, too, is eager to learn what form on-line auctions will eventually take. "Every day brings yet another twist that forces you to change your business plan," he said.
