HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By JANET PIORKO 

 BODY:

Irish Famine Remembered
Q. We plan to travel to Ireland this year and would like information on events commemorating the Great Famine. -- Doris Moran Weisberg, Lawrenceville, N.J.
A. Hundreds of thousands of people died and more than a million emigrated from Ireland during the famine from 1845 to 1850; 1997 marks 150 years since "Black '47," considered the worst year. 
 One major project designed to commemorate the tragedy and recognize the emigrants' contributions is the Great Irish Famine Event, centered on Millstreet in County Cork on May 31 and June 1. It is being organized, with the support of the Irish Government, by the Big Issues Social Initiative, a charity that publishes a magazine sold by vendors who are homeless or unemployed.
The event will include "The Gathering" on May 31 at Drishane Castle, with readings and songs and the lighting of a Famine Candle by Ireland's President, Mary Robinson. Also in Millstreet, there will be a concert June 1 celebrating Irish culture, with the Chieftains and the Dubliners expected to appear.
In Cobh (the port for Cork, about an hour's drive from Millstreet), a copy of a 19th-century ship will be moored, with flowers placed on board by visitors in memory of the emigrants; on June 1, the ship will set sail to lay the flowers at sea.
A single ticket for both days' events is about $171, calculated at $1.71 in United States currency to the Irish punt, including a contribution of $103. Information or reservations: (800) 586-3197. The event has a Web site at http://www.famine.ie/
A Boston-based company is arranging packages around the event; contact Conferences International, 25 Huntington Avenue, Suite 607, Boston, Mass. 02116; (617) 266-5800 or (800) 221-8747, fax (617) 266-5886.
 
Barrier Reef on the Cheap
Q. A friend and I are planning to visit the Great Barrier Reef in Australia for two weeks in late December. We are students on a tight budget. Can you tell us the cheapest time to purchase tickets? Do you have any ideas on where to stay? -- Stacy Khong, Lakewood, Calif.
 
A. Late December, with school vacations and Christmas holiday travel, is a busy travel time in Australia, and air fares, too, are on the high side then. The lowest student fare currently available from S.T.A. Travel, an agency that has contracts with several airlines flying to Australia, is $1,206 round trip midweek between Los Angeles and Cairns, gateway to the Reef. Reservations by October are recommended.
S.T.A. has 17 locations throughout the country, including three in Southern California; the company's toll-free number is (800) 777-0112. You will need an international student ID card, which the company can issue.
Of the islands that belong to the Great Barrier Reef National Park, camping is permitted on about two dozen. A permit is required, and in most cases you must take all provisions and gear. The cost is generally $2.50 a person a night. (Prices calculated at $1.19 Australian to the United States dollar.) The reservations procedure is outlined in a flier from the National Parks and Wildlife Service, Department of Environment, Box 155, Brisbane Albert Street, Queensland 4002, Australia; (61-7) 3227-8187, fax (61-7) 3227-8749.
If you don't camp, staying right on the Reef may be beyond your budget. On Lady Elliot Island, prices in late December will be $97 a person, double occupancy, in a tent cabin, including buffet breakfast and dinner. Reservations: (800) 531-9222 in the United States. Heron Island, another atoll, has cabins starting at $125 a person, double occupancy, including three meals. Reservations: (61-79) 78 1488, fax (61-79) 78 1457.
You have many more options if you stay on the coast and make day trips to the Reef. The Australian Tourist Commission's Aussie Help line, (847) 296-4900, can provide information on hostels. Among the possibilities in Cairns are the Bellview, 85 The Esplanade, (61-70) 31 4377, where rates start at $14 a person in a four-bedded dormitory room, and Jimmy's on The Esplanade, 83 The Esplanade, (61-70) 31 6884, with rates starting at $13 a person.
About three hours' drive north of Cairns, in Cape Tribulation, another recommendation is PK's Jungle Village, at Avalon Street and Cape Tribulation Road, (61-70) 98 0040, fax (61-70) 98 0006, which is set on a beach and has a pool, restaurant, water sports and a party atmosphere; the cost is $40 for two people in a double room (shared bath), $13 a person in a room with eight beds. Boats go to the outer reef, about 30 minutes away, from $42.
Eight or nine hours by road south of Cairns, the town of Airlie Beach is a good jumping-off point for the 70-odd Whitsunday Islands, as well as reef trips. Two hostels recommended by the local tourist information center: Whitsunday Backpackers, 13 Begley Street; (61-79) 46 7376, which charges $12 a person in four- or six-bedded dormitory rooms or $30 for two in a double, including breakfast. Beaches Backpackers, Shute Harbor Road, (61-79) 46 6244, charges $12 a person in a five-bedded dorm room with its own bath.
For an island experience, Hook Island in the Whitsunday Group, has cabins for $46 a night for two people (shared bath), or dormitory accommodations for $12 a person. Reservations: (61-79) 46 6900.
 
On the Ice in Paris
Q. While in Paris in late May, I would like to go ice-skating. Is there an indoor rink in the city or nearby? -- Charlotte L. Thorp, Brooklyn, N.Y.
A. The Patinoire de St.-Ouen, about 10 minutes by Metro from the center of Paris, was built in 1980 and has large glass walls that provide plenty of light. Like most rinks in the city, it closes June 1 to Sept. 10.
Hours vary by the day: Tuesday, 11:30 A.M. to 1 P.M. and 8:30 to 11 P.M.; Wednesday, 10 A.M. to 12:30 P.M. and 2:30 to 6 P.M.; Thursday, 11:30 A.M. to 1 P.M. and 5 to 8 P.M.; Friday, 11:30 A.M. to 1 P.M., 4:30 to 6 P.M. and 8:30 to 11 P.M.; Saturday, 2:30 to 6 P.M. and 8:30 to 11 P.M., and Sunday 10 A.M. to 12:30 P.M. and 2:30 to 6 P.M.
Admission, $2.30 to $5.10; skate rental, $2.30 to $3.10 (at 5.42 francs to the United States dollar).
The rink is a one-minute walk from the Metro station Mairie de St.-Ouen on Ligne 13, Chatillon-Montrouge/St. Denis-Basilique. From Paris, be sure to take the train that is going to St. Denis-Basilique; look for that name on the electronic boards on the Metro platform, since the line separates into two directions at some points. JANET PIORKO

HEADLINE: ARTS/ARTIFACTS;
Works of Art That Once Humbly Bore the Soup

BYLINE: By MITCHELL OWENS 

 BODY:
HEARTY STEW OR EFFETE consomme, soup has been a culinary constant in most world cultures, its presence on the menu symbolic of prosperity and hospitality. But it was not until the middle of the 18th century that the tureen -- an oval lidded container designed expressly for the serving of soup -- made the esthetic advance from rustic receptacle to masterly, occasionally lurid art form.
"Think how marvelous it must have looked, carried in by candlelight, the soup steam issuing from its nostrils," said Patricia Halfpenny, the curator of ceramics and glass of the Winterthur Museum in Wilmington, Del. She was waxing lyrical over a new acquisition, an antique tureen whose iconography is not for diners of weak constitution. 
 Made in England in 1754, at the Chelsea Porcelain Manufactory, the tureen depicts a queasy-making sight: a life-size boar's head, severed by hunters and set on a platter. Painted blood drips from its eyes and mouth, and its flared nostrils are cunningly pierced to allow steam to escape, a practical consideration that also added considerable drama to the plate passing of dinner time.
Until recently, the tureen, appropriately enough, was in the collection of the Campbell Museum in Camden, N.J. A creation of John T. Dorrance Jr., a former chairman of Campbell Soup Company, the museum was built in 1970 to house 300 tureens and other soup-related tableware: spoons, ladles, plates, broth bowls.
Poor attendance forced the museum to close last March, but its contents, which were assembled between 1966 and 1993, were donated to Winterthur. Of the 125 tureens that will go on permanent display there on May 24, eight are temporarily housed in a small alcove on the second floor of the Galleries, Winterthur's primary exhibition building. This recently opened installation acts as a sort of appetizer to May's main course.
As a form, the tureen came into its own as a result of the 18th-century fashion for meals served a la francaise, where the dishes and serving pieces were set on the table at once in a sumptuous groaning-board sort of mosaic-cum-buffet.
In royal and aristocratic houses -- or those whose owners aspired to a similar distinction -- French-style dining was a fad that demanded, and inspired, the creation of extravagant tableware. When assembled en masse, these pieces would provide a crass but highly gratifying metaphor for a host's financial success.
The queen of serving pieces was the tureen. And its piping hot contents were not only fashionable; it also provided the first step in multicourse meals whose evolution -- from primal broth to artistic desserts -- would have appealed to the deep thinkers of the Age of Reason. Simply put, a tureen was one of the tickets to chic in the 18th century.
"Did I write you word we had got a new terene?" Mary Delany, an Irish artist, proudly reported to a friend in the middle of the 1740's. "The chasing is mighty well done; it holds six quarts, and has a very light look."
Inspired by contemporary fashions -- Roman antiquities, rococo naturalism, the bucolic artifice fostered by faux shepherdesses like Marie Antoinette -- potters and silversmiths of the day elevated tureens to a stylistic apotheosis.
Tureens took the form of livestock and farm produce: swans, rabbits, a head of cabbage, a speckled hen with her golden chicks. Some designs refer to regional food specialties. An especially splendid example at Winterthur, a faience tureen made in Portugal in the 1700's, takes the shape of a wooden bucket full of freshly caught fish, making it the perfect container for a seafood stew.
Scottish, American and Polish silversmiths created tureens that resembled neo-classical chalices, while other artisans took the opportunity to incorporate little history lessons. For all its glazed gore, the Chelsea-ware boar's head has noble precedent. It refers to the medieval habit of opening a banquet with a fresh boar's head encased in decorative pastry and icing.
Then there were tureens that acted as giant postcards, like those from a dinner service made around 1825 as a wedding gift for Princess Louise of Prussia. Mounted on leather-topped ormolu presentation stands, the tureens are emblazoned with meticulous hand-painted scenes of Berlin buildings and gardens.
The illustrations perhaps acted as much as aides-memoire as symbols of national pride. The bride, after all, was leaving her country behind to marry a Dutch prince. Still, it is doubtful that her tureens ever saw much use, for the same reason many modern wedding gifts gather dust.
"Dinner services like that often had a formal, ceremonial function," Ms. Halfpenny said. "So it was very likely that the tureens were used once, at the wedding dinner, and then never again."
By the end of the 19th century, however, the fashion for soup as a first course among trend-setting hosts had declined, thanks in part to the efficiency of the Industrial Revolution. Dinner services, and hence tureens, had become widely available, and at prices low enough to enable diners of every economic station to declare "Soup's on."
Which, perhaps, explains the anti-soup rhetoric of Elsie de Wolfe, a decorator of the 1920's. Her standards as a hostess were as formidable as her interiors. "Never begin a meal on a lake," she counseled. Perhaps all she lacked was the right tureen.

HEADLINE: Connecticut Q&A: Terry Cassidy;
High-Tech World, Low Scores in Literacy

BYLINE: By NANCY POLK 

 BODY:
BETWEEN 300,000 and 400,000 Connecticut residents are functionally illiterate. The information comes from Terry Cassidy, who for 16 years was executive director of the Connecticut Association of Boards of Education and since September has been the executive director of the Literacy Volunteers of America-Connecticut Inc.
"We are becoming more aware that we have a real problem as businesses become more sophisticated, more dependent upon computers, the manuals become more difficult to follow. If you have a problem with reading it is more and more difficult to hide," explained Mr. Cassidy. 
 Not that problems only arise in high-tech environments. "Someone came to Literacy Volunteers after learning that he'd been sneaking cigarettes behind a boiler under the sign that said, 'Caution flammable liquids, no smoking,' " Mr. Cassidy said.
At the national level, President Bill Clinton has announced the creation of America Reads, with 100,000 new college work-study jobs devoted to tutoring in reading.
In Connecticut, Mr. Cassidy recently discussed his concerns about illiteracy. Following are some excerpts from that conversation.
Q. Does the term "functionally illiterate" mean that someone cannot read at all?
A. People who cannot process words at all are illiterate. Someone who is functionally illiterate cannot fill out a job application, follow certain directions, handle mail, read traffic signs or do very basic things an office needs to do.
The illiterate population is high. In some respects it will get higher, because business and industry are more complicated. So that someone who was able to just get by won't be able to get by a few years from now because of the demand to read more complicated materials.
Q. With changes in public assistance many more people will be seeking entry-level jobs. Does literacy have a role in this social issue?
A. Clearly a large percentage of people on welfare are challenged when it comes to literacy. How are these people going to work? It's almost an impossible situation for them. Employers aren't in business to help people learn how to read.
A lot of people who are going off welfare will get positions and not stay with them very long. We'll see people going from employment to unemployment, back and forth. It is very discouraging.
Even to flip a hamburger you might have to read a sign that says, "caution," or directions on how to get the french fry machine going. There are simple cleaning fluids that can become lethal when combined.
If policy makers do not develop strategies to help people who are going off welfare to develop the capacities they need to succeed at work -- literacy being one of them -- the crisis among poor people is only going to worsen.
Q. Can Literacy Volunteers take care of the problem in Connecticut?
A. It is amazing that in the wealthiest state in the nation, the wealthiest country in the world, we don't seem to get the importance of providing people with the context in which they can flourish. We have 17 affiliates with close to 4,000 volunteer tutors. They help approximately 6,500 adults learn how to read or speak English. We cannot help everyone. It is getting more difficult to recruit volunteers. Tutors, particularly in basic reading, tend to develop close relationships with their clients.
Literacy Volunteers is doing a wonderful job with a relatively small group of people but there is an enormous unmet need out there that we can't respond to because of resources and getting enough tutors.
Q. Is this a problem concentrated in Connecticut's urban areas?
 A. No. Fairfield County has one of the largest Literacy Volunteers, with English as a second language and basic literacy instruction their mission. The problem with illiteracy is not a problem of minorities. Fully 50 percent of the nonreading population is white. It is a problem of our entire society. It tends to be a problem of lower-income people, but not always.
It can be people like spouses who stay at home; they find it most difficult to admit they have a reading problem. It can be people who own their own business; recently we had a fellow who has run a candy store in Hartford's North End for many years. Clever, resourceful people can explain away the fact that they aren't writing something down.
Q. Does Literacy Volunteers work with immigrants in Connecticut?
 A. Absolutely. One of the fastest growing populations that we're working with are people who do not speak English as their primary language. The largest percentage are Spanish speakers but we have people from Bosnia, a relatively large number from Asian countries. I suspect we have about every language you might imagine.
There is a difference between people who come to us for language instruction and people who come to us for literacy. No shame is involved in learning to speak English. People are ashamed that they can't read.
Q. Do public schools have a role in alleviating illiteracy among adults?
 A. There is a the lack of connection between public schools and the issue of adult literacy. Family literacy is one of the major concepts that literacy groups are looking at now. Involving parents who are illiterate with their young children who are learning how to read is sometimes a very positive motivator. Family literacy centers located in public schools might be very helpful.
One of the keys to getting an adult to learn how to read is to remove all the barriers to learn. One could be lack of eyeglasses, another could be child care. It's tough to concentrate on learning how to read when you don't know where your child is. Schools with parent centers have a facility where parents come where their children are at the same time. Tutoring under those conditions can be pretty successful.
Q. Is there a link between imprisonment and illiteracy? A. A very high percentage of prisoners don't have high school diplomas. There are few programs in prisons to help people who are illiterate. Literacy volunteers are involved to some extent, but our presence is nowhere near as great as it should be. The state does not provide the kind of intervention that any prisoner needs to learn and grow.
Q. Is it possible to graduate from a Connecticut high school and not know how to read? A. I hear enough anecdotes that suggest that some young people getting out of high school read at very low levels. There is a reading system called the National Adult Literacy Survey that divides the reading population into five categories. The lowest is complete illiteracy. Next is fifth-grade literacy level. People are graduating at that reading level. When they get into the workplace they are at a serious disadvantage. There are myriad reasons why people don't learn how to read in school. The fact that no one diagnosed the need for eyeglasses is one. Learning disability is another. Attention disorder is another. I suspect I wouldn't have learned to read very well if I came from a violent family where my mother were being abused and I was being abused. There are emotional factors that get in the way of learning how to read. There is also institutional racism, which will expect little from some children and reinforce the fact that they are not achieving.
I don't think it is reasonable to call a second-grader lazy or unwilling to read. A child that age isn't capable of making that decision.
I would like to see public education put us out of business by making sure that every child learns how to read, but we're always going to have problems with poverty and problems with learning disabilities.
Q. What method do you use to teach someone to read?
 A. Literacy Volunteers is based on a model that is student centered. That means we do an individual assessment of each person who comes to us to determine his or her level of ability. Then we develop programs based upon their needs.
What I hear causes people to come into L.V.A. is that something happens in their lives that challenges them in a new way. An example would be a divorce or death where the person who was a good reader is no longer present.
Q. What is your vision for the Literacy Volunteers in the future?
A. I would like greater coordination with the Department of Social Services. I would love for us to become more closely associated with hospitals: first, to make sure that every health worker can read -- and to identify patients who can't read. After all, these patients will be going home with prescription bottles.
I would like us to develop a much closer relationship with business and industry. We ought to be providing workplace literacy.
Programs that occur on the job and with tutors from the industry are the most successful.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Terry Cassidy, head of a statewide literacy effort, says that illiteracy is becoming harder to hide. (Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 2; Page 36; Column 5; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 848 words

HEADLINE: TELEVISION VIEW;
At the Center Of Modern Architecture

BYLINE: By Herbert Muschamp 

 BODY:
TUNE IN TO A NATIONAL TREASURE ON Wednesday night at 9, when PBS presents a 90-minute documentary on I. M. Pei., the elder statesman of American architecture. Best known for large institutional projects like the East Building of the National Gallery in Washington and the overhaul of the Louvre, he is also the embodiment of charm. "First Person Singular: I. M. Pei," produced and directed by Peter Rosen, an Emmy Award winner, and narrated mainly by Pei himself, documents the combination of esthetic conviction and personal charisma that enabled the architect to get these projects built.
His work is well worth looking at in this season of yearning for the "vital center." No architect more fully embodies that concept. Pei is the great architect of liberal consensus culture. His work epitomizes the American ethos that by midcentury had embraced the tenets of modernism as the authentic expression of our age. Pei recast those tenets in projects that ranged across the social and economic spectrum, from low-cost housing in Washington to the grandly dynamic East Building. It is moving to recall a time when the ends of that spectrum seemed less far apart. 
 Aptly, it was the commission to design the John F. Kennedy Library in Boston, bestowed by Jacqueline Kennedy, that catapulted Pei into the front ranks of American architects in the late 1960's. And his work in the decades since then has been suffused with a Camelot-like aura.
"First Person Singular" shows Pei in Paris, revisiting the underground building topped by a glass pyramid that he designed for the Louvre, and a handful of his other projects on three continents. He appears not simply as an architect but in fact as a kind of ambassador of culture, an emissary from a time before the liberal consensus crumbled beneath pressures from left and right. The archetypal Pei space -- a sculpturally geometrical atrium radiant with light pouring through a glazed metal frame -- is a glowing shrine to the belief in progressive art and architecture.
Viewers of this first of three films (the historian John Hope Franklin, author of "From Slavery to Freedom: A History of African Americans," considered the definitive text on the black experience in America, and the economist John Kenneth Galbraith are the other subjects), will have to flesh out much of this context for themselves.
From segments on Pei's childhood in China to one covering opening ceremonies at the Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame in Cleveland in 1995, this program is all foreground. We see little about the enormous changes that have overtaken cities during the years Pei has been practicing. We hear nothing about the post-modern critique of work like Pei's. Indeed the program offers no commentary to contradict its premise that Pei is "the architect of our time."
More damaging, the documentary barely sketches in the contentious chapters of architectural history that made Pei's success possible. Pei speaks in passing of the pioneer modernists who influenced him, like Walter Gropius, Le Corbusier, Alvar Aalto, and Marcel Breuer. But the account scarcely hints at the battles these architects waged for their beliefs. Conviction, not compromise, was what made the vital center possible. As a second-generation modernist, Pei faced fewer obstacles to the realization of his architectural vision. Even before he obtained large institutional commissions, the so-called International Style had become the house style of the establishment.
BUT THE TRIUMPH OF MODERN architecture created new problems in turn. For some observers, the corporate acceptance of modernism tarnished the movement's image as a moral force. These feelings resurfaced two years ago, in the negative response to Pei's design for the Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame. Younger architects, especially, resented that the man who designed the Louvre had been hired to create a building honoring Elvis and his progeny. My response was: this is America, rock-and-roll is our history, Elvis our "Winged Victory." Elvis wearing black leather in the Louvre is exactly what we all want to see.
Pei has, on the whole, managed to outlive the stigma of his success, largely because he did stick to his guns. With his work, there is no slippage in standards of the kind that has afflicted other successful firms like Skidmore, Owings & Merrill or Kevin Roche, John Dinkeloo & Associates. One could object that the "first person singular" format of this documentary is wrong for representing architecture, the most collaborative of the arts. And the program does slight the contributions of Pei's partners, including Henry N. Cobb and James Ingo Freed.
Even so, Pei's personality is not a bad lens through which to see his work. "Architects talk to people," Frank Lloyd Wright once commented, and this very human aspect of the architect's work is often underestimated. It is useful to gain a glimpse of the social skills that have enabled this architect to soar. In describing his design process, Pei tempers his convictions with a grin at once mischievous and wise: "Or so I believe."

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 1; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2712 words

HEADLINE: Perish? No, Publish!

BYLINE: By BARRY SCHWABSKY 

 BODY:
IF you're an assistant professor of French history hoping to make tenure at your university, achieving your goal these days may not be as simple as it used to be. One of the most important criteria in tenure decisions is the candidate's publishing record. While journal articles are fine, a book (perhaps derived from your doctoral dissertation on, say, Oratorian education and the origin of French revolutionary ideology) would be even better. Preferably, it would be published by a leading university press -- a shining badge of scholarly merit.
Unfortunately, times have never been so tough for publishers of scholarly monographs on French history, among other once-standard areas of research in the humanities. Twenty years ago, an assistant professor's monograph might have been expected to sell as many as 1,500 copies. Since its publisher might have broken even at 1,100 copies, everyone was satisfied. Today, an author in the same position would be lucky to sell 800 copies, but the publisher's break-even point remains about the same. 
 So that monograph may never be published. Thus you may not win tenure, the tenure committee may not even be sure how to make such decisions, and students as well as other scholars may lose access to the knowledge the book would have shared.
The face of scholarly publishing is changing in ways that may affect universities for years to come. Money has become scarcer, not just for the presses but also, perhaps more alarmingly, for libraries, once the academic presses' most dependable customers. Some presses are hoping that the new superstores like Barnes & Noble and Borders will pick up the slack, but while the chains are ordering lots of scholarly books, it remains to be seen whether they can sell them. Beyond these immediate concerns, there are worries about how electronic publishing will affect its paper-based progenitor.
Which of these factors are most important? The directors of New Jersey's two major academic presses -- Walter H. Lippincott of Princeton University Press, which releases 200 titles a year with a staff of 95, and Marlie Wasserman of Rutgers University Press, whose staff of just 20 produces 140 books a year -- have divergent views.
For Ms. Wasserman, the big question is the effect of superstores. "Our part of New Jersey is loaded with the kind of superstores where I love to spend an afternoon sipping coffee and looking at books," she said, "though I lament the loss of so many of the mom-and-pop stores at the same time.
"But as these superstores proliferate, they need to line their shelves. What's new is that we've never had so many linear feet of shelf space to fill. In a sense, these books are being used as wallpaper. There's no evidence that any more of them are being bought. Instead, we've been seeing record returns."
Returns have always been the thorn in book publishers' side. Under longstanding tradition, booksellers who cannot sell what they order have the right to return them to the publisher for a full refund. The practice is specific to the book business; as Ms. Wasserman points out, "Macy's can't return a blouse they haven't sold." And while publishers have always grumbled about this system, the escalating rates of returns from the superstores have them more worried than ever.
One result is that "we do the opposite of what people might think," Ms. Wasserman said. "We try not to sell too aggressively. We want to try to have an order that realistically reflects what they can sell. Sometimes authors call and want to know why they didn't see their book on the shelves. Seeing that makes the author feel good, but we like to see our books in someone's hand at the cash register."
At Princeton, Mr. Lippincott is far more sanguine about the effect of the superstores. "So far they've been a big help," he says. Returns of Princeton's books increased by 12 percent last year, he acknowledged, but net sales increased by 9 percent, so "it's not something we're nervous about."
To him, the fundamental problem is the precipitous decline in the purchasing power of libraries -- a problem that some publishers had hoped expanded sales at superstores would solve. "We used to be able to sell 800 to 900 copies of each of our books to research libraries worldwide," Mr. Lippincott said. "Now, that figure is down to 300. That's just not enough to sustain the publication of a monograph. With only a few exceptions, even the most brilliant book in French history is unlikely to sell more than 500 copies."
Ms. Wasserman, too, is concerned. She estimates that 20 years ago, libraries accounted for half the sales of a typical Rutgers publication, but now the average would be closer to 5 percent. "It's an enormous change," she says, "and it's not going to get better, with the lack of funding to libraries and the growth of interlibrary loans."
But Rutgers's strategy involves developing a certain independence from the institutional market, which is why the consequences of the superstores' spread worry her so much more than Mr. Lippincott.

Catching the Eye Of the Browser
 Like many other university presses around the country, both Princeton and Rutgers publish a certain number of trade titles, books they hope may reach the broader book-buying public beyond the campuses.
At Princeton, many are in the sciences, like this spring's lead title, "T. Rex and the Crater of Doom," by the geologist Walter Alvarez of the University of California at Berkeley, who contends that the dinosaurs were rendered extinct by the Earth's collision, 65 million years ago, with a comet or an asteroid larger than Mount Everest. That book's first print run is a healthy 15,000 copies (a mid-size run for commercial publishers), and it's been picked up as a selection by the Book-of-the-Month Club and the Quality Paperback Book Club, as well as a number of more specialized clubs. (A cute title seems to be one good sign for a trade science book. Also forthcoming from Princeton is "Why Toast Lands Jelly-Side Down: Zen and the Art of Physics Demonstrations," by Robert Ehrlich.)
Rutgers devotes an even larger portion of its list to trade titles than Princeton does, and many are books of regional interest. "We are the best and biggest publisher of books on New Jersey," Ms. Wasserman likes to say, adding that she also looks for books that focus on New York City, the Hudson River and the Poconos.
Among Rutgers's books this spring that fall into this regional rubric are "Fields of Sun and Grass: An Artist's Journal of the New Jersey Meadowlands," by John R. Quinn of Ridgefield Park; "Newark's Little Italy: The Vanished First Ward," by Michael Immerso, who grew up there, and "Subway City: Riding the Trains, Reading New York," by Michael W. Brooks, a professor at West Chester University in Pennsylvania.
Regional books account for 15 percent of those Rutgers publishes, and Ms. Wasserman says she has been so pleased with their performance that she hopes to raise that figure to 20 percent, if only she can find enough good ones. She says she has a list of books she would publish if only she could find the right authors.
"For 10 years I've been looking for someone to write a social history of the Jersey Shore," she says. "I'd love to find the right person to write a guide to the area's fresh- and salt-water fishing, or a kind of lyrical guide to New Jersey's northwest counties."
She laments that so few authors think to champion the Garden State. "In many states, it's the opposite," she says. "In the South, in California, this kind of regional writing is a very active field. Here people look elsewhere for their subjects."
The idea of going out in search of authors for books that might find a market niche among general readers might once have raised eyebrows at university presses, whose editors were more used to passing judgment on scholarly monographs. Princeton is sticking more closely to the traditional model. Mr. Lippincott points up the distinction by remarking: "We're not going out to get someone to write 'The Best of New Jersey Cooking.' If I were Rutgers, I would." Princeton's strategy has been to try to increase the average dollar volume per book by changing the mix to include somewhat fewer titles in the humanities and more in fields like science and economics, in which more copies can be sold at higher prices.

Acceptance, Rejection And the Bottom Line
 Typically, the editorial process at a university press begins when an author submits a finished manuscript for consideration by an editor with expertise in the field. If the editor thinks the manuscript is a good candidate for publication, it is then sent out for readings by two scholarly experts in the field, who write detailed reports that are sent both to the editor and, anonymously, to the author. The readers may recommend that the book not be published, or that the author rework it before a final decision is made.
The power these readers wield over a book's fate makes their selection one of the most delicate aspects of this editorial process. Stories of outrageously arbitrary reasons for rejection are legion in the academic world; one philosophy professor, speaking on condition of anonymity, mentioned a case in an anonymous reader disparaged one of his books on the ground, among others, of his decision to use "she" rather than "he" as an indefinite pronoun.
If these outside readings are favorable, the editor submits the manuscript to an editorial committee for approval. Although the committee, consisting of members of the university's faculty, usually follows the recommendations of its editors and the outside readers, it need not do so. While "in a vast majority of cases there is consensus" at Rutgers, Ms. Wasserman said, "about once a year we are disappointed" at the rejection of a manuscript.
So what about that assistant professor's new monograph on French history? Does it languish unpublished? Mr. Lippincott insists that while "our goals can't be filled by publishing only monographs, any editor is free to propose a book that will lose money."
One reason scholarly books can lose money is that their publishers needn't turn a profit. Rutgers makes up its losses through support from its parent university -- a subsidy that, as Ms. Wasserman ruefully points out, has remained flat over the years even as expenses have grown. Princeton is in the more comfortable position of being able to operate without any direct financial contribution from the university; the press owns its own building and land and has its own endowment, through which its deficit is financed. By contrast, Mr. Lippincott points out that the University of Chicago has determined to convert its distinguished publishing arm into a profit center, which could radically change the nature of its list. "If we were forced to break even, there are a lot of books we could no longer do," he says. "If you want a press to make money, it won't do what the faculty wants."
Still, even money-losing institutions need to meet their budgets. If they lose more money than expected, the consequences may be even more dire than for a company whose profits fall short, As a result, academic presses need to sell more copies of each book than in the past.
For Ms. Wasserman, a sales figure of 2,000 copies over four years is a minimum goal for most books, although, she adds, "3,000 would be better." For now, she estimates, only about a quarter of the books Rutgers publishes meet that goal, but the shortfall is made up by a few books that sell much better than average.
Rutgers's top seller so far is " 'Quicksand' and Passing.' " That 1986 reissue of two short novels by Nella Larsen, a rediscovered protagonist of the Harlem Renaissance, has sold nearly 70,000 copies. Another best seller has been "Black Athena," by Martin Bernal, whose thesis is that Greek civilization derived from Egypt, and that the ancient Egyptians were black. Mr. Bernal says this history has been suppressed because of the racial biases of classical scholars, from whom the book has prompted spirited rebuttals. Ms. Wasserman attributes her press's emphasis on multiculturalism and on books dealing with racial issues not only to the region's demographics and her editors' interest, but also to the fact that there is a market for such books.
Mr. Lippincott cites a more conservative goal of selling 1,250 to 3,000 books for the average title, although he is quick to add that some of Princeton's books are never intended to sell that many, while some sell considerably more. For example, "The Nature of Space and Time," by Stephen Hawking and Roger Penrose, has sold 19,000 copies, mainly on the strength of the authors' names, Mr. Lippincott says, "although you'd need a Ph.D. in astrophysics to understand it."

The Future Is Here, But It May Not Last
 One much-discussed factor that Mr. Lippincott and Ms. Wasserman agree has had little effect on their business is the brave new world of electronic publishing. One reason is that computers are more suited to short chunks of text than to book-length ones, so electronic publishing has had a more immediate impact on publishers of journals than of books. Princeton publishes just two journals, "Annals of Mathematics" and "Philosophy and Public Policy"; Rutgers none at all. In any case, Mr. Lippincott insists, "no one anyway has made a dime in electronic publishing."
Nonetheless, Princeton has recently experimented with the publication of its classic Richard Wilhelm-Cary F. Baynes translation of the ancient Chinese I Ching as a multi-media CD-ROM.
As Douglas Kincade, Princeton's publisher for electronic products, points out -- and the book's many users know full well -- "the I Ching has always existed uncomfortably in book form"; its structure is already a kind of proto-hypertext demanding that users flip back and forth from one section of the book to another to follow its multi-layered commentaries. There also seems to be a natural overlap between computer users and the New Age types who have made this scholarly landmark into a perennial seller.
But to develop such a disk, even from an existing book (or rather two books, since the CD also incorporates a separate volume of commentary by Hellmut Wilhelm, Richard's son, who is a distinguished China scholar in his own right) turns out to be an extremely expensive proposition, and as a result, Mr. Lippincott "would be very surprised to see it break even," he now says. "Although the product is very good, it's an experiment I don't see repeating."
Indeed, he points out that many publishers, among them Simon & Schuster and HarperCollins, are closing down their CD-ROM divisions because no adequate distribution system has emerged to handle them.
"There are 10,000 titles out there," he says, "but if you go out to the stores, only 50 titles are stocked, and those are games." Mr. Kincade admits, just a bit more optimistically, that "right now there's a tremendous down market for CD-ROMS, which we're hoping 'The Multi-Media I Ching' survives."
For now, Mr.Lippincott foresees limiting Princeton's ventures into the realm of CD-ROM to ones that are packaged with books, and in which the CD has been developed (and its development financed) by an outside source -- for instance, a tutorial in intermediate Chinese ("basically a talking workbook," as Mr. Kincade puts it) currently in the works.
What both the Rutgers and Princeton University Presses seem to agree on is that, as Ms. Wasserman says, they are facing a "harder, more challenging environment" for publishing, in which the demands of the intellect and of the market must be more carefully coordinated. For Mr. Lippincott, the challenge comes down to selling more copies without increasing the number of titles published, "so we can keep our jobs and prosper."
That assistant professor had better learn to write clearly, and perhaps with a broader focus. "The burden is now on the author to show there is a readership for what he or she is writing," Ms. Wasserman says. "Most of what doesn't get published just isn't good or has no audience. It's not that there are a lot of good books looking for publishers. There are a lot of good publishers looking for books."

HEADLINE: JERSEY;
Real Beach Kitsch, Not the Fake Stuff

BYLINE: By JOE SHARKEY 

 BODY:
AS amusement parks go, Disney World gives me the willies: All those preternaturally rapturous people wearing shirts plastered with advertisements, strewing disposable incomes across manicured Technicolor midways, while that dreadful mouse-face beams down over all like a penitentiary's searchlight. A day of this is enough to send me to the phone book for the number of an exterminator. One more rendition of "It's a Small World After All," and I'm ready to call Amnesty International.
All things considered then, on those infrequent occasions when the urge to visit an amusement park hits me, I'd rather be in Wildwood, New Jersey's most exuberantly declasse boardwalk resort. As the millenium approaches in a world where entertainment is all, Wildwood is the anti-Disney. 
 But there is startling cultural news from Wildwood, where the boardwalk curls for two miles along the Sahara-sized beach that piles up near the southern tip of the Jersey Shore. Last week, a squadron of earnest architects and design students was crawling all over the place, taking notes and snapping pictures and using sentences not normally heard in Wildwood, such as "look at that porte-cochere!"
The scholars were from the architecture school at Kent State University in Ohio, on a field trip to document (for the Library of Congress) Wildwood as a unique architectural trove of seaside boardwalk-town architecture from 1955 to 1965, the last golden age of America's endless summers. Besides the academics from Kent State, cultural historians from Cornell University have also begun studying Wildwood this year.
This will probably shock many South Jersey baby-boomers who once summered in Wildwood and have peeled away to more genteel spots like Avalon, Long Beach Island, the Hamptons, the Cote d'Azur: Wildwood, it seems, has been unearthed as a virtual Pompei of the school of design known as "doo-wop" (or, sometimes "populuxe") architecture, an exuberant late 1950's style of motel-building in which Gothic arches evolve into 40-foot plastic palms and flying buttresses become "Jetson Fins" painted cherry-blossom pink.
"We've been sitting on this huge collection of 1950's and 1960's architecture," said Jack Morey, the 37-year-old executive vice president of Morey's Piers, which operates several first-class amusement-park piers that are the major attractions on the otherwise tacky, honky-tonk boardwalk.
"Don't get me wrong, I love Disney World," said Mr. Morey, whose family has stubbornly upgraded its attractions every summer since his father and uncle left the motel business for the world of roller-coasters and Ferris wheels in 1969. "But where Disney creates nostalgia for things that never were, we have the real thing," said Mr. Morey, who has emerged as the head cheerleader for what some business people hope is an incipient revival of Wildwood, which has been having hard economic times in recent years, based on its "doo-wop" style.
Wildwood still occupies a time zone of the past in which neon signs are shaped like champagne glasses. Motels -- which only began taking credit cards in recent years -- still do business under oddly old-fashioned space-age names like Galaxie, Satellite and Astronaut.
"The style evokes a time when there was so much optimism in this country, when things were just sort of functioning well," Mr. Morey said.
But it will be a long haul, reviving Wildwood, which only recently was so desperate to turn things around that local officials hoping to open a gambling casino were in talks with an Indian tribe in Oklahoma. The tribe claimed it had aboriginal land rights in Wildwood inherited from ancestors who once roamed South Jersey.
Don't even mention the last flurry of publicity before that, in 1989, when five local businessmen were arrested on the beach, where they were tossing handfuls of chlorine tablets into the sea to try to improve clean-water ratings.
Mr. Morey insists that Wildwood is finally getting its act together. "Our boardwalk is the real thing," he said. "And we also have that beach."
That beach gathers in bewildering abundance and keeps growing in the five-mile nook above Cape May, while the rest of the shore screams about erosion. This is not always welcome. In some places, the beach is more than a quarter-mile wide, and lifeguards need to watch not only for floundering swimmers but also for those who faint of heat exhaustion on the way to the ocean.
Mr. Morey takes that in stride. "Heck, the amusement piers wouldn't be half their size if the ocean didn't keep moving back," he said.

GRAPHIC: Drawing. (Nancy Doniger)

HEADLINE: State Dollars: Whalers Arena Vs. Rails, Schools

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH 

 BODY:
THE vast majority of patrons at Bobby Valentine's Sports Gallery in Norwalk who watch hockey on one of the restaurant's two 42-inch television screens prefer to watch the New York Rangers. And when there is no game on and talk turns to hockey, it usually centers on the New York Rangers.
"This is Ranger territory," said Mike Allegra, the manager of the sports hangout, one of two Bobby Valentine-owned Sports Galleries in the state. Mr. Valentine, a native of Stamford (where the other one is situated) is the manager of the New York Mets. 
 Indeed, the same situation applies at practically all the sports bar-restaurants in Fairfield County. Likewise, sports sections of newspapers in Fairfield County tend to play up stories about the Rangers and even the New York Islanders, while relegating reports about the Hartford Whalers into wrapups about other National Hockey League games.
"There's not much interest in the Whalers around here," said Bob Birge, a sportswriter for The Connecticut Post in Bridgeport, only 50 miles from Hartford. "We cover the Rangers on a fairly regularly basis, but we don't cover the Whalers. To us, they're a Hartford team."
And they may not even be that for much longer, unless the state agrees to build the team a new arena. Peter Karamanos, the owner of the Whalers, has said he will move the club elsewhere, most likely to Nashville, or St. Paul, Minn., or Columbus, Ohio. And though the Whalers have a lease to stay at the Hartford Civic Center through the 1997-98 season, the state is expected to permit them to leave after the current season if a deal for a new arena cannot be worked out within the next few weeks.
This marks the second straight year that Mr. Karamanos has threatened to pull his team out of Hartford. A year ago, he said the Whalers organization would try to get out of its lease and move before this season began unless the team could increase its season-ticket sales from 5,800 to 11,000 by last May 1. (The Whalers did sell 9,200 season tickets, which, although less than the goal specified by Mr. Karamanos, apparently was sufficient to keep him from trying to move elsewhere.)
At the time, Mr. Karamanos and other club officials said the Whalers also would eventually need a new arena, even though the Civic Center is only 25 years old. But the Whalers general counsel and consultant for business affairs, Lou Beer, said, "It's ludicrous to think about a new arena when we can't fill the one we have."
The Whalers, again enduring a losing season, still can't fill the Civic Center Coliseum, although the team is averaging about 13,500 spectators -- largely because of a good start -- But the Hartford Civic Center seats only 14,660 for hockey and average attendance in the league is 15,000. Now the team says it needs a larger arena that would include more sky boxes (30 of 45 are currently leased for about $60,000 each) and "club seating" suites along with other amenities that would tend to increase the Whalers' income. Mr. Karamanos says losses have totaled about $40 million since he bought the team in 1994.
Under an agreement with the Connecticut Development Authority, a quasi-public body that bought the Civic Center from Richard Gordon, Mr. Karamanos is free to take the Whalers elsewhere after next season if the team has lost $30 million by then.
Gov. John G. Rowland, who has been the state's key negotiator in the effort to keep the Whalers in Hartford, and others who support that initiative, have made it a point to stress that the Whalers are in effect a state team and that to lose them would be calamitous.
Not everyone shares that feeling. Practically all the Whalers' fans -- and there have not been enough of them to suit Mr. Karamanos -- are from the Hartford area only. Gary Samek, the sports editor of the Norwich Bulletin in eastern Connecticut (where some hockey fans historically have followed the Boston Bruins), said, "We never staff their games and I've never had a single complaint."
Despite an apparent indifference to the Whalers across most of the state, Governor Rowland has indicated he would like to build a new arena for the Whalers (cost has been estimated at between $150 million and $250 million).
At a time when the Governor is trying to cut state college and university spending -- and eliminate the Danbury and Waterbury branches on the Metro-North Commuter Railroad along with the Shore Line East service from New Haven to New London -- any attempt to spend state money on an arena for a professional hockey team owned by a millionaire is likely to face resistance in the legislature. That the team's payroll has more than quadrupled from $5 million to about $20 million in less than a decade is also not likely to help the Governor's case.
Yet Mr. Rowland is on record as saying that he feels that it is essential to keep the Whalers in Hartford because they are an important asset to the state and give the capital the imprimatur of a big league city. Should the Governor recommend that state bonds be used to build an arena in order to keep the Whalers in Hartford, the issue would be bound to be one of the most provocative on this year's legislative calendar.
Though Mr. Karamanos says it has nothing to do with his hope of having the state build his team a new arena, he recently said he was considering establishing a branch of his Michigan-based company in the Hartford area. He said that such a move could create as many as 1,500 jobs. He said he would pursue the matter even if the Whalers do not stay in Hartford.
No one doubts that the loss of the Whalers would have a substantial impact on the Hartford Civic Center itself, since it would deprive the center of its prime tenant.
"We certainly have a vested interest in the Whalers remaining at the Civic Center," said Fred Laberge, a spokesman for Aetna Inc., which owns the Civic Center mall, including its stores and restaurants, along with the atrium and the building's office space.
Mr. Laberge said that since the Civic Center mall opened in 1972, it has lost $56 million, even though the occupancy rate has remained "fairly good."
Restaurateurs and store owners in the mall say that much of their business is based on Whaler home games, even though the team has enjoyed only three winning seasons since moving to Hartford from Boston during the 1974-75 season. "As for their potential departure, it would not help," Mr. Laberge said.
Indeed, it would leave a huge void, the Whalers' perennially poor performance notwithstanding. In recent years the Civic Center has also lost virtually all the concert business that was a major staple.
Mr. Karamanos, the chief executive officer of a computer software company, the Compuware Corporation, based in Farmington Hills, Mich., maintains that "it will be impossible for us to stay unless we get a new building," and that "the team can't afford to pay for it."
"We're losing money, don't get any of the concession or parking revenues and are one of the smallest markets in the National Hockey League," he said. "Other cities and states have built arenas that create economic conditions which generate revenues that can help pay for them."
Governor Rowland has indicated that he agrees, and that surcharges on game tickets, along with other tax revenues from a new arena could help pay off state bonds that would be needed to build the arena.
Thomas D. Ritter, a Hartford Democrat who, as the House Speaker, is one of the state's most influential political figures, has offered similar sentiments.
"The assumption is that the arena would pay for itself," said Mr. Ritter, who favors building a second sports center alongside the one for use by an upgraded University of Connecticut football team. "I'm apprehensive about building just one facility," he said. "But any arrangement has to be structured in such a way so that it doesn't place a burden on the taxpayers."
Two prominent Democratic lawmakers seem a bit less sanguine. "Mr. Karamanos is in a wonderful position," said Moira K. Lyons of Stamford, the House Majority Leader. "He can either get a new arena and stay in Connecticut or he can move to a new arena elsewhere. But we have to be careful about our priorities. The major question here is whether sufficient money would be generated by the Whalers staying in Hartford to pay for the new arena."
Even though few people in Fairfield County seem to care much about the fate of the Whalers, Ms. Lyons said keeping the team in Hartford could affect taxpayers throughout Connecticut.
"Revenues generated from the Whalers can help revitalize a city like Hartford," said Ms. Lyons, who described herself as an avid hockey fan but who has seen very few Whaler games. "And when urban centers are revitalized it helps the whole state because not as much outside taxpayer support is necessary."
Another Stamford Democrat, George C. Jepsen, the State Senate Majority Leader, agreed with Ms. Lyons that the Whalers' issue goes beyond regionalism.
"I would love to see the Whalers stay, but a new arena has be justified on a statewide basis," Mr. Jepsen said. "And advocates for building a new facility face an uphill battle. My own impression, based on a number of studies, is that more often than not the cost outweighs the benefits."

SECTION: Section 13CN; Page 1; Column 3; Connecticut Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1815 words

HEADLINE: Women Really Mean Business

BYLINE: By DIANE SIERPINA 

 BODY:
DEBRA LEWIS remembers her father's advice from many years ago: learn to type so you can earn pin money when your children are grown. Today, she's making better than pin money, and doing so by publishing a new business directory that proves women have branched way out from the typing pool. Her father, she says, would have been proud.
It's another example of the sort of mutual support that has women's groups excited. 
 "The old boy network has been very difficult to crack," said Ms. Lewis, a former sales manager, "but we're now inventing what I call the young girl network."
Ms. Lewis is identifying hundreds of businesses around the state owned and managed by women for inclusion in the annual directory, the Connecticut edition of the Women's Yellow Pages, which was published for the first time last fall.
That doesn't surprise Connie Galley and Carol Wallace, both presidents of sizeable Connecticut companies, who have held leadership roles in the state's two largest, mainstream business associations for the past couple of years. Tokenism? No, they say, but rather a sign that women are succeeding in business in big numbers.
"This is really a terrific time for women," said Ms. Galley, chairwoman of the board of the business organization called SACIA, and president of T.S.I. International Software Ltd., a $25 million company based in Wilton. "The doors are wide open. A new generation is coming up that has grown up with the expectation that they can do anything. And that generation is here now."
For the past decade, the number of women-owned businesses nationally and statewide has shot up, say experts, and 1996 was no exception. According to estimates from the National Foundation for Women Business Owners, the number of companies owned by women rose 78 percent between 1987 and 1996 to almost 8 million nationwide. As of last year, these companies employed more than 18.5 million workers and generated nearly $2.3 trillion in sales.
In Connecticut, the rise in that same period was 56 percent, to 104,00 businesses, for a ranking of 25th out of 50 states. These companies employed more than 250,000 workers and generated more than $38 billion in sales, according to the foundation.
It's been 20 years since many national organizations were created to promote and support women. Today, the state's Permanent Commission on the Status of Women publishes a directory listing 500 organizations around Connecticut that serve the health, social, business and political needs of women. "The good news," says Barbara Potopowitz, the commission's spokeswoman, "is that there are so many and they are fast-growing."
As the number of women executives and entrepreneurs has grown, so have the number of associations for such women, focusing primarily on networking, mentoring and economic development assistance -- and attempting not to overlap each other. But their number doesn't appear to disturb traditional business leaders.
"America is a very diverse place and we do business in a diverse set of ways," observed Christopher Bruhl, president and chief executive officer of SACIA, the second-largest business association in the state. "We have an association for everything; why shouldn't there be a lot of associations relating to women in business? It's a natural outgrowth of women's place and presence in the work force as leaders."
But Sue Glasspiegel said she noticed two years ago that the existing associations did not focus on the latest phenomenon -- the more established women-owned businesses in the state. Ms. Glasspiegel was among the early members and now serves as president of the 18-month old Connecticut chapter of the National Association for Women Business Owners, based in Simsbury. The chapter has 100 members whose companies are at least five years old and have 1 to 1,500 employees.
The national association estimates Fairfield County has the most women-owned businesses of any county in the United States, but there are no hard figures, says Ms. Glasspiegel.
"There are a lot of organizations that cater to women, but each has a special focus," said Ms. Glasspiegel of the overlap issue. Her group, one of 64 chapters of the national organization, lobbies the state and Federal governments for legal changes, helps secure government contracts, and brainstorms on issues that apply to its members.
In January the chapter sponsored (along with the Small Business Administration and Representative Christopher Shays, a Republican of Stamford) a forum in Norwalk designed to bring government contractors and women business owners together. More than 20 contractors and 70 women business owners participated. Although the goal for government contracts to women-owned businesses is set at 5 percent, currently the figure nationwide is 2.4 percent, said Mr. Shays.
"We're not so much a networking group as a support group," Ms. Glasspiegel said. "We face a different set of issues than men, all tempered by the issue of balancing work and family." Women need their associations, in addition to mainstream chambers of commerce and business groups, she said, adding "It's not a disservice to have these all available to you. I pick and choose how I want to spend my time."
Fran Pastore, director of training and counseling for the American Woman's Economic Development Corporation's Stamford office, said women feel more empowered and safer in their own groups. "There's a synergy and freedom of expression." she said. "It's amazing to see the bond that forms in the first 20 minutes. A lot of them end up doing business together."
Ms. Glasspiegel said "I would do business with a woman over a man, if all things are equal. I think most women feel that way. There's a sense of loyalty and support among women." Since its formation three years ago, AWED has helped 500 women start and grow businesses, linked some with mentors and held workshops, she said. The IBM Corporation recently donated computers and $15,000 to help AWED's establish a resource center with free access to the Internet for clients and members.
The first issue of the Women's Yellow Pages features 250 advertisers across the state, ranging from herbalists, counselors and lawyers to furniture movers and the owner of a septic tank removal service. The second edition is in the works.
"One of the things that came out from our initial marketing study," said Ms. Lewis, agreeing with Ms. Glasspiegel, "is that, given the option, women would rather work with other women." Although there is no typical female business owner, Ms. Lewis said many are better educated than in the past and have had corporate experience.
"When we start our own businesses, we know all the stuff that came out of those corporate environments that we didn't like and we've determined that we're going to be different," Ms. Lewis said. "I also think that we're much, much better prepared. The failure rate of women-owned businesses is absolutely miniscule."
While Ms. Lewis allows men to advertise in her directory if they provide services or products for women, Rolande Hodel's newly published Purple Pages directory lists businesses in the Connecticut, New York and New Jersey area owned only by women. Ms. Hodel, a research chemist from Ossining, N. Y., lists 600 businesses, one-third of which are in Connecticut, mostly in Fairfield County. The Purple Pages are published bimonthly, but Ms. Hodel said her goal is to publish one annual directory.
The growth of women-owned businesses around Connecticut has been a trend since at least the early 1980's, said Lee Lemaire, president of the Connecticut Small Business Federation. Of the 50 inquiries a day to his association, he said most are from women. Many are starting unusual businesses, including manufacturing companies in such areas as metal stamping and machine tool production. A growing number of companies are started by women working flexible hours so they can care for their families, he explained.
"Most of the new businesses started today are by women," said Mr. Lemaire. "The principle breadwinner is going to shift at some point. I'm not going to say in the year 2000, but pretty well early into the next century, I see that happening. I see them as the generators of income and wealth. It's very very slow at this stage, but it's going to skyrocket.
"Women are smarter -- that's a point blank statement I can make," added Mr. Lemaire. "In business, women are smarter. They are better at people relationships. They are not as impatient. The two major ingredients are already there. Pretty soon, the new style -- accommodation, negotiation, concession, conciliation, all of those nice words -- they're becoming more and more a part of our business life. It's a better workplace in my point of view."
Mr. Lemaire will move to chairman this fall after 22 years as president and be replaced by Anne Evans, who is an owner and president of Elm Energy and the Performance Services Corporation, two energy companies in Hebron.
Although associations only for women help retain and increase women-owned businesses, said Mr. Bruhl of SACIA, "it's important that women don't only work in those groups because then you accidently reverse-catagorize yourselves."
For almost two years, Connie Galley has served as chairwoman of SACIA's board, the first woman and first president of a small business in that post. Ms. Galley earned a degree with majors in mathematics and chemistry from Duke University and came from a family of entrepreneurs. "I never felt uncomfortable in the regular business world," she said. "Maybe it has to do with how you are raised."
Carol Wallace, president and chief executive officer of the Cooper Instrument Corporation in Middlefield with 110 employees, is vice chairwoman of the board of the Connecticut Business and Industry Association, the state's largest, and will take over the leadership post in November. Cooper, a time and temperature instrument manufacturer, was founded in 1885 and bought by her father in 1960. Ms. Wallace, a biology major, has been president since 1993.
"It's a real tribute to C.B.I.A. and its members that they recognize there are more women business owners and executives who do need to be represented," Ms. Wallace said. "I do think I probably was put ahead of some of the men who have paid their dues, but I think it was for good cause."
Overall, she said, "I've always had to be a step ahead as a woman."
Growth areas for female entrepreneurs are seen especially in technology and financial services, said Mr. Lemaire. He advises women to go back to school and take more business, personnel, labor relations and general management courses.
"Women are waking up to the whole slew of opportunities that were not available before," said Ms. Glasspiegel. "All of a sudden, they're unifying and fighting for a piece of the pie."

HEADLINE: Seeking to Promote Arab-Jewish Harmony

BYLINE: By HERBERT HADAD 

 BODY:
LAST year Dr. Lee Katz of Rye, a former vice president of Purchase College, took on the educational mission of a lifetime -- to teach Arabs and Jews to coexist peacefully in Israel.
She became executive director of the Abraham Fund, named for the biblical patriarch of both Arabs and Jews. 
 Returning recently from observing some of the projects the fund supports in Israel, Dr. Katz said she was heartened. "I have to tell you about a profoundly moving experience," she said, referring to a visit with a group of battered women. "I saw Jewish and Arab women sharing their common problems together. All ethnic differences had disappeared. One individual was talking to another. These people were being helped by Arab and Jewish staff, and they were being reached in a way never reached before."
Accompanied by Alan B. Slifka, a New York financier who provided seed money to help establish the fund eight years ago, Dr. Katz also met with a woman who came up with the idea of creating a magazine called Windows, printed in both Arabic and Hebrew and distributed in schools.
"This woman, a single parent, assembled in her home 10 Arab and Jewish children," Dr. Katz said. "These children were intelligent, alert, animated, involved with each other. And these children were the editorial board. It was a remarkable thing to see."
Dr. Katz, who was vice president for external affairs and development at Purchase College for 10 years, joined the fund last March and directs its activities from a Madison Avenue office with a staff of eight. On the doors leading to the office is the name of the fund in English, Hebrew and Arabic, and on the office walls and coffee tables are artworks and books reflecting Israeli and Arabic cultures.
The nonprofit educational and fund-raising organization considers itself apolitical and motivated by humane values. Its motto is, "In Israel, coexistence is the only alternative."
Dr. Katz said there had been no change in the reception given the fund's projects in Israel after the Government of Benjamin Netanyahu replaced that of the late Yitzhak Rabin and that no official approval was needed to carry out projects. "Both Governments have greatly supported our efforts," she said.
Starting in 1989 Mr. Slifka, who was also founder of the Big Apple Circus, became involved in trying to make Israel a more harmonious state and helped found the Abraham Fund, to which he donated about $500,000.
He is president of the board of directors of the fund.
Mr. Slifka will talk about "Coexistence as a Rising Issue on Israel's National Agenda" on Thursday at 8 P.M. to members of the American Jewish Congress at the Scarsdale Synagogue. The talk is open to the public free of charge. The number to call for more information is (800) 301-3863.
The Abraham Fund is better known in Israel than in the United States but is building a membership in this country. It provides grants for projects related to community cooperation, the arts, curriculum development, economic development, interfaith dialogue, medical care and advocacy, teacher training and women's issues.
Last year it spent more than $1 million to support 68 such projects and has awarded $4 million to 230 projects since it began giving grants four years ago. The fund also operates outreach and educational programs in North America and has established forums in Boston, Detroit, Los Angeles, Miami, New Orleans and Washington to spread the word of Arab-Jewish coexistence in Israel.
In addition, an-adopt-a-program matches coexistence projects with individual donors, families, community groups or foundations that underwrite them. The projects range in cost from $5,000 to $100,000.
The United States is the primary source of funds, Dr. Katz said, with some amounts beginning to come from Canada and Israel. She said support in the United States included donations from a small number of Arab-Americans.
One donation that particularly touched officials of the Abraham Fund came from a child in the Middle West. "His parents were deeply involved in philanthropy and Israeli activities," Dr. Katz said. "The boy was bar mitzvahed and gave us a gift of several thousand dollars."
She said donors now numbered in the thousands with 500 new contributors added last year. "It's a young organization and the word is spreading," she said.
One man in England responded dramatically. He had been listening to an audio tape of an Arab-Jewish musical group called Bustahn Avraham, Avraham being Hebrew for Abraham and Bustahn the word for garden in both Hebrew and Arabic. He then called the fund in New York.
"He saw that the Abraham Fund sponsored the group," Dr. Katz said. "And he said he would like to support us. He sent $15,000."
She said every project was evaluated each year and suggested that not every one had been a success, although she declined to give details. "If you don't have failures you have not really tried," she said. "We're not afraid to take a risk."
Another project Dr. Katz and Mr. Slifka visited earlier this year was an integrated kindergarten in the Y.M.C.A. in Jerusalem, which features cultural and language exchanges between Arab and Jewish children, the tasting of each group's foods and field trips to one another's homes.
"Change comes about one on one," Dr. Katz said. "My great joy in doing this work is that I am privileged to see the kind of change that is possible."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Lee Katz of the Abraham Fund, in her Manhattan office. (George M. Gutierrez for The New York Times)
