HEADLINE: Westchester Q&A: Jim Brown;
Producing a Showcase for Harry Belafonte

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
CONCERTGOERS at Purchase College on Nov. 30 and Dec. 1 had the chance to see and hear Harry Belafonte. What they experienced, however, was more than just a concert -- it was the making of a television special and record album.
It was the brainchild of Jim Brown, a resident of Putnam Valley, and his wife, Ginger, who were coproducers and directors of "An Evening With Harry Belafonte and Friends," which was broadcast last night on PBS and will be repeated throughout the month. The Browns have a production company, the Ginger Group. 
 Mr. Brown grew up in Croton-on-Hudson. He has been producer and/ or director on a number of television specials for PBS, the Disney Channel and others, including "We Shall Overcome," which won an Emmy Award in 1989; "Child of Mine," which won a Cable Ace Award in 1994 and "In the Spotlight: Mary Chapin Carpenter at Wolf Trap" in 1995. He also teaches film and television at New York University and is working on a documentary biography of Harry Belafonte.
Here are excerpts from a recent conversation with Mr. Brown:
Q. How does a show like the Harry Belafonte concert originate?
A. It's Harry Belafonte's first television concert in over a decade. Basically, it started because I was doing a documentary on Harry's life. We were in Jamaica with him last year and on returning we decided to go to one of his concerts, and that's when I thought it would be particularly good for the PBS audience. When we got into it, it became not just a concert but a record as well.
Q. Did he already have the concert at Purchase College booked, or was that a specially created event?
A. No. I mean he had been touring sometimes as many as 100 days, but to prepare this concert was about six or seven months in the making from the time that we started to talk about it. He brought in really world-class musicians from Senegal, from Cameroon, from Brazil to augment his already wonderful band. We rehearsed materials this summer. He made the rounds with it in Canada and tested it at his regular concerts. Then for about a month we just did rehearsals before this concert.
Harry has long been involved in world music, but in the last years he has been very active in trying to get new songs together that I would say are Afro-centric in origin. Also, he has taken his older songs and given them a new-suit approach. So for this concert, besides bringing in the new band members he prepared some new material.
Q. What did you, as the co-producer, do?
A. In this case we came up with the idea, sold the show, then also made the deal with the record company and for the video distribution. We oversee the promotion of the show and the exploitation of it.
Q. What about how it actually looks?
A. We brought in, I think, one of the best crews in the world for doing music specials. We were responsible for bringing in Harry's lighting, really transferring a stage show to television. You light a television show in an entirely different way than a concert hall.
Q. Did you light it while it was going on, or did you alter the tape later?
A. It's basically a live show, so we record it with, in this case, eight cameras. There were a lot of huge trucks, a 48-track digital sound studio encased in one truck, a control room monitoring all the cameras. We had to bring in probably 150 people to be involved with doing this, and we did it over two nights.
As producers, we had to facilitate anything that Harry Belafonte and the band wanted and negotiate all the deals.
Q. How is the show put together?
A. It's pretty much like live television. It's all edited live.
Q. Meaning you are making decisions on which camera angle to use as it happens?
A. Yes. Then you can clean it up if you have to.
Q. What is Harry Belafonte like?
A. Oh, a dream. Everything you can imagine and more. He's a consummate entertainer; he's a perfectionist. He's probably, out of all the entertainers that I have worked with, the most conscious about every little detail of the show. He has a great presence. The camera just loves him. He's about to turn 70, but he looks about 55.
Q. His voice is still strong? And his energy level is still there?
A. Yes. He's probably one of the most -- I would put him certainly in the top three -- energetic people I've ever met.
Q. Why has his voice been preserved? Clean living? Good genes?
A. I think a combination of both things. He's an artist who thrives on the things that he does, and because of his early, enormous success he has had an economic base to really just do those things that were meaningful to him.
I think what attracted me to him as an artist and as a person to be the subject of a biography is that he has got several different careers and he has excelled in all of them. He's a recording artist -- one of the first recording artists ever to sell a million albums. He was probably the first black heart-throb of America through movies and Broadway and television and his recordings. He was the first black producer of feature films and television shows. In addition to that, he was a statesman. He was a very political person, one of Martin Luther King's best friends. He was an architect of the civil rights movement. He was a go-between between John Kennedy and the civil rights movement and provided a lot of money and backing for the movement. And he was the guy who came up with the "We are the World" campaign for Africa. He has been a Unicef ambassador for years. He also was responsible for promoting Bishop Tutu's first tour, then Nelson Mandela's first tour to the United States.
Q. Is he basically self-educated?
A. Harry grew up in Jamaica, was born in Harlem but his mother was a domestic and his father was a cook. His father left early on, and Harry's care was entrusted to relatives in Jamaica. He went there at a very early age, and it was kind of a lonely time. He was a little bit of an outsider. It was undiagnosed at that time, but he was dyslexic, so he had problems at school. Last year he returned to Jamaica to celebrate his getting an honorary degree, one of several he has been given. This was especially poignant for him.
Q. Where would you market a biography?
A. I think we're going to try and release it as a feature film. It's a collaborative effort, his life through his eyes.
Q. Has Harry Belafonte crossed the generation lines? Can he attract people of all ages?
A. Yes. We're trying to do something very much like what was done with Tony Bennett. Harry is one of the hippest people I know -- intellectually, politically, stylewise.
Q. Where do you want to take your career from here?
A. I very much enjoy what I'm doing. I feel like I lead a very charmed life. I get to work with my wife, and our daughter, who just turned 12, often comes to the studio. I get to work with some of the people I really admire in the world, either in translating their work to television or concert or documenting some aspects of their lives.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jim Brown, producer and director of a special television show and record album featuring Harry Belafonte, at Sony music studios in Manhattan. The show is being broadcast on PBS. (Barbara Alper for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 9; Page 3; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1615 words

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Pomona, N.Y.;
Easy City Access In a Ramapos Setting

BYLINE: By CHERYL PLATZMAN WEINSTOCK 

 BODY:
FROM her 10-room colonial with sweeping decks and a panoramic view of the Ramapo Mountains, Leslie Sanderson enjoys the simple pleasure of greeting the deer that sometimes peer into her window in the morning as the dew sets on her one-acre wooded property.
"Compared to Westchester or Connecticut, this style house was a pretty good value at $419,000," said Ms. Sanderson, who with her husband, Nicholas, built their home in the Rockland County village of Pomona seven years ago. 
 Houses in the village's developments are especially appealing because "the homes are not cookie-cutter houses," said Dorothy McNamara, a broker for Century 21 Len Carr Realty in Pomona, adding that today the Sandersons could realize at least what they invested in their house.
The original old farmhouses, bungalows and Revolutionary War Colonials on Old Route 202, Route 306 and Camp Hill Road were built on large lots that once drew wealthy people seeking a summer retreat to what was then an unincorporated area, even then known as Pomona. In 1967 part of the community straddling the Towns of Haverstraw and Ramapo was incorporated into a village to control zoning. A main issue was a proposal to build a large condominium complex. Those favoring incorporation wanted to retain the rural ambiance.
Many farmers began selling off their land and new subdivisions with one-acre lots for detached houses replaced the orchards that gave the community its name -- Pomona was the Roman goddess of fruit.
"We did a little pioneering back then," said Sam Schechter, a local developer. "We built and kept most of the trees and foliage when it wasn't fashionable."
Show business is well represented among present and former residents such as Joe Harris, who produced and managed "Sweet Charity," "Dancing at Lughnasa" and "Mame." And Frederick Loewe and Alan Jay Lerner wrote "My Fair Lady" in Mr. Lerner's 1732 home. In his book, "The Street Where I Live," Mr. Lerner called his Pomona a "unique community." The house was previously owned by, among others, Charlie Chaplin when he was married to Paulette Goddard and Burgess Meredith when he was married to Ms. Goddard.
Buff Blass, 47, a creative director in advertising, said she was "very, very happy" living in a community with easy access to Newark, La Guardia and Stewart Airports over the Palisades Interstate Parkway, the Garden State Parkway and the George Washington and Tappan Zee Bridges.
"The village also has all the conveniences the city has, but at a more civilized pace," said Ms. Blass. Strip malls along Route 202 just outside the village provide diversified shopping, services and food outlets, and the huge Nanuet Mall is just a short drive away.
BUT for many of Pomona's residents, whose median income is 4 percent higher than the county average, the village, with its 60 acres of parkland, is an amalgam of serenity and challenge.
Most people in Pomona get involved, said Deputy Mayor Herbert Marshall, "to produce the best educational product we can in spite of budget and any political infighting that occurs."
"When we built our home we could have gone anywhere," said Ms. Sanderson, who has two children and is co-president of the Grandview Elementary School P.T.A. "I specifically wanted to stay in the East Ramapo Central School District. I know the school district, I went through it. I definitely like it because of its ethnic and cultural diversity. I didn't want my children to go anywhere else. Here my children get a true picture of the real world."
With 9,200 students enrolled in the East Ramapo Central School District, 65 percent of the children represent 40 different nationalities; the district encompasses three towns, including heavily Hispanic Haverstraw, and eight villages, including Spring Valley, which has a concentration of Haitian immigrants. "The only problem that this presents is that there are 500 students enrolled in English as a second-language classes, which are task-intensive and expensive," said Dr. Jack R. Anderson, the district superintendent. "But we try to mainstream students within three years."
He said that he preferred to consider diversity in the community and public schools as something to celebrate. (Another measure of diversity in the district is the fact that 9,500 students within it -- from the Orthodox Jewish communities of Kaser, New Square and Monsey -- are enrolled in private schools.)
"We work toward maximizing and teaching students to live and work in the real world," Dr. Anderson said. "We have students coming back from their first year of college telling us how easy their academic and social life have been."
Of the district's 631 high school graduates last year, 88 percent went on to higher education, said Dr. Anderson. The average Scholastic Assessment Test scores were 511 on the verbal section and 525 on the math part, above the New York State average of 497 and 499, respectively.
"Both of our high schools are in the top 1 percent of all high schools in the United States in regard to the advanced placement courses we offer," Dr. Anderson said, noting that more than 100 college credits were available. But after many years of success, the East Ramapo Central School District, which has eight elementary schools -- four for kindergarten to third grade, four for fourth to sixth grade; three junior high schools and two senior high schools -- has come under fire by some.
"I think the school district does an amazing job in integrating everything," said Scott Shabot, who moved to Pomona in 1983. "But the bottom line is we'd all like it to be better. We serve a wide economic spectrum with all the problems of the urban poor. Sometimes it becomes politics in the school district and educational considerations become secondary. "
Harvey Katz, a school-board member and Munsey businessman, disagreed. "We don't have politics in the school system," he said. "I am here to see to it that there is as cost-effective high quality education in the district as possible."
WHILE East Ramapo is one of five school districts in the state where more students are enrolled in private schools than public schools for religious reasons, the parochial-school parents are nevertheless obliged to pay taxes to support public schools. Yet some public-school parents see the high proportion of parochial-school parents as a threat to the school system, arguing that residents who send their children to private schools are likely to have less of a commitment to public schools.
Not so, said Mr. Katz, one of four Orthodox Jews on the nine-member school board. "Just because my children are not in the public schools doesn't mean I don't care about all the children," he said. "Children are our future, wherever they may be."
For all the complexities of the school system, the village parks can offer the solace of quiet, wooded trails, swimming, tennis courts, or fishing. Burgess Meredith Park, dedicated in 1971 and named for the actor who helped incorporate the village, offers residents 21 acres of walking paths, a playground and baseball field. The 16-acre Jon Van Den Hende Park has two tennis courts; the 17-acre passive Tamarack Lane Park has trails. The newest addition, the 3.6-acre Secor Park, will offer a stocked fishing pond when it opens in late spring.
Early last month, the Pomona Cultural Center, a fieldstone building that was a one-room schoolhouse in the early part of the century, exhibited challenge quilts. Participants in the contest that created them were given a certain amount of fabric and asked to use only that in their projects. While the quilts were being viewed by visitors, a workshop on Japanese brush painting was in session in the center's basement.
Not far from the Cultural Center is Camp Hill Road, where George Washington's soldiers encamped during the Revolution. A short distance to the west of the road is the Ladentown United Methodist Church, built in 1865, one of the oldest still active churches in the county. The only other house of worship in the village is the Pomona Jewish Center, a Conservative synagogue. A Hindu temple is on the drawing boards.
Carole Novick, proprietor of Carole Novick Realty, said the housing market, with homes in the village starting at $180,000 and going to $1 million and more, was getting stronger. "Right now," she said, "there are excellent values because there are a lot of failed bank properties up here."
Bruce Sokol, a real estate appraiser, said that in the wake of the bankruptcy of the developer of a 200-lot mountain subdivision in 1989, lots that had been selling for $225,000 in 1987 are now selling for as little as $50,000 from banks that acquired the properties.
When homes can be built more cheaply in the same subdivision, he explained, values of existing properties are driven down. A further factor in prices in recent years, he said, has been the multiracial character of the school district, and the conflicts over school policies and spending.
As for prices in different parts of the village, Mr. Sokol said, homes in the Haverstraw section of Pomona are generally less expensive because they are taxed at lower rates. Taxes on a four-bedroom house on the market in the Ramapo section for $268,000 are $8,900. In the Haverstraw tax district, a four-bedroom home for $269,000 is taxed at $6,200.
Mary Whelan, who moved to the village from Woodside, Queens, in 1993 said she discovered the area when she came to Rockland County to pick apples. "It reminded me of where we lived in Ireland because of the trees and it was rural," she said. "I don't believe I got something like this. Nowhere compares to Pomona."

BOND ISSUE: In January the East Ramapo School District faced its biggest challenge: In a petition, three taxpayers charged that the district had failed to include in its proposal for a $22 million bond referendum for repairing and renovating schools specific costs and how the renovations would proceed. In what was termed "an unprecedented interim order," Richard P. Mills, the New York State Commissioner of Education, stayed the bond vote. When the school district amended the referendum, an amended petition was filed. This time, the Commissioner ruled that the petition was insufficient to block a vote on the bond issue, now scheduled for March 18.

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Buying In a New Building

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
FEW savvy consumers would buy a new car without at least taking a test drive in a floor model. Fewer still would make such an investment based solely on a car dealer's glossy brochure.
Yet, when it comes to what is often the most significant investment of a lifetime -- the purchase of a home -- some people get downright giddy at the prospect of buying a house or apartment that hasn't even been built yet, a decision that is often based largely on a developer's glossy brochure. 
 "In certain circumstances, buying a house or apartment under construction can be a wonderful thing," said Nathaniel Plotkin, chief executive officer of S. Goodstein Realty in Manhattan. "On the other hand, there's always risk involved as well."
For nearly a decade potential buyers in New York City did not have to worry too much about those kinds of decisions, because residential construction was rare. Now, however, it appears that residential construction in Manhattan is on the threshold of a resurgence.
"We're seeing a resurgence of a trend," said Vicki Chesler, executive editor of The Cooperator, a Manhattan-based publication targeted at co-op and condominium owners. "In the 80's, people would go into a developer's office, look at plans and buy apartments that didn't even exist yet. And now, we're starting to see that happen again."
Ms. Chesler said that a combination of factors was responsible for the apparent resurgence of interest. With the economy fairly stable, Wall Street booming and rents hitting all-time highs, she said, the inventory of available apartments has essentially dried up. "The biggest problem for real estate brokers today is not having enough apartments to sell," Ms. Chesler said. "So any new construction coming on line is in great demand."
Less than a year ago, for example, the Jack Parker Corporation, a Manhattan development company, opened an on-site sales office at the Knickerbocker, the company's 75-unit luxury condominium then under construction at Second Avenue and 72d Street.
"We sold out in six months," said Robert S. Skolnick, director of marketing and new development for the company. "We obviously hit the market at an unbelievable time."
While economics may play some role in a buyer's decision to invest in an apartment that hasn't yet been built, Mr. Skolnick said, there are more personal reasons at work. "It really offers a tremendous opportunity for buyers to pick and choose where they want to live in a building," he said, explaining that the first buyers in new buildings have the luxury of getting the pick of available apartments.
A more subtle advantage to buying in a new building, Mr. Skolnick said, is the absence of established interest groups and the presence of fellow pioneers. "When you buy in a new building, everybody's moving in at about the same time," Mr. Skolnick said. "So there are no established cliques or hierarchies and the atmosphere is usually more friendly."
Edward T. Braverman, a Manhattan real estate lawyer, said that to the extent that economics drive preconstruction buyers to invest in little more than blueprints and offering plans, the buyers themselves also help drive the economics.
"Developers structure their pricing policy to create the impression of a fast-rising market with a heavy demand," Mr. Braverman said. "That means that early buyers can often do very well in the pricing."
At the same time, he said, there is always the possibility that a developer will promise more than he or she can deliver.
"You might be dealing with a developer who is selling you by using models or plans and then you find out that the finished product doesn't equal the puff," Mr. Braverman said. Accordingly, he said, buyers and their lawyers should insure that contracts for apartments under construction be as specific and detailed as possible. "Make sure you get a copy of the layout and that the offering plan includes all of the amenities that are supposed to go along with the apartment," Mr. Braverman said, adding that it is essential to insure that any deposit paid by the buyer is placed in a lawyer's trust account and not turned over to the developer.
It is also wise, he said, for buyers or their lawyers to negotiate a clause in the contract that gives the buyer the right to assign the contract to a third party if the closing doesn't take place by a specific date.
In fact, one of the most common, frustrating and potentially costly problems associated with buying new construction is the often significant amount of time it takes to go from buyer to owner.
"The sale documents are usually drafted in such a way that you don't really know when you're going to be moving in," said Errol Brett, a Manhattan lawyer who specializes in co-op and condominium law. Even reputable and experienced developers occasionally end up behind schedule, Mr. Brett said. And when a closing is delayed, he said, the result can range from minor inconvenience to major hardship for the buyer.
"What happens if the buyer is renting an apartment, gives notice to his landlord that he's moving out, and then finds out that the closing has been put off for two months?" Mr. Brett said. "And more importantly, what about the buyer who sold his previous home to buy the new one and has to roll over the profit within two years to avoid paying capital gains tax. What happens if two years go by and he still hasn't closed on the new apartment?"
Generally, Mr. Brett said, while a lawyer can protect a buyer by insisting on a clause in the contract that allows the buyer to assign the contract or walk away from the deal if the closing doesn't take place within a specified time period, even that wouldn't help someone whose capital gains tax clock is ticking away.
"You can tell I'm not a fan of preconstruction deals," Mr. Brett said.
Mr. Plotkin of S. Goodstein Realty said that one way buyers can avoid being surprised is to avoid being bashful when dealing with their lawyers and developers. "Make sure your attorney knows how to read a set of plans," Mr. Plotkin said. "And it never hurts to have a clause in the contract that says if the developer is having trouble and reduces prices, your price will be reduced as well."
It is also worth the effort for potential buyers to get into the building and get a feel for the location and layout of their apartments.
"If you're thinking of buying apartment 10A and 8A is almost done, then tell the sales agent you want to see 8A," Mr. Plotkin said. "And even if there's nothing but open space on the 10th floor, ask the agent to take you up there in the construction elevator so you can at least get an idea of the view."

HEADLINE: 1926 Broadway: Behind the Facade;
The Anatomy of a 'People Building'

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
EVEN in their name -- "Class B" -- old office buildings like 1926 Broadway take a back seat to the centrally air-conditioned and centrally located Class A towers that define corporate New York.
Yet Class B buildings, typically of prewar vintage (the First World War in some cases), are the workhorses of commercial real estate. They are home to light industry, small service businesses, emerging creative enterprises and nonprofit organizations who cannot pay the $40-a-square-foot annual rent that a top building might command but can certainly afford $20. 
 "These tenants truly fuel our city," said Stephen L. Green, chairman of S. L. Green Real Estate, which owns or operates almost two dozen Class B buildings. Such tenants also fuel an enormous sub-market. For example, there are 595 Class B buildings in mid-Manhattan, Mr. Green said, but only 85 Class A buildings.
By their nature, Class B buildings tend to operate in the background. But the spotlight fell recently on 1926 Broadway, a six-story, 90-year-old loft building at 64th Street, with 154,000 square feet of space and 25 tenants.
Millennium Partners reached an agreement last month with the three owners of 1926 Broadway -- Richard M. Cohen, Arnold Sollar and Stephen Blank -- to acquire a longterm lease on the property and redevelop the site in a joint venture. They contemplate clearing out the building "at or about the turn of the century" -- a deliberately vague horizon. Millennium envisions another in the cluster of high-rise, multi-use structures it has been building around Lincoln Square in recent years. This one may include a new Lincoln Center theater at its base.
Even if these plans do not materialize, it is plain that the days of 1926 Broadway are numbered. It is dwarfed by its neighbors to the north and south and has become one of the likeliest development sites in the area.
This moment of transition affords the chance to look at the history and anatomy of a Class B building. Typical in its age, condition and tenancy, 1926 Broadway is also distinguished by a cast of characters ranging from the patrician Goelet family to the rock-'n'-rolling Cousin Brucie, with a cameo appearance by Dustin Hoffman.
"I see this as more of a people building, as opposed to an office building," said M. Annette Ensley, director of human relations for the Nathan Cummings Foundation, which has occupied much of the sixth floor since 1993.
People dine out on the ground floor, work out on the second floor, rebuild antique violins or peruse contemporary art on the third floor, sell furniture on the fourth floor, archive countless hours of film and video on the fifth floor and devise marketing campaigns or give out $14 million a year in grants on the sixth floor.
Not bad for a building that came into existence as a garage.
In 1905, when he was 25, Robert Goelet arrived at Broadway and 64th Street with $500,000 in his pocket. He purchased nine lots forming an odd-shaped parcel through the block, with 174 feet on Broadway and a notch cut out at 65th Street.
The transaction was noteworthy, The New York Times reported, as the first major real-estate purchase by any member of the Goelet family in recent years. The Goelets, who arrived in the New World in 1676, would have been as celebrated as the Astors for their extensive Manhattan land holdings -- they were said at one time to own 55 acres of the East Side -- had they not been so averse to publicity.
What Goelet built, from 1906 to 1907, was the Goelet Garage. This was a logical development choice, since the parcel sat on Automobile Row, which ran from the West 40's to the West 70's, and was lined with showrooms, garages and the offices of major motor-car and tire companies.
GOELET employed two architectural firms for his Broadway garage. Maynicke & Franke had just completed another project for the family, the enlargement of the Goelet Building, which is still standing at Broadway and 20th Street.
The other architect was Frank M. Andrews, who also designed the 1,500-room Hotel McAlpin, at Broadway and 34th Street, which was the largest hotel in New York City on its completion in 1913.
No mean utilitarian structure, the Goelet Garage is a forceful yet delicate composition. Its broad window bays have 7 1/2-foot-wide center panes flanked by smaller side lights, reminiscent of the Chicago school of architecture. These bays are framed by terra-cotta borders, pediments, brackets and medallions. The freight elevators, which had to transport horseless carriages, are larger than some studio apartments: 10 feet wide, 20 feet long, 10 feet high.
To contemporary eyes, 1926 Broadway looks extravagant for a garage, but it was on a par with the esthetic tenor of Automobile Row. Other elegant survivors of the era are the Peerless Motor Car and A. T. Demarest Motor Company Buildings at 57th Street and the United States Rubber Company Building at 58th Street.
The Goelet Garage was renamed the Macfadden Building in the 20's, after Bernarr Macfadden, the eccentric publisher of Liberty, True Story, Physical Culture and The New York Graphic, a forerunner of supermarket tabloids, according to "Upper West Side Story," by Peter Salwen.
The building was purchased in the 1940's by Louis D. Cohen, Ira Sollar and Robert Blank, whose sons continue to own it; not as partners but each with a roughly equal interest, the largest of which is controlled by the Cohen family.
By the late 1950's, the neighborhood was known popularly as the slum setting for the gang battles of "West Side Story." But in the early 60's, the buildings of Lincoln Center started to rise, kicking off a transformation that is still playing itself out.
Following the Lincoln Center lead was Louis Cohen's son, Richard, who built the five-story Empire Mutual Building in 1963 at Broadway and 66th Street. Mr. Cohen founded what is now Goodrich Associates of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., and Los Angeles. He has developed 200 shopping centers and office buildings around the country, said David R. Rogol, president of the Goodrich Development Corporation and Goodrich Management Corporation.
It was the O'Neal brothers, Michael and Patrick, who put 1926 Broadway back on the map and in the guidebooks. In June 1964, they opened a 60-seat restaurant called the Ginger Man on the 64th Street side of the building, in what had been a ground-floor storage room for National Cash Register.
Although they were pioneers, Michael O'Neal says today that it did not take genius to anticipate what was about to happen.
"We weren't stupid," he said, "but we weren't that smart. Philharmonic Hall had been finished and the State Theater was a hole in the ground. We knew what was coming." Indeed, Mr. O'Neal could watch the construction at Lincoln Center from his $20-a-week room in the Empire Hotel.
"When we applied for a liquor license, we got turned down," Mr. O'Neal recalled. "The State Liquor Authority said, 'We don't issue licenses for high crime-rate areas.' " The O'Neals prevailed with a petition signed by friends and neighbors, including Leonard Bernstein, testifying to the need for a nice restaurant near Lincoln Center.
Mr. O'Neal remembers a constant stream of cash registers being trucked into and out of the building, where N.C.R. maintained a large service center. He also remembers the Cadillac that was always parked across the street. It bore the license plates "CUZ-7," for Cousin Brucie (Bruce Morrow), a disk jockey who commanded the airwaves from the 1960's through the early 70's with his "WABC Superhit Survey."
As a fledgling network, ABC improvised a broadcasting campus in the West 60's out of a riding rink, a skating rink and a couple of old garages. It ultimately occupied two-thirds of 1926 Broadway.
"I grew up in that building," Mr. Morrow recalled. "This is where the Cousin Brucie persona developed. That building had a magic to it, a glow to it."
It also had cranky elevators. On one memorable evening, Mr. Morrow was escorting the Dave Clark Five to the studio when they got stuck between the fourth and fifth floors. With no time for repairs, WABC crews lowered provisions (a chocolate malted for Cousin Brucie) through a hatch at the top of the cab. They also lowered in a microphone and the show originated in the elevator.
"Very frankly, we didn't want to get out," Mr. Morrow said. "Dave Clark said, 'It's the first time I've been able to collect my thoughts in months.' " When they emerged two hours later, 1926 Broadway was surrounded by throngs of teen-agers.
ABC correspondents like Lynn Sherr, Richard Threlkeld and James Walker also had offices in No. 1926, said Jane Maxwell, director of research and video resources, who worked there. On the third floor was the special events division, where election-night and space shuttle coverage was coordinated and programs were produced for the 11:30 P.M. slot. "If a plane went down or a foreign leader died, we'd try to slam together a special," said Michael G. Duffy, vice president of operations for ABC News. "We were the precursors of 'Nightline.' "
The Ginger Man, meanwhile, expanded into the adjoining Liberty Warehouse building, which is topped by a small version of Bartholdi's colossus. Eventually, the O'Neals vacated 1926 Broadway altogether. Their space is now the Lincoln Tavern. There are three other restaurants in the building: the Saloon, which replaced the Magic Flute in the early 1980's; Sfuzzi, which opened in 1988, and Opera Espresso.
BY 1990, with the departure of N.C.R. and ABC, the five upper floors were vacant. In the midst of the deep real-estate recession, the owners set out to fill the building again.
They looked for tenants who could help "carry the building on an economic basis until market conditions were such that the redevelopment of the building made sense," said Mr. Rogol, speaking on behalf of Mr. Cohen and in consultation with Mr. Sollar.
There was no mistaking the new tenant on the block in July 1992, when the World Gym took over the 25,000-square-foot second floor. Those 7 1/2-foot-wide windows provided a splendid panorama to gym members as they climbed Stairmasters and pedaled Lifecycles, but the view worked both ways, as diverted passersby could attest.
Because World Gym is open non-stop from 5 A.M. on Mondays through 11 P.M. on Fridays, it effectively turned 1926 Broadway into a 24-hour-a-day building. The constant traffic is cited by other tenants as contributing a sense of safety.
"Every time we move into a completely empty building, it suddenly fills up with upscale tenants," said Karen Wong, vice president of World Gym Fitness Centers.
World Gym now has about 2,000 members, Ms. Wong said, and anywhere from 450 to 700 people use it every day. She emphasized that World Gym is continuing to renovate its space, purchase new equipment and sell new memberships.
As they tune up their bodies, few gym-goers are aware of the painstaking work going on overhead, in the third-floor workshop of Machold Rare Violins. The other day, for example, Julie Reed-Yeboah, a restorer with 21 years' experience, was cleaning and adjusting an 1826 Vuillaume.
The 5,000-square-foot Machold suite includes a soundproof playing room lined in acoustical baffles and closed off by doors that are three inches thick. In the vault is a wall of violin cubbyholes, lined in blue velvet, with nameplates like "Antonio Stradivari" and "Guarneri del Gesu."
Dietmar H. Machold, heir to a family business based in Bremen, Germany, opened his first United States office in 1926 Broadway two years ago, in large measure because the building was across the street from Lincoln Center. "You have to be in the right spot for these musicians," said his assistant, Leah H. Ramirez. "They keep odd hours. If a sound post falls down, they can literally come across the street."
Mr. Machold may have been the only tenant not to recognize Dustin Hoffman when he moved his film company, Punch Productions, to the third floor. "I don't have a TV," Mr. Machold reportedly explained to Mr. Hoffman. "I don't watch movies. No, wait. I saw a movie. In 1970."
Proximity was the key for A.F.D. Contract Furniture, which moved from 8 West 38th Street not to be close to Lincoln Center but to be within walking distance of Steelcase Inc., which had just bought a building at 4 Columbus Circle. "We're the largest Steelcase dealer in the country," said Richard Aarons, president of A.F.D., which occupies the entire fourth floor at 1926 Broadway, where it employs 120 people.
When Rick Gell moved into the fifth floor in 1992, it was something of a homecoming. He had worked in the building 13 years earlier as an intern at ABC. Today he is a principal, with Todd and Rob Pavlin, in a group of companies that specialize in stock film and video images. There are two library companies, Action Sports Adventure and Hot Shots/Cool Cuts, and a research and licensing company, Second Line Search.
The companies have doubled in size, to about 70 employees, since moving from the former McGraw-Hill Building, 330 West 42d Street. They now occupy 15,000 square feet of space, which is filled with a jumble of monitors, editing machines, 20,000 video cassettes and 50 million feet of film.
Some sense of the variety of their offerings can be gleaned from the labels on just one shelf: "Senegal," "Cow footage," "Deep-sea divers" and "Vegetables."
Another fifth-floor tenant is Strings and Things, a 3,000-square-foot violin shop run by Christophe Landon. He is also the proprietor of the 4,000-square-foot Landon Gallery on the third floor, together with his wife, Annette, who is the director. Boldly colorful paintings by Fares Rizk were on view there recently. A grand piano sat at the end of the long, white room, attesting to its other role as a concert venue.
"There's a big artistic life around this place," Mr. Landon said, "but we're basically the only art gallery in the neighborhood."
They are not the only tenant concerned with the arts, however. On the sixth floor is the Nathan Cummings Foundation, named for the founder of Consolidated Foods, now known as the Sara Lee Corporation. The foundation has 20 employees.
It had been on the 31st floor of the "Lipstick Building," at Third Avenue and 53d Street. "The views were magnificent," said Ms. Ensley, the human relations director. "But being so high up, you couldn't see people. It was so far removed. It didn't represent what this foundation is about."
More practically, however, the foundation needed more room. At No. 1926, it found an open, airy, 12,000-square-foot space that it organized as a village whose main street parallels Broadway. Each "house" along the way corresponds to an area of the foundation's interests: the arts, the environment, health and Jewish life. The "village green," under a skylight, has garden furniture and a fountain. The architects were Wormser & Associates.
NEXT door to Cummings is the Kreisberg Group, a public-relations firm that represents cultural clients. It moved to the building four years ago from a brownstone on West 56th Street and occupies 2,700 square feet, remodeled to designs by Christopher Barriscale. There are 12 employees. "Being across from Lincoln Center, we're associated in people's minds immediately with the arts," said Claire Whittaker, senior vice president.
About 95 percent of the tenants gathered for a meeting Thursday morning in the Saloon at the invitation of Michael Weinstein, president of Ark Restaurants Corporation. "The tenants are very concerned and that's about all we really want to say," said Mr. Reed-Yeboah of Machold.
But the owners are unmoved, noting that tenants walked in with their eyes open. "Each and every lease which was signed for space in the building contained a so-called 'demolition clause,' " Mr. Rogol said in a written statement. "These demolition clauses enable the landlord to terminate the lease after giving advance written notice to a tenant. The combined effect of all these clauses will give the landlord the right to clear out the building and redevelop the property at or about the turn of the century."
The statement said the owners "appreciate that a tenant required to relocate may encounter some disruption and attendant costs" but added that "these 'demolition clauses' are a matter of contract."
Exactly how much advance notice tenants will receive is unclear because each lease was negotiated separately.
"It's very much a David and Goliath situation," said Laurence Price, who runs an art gallery bearing his name and a television production company, Paley/Price Productions, in 1,200 square feet on the third floor. "Suddenly we face the prospect of being swallowed up by a developer who wants to put up a huge building and destroy what almost amounts to an artists' colony on the Upper West Side."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/The Hotel Business;
In an Up Market, Rooms by the Month

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
CHRISTOPHER JEFFRIES of Millennium Partners had no intention of going into the hotel business. His company was too busy developing residential and retail properties in the Lincoln Square area and other projects around the country.
But he and his partners, Philip Aarons and Philip Lovett, started noticing that people were trying to lease apartments for several months, but less than a year. Since they did not lease apartments for less than a year, the business was simply turned away. 
 At the same time they found that some potential customers were looking for furnished apartments and asking for assistance in renting furniture for extended, but temporary, stays in the city.
Millennium's response to this apparent market demand was the Phillips Club, a cross between an apartments and a hotel that opened at 1965 Broadway at 67th Street in December, just north of Lincoln Center. The facility, which occupies four floors of a 32- floor building, has 96 furnished studio, one- and two-bedroom apartments that rent for a minimum of a month at monthly prices ranging from $4,950 to $11,000.
"We realized that New York is the center of the investment banking industry and that there are a lot of high-income earners coming in and out of the city" who would be attracted by an extended-stay facility, Mr. Jeffries said.
Declining to give figures, he said occupancy has met projections and is doing so well that Millennium is including a Phillips Club in a project now under construction in San Francisco and is looking for sites on the East Side and in Lower Manhattan.
The key to managing the property is to realize that it is more than an apartment house but less than a full-service hotel, Mr. Jeffries said.
Because the stays are lengthy, there is no need for a large clerical staff to check people in and out and to prepare bills. There is no dining room, but local restaurants will deliver meals to guests who do not feel like cooking in the fully equipped kitchens that are part of each apartment.
"We talked to the major hotel operators, but they wanted to run it too much like a hotel, and that is too costly," Mr. Jeffries said. "The chains did not get the concept."
Stephen Rushmore, the president of HVS International, a hotel consulting company, said that Millennium "should do well in terms of occupancy."
"A typical hotel does well Monday to Thursday, but dies on the weekend," he said. "With extended stay, they have the weekend covered."
Certainly, Millennium could not have timed the opening of its new hotel much better, although extended stay hotels, such as the Bristol Plaza and the Sutton, have been on the scene for years. Occupancy rates at hotels in New York City are at near record levels and room rates are surging. But at the same time, with the exception of a few conversions and renovations, none of the new hotels for which plans have been announced is yet under construction.
The most recent plan was announced last week, when Sofitel, N.A. said it would build a 27-story, 400-room hotel on a site stretching from 44th to 45th Streets, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues.
According to figures compiled by Coopers & Lybrand, hotel occupancy in Manhattan rose 2.8 percent in 1996 to an average of 83.6 percent. The average room rate increased 10.5 percent to $160.57 for the year, from $145.35 in 1995.
Although the entire year was good for New York's hoteliers, the end of the year was particularly bountiful.
In October, for example, the lower-priced convention and tourist-class hotels had occupancies of 96.4 and 97.5 percent respectively. Even in the high-priced deluxe and luxury categories, where room rates are over $200 a night, October occupancy was over 90 percent.
In January 1996, the deluxe and luxury hotels had occupancies of 58.5 and 58.0 percent, while the convention and tourist class properties were 73 percent and 59.5 percent. Although January is typically a low activity month, growth is evident in occupancy rates of 61.9 percent and 63.7 percent for deluxe and luxury segments in January 1997.
"The city is nearing capacity; you can't have 100 percent occupancy," said Arthur Adler, a partner in the hospitality consulting practice of Coopers & Lybrand. "The current occupancy rates are as high as I have ever seen."
In addition to boosting room rates, Mr. Adler said, upper-crust hotels are starting to concentrate on the transient commercial and leisure business and turning away wholesale deals, such as group tours.
The reason is simple, he said. Individuals who are going to stay in New York for a few days on business or for tourism typically pay the full rate. Wholesale operators typically negotiate a lower rate.
In practice, he said, the tour operators will attempt to switch to periods of the year that historically have had lower occupancy rates or shift down to a lower class of hotel, which benefits from the added business.
 ANALYSTS say a robust local economy and a surge of tourism -- an estimated 30.3 million people visited New York in 1996 -- are the reasons for the demand for hotel rooms. And with the closing of the 428-room Dorset Hotel in July to expand the adjacent Museum of Modern Art, the supply of rooms actually declined during the year.
Michael A. Fishbin, a partner in the E&Y Kenneth Leventhal Real Estate Group, pointed out, however, that plans to convert the Mayfair and St. Moritz Hotels into condominiums were an indication that the residential market in Manhattan is even hotter than hotels.
"The highest and best use of these properties is conversion to housing, which tells you something about the market," Mr. Fishbin said.
Most of what has been happening in the hotel business recently is conversion and renovation. The 167-room Trump International Hotel, part of the renovated former Gulf and Western Building, officially opened for business in January.
One of the most prominent of the renovators is Bernard Goldberg, whose Gotham Hospitality Group has refitted four hotels on the Upper East Side and in midtown and is working on projects near Grand Central Terminal and at 31st Street and Madison Avenue.
Mr. Goldberg, a real estate lawyer by trade, said he had not planned to get into the hotel refurbishment business.
"I live on the Upper East Side and I used to walk by the Hotel Wales all the time," he said. The hotel, on Madison Avenue, was rundown, filled with loiterers and only able to charge $50 to $60 a night. But it was located within blocks of some of the city's major cultural institutions, including the Metropolitan Museum of Art and Guggenheim Museum.
"I started thinking, 'What is the best use for this property,' " he said. "A condo conversion was one way to go. But it seemed to me there was an increasing need of a medium priced, luxury hotel."
Eventually his group did buy the building, restored it and operates it with and emphasis on art and music.
"You can listen to the harp on Friday and chamber music on Sunday," he said. Since then Gotham has restored the Franklin Hotel on the Upper East Side and the Shoreham and Mansfield Hotels in midtown.
All are operated on an all-inclusive pricing policy that includes breakfast, cappuccino, all-day tea, desserts in the evening and video libraries. Rates at the hotels vary, but most are under $200 a night for a standard room.
Recently, Mr. Goldberg offered the four completed properties for sale or some financial arrangement that will allow him to raise cash to do more projects in New York and other cities.
"We think the concept of the luxury boutique hotel is exportable and we want to take it on the road," Mr. Goldberg said. He said the Gotham group was looking at projects in the Washington and Chicago areas, as well as bidding on the Iroquois Hotel on West 44th Street and seeking other projects in New York.
He said that the final answer may be a real estate investment trust or a sale and leaseback that would allow the group to continue managing the hotels.. "But if someone wants to pay us a lot of money to create a flagship with one or two of our hotels, I'll adapt to that scenario," he said.
Hotel analysts say there is nothing on the horizon to trouble New York's hotel industry, short of a major economic shock. "We are going to get some new rooms, but that is good, we need them," Mr. Adler said. "If something happens it will be external; something like a stock market crash or a steep recession."
"New York is the center of the world today and it will only become more so as the end of the century approaches," Mr. Goldberg said. He said some hotels in the city were taking reservations for New Year's Eve 1999 at rates of $1,500 to $2,000 a room, and some are insisting on three-night minimums.

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
A Balanced Budget? Yes! But Not This Way. Not Now.

BYLINE: By Brett Pulley; Brett Pulley reports from Trenton for The New York Times.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Senator Orrin G. Hatch, the Republican from Utah, was sitting at his desk on the Senate floor Wednesday afternoon, a stack of 28 years of unbalanced Federal budgets in front of him. Like many people in town here that day, Mr. Hatch, the sponsor of his party's proposal to balance the budget by the year 2002, was eagerly waiting to hear whether New Jersey's freshman Senator, Robert G. Torricelli, would agree to cast the deciding vote in favor of the balanced-budget amendment.
The moment of truth came when Mr. Torricelli walked over, sat down next to Mr. Hatch, placed his arm around the senior Senator's shoulder, and started speaking quietly in his ear. After a few moments, the decision was painted all over Mr. Hatch's stern face. "I told him I do not feel comfortable placing that amendment in the Constitution," Mr. Torricelli later said of the conversation. "I don't like to disappoint anybody. But I saw too many potential problems." 
 As it turns out, Mr. Torricelli's decision to break his campaign promise to support a balanced-budget amendment has disappointed more people than just Mr. Hatch. Although his reason for refusing to support the amendment may be correct, the fact that Mr. Torricelli had supported identical bills during his days in the House, and even made that support a part of his platform last year, could cost him some credibility among constituents.
After he announced his decision this week, the criticism machine started churning. Radio talk-show hosts, from former Mayor Edward I. Koch of New York, to the ultra-conservative Bob Grant, lashed out. Richard A. Zimmer, the Republican candidate who was defeated by Mr. Torricelli last November, issued a statement saying the constituents "have a right to be dissapointed." Governor Whitman, who kept her lofty promise to cut taxes by 30 percent, warned the new Senator that "keeping campaign promises is something New Jerseyans have come to expect." And the red meat quote of the week came from Mr. Zimmer's former campaign consultant, Lawrence Weitzner, who said that Mr. Torricelli "lied about his philosophy" and "he's going to be wearing the stamp of fraud for a long time." (And you thought that nasty little campaign ended in November.)
In defending his decision, Mr. Torricelli said he would vote against the measure this Tuesday when it comes to the floor because the Senate refused to adopt changes he recommended that would give Congress the ability to borrow money to pay for long-term capital projects, like bridges and highways, education programs, and public transportation systems. Mr. Torricelli also proposed changing the amendment to allow for deficit spending during times of economic recession or national emergencies.
Noting that he voted for a balanced budget on three occasions as a member of the House, Mr. Torricelli said that Mr. Hatch's bill was "good, but not good enough." Mr. Torricelli was aware of the weight that his one vote carried, and he seemed to enjoy being in that position. "I am aware of the uniqueness of the moment," he said during debate, a few hours before he announced his decision. "The U.S. Constitution is a precious document."
A skillful politician, Mr. Torricelli knows that he has almost a full six years to place between this decision and re-election. His future actions could far outweigh this one flip-flop. But voters are sure to wonder whether Mr. Torricelli switched positions because he has really come to realize that the measure he supported earlier has some real flaws, or because he wanted to earn some points with the White House and his Democratic colleagues?
And then in the view of many voters, campaign promises don't mean much anyway. Is it not important that our elected officials have the ability -- independent of some promise made in the past -- to weigh a decision based on all of the information that is available at that moment?
About an hour after he announced his decision in a news conference on Wednesday, Mr. Torricelli was back in his office, relaxed and basking in the slaps on the back he had just received from his fellow Democrats. As telephone calls from the media came in, he never ceased being the politician. At one instant, he told a caller, "I found your editorials so persuasive." A few minutes later, he told another caller the same thing -- verbatim.
But Mr. Torricelli still pledged to some day vote for a balanced-budget amendment. "I have to choose the ones that I think are in the national interest," he said. "I have voted for the Democratic version offered in the House of Representatives, and I'm going to do so again."
Promises, promises.

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Subaru Legacy 2.5 GT;
GT, as in Grand Touring (Or Is It Great Traction?)

BYLINE: By MARSHALL SCHUON 

 BODY:
I WAS out there being a daredevil, dashing along, flinging Subaru's sporty new sedan, the Legacy 2.5 GT, through the curves, wringing out every bit of power and testing the G-forces. Sure I was.
Actually, I was driving like everybody else, which is to say reasonably. And when I got home from my trip to the hardware store, curtain-rod brackets safe in their bag on the bucket seat beside me, I began to wonder about the popularity of the sport-sedan concept. 
 I mean, I had just shared the road with everything from BMW 328i's to Hyundai Sonatas to an old Peugeot 505S, many of them designated sport sedans and all of them going quietly about their business. Almost every car maker now puts the sports tag on at least one of its models, and the designation sells, but I was wondering why.
So I carried my brackets into the house and called Subaru.
"Well," said a company spokesman, Alex Fedorak, "I guess you could call the 2.5 a sport sedan, but it's more of a GT in our opinion -- a grand touring sedan as opposed to an all-out performance car. We think it's a nice all-wheel-drive touring vehicle, a vehicle in balance."
All right. But that didn't give me much perspective on the public passion for sport at the wheel, so I thought I'd try for some historical notions from John Gunnell, a friend who edits Old Cars Weekly, a newspaper for collectors that has its fingers firmly on the past.
"Ah," John said, "this goes all the way back to the 20's. Some of the cars then had what was called a California top, a removable hardtop that gave a big touring car a sporty look. Studebaker was famous for those. And Duesenberg actually had a car called the Sport Sedan from 1933 to 1936."
As early as 1925, Stutz also had a car called the Sports Brougham, he said, adding that the multivalve engine gave sedan buyers the hot performance of a roadster. "Those cars could really get up and go," he said. "And some of them even had leatherette-covered bodies. They were outrageous, but really gorgeous."
Gorgeous was not a word that jumped to mind when I first surveyed the Subaru, even dressed as it was in "Rio red," which along with "granite black pearl" is a new color for 1997. Nor did the semi-econobox four-door seem to equate with the "grand" image of a big Stutz or Duesenberg, but I guess inflation has taken its toll on the language just as it has affected prices.
And cost may be the compact GT's biggest drawback, with its hefty base price of $23,290 putting it head-to-head with some stiff competition, both domestic and imported. Of course, there is the car's all-wheel drive, which is always valuable and always there -- although the only time you'll know it is when you sail by other cars that are skittering on the ice or stuck in the mud.
The GT, manufactured in Lafayette, Ind., comes as a sedan or a wagon, and, for 1997, the visible sportiness derives from a different bumper with an integral air dam, a new grille and large fog lamps, as well as a spoiler across the trunk of the sedan. Bigger tires than in the past also grace 16-inch molded wheels that look as if they came off a BMW. A working scoop in the low hood helps to cool the GT's redesigned four-cylinder 2.5-liter engine.
That engine is flat, with the pistons opposing each other in "boxer" fashion. The power plant is a bit noisy on acceleration, but it is fast-revving and gutsy, putting out 165 horsepower, 10 more than last year and a healthy 28 more than the 2.2-liter engine in the base $19,600 Legacy sedan.
This year, too, it runs on regular instead of premium gas, and its economy rating is 21 miles a gallon in the city and 27 on the highway. With a 16-gallon tank, that translates into a cruising range of about 440 miles, which helps the "touring" part of the grand-touring equation. The test car was also surprisingly roomy, with a deep, flat-floored trunk and a rear seat that folds down, making it a good vehicle for hauling.
With the seat up, the rear compartment affords lots of room. But passengers back there won't want to take any long trips, however much they can stretch out, because the bench is unfortunately uncomfortable, hard and without contour. Up front, the cloth-clad buckets are somewhat better, but still not the lap of comfort.
The GT offers the usual amenities, and the standard equipment even includes a power sunroof. Interior storage is also ample, with a glove box that is, surprisingly, bigger than that of many larger cars. For the driver, there is a four-spoke wheel wrapped in leather, and the driving position is excellent.
On the road, the GT is indeed sporty and tight, offering a pleasant connection to the road. Anti-lock brakes are standard, so the car stops as well as it goes. And a five-speed stick is available this year, a good choice over the automatic that was the only transmission in the past. Firm and positive shifts let you run through the engine's new torque curve, which gives you more power at the lower speeds where you need it and makes the car more fun to drive.
And maybe that's the real answer to my original question. Whether you go back in time or take a trip today, sport sedans are always fun. Even when your treks are mostly to the store.

INSIDE TRACK: A tourer, maybe. But grand? I don't think so.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BAY RIDGE;
Water's Fine! Worms Dine On the Pier

BYLINE: By DAVID ROHDE 

 BODY:
When the 69th Street Pier closed in November, Brooklyn lost one of its most popular spots for strollers, families and especially fishermen. And oddly enough, the fact that the water is now clean enough to fish in is what led to the pier's demise.
The City Economic Development Corporation, which maintains the pier, said pollution had ebbed so much in New York Harbor that there has been a rapid growth in marine bore worms that feed on pilings. City inspectors sent to examine the 69th Street pier in the wake of the collapse of a nearby pier in Sunset Park last September were stunned by how badly its pilings had deteriorated, said Bernadette O'Leary, a spokeswoman for the corporation. 
 Refurbishing the 69th Street pier would cost $5 million, according to an estimate by the Brooklyn Borough President's office. The Borough President has committed $2 million for repairs, but the funds will not be available until the 1999 fiscal year.
"It's really a shame," said Joe Basile, 64, a retired salesman who frequented the pier. "I'd be willing to have them put up a sign to say, 'Do this at your own risk.' "
Denise Virga, district manager for Community Board 10, questioned how the pier was allowed to fall into such disrepair. It was refurbished to allow for ferry service run by Express Navigation to Wall Street, but somehow the decay was missed. "If the money had been allocated before the disaster happened, it could have been fixed." Ms. Virga said.
Economic Development Corporation officials said agencies previously responsible for the pier failed to perform necessary maintenance. The Port Authority, the City Department of Business Services and the City Department of Ports and Trade are among the agencies that maintained it in the past, Ms. Virga said.
The ferry service, suspended since November, is to resume tomorrow at Pier 4 at the Brooklyn Army Terminal. It will run to Pier 11 at Wall and South Streets in lower Manhattan. DAVID ROHDE

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
After the Talk or the Touching Gets Too Personal, Where to Turn?

BYLINE: By BARBARA B. BUCHHOLZ 

 BODY:
BING the victim of sexual harassment is bad enough. But what do you do when the offender is a member of senior management? Will your complaint end your career? And is there really anyone in your company to whom you can realistically complain?
Sgt. Maj. Brenda L. Hoster asserts that she was harassed last year by her boss, Gene C. McKinney, the Sergeant Major of the Army who was named last fall to a commission charged with reviewing the Army's sexual harassment policies. Sergeant Major Hoster said that when her complaint was ignored, she felt compelled to retire. The Army suspended Sergeant Major McKinney last month. 
 Mary Dixon also quit her job, after contending that she was harassed by Dan K. Wassong, the chief executive and president of Del Laboratories, a cosmetics company in Farmingdale, L.I.
"When I complained to my boss, he said, 'Find another job,' " said Ms. Dixon, a former executive assistant who sued the company and eventually shared a $1.19 million settlement with 14 colleagues. "There were so many incidents over the 19 months I worked there that I was in absolute terror, but I needed the job. I was newly married and had a mortgage. I finally quit after he grabbed my buttocks."
Howard Rubenstein, a spokesman for Del Laboratories, said Mr. Wassong and the company deny wrongdoing and the company settled "only to avoid protracted litigation and extraordinary publicity." He said the company had also changed its policies on sexual harassment to make it easier for employees to seek help.
LAWYERS say the corporate environment for women has improved since Anita Hill accused Clarence Thomas of sexual harassment in 1991, but the process of filing charges is still daunting, especially if the accused offender is the chief executive. Still, there are smart steps that workers can take to win a claim.
The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, the Federal agency responsible for enforcing discrimination laws, said that since the Civil Rights Act of 1991 allowed plaintiffs in these cases to sue for compensatory and punitive damages, the number of charges filed with the agency had more than doubled, to about 15,000 last year.
Trisha Brinkman, of Brinkman & Chersky, a consulting firm in San Francisco, said companies tended to settle quickly and quietly in quid pro quo claims -- involving supervisors who seek sexual favors in return for job benefits -- because they fear the liability and adverse publicity.
More difficult to prove, but more commonplace, are complaints of a hostile work environment. These often involve unwelcome, repetitive and subtle harassment, said Pauline T. Kim, an associate professor at the Washington University School of Law in St. Louis.
"Your boss might call you a slut once or 10 times, but a court might not consider it harassment because it doesn't affect your ability to perform your job," said Laurel Bellows, a Chicago lawyer and the president of the American Bar Association's Commission on Women in the Profession. "But if the person brushes up against you several times, that may be viewed differently because it's not what's considered reasonable behavior."
In its suit against Del Laboratories on behalf of Ms. Dixon and her co-workers, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission contended that Mr. Wassong had sexually harassed employees by blatantly seeking sexual favors in return for job benefits and by more subtly creating an intimidating or hostile work environment.
Ms. Dixon now works from her home in Commack, L.I., filing medical billing claims for doctors and consulting for supermarkets. She said she would never feel safe working again outside her home.
Many who have filed harassment claims concur with Ms. Dixon that even when they win, they lose, because of the emotional and financial toll of the process. Because those who complain may be labeled troublemakers, they often decide to find another job.
SUCH is the case of a 36-year-old former professional at a Fortune 50 company who quit her job two months ago after what she described as a year of enduring remarks like "How is your sex life going?," harassing calls to her home and an inability to obtain a transfer because her harasser was protected by upper management. The company settled out of court.
Single and unemployed, she vacillates between feeling good about speaking up and feeling terrible. "It's not like my life is ruined, but depending on your work life and community, you can be perceived as a pariah and a woman who wants to shake down an organization," she said. "There's a lot of guilt by association." The terms of her settlement prevent her from revealing her name, her employer or the industry in which she worked for a decade.
Lawyers say the burden rests on the worker to prove a claim, which requires following a long list of steps that differ by company, but that often involve going to a human resources supervisor, who investigates the complaint.
And therein lies the problem. "It's an oxymoron to think that an H.R. person can keep a complaint confidential when investigating," said Freada Klein, a consultant in Boston who advises companies on their sexual-harassment policies. "When the harasser heads a company or is in management, follow-up and action become less likely."
Jeffrey Liddle, a lawyer with Liddle & Robinson in New York, said: "H.R. personnel represent management, not employees. Even when they say, 'Yes, this is awful,' you may find the harasser in your face the next day, or subtler discrimination, such as your work criticized."
What do you do if you have been harassed? Here are experts' recommendations:
* Read your company's policy. "Know what procedures it offers to voice complaints," said Marcia L. Worthing, senior vice president for human resources and corporate affairs at Avon Products. "Know how it defines sexual harassment and understand what such behaviors are."
* Speak directly to the harasser. Immediately tell him or her that a comment or action is unacceptable and you want it stopped. "Be specific rather than general," said Joann Keyton, an associate professor of communication at the University of Memphis. "Say, 'I feel uncomfortable when you touch me unprofessionally,' rather than say, 'I don't like the way you treat me.' "
* Document all actions and comments. If words and actions persist beyond a few incidents, keep notes of what was said, how you responded, who was present, where the conversation or incident took place and how you felt, Ms. Bellows advised. Some states permit tape-recording of conversations in which you are a participant, though some companies prohibit taping, said Bradley Kafka, a lawyer with Gallop, Johnson & Neuman in St. Louis.
* Speak up to company management. Tell the appropriate supervisor about the harassment and follow up the conversation with a memo. If he or she isn't responsive, go to others until you get a response.
If the company has a harassment policy and fails to investigate, it may be liable. Conversely, if you don't give the company a chance to investigate your complaint, you risk losing in a lawsuit. Even though the human resources department represents management, you may have no choice but to file your first complaint there.
* Get emotional and legal support. Because those who complain often feel -- and sometimes are -- ostracized, tell someone you trust at work. Also have a confidant outside of work. Consider hiring an employment lawyer to walk you through the process, read documents you may be asked to sign and weigh any company offers.
* Refrain from the urge to sue. A lawsuit should be a last resort because of the time, money and emotional distress involved, said Nina Stillman, a lawyer with Vedder Price Kaufman & Kammholz in Chicago.
Before suing, be sure to file a charge within the equal employment commission's statute of limitations -- 180 days, unless the agency has contracts with a state or local agency, which extends the period to 300 days, said Michael Widomski, a spokesman for the agency. A commission employee will investigate and issue a letter of determination to the company. If conciliation fails, the agency may file a suit.
* Move on. If you file a complaint and the company begins passing you over for promotions or plum assignments, lawyers say it is difficult to prove that this is retailiation. Dale Winston, chairman and chief executive of Battalia Winston International, an executive recruiting firm in Manhattan, says it is better to simply leave the company and start over someplace else. And the quicker the better. "Put your resume on the market and get out of there," Ms. Winston said. By moving quickly, she said, there will be no gap in your resume that will have to be explained during job interviews. But if you are asked about why you left, don't lie.
* Don't bank on a big monetary award. The Civil Rights Act of 1991 capped punitive and compensatory damages based on the number of employees at the company. A company with 500 workers would have to pay a maximum of $300,000; one with 100 or fewer would pay up to $50,000, said Mary Stowell of the Chicago law firm of Lang Stowell Friedman & Veron.

LENGTH: 428 words

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;
City Yields on $600,000 for Housing

BYLINE: By JANE H. LII 

 BODY:
After Community Board 9 in West Harlem raised a ruckus, the Department of Housing Preservation and Development has changed its mind and decided to use $600,000 from a special city fund to reclaim housing in the community itself rather than throughout the city.
Instead of yielding to Board 9's request that it be allowed to use the money for various projects, the department will rehabilitate 260 buildings within the board's boundaries -- from 110th to 155th Streets and from Morningside Avenue to the Hudson River -- according to the outgoing Commissioner, Lilliam Barrios-Paoli. "If you are a housing agency and you have an overwhelming housing need," Ms. Barrios-Paoli said, "it's not unreasonable for the money to go to housing." 
 The city began the fund, known as the Tax Syndication Sharing Program, in the late 1970's. It was intended to energize neighborhood renewal by requiring developers who received Federal financing to build low- and middle-income housing to deposit 2.75 percent of profits from those projects into an escrow account. The department planned to distribute the money to local nonprofit groups. But because the agency did little to publicize the fund's existence, few groups knew about it. Of the $7.1 million collected between the late 70's and mid-80's, when the requirement was phased out, $6 million remains.
Over the years, Board 9 has pressured the city for the $1 million collected from developers who put up housing in West Harlem. Its chairwoman, Marita Dunn, said the board had wanted to upgrade its computer system, install fence and outdoor lighting at community gardens and open an adult education center, among other projects.
But since 1991, the city has approved only 2 of 11 board proposals: restoration of Annunciation Park, at 135th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, and renovation of the 369th Regiment Armory, at Fifth Avenue and 143d Street, which together cost $390,00. That, combined with $27,000 given out during the early 1980's, left almost $600,000 collected in the community.
Last month, the city notified the board that that money, along with the rest of the fund, would be used to rehabilitate 2,000 buildings citywide, a decision that outraged Ms. Dunn and other board members. She said she had called the agency and wrote letters demanding that the money remain within Board 9's boundaries. On Thursday, Ms. Barrios-Paoli said she had decided to reverse the agency's decision, a move Ms. Dunn applauded. "There is a tremendous need for the money in this community," she said. JANE H. LII
