HEADLINE: Anacortes Journal;
There's a Boat That's Leaving Soon, Islanders Fear

BYLINE: By CORNELIA DEAN 

DATELINE: ANACORTES, Wash.

 BODY:
To the people of the San Juan Islands north of Puget Sound, few things are as reliable -- or important -- as the ferries that run from island to fir-trimmed island, carrying freight, mail and tourists, especially tourists.
With natural beauty joining timber and fish as a major money-maker in the region, the ferries are an important attraction. But now the Washington State Ferry System, which has operated the ferries for more than 40 years, wants to curtail some of the service. The proposal has islanders in an uproar. 
 Specifically, ferry officials want to end the international trip linking the main San Juan ferry terminal, here on Fidalgo Island, with Sidney, on Vancouver Island, British Columbia. The three-and-a-half-hour run weaves through the islands daily -- twice a day in summer -- offering spectacular views of water, wildlife and rugged cliffs.
Officials in Anacortes (pronounced anna-CORT-ez) estimate that 300,000 people pass through their town every year to ride the ferry to Canada, spending at least $30 million along the way.
The system's 25 green-and-white boats, descendants of the "mosquito fleets" of smaller craft that began plying the sound more than 100 years ago, make up the largest ferry operation in the nation. But the state operates the boats for local residents, not as a tourist attraction, ferry officials say. Though the boats draw tourists, the system said, "tourist routes are not within the scope" of its mission.
The officials say the run already loses money and would lose more if the state complied with new international safety standards for routes leaving the country. Just bringing the run's two ferries, the Elwha and Evergreen State, up to the standards would cost $3.3 million, they say.
Islanders reject these arguments. Only one of the state's 10 routes, the profitable and heavily traveled link between Seattle and Bainbridge Island, covers a higher proportion of its expenses than the Anacortes-Sidney run, said Mayor Dean Maxwell of Anacortes, a leader in the fight to save the ferry. Andrew T. Mayer, executive director of the Anacortes Chamber of Commerce, said simple steps like improving the reservation system and altering the fare structure might even put it in the black, even under the stricter standards.
And while the ferry system's mission might not be tourism, its supporters say, it is administered by the State Transportation Commission, which is charged with improving economic development, enhancing tourism and encouraging good connections across state and international borders, all of which the ferry does. Besides, the weekly San Juan Islands Journal said on its editorial page, nowadays "we are all in the tourist business."
To rally support, people in Anacortes have hung a huge "Save Our Ferry" banner across Commercial Street, the four-lane road lined with motels and restaurants that is the major approach to town. Signs bearing similar messages, along with the phone number the ferry service established to hear public comment, have sprouted on lawns. Supporters of the ferry run put petitions in the Anacortes terminal gift shop and workers there say 9 out of 10 passengers sign. Mayor Maxwell said 8,000 people in British Columbia signed similar petitions after the ferry plan was announced in January.
On Feb. 19, four busloads of islanders, accompanied by a busload of British Columbians who rode the ferry from Sidney to join them, traveled 140 miles to Olympia to testify before the commission. "They had only been briefed by the Washington State Ferry System," Mr. Mayer said. "They really heard a different perspective." The commission is to vote on the proposal at its next two-day meeting, on March 19 and 20.
Mayor Maxwell said he did not understand why the ferry system would want to end the run. "We suspect a little politics," he said, possibly on the part of Seattle residents who hope that taking boats off the Sidney run would mean better service for them. There is also talk, Mayor Maxwell said, that closing the state ferry to Sidney might make things more lucrative for private operators. Or, he said, it might all be a bluff by ferry officials who think the furor will produce more state money.
For their part, ferry officials say they are willing to consider the objections and suggestions of the islanders. "That's why we're having public hearings," said Susan Harris, a spokeswoman for the system.
People in Anacortes and elsewhere in the San Juans say they hope their protests will turn things around. "We're not ready to declare victory by a long shot," Mr. Mayer said, "but we do think we opened their eyes."

HEADLINE: U.N. Plans To Streamline While Aiding Poor Nations

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 28

 BODY:
In an effort to end the United Nations' financial troubles by persuading Congress to pay the United States' late dues, the new Secretary General, Kofi Annan, is working on a plan to streamline the organization by eliminating some $200 million a year of administrative spending and shifting the money to development aid for poor countries.
The Secretary General hopes to secure these savings in the administrative budget by eliminating 500 jobs from a work force that has already shrunk from 12,000 to 9,000 since 1985, by ending duplication in some agencies and by reducing red tape. The moves would slash administrative spending nearly in half, and reduce administrative costs to 20 percent of the United Nations' $1.3 billion budget, from 38 percent. 
 "What we aim to do is to cut administrative expenses within a frozen budget so as to free more cash for our programs," Mr. Annan said in a recent interview, recalling that at their summit meeting in France last summer, the Group of Seven major industrial democracies agreed that money saved by slimming the United Nations bureaucracy should go to development assistance rather than be returned to member countries.
The new economies that the Secretary General is considering will be the centerpiece of the package of changes he plans to propose this summer in an attempt to make the unspecified reforms the Clinton Administration and Congress are demanding in return for paying the $1 billion the United States owes in unpaid dues.
While the Clinton Administration has asked Congress to make an immediate payment of $100 million to the United Nations, it wants the remaining $900 million appropriated now but held back until 1999, when it has had time to judge the changes Mr. Annan makes.
The bureaucratic pruning the Secretary General has in mind clearly falls well short of the "50 percent cut in the entire U.N. bureaucracy" demanded last year by Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican who is chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and the most powerful congressional critic of the United Nations.
But the economies he proposes may well be judged excessive by other members, many of whom deeply resent the United States' attempt to put conditions on payments it has a legal obligation to make.
The Secretary General's proposals will be one element in a wider debate on overhauling the United Nations.
While Mr. Annan has considerable discretion over how he spends the secretariat's budget, five working groups of the 185-nation General Assembly are working to prepare recommendations for change in other areas.
To meet the United States' demand for a cut in its share of the regular budget to 20 percent, from 25 percent, and of peacekeeping bills to 25 percent, from 30 percent, members are debating a new scale of assessments under which the rest of the world would pay a larger share.
Also under debate is a plan to enlarge the Security Council by creating new permanent seats for Germany and Japan in recognition of their economic power as well as for other leading developing nations.
Finally, member states are considering how to strengthen the role of the United Nations in peacemaking and development and transform the General Assembly into an effective forum for debating world problems.
Taken together these proposals are supposed to help the United Nations deal more effectively with the problems of the post-cold-war world. But it is already clear that all of them are linked by the need to resolve the organization's financial difficulties if the United Nations is to have any future at all.
Germany and Japan say they are to help fill the budget gap a reduced American assessment would create -- provided they get the permanent Security Council seats they covet.
And there is little point in trying to strengthen any aspect of the United Nations' work unless the institution returns to solvency, with the United States paying off its debts and becoming a reliable contributor again, diplomats say.
As Japan's representative, Hisasi Owada, recently put it, "We will never agree to improve the U.N. unless we know it has the means to be effective."
Since taking office, the Secretary General has already taken several steps to make the organization more effective and to eliminate red tape and duplication. He has brought in Maurice Strong, a Canadian businessman, to oversee the drive for administrative reform at a nominal salary of $1 a year.
He has also reorganized all United Nations activities into four "clusters" -- peace and security, humanitarian relief, economic and social affairs, and development -- and instituted regular meetings among those involved in each area.

HEADLINE: In Pacific, Growing Fear of Paradise Engulfed

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF

DATELINE: TARAWA, Kiribati

 BODY:
One sunny day in January, as Teunaia Abeta stood by and watched horror-struck, a high tide came rolling in from the turquoise lagoon and did not stop.
There was no typhoon, no rain, no wind, just an eerie rising tide that lapped higher and higher, swallowing up Mr. Abeta's thatched-roof home and scores of others in this Pacific island nation. 
 "This had never happened before," said Mr. Abeta, 73, who wore only his colorful lava-lava, a skirtlike garment, as he sat on the raised platform of his home fingering a home-rolled cigarette. "It was never like this when I was a boy."
That tidal surge was followed by another one in February. The flooding has helped focus minds here on warnings that global warming could cause the seas to rise enough in the next century or so to obliterate island nations like this one scattered in the middle of the Pacific Ocean.
"The only resource we have is water," said Phillip Muller, Foreign Minister of the Marshall Islands, another country that could easily be drowned by rising seas. "Our livelihood is the sea. Now all of a sudden, it's not a friend. It's threatening our existence."
Officials of some 160 countries are gathering in Bonn to try to negotiate cutbacks in the emissions of heat-trapping gases linked to global warming. Although most experts agree that these gases may cause the seas to rise, there are major disagreements about the scale of the change and the severity of the problem.
Gases like carbon dioxide are suspected of causing global warming by effectively creating a greenhouse around Earth. Warmer temperatures, in turn, are linked to a rising of the seas in two ways: by causing the water to expand as it warms, and by melting glaciers and icecaps.
"It's so close to the heart here," said Giff Johnson, editor of the Marshall Islands' newspaper, "because you're talking about people's very existence being wiped out by the ocean rising. It scares the hell out of people to think that their country might just be gone."
Industrialized countries like the United States are responsible for most of the greenhouse gas emissions, and they are reluctant to curb industry much while the scientific jury is still out on the seriousness of the effects. That annoys the island nations, which argue that by the time the jury reaches its verdict they may be visible only at low tide.
"It's like little ants making a home on a leaf floating on a pond," grumbled Teburoro Tito, President of Kiribati. "And the elephants go to drink and roughhouse in the water. The problem isn't the ants' behavior. It's a problem of how to convince the elephants to be more gentle."
Many of the island countries in the Pacific, including Kiribati (pronounced KIH-rih-bus), are collections of coral formations. Usually a string of islets around a turquoise lagoon, they resemble not so much nations as sandbars.
Each island peeps just a few feet above sea level and is only about a hundred yards wide, sometimes less. Many homes offer bicoastal views, from sea to shining sea, and a country like Kiribati, situated about halfway between California and Australia, can at low tide be three times as big as at high tide.
In such countries the lagoon is central to the economy and national identity, for children play in the water from infancy, and many adults fish or sail for a living. The Kiribati men in their loincloths go out in outrigger canoes each day to catch tuna, and the women wade out on the coral reef to dive for shellfish and net smaller fish for dinner.
The countries most likely to go under the sea include Kiribati, the Marshall Islands and Tuvalu, all in the Pacific, and the Maldives, in the Indian Ocean. Many other island countries, including Tonga, Palau, Nauru, Niue and the Federated States of Micronesia, may lose much of their territory but for now are probably not in danger of total submersion.
The populations are tiny: Kiribati has 75,000 people, and only 10,000 live on Tuvalu. Those numbers pale beside the 150 million additional refugees worldwide forecast as a result of climate change by 2050, according to a 1993 academic study published in the journal BioScience. Other studies suggest that a rise of 3 feet in ocean levels would force the evacuation of perhaps 70 million Chinese and 32 million Bangladeshis. One-fifth of Bangladesh would also disappear.
Yet at least countries like Bangladesh would survive, though perhaps in truncated form. The Pacific islanders fret not only about whether their countries will exist outside of history books, but also about changes they see in their climate today. For all the scientific uncertainty about global warming, they insist that the weather has been getting stranger in recent years and has produced some unprecedented tidal surges.
"These aren't storms, they're surges," said Mr. Johnson of the Marshall Islands. "It's nice weather, and all of a sudden water is pouring into your living room. It's very clear that something is happening in the Pacific, and these islands are feeling it."
By some accounts, there have also been more frequent storms, changing weather patterns and other unexpected events, like a tidal wave that recently washed over the island of Kili in the Marshall Islands. Nobody has any evidence that global warming is the culprit, but there is a tendency now for people to point to any odd weather and blame the greenhouse effect.
Perhaps the most comprehensive study was issued last year by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, an international group of experts. It suggested that seas may rise 18 inches by 2100. But it emphasized the enormous uncertainties and suggested that the real figure could be much lower or higher.
Even a rise of two or three feet would devastate Pacific island countries like Kiribati. President Tito says such a rise would leave the country uninhabitable.
Some people find the notion that their country might disappear so overwhelming, and so frustrating because there is so little they can do about it, that they choose not to worry too much.
"What can we do?" asked Johnny Johnson, a middle-aged Marshall Islander. "Nothing but sit around and see our people washed away by the water."
Roote Claude, whose home was flooded recently in Kiribati, simply laughed -- a bit nervously -- when asked if her country would sink below the waves.
"God will protect Kiribati," she said, in a tone that seemed to reflect more hope than faith.
Technical solutions like sea walls are available to protect low-lying lands. In Japan, some two million people live below the high-water mark.
But the solutions are unaffordable for most low-lying island countries. In Majuro, the capital of the Marshall Islands, where the islets are in some places only as wide as the two-lane road that traverses each of them, a single wave often sprays the country from coast to coast. One study found that protecting the capital alone would cost up to three times the total national economic output.
To be sure, some studies also point to benefits from global warming. Mid- and high-latitude countries might enjoy not only warmer weather but also longer growing seasons.
This is small consolation to the Pacific islands, which last year began a climate monitoring project to gather evidence of rising seas and changing weather. So far, 39 countries have formed the Alliance of Small Island States to press for an obligatory 20 percent reduction in greenhouse gas emissions from 1990 levels by 2005.
The United States endorses the idea of legally binding cutbacks, to be adopted late this year in an international conference in Japan, but only by 2010 and with various conditions. In the meantime, America's industrial carbon dioxide emissions are growing by 8 percent a year, environmental groups report.
Developing countries are also a growing source of greenhouse gases. A corollary of China's economic boom is that it is projected to overtake the United States as the leading source of such gases early in the next century.
And in the Pacific, people are beginning to look at the sea in a new way, with suspicion.
"People here think of the ocean as their source of livelihood, as their friend," said Ross Terubea, a Kiribati radio reporter. "It's hard to think that it would destroy us."

HEADLINE: CHINA FACES TEST OF RESOLVE TO JOIN GLOBAL ECONOMY

SERIES: THE CHINA BUSINESS -- First of two articles.

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
The Chinese Government next week will face the first test of its resolve to speed the opening of the country's economy since the death of its paramount leader, Deng Xiaoping.
The moment will come not in Beijing, but on the shores of Lake Geneva, in the giant mansion that serves as the headquarters of the World Trade Organization. Starting on Tuesday, at a three-day meeting with American and European officials that was scheduled long before Deng's death, Chinese officials are expected to make their strongest case for their long-desired entry into the World Trade Organization, the leading club of trading nations. 
 They are supposed to describe in painstaking detail just how far their Government is willing to go in dismantling layers of protection from competition for its state industries. They are also supposed to reveal how many billions of dollars the Government spends propping up many of those enterprises, which employ nearly two-thirds of the urban population and are a mainstay of the Communist Party's control of the country.
Technically, the trade negotiations involve only the conditions of China's entry into the World Trade Organization. But for both China and the United States the talks transcend questions of commerce. They are really about the pace at which China will reform its economy and open its society.
While China tries to manage Western pressure to change the workings of its booming economy, the Clinton Administration is attempting to prove that its policy of economic engagement with China can work -- both to reverse a $39 billion trade deficit that is on the cusp of overtaking Japan's, and to alter China's behavior in human rights and arms proliferation gradually.
But Mr. Clinton clearly cannot afford to make many concessions to China. A rising anti-China sentiment in Congress, combined with the many questions surrounding what the Clinton campaign's Asian donors sought from the White House, will make these ordinarily obscure trade talks the subject of enormous scrutiny here.
After years of stalemated talks with China on a variety of subjects, American officials hope to use this meeting to jump-start the relationship. Finding a way for China to join the trade organization "is likely to be the area where we have the best chance to make serious progress in our relations with China this year," said Charlene Barshefsky, the acting United States Trade Representative.
First, though, China's leaders face vexing choices. They must decide whether they have traveled too fast on the road to reform, or not nearly fast enough to join the global economy. And those leaders must make their decisions as they jockey for position in the vacuum created by Deng's death, judging whether the economic benefits of joining the club of trading nations are worth the potential upheaval and political risks at home.
If the consequences of opening China's economy are even more unemployment and further weakening of state-run enterprises, some of which are near bankruptcy, could joining the trade organization weaken the Communist Party's hold on power? Or does China have the power, given its enormous size and its potential as the world's greatest emerging market, to join on essentially its own terms, delaying the opening of its markets while the world continues to pour billions of dollars a year into the Chinese economy, building factories to pump out exports and transferring technology to Chinese workers?
China must weigh domestic imperatives against its clear ambition to become a world-class competitor in the industries -- including electronics, telecommunications and aircraft -- that have brought wealth to the United States, Japan and Europe.
China is seeking membership in the trade organization to assure that it can get into all of those markets and others around the world and that its products are charged minimal tariffs.
"This has to be an agonizing decision for these guys," one of President Clinton's top foreign policy advisers said after Deng's death. "They know that to play in the global economy, the world demands that they open up their own. But they also know how quickly the market eats into their control."

Little Evidence Of American Gains
Yet it is no less delicate a problem in Washington. Here, the trade organization negotiations have begun to bring to a boil the constantly simmering debate over whether the American policy of engaging the Chinese through trade and investment has any chance of yielding both the commercial and political benefits once envisioned.
Many in Washington view China's desire to enter the trade organization as a last opportunity to use economic incentives to change China's behavior, not only in trade, where its mounting surpluses with the United States have caused alarm, but also as leverage over China's treatment of Hong Kong, Tibet and Taiwan and a host of other political issues.
On the left and the right, from the Democratic minority leader, Richard Gephardt of Missouri, to the Republican chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Jesse Helms of North Carolina, critics of the Administration's China policy argue that Mr. Clinton should recognize that separating the issues of trade and human rights, the major shift he made in 1994, has failed. By the State Department's own accounting, China's treatment of dissidents is as harsh as it ever was before Mr. Clinton took office.
Clearly, the views in both capitals differ greatly. China sees itself as a developing nation, struggling to catch up, while some in the United States see it as the next Japan. Hard-liners in China believe the United States is trying to contain their country's economic power. The mainstream view in Washington is simply that China must be compelled to play by the international rules by which most other nations abide.
The tremendous sensitivity of the China issue on Capitol Hill was particularly evident last month, during confirmation hearings for Ms. Barshefsky. Of 17 written questions submitted to her by the Senate, all but one concerned China. Ms. Barshefsky still awaits Congressional confirmation to her post.
During her hearings, Max Baucus, the Democratic Senator from Montana, issued the kind of warning that is heard often these days. "Take a realistic view," he said. "My concern is that the Administration will be a bit too naive, a bit too Pollyannaish on China, that it will let China accede to the W.T.O. and hope it will all work out."
Mr. Clinton and his aides say they are anything but Pollyannaish, and that they will only let China into the trade organization on "commercially viable terms," not as a political gesture to Beijing. While President Clinton acknowledged recently that economic engagement had not yet yielded the results he sought, he repeated that it was the only way to keep China from turning inward, isolated and militaristic.
But there are many definitions of engagement, and the Administration's interpretation of the phrase is clearly a moving target. None of Mr. Clinton's top economic officials, for example, use the term "commercial diplomacy," a favorite of the late Secretary of Commerce, Ronald Brown, during his trade missions around the world. As one senior Administration official noted recently, the term sounds too much like commerce and too little like hard-nosed diplomacy.
At the core of the Clinton Administration's problems selling "economic engagement" with China is this statistical reality: While China's economy has made a great leap forward, American exports to China are standing still. That in turn has undercut one of the central arguments that Mr. Clinton and many large American companies with interests in China have made to justify the separation of trade from political disputes -- that business with China is creating jobs in America.
Last year, for example, China's economy grew at a remarkable 9.5 percent. But overall American exports to China barely rose at all. By all economic logic, those exports should be soaring, as a fast-developing China sucks in food, industrial equipment and expertise to build the nation's telephone systems and factories, its roads and its computer industry. In fact China is importing more -- but largely from countries like Japan, its largest supplier of foreign aid, whose exports to China have surged far ahead of the United States' since 1992.
"China is not buying American," Mr. Helms wrote recently in The Weekly Standard, a conservative magazine. "Belgium buys more U.S. goods than China does," he continued, citing a figure borne out by numbers the Commerce Department just released.
Not surprisingly, those numbers have become a magnet for a host of special interest groups that are enormously frustrated by America's lack of progress with China: human rights groups who believe the Administration has largely abandoned their cause; conservatives who warn that the technology-hungry Chinese military is an enormous beneficiary of current American trade policy; nonproliferation groups that doubt China's commitments to stop arming nations like Iran and Pakistan; pro-Taiwan groups fearful of threats to the island, and many groups fearful that Beijing is already scaling back liberties long enjoyed in Hong Kong.
"Trade becomes the lightning rod because trade happens," said Ms. Barshefsky, the Administration's negotiator -- with China and Congress -- over Beijing's entry into the World Trade Organization. "It is the one constant, back-and-forth interchange between the two countries, and it is the one that China needs. So, naturally, it is often viewed as the vehicle to address any number of other issues."
Until now, the chief vehicle has been the annual renewal of China's most-favored-nation trading status -- a misleading name, because the status is accorded to virtually every one of America's trading partners. But after 16 years of saber-rattling by Congress, followed every year by a renewal of China's privileges, that debate has become sterile.
Renewal became a foregone conclusion because the price of canceling most-favored-nation status rose astronomically: American retailers would send in mounds of faxes to their Congressmen pointing out that all their toys and many of their clothes came from Chinese factories -- meaning that consumers would be hurt by higher tariffs -- and lobbyists from Boeing, I.B.M. and the Big Three auto makers would detail how much extra they would have to pay for Chinese-made parts.
In fact, a growing number of American companies -- led by Boeing and other large American manufacturers that have seen business slip away when political tensions with China rise -- have been lobbying for two years now for Congress to abandon the annual ritual and simply grant China "permanent M.F.N.," which most countries in the world enjoy. They argue that the annual debate over renewal has not only become a pointless exercise but also a debilitating one, because it makes America appear to be an unreliable trading partner.
Now China's move to enter the World Trade Organization has set off furious lobbying on both sides. The American "China lobby," led by the U.S.-China Business Council, has pressed for China's admission, making a familiar case that the only way to bring discipline and change to China's economic behavior is to bring it inside the world's trading system.
Perhaps the most persuasive case for that position is that China is already enjoying a free ride: Its annual most-favored-nation renewal assures that Chinese products enter the United States under the very low tariffs applied to goods from members of the World Trade Organization, but China does not now have to adhere to any of the trade organization's trading rules.
Administration officials have hinted that they would press for permanent most-favored-nation status after China was admitted to the World Trade Organization. But its entry would make the issue almost moot.
At the same time, a countermovement has begun on Capitol Hill. Both Republicans and Democrats are beginning to argue that Congress, acting on powers it gave itself in the bill that approved the global trade treaty that created the World Trade Organization in late 1994, must "review" China's application to join the trade organization before the United States gives its assent.
"Here is the problem," said Mr. Gephardt, the Democratic minority leader, who has openly split with the White House on China policy and is leading this effort. "In the case of China you have a country that does not have the rule of law, that does not abide by the trade agreements we already have with them. You have a country we have tried to change through 'commercial engagement,' and we have gotten nowhere. You have a country where we lurch from one crisis to another, and when we reach an 11th-hour settlement we say 'Whew, at least we preserved the relationship.'
"And so perhaps we have to say to them that membership in the W.T.O. involves more than just their economic behavior and their economic relationships."

Negotiations Rooted in Mistrust
Even when it comes to dealing with purely economic behavior, negotiating over trade with China is wildly different from negotiating over trade with Japan.
As generations of American trade negotiators have learned, striking a deal with Japan is almost always a lengthy, frustrating affair in which months are spent haggling over phrases. But in the end compromises are usually struck and obeyed, often for reasons that have as much to do with preserving a broader relationship -- especially a military alliance in which 60,000 American troops are stationed on Japanese soil -- as they do with trade.
"There's a political and strategic relationship underlying every negotiation," said Mickey Kantor, the former Commerce Secretary and trade representative, and a veteran of negotiations with both countries. "There is a huge cross-investment, and a mutual interest in a peaceful Asia. That carries the implication of trust."
None of that exists in negotiations with China. In fact, direct pressure from the United States often backfires, as it did last year when the Chinese, to demonstrate their pique at Washington, switched a major aircraft order from Boeing to Europe's Airbus.
As a result, some in the Administration believe the best way to deal with China on trade issues is through the World Trade Organization. "That way it does not look like Washington is always the one raising the stick," one State Department official argued recently.
The first step is to force China to change the complex rules that prevent foreign companies that invest in China from selling their goods to the Chinese. One reason that Chinese exports to the United States have surged so dramatically is that foreign investment in new factories there has risen steeply. And the Chinese Government requires most foreign investors in electronics and other high-tech industries to export virtually everything they produce, so that the goods do not compete in China's home market with state-owned industries.
Inch by inch, China is backing off from those rules. In the showdown last year over the "pirating" of billions of dollars in videos, software and compact disks, China agreed to open the way for Hollywood to invest in the plants that were stealing their goods, and sell legitimate wares to the Chinese.
Now, in the negotiations over China's entry to the World Trade Organization, the United States has insisted that China do away with the laws that treat foreign investors very differently from Chinese entrepreneurs. For example, under Chinese law no foreign companies have "trading rights," meaning that they must negotiate permission to import goods and sell them to the Chinese public. For example, when Cargill Inc., the American agricultural concern, wants to sell wheat to a Chinese flour mill, it is prohibited from making a direct sale. Instead, it must sell it to the China Cereals, Oils and Foodstuffs Corporation, which then sells it to an internal Chinese trading company, which then sells the flour.
Last month Chinese trade officials assured Lee Sands, the lead American negotiator with China on trade issues, that they would eliminate such rules. The only thing that counts, though, are the written commitments contained in China's "offer" to join the World Trade Organization, and Mr. Sands noted that "we don't know what the top leadership believes, how far it is willing to go."
Even if China gains entry to the trade organization, however, it will hardly be a wide-open market. Chinese officials know that their status as the world's leading emerging market gives them tremendous negotiating leverage. And they use it.
For years, for example, China has demanded that in return for buying American aircraft and other high-technology equipment, companies like Boeing and McDonnell Douglas must teach Chinese the art of building airplane parts and train Chinese workers to do work that previously was performed in Seattle and St. Louis. That is why Boeing produces tail sections for many of its planes in China, and why McDonnell Douglas has built a vast aircraft factory near Shanghai. And when Chinese officials are unsatisfied with the technology they obtain, they play the American makers off against Airbus Industrie, which is eager for a piece of the China market.
These days China's efforts to squeeze more technological know-how out of the West extend far beyond aircraft. The demands for technology extend to computer and telecommunications companies. By some estimates, China's military has set up dozens of companies in the United States to both obtain technology and earn profits that flow directly to the military's coffers. Their operations are an increasing focus of attention at the Central Intelligence Agency.
That is why Mr. Clinton was particularly embarrassed by the revelation that Wang Jun, the head of Polytechnologies, China's largest weapons maker, was invited to join a White House "coffee" last year, apparently by a large donor to the campaign who was trying to curry favor with the Chinese Government. Weeks later officials of an American subsidiary of the companies were arrested for trying to smuggle assault weapons to gangs in Los Angeles.
Other prominent Asians and Asian-Americans who played a role in the Presidential campaign -- including the Riady family in Indonesia -- are major investors in China, and thus have a strong interest in seeing it enter the World Trade Organization.

The Bottom Line: Where's the Deal?
The specter of China as an unfair trader, a covert acquirer of technology and an influence peddler puts enormous pressure on the Administration to drive a hard deal if China is to join the World Trade Organization.
And China, naturally, is resisting the kind of speedy changes that the United States -- and to a lesser degree, Europe and Japan -- insist must take place. Its trade barriers that are designed to protect state-owned enterprises came into being at a time when Communist leaders worried about five-year plans, not about international competitiveness. If foreign competition is allowed in too fast, those enterprises are almost certainly headed to bankruptcy and vast downsizing.
So China is pleading for time, and Mr. Clinton's advisers say that timing -- though not principle -- is negotiable.
"The appropriate analogy is buying a house," Nicholas Lardy, an economist who argues that it is essential that China be brought into the trade organization, wrote recently. Everyone wants China to buy the house, but only at an acceptable market price. Mr. Lardy argues that what the United States should do "is lower the down payment on the house to a level that is politically affordable to China." In other words, it would be given time to open up its markets. But that will only work if the Administration can argue that it has set up a strict review procedure to make sure that China complies with the rules.
Of course, come July 1, when Hong Kong reverts to China, the world will see an odd political anomaly. Hong Kong is already a member of the World Trade Organization -- and it will remain so as an ostensibly separate "autonomous" region in China. That status is largely a fiction, and China will undoubtedly be able to use Hong Kong's status to its trading advantage. But not long ago, Wu Yi, China's Trade Minister, told Ms. Barshefsky that this situation was intolerable.
"China is the parent," she said. "Hong Kong is the child."
Ms. Barshefsky recalled that she smiled at her Chinese counterpart and said: "That's right. But in America, the children always do better than their parents."

"COMPARISONS: Japan All Over Again?"
Long-running trade tensions between the United States and Japan have their roots in the late 1970's and early 1980's, when American imports of Japanese goods began to grow rapidly while American exports to Japan lagged. America's deficit with Japan has widened since then, but in the context of huge growth in overall trade flows in both directions. If anything, the yawning American deficit with China that has developed in the 1990's appears more one-side than America's deficit with Japan, because the overall trade relationsip is smaller. HEADLINE: New Agency Is Proposed For Managing Indian Assets

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
Citing longstanding Government incompetence, a Federal trustee has proposed that responsibility for billions of dollars of American Indian assets be transferred to a new independent agency run by financial professionals.
"I've never seen a worse operational mess than exists at the Department of Interior and the Bureau of Indian Affairs," said Paul M. Homan, a former bank regulator and banker appointed 18 months ago by President Clinton to devise a plan for overhauling the administration of Indian money, land and other assets. 
 For example, he said in an interview, of 300,000 individual Indians' accounts, no name or address could be found for 45,000 of them containing a total of $27 million.
The Indian assets come from sources like leasing land to energy companies or collecting grazing fees.
Mr. Homan has proposed the creation of what is tentatively called the American Indian Trust and Development Administration, which would function like a bank trust department.
As described by Mr. Homan at a news conference on Wednesday, the agency would consist of a chief executive and two board members, financial experts; three beneficiaries of Indian accounts, and three members from the public at large. Creation of the agency would require an act of legislation.
Initial reaction to Mr. Homan's plan, which was considerably more sweeping than most observers of the process had expected, was skeptical.
Indian groups agreed that drastic measures were required to improve the oversight of their $2.67 billion of federally held assets but they worried about separating trust management from the Government's social responsibilities for the first time.
Among other things, Washington provides substantial support for tribal education, housing, welfare programs and law enforcement.
"There are some great things, but it's also trying to be a catchall for a lot of longstanding problems -- and there's a lot of suspicion," said Dave Tovey, treasurer of the Affiliated Tribes of Northwest Indians, representing 54 tribes. While enthusiastic about the plan, Mr. Tovey said that to many of his constituents "it looks like our rights are being privatized."
Elouise Cobell, a Blackfoot Indian who advises Mr. Homan's Office of the Special Trustee, endorsed the plan but said tribes would need time to be convinced that Washington is acting in good faith. "They've been burned so often," Ms. Cobell said.
Mr. Homan's 67-page strategic plan calls for transferring trust management duties from the Interior Department's Bureau of Indian Affairs, currently headed by Ada Deer, a Menominee Indian, over a two-year period at a cost he estimated at $80 million to $100 million.
These activities include approving and monitoring oil, mineral and grazing leases; selling timber; collecting, investing and disbursing revenue, and managing land records.
Keeping track of who owns land has become inordinately expensive, Mr. Homan found, reflecting the Government's assignment of common land to individuals more than a century ago and the fact that since then, law governing Indian probate causes property to descend to heirs as undivided, ever-shrinking pieces to a growing number of owners.
While legislation would be required to consolidate fractionated interests and free land for development, the new agency would move on its own to remedy the understaffing and underfinancing that Mr. Homan said had plagued the bureau's administration of Indian assets.
Fiduciary standards have been compromised because of "politically expedient" trade-offs in which resources have been channeled to popular programs, the report said, while responsibilities fall within 16 separate organizations and are carried out by more than 100 field offices.
Mr. Homan, who was a senior regulator for the Comptroller of the Currency and later specialized in the rescue of failing banks, also cited $575 million of unreconciled disbursements from Indian accounts and the bureau's total lack of accounting professionals.
"Managers and staff of the B.I.A. have virtually no effective knowledge or practical experience" in financial management, the report said.
A second stage of the trustee's plan would create a bank as a dependable source of credit and investment for tribal economic development.

HEADLINE: As Mines Fade, Workers Hunt for Jobs

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: SUMITON, Ala.

 BODY:
The nice paycheck made up for the fact that Douglas Sanders seldom saw the sun. For more than 20 years, Mr. Sanders worked deep underground in the coal mines of northern Alabama, providing for his family and surviving the layoffs commonplace in this part of the country.
Just like his father and his two brothers, Mr. Sanders would ride the mine elevator six days a week to almost a mile beneath the earth's surface. "A lot of days, in the wintertime especially, you would go underground in the dark and you would get out in the dark," Mr. Sanders said. "All you knew was darkness, five days a week. You'd come out of the shaft and see the sunshine, and it would just blind you." 
 In this area of the southern Appalachians, where coal has been the primary fuel of the economy for nearly a century, mining goes through phases. As finite reserves are depleted, mines close and workers are displaced. But new mines have always opened, and the miners with the most seniority have been called back, even as the overall number of miners steadily declined.
Now, that decline, like a slow cave-in, has finally swallowed men like Mr. Sanders, robbing even the most senior miners of their jobs.
"Every day you work, you are working yourself out of a job," said Mr. Sanders, who, at 42, was one of the younger miners still working. "When they run out of resources in an area, then it is over."
This time, however, there may not be any callbacks.
The Drummond Company, the largest coal producer in Alabama, closed two of its largest mines in January, Mary Lee No. 1 and Chetopa, laying off about 725 miners. The economics of mining -- Western strip-mined coal is much less expensive to produce than deep-mined coal -- means that there are few underground mines left in northern Alabama, leaving virtually no hope for future employment in the industry for the idled workers.
Many of these middle-aged men, most of whom had been in the mines for more than 20 years, are now finding it necessary to leave the only career they have ever known because of the decline of the coal mining industry in this area. Many are being retrained at Bevill State Community College here, using state and Federal funds, for skilled jobs like electrician and welder. Those jobs offer the hope of employment and job security, but at a cost: pay that is far below the average of $45,000 a year that miners here made.
"You are going to see coal mining fade out in the area," said David Knight, executive director of the Walker County Economic and Industrial Development Authority. "The miners are looking for opportunities elsewhere, to learn new skills, if that is what is needed."
Earl Hudson is in the second layoff in his 22-year career. This time, he does not see a future in coal mining. "I don't look for the big call," said Mr. Hudson, who was laid off from the Mary Lee No. 1 Mine. "I don't think it is going to come this time."
Miners in this area had never before thought this way. If asked a few years ago, coal miners like Mr. Hudson would have responded that they would be in the mines until they died or until they retired.
Right now, however, Mr. Hudson, who is 46, said that he was satisfied to seek a new career outside the mines. Mr. Hudson is in a six-week training program for truck drivers and is a part-time tree trimmer to help supplement the income of his wife, Derry, who is an assistant supervisor at a day care center. "Financially, I miss it," Mr. Hudson said. "Coal miners made good money and they are going to have to make some adjustments. We are cutting back tremendously, but I'm going to bounce back because I'm a fighter."
This determination is expressed over and over again by the laid-off miners. Marc Lockhart is in the first, and probably only, layoff of his 17-year mining career.
"It is bad and it is hard," said Mr. Lockhart, who, since his layoff from Mary Lee No. 1, has turned to the ministry, becoming associate pastor of Old Mount Carmel Baptist Church. "For two days, I took it hard. I'm not going to tell you a story. I took it like a death in the family or something. It hurt."
Jefferson and Walker Counties were among the most heavily mined areas in Alabama, which ranks 13th in coal-producing states. Together, Jefferson and Walker Counties accounted for 62 percent of Alabama's coal supply, said Andrew Blumenfeld, a senior consultant at Resource Data International, which is a data base and consulting company for the coal and electric utility industries.
"It is a real devastating blow to the economy up there," said Jerry C. Ray, Alabama's Labor Commissioner whose office is in Montgomery. "It is not like this is 700 or 800 Wal-Mart jobs or Kentucky Fried Chicken jobs. These were $45,000-a-year jobs. It is going to be devastating."
Neal Capps, a 17-year veteran of underground mines, was the local president for the United Mine Workers of America. Every two weeks, Mr. Capps received about $1,000 after taxes. He is now making $180 a week on unemployment while he is training to become a truck driver.
Even when Mr. Capps finds employment as a truck driver, he will not be making what he did as a mine worker. "Mining was a good-paying job," Mr. Capps said. "Most of us are going to try to go to other occupations. I am going to truck driving. Big demand for drivers."
"I told some people, the Monday after we got the notice, I told them my wife and I have planned and worked and saved hard, and we have got enough to live off the rest of our lives, if we don't live over two months," Mr. Capps said. He said such jokes were necessary. "That's the only way you can take it."

HEADLINE: Brinkmanship in Atlantic City;
Tense Talks Behind a Casino Road and Tunnel Project

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Feb. 28

 BODY:
The phone rang late in the afternoon last July 3, not long after Gov. Christine Todd Whitman had returned to her office. She had just announced that New Jersey and Mirage Resorts had reached an agreement on building a $330 million road and tunnel that would speed casino goers to Mirage's planned Atlantic City resort.
The caller was Stephen A. Wynn, the chairman and chief executive of Mirage, complaining that Mrs. Whitman's announcement did not accurately reflect their agreement. If the terms were not changed, he warned, the deal was off. 
 Mrs. Whitman did not flinch. Instead, she told the casino mogul that he could either accept the terms she had announced -- which she insisted reflected their agreement -- or she would immediately issue a news release stating that there would be no partnership and no tunnel.
Apparently unhappy with the ultimatum, Mr. Wynn delivered a parting shot. "This is Steve Wynn," he announced over the speaker phone. "I don't accept this deal. Good night, ladies and gentleman."
But, according to one of the state employees in the room, neither called off the deal, instead agreeing later that night to go back to the table. And in January, they signed an agreement to build the road and tunnel. Still, the brinkmanship last July signaled how rough the negotiations over the next six months would be, as both sides struggled to coordinate their inherently disparate concerns.
With some 30,000 jobs and hundreds of millions of dollars in casino revenues on the line, the two sides fought over a wide range of issues, from the placement of a traffic light to cost overruns to the state's representative at the negotiating table.
The Mirage resort, with three casinos and 7,000 hotel rooms planned in the marina district, is part of Atlantic City's effort to transform itself from a gambling town for day travelers to a major vacation destination. The road and tunnel project would provide access to the marina district and improve other roadways around the city, including those that serve casinos by the boardwalk.
The pact is expected to clear the way for major growth, and developments are being watched throughout the nation by the casino industry.
Interviews with some of the participants in the talks offer rare details of how a state government and a large publicly traded company work out a deal. Each side wanted the highway project to go forward, but neither wanted to bear the ultimate responsibility for getting it built. While Mrs. Whitman fought to limit the taxpayers' cost, Mr. Wynn tried to limit his company's liability.
Both sides said they were pleased with the final agreement, but both had to accept more responsibility.
"Everybody's been beat up," Mr. Wynn said in a recent telephone interview. "This is the most complicated deal we've ever done." Mirage operates four casinos elsewhere, has two more under construction and had revenues of $1.5 billion in 1996.
Mr. Wynn has rarely commented publicly on the negotiations between Mirage and New Jersey. Nor has he discussed the fervent opposition to the project led by Donald J. Trump, the operator of three casinos in Atlantic City. In recent days, two more casino operators have sided with Mr. Trump and said that they also were concerned that the road plan served the area around Mr. Wynn's casino and neglected the casinos along the boardwalk.
Mr. Wynn has contended that his casino will attract more gamblers to Atlantic City, stimulating business for all the casino owners. Of Mr. Trump's opposition, Mr. Wynn said, "He's scared; he doesn't want the competition."
 
Cost Overruns Are Critical Issue
 The July 3 phone call by Mr. Wynn centered on who would pay for cost overruns. On a project of that size, contractors often run into unexpected problems and their costs go higher than anticipated.
Mrs. Whitman had announced that the agreement called for Mirage to serve as the developer and accept all responsibility for completing the project, including any excess costs. But Mr. Wynn contended that no such agreement had been reached. The Governor had "the wrong impression" about the agreement, Mr. Wynn said. "The fact that the Governor's staff did not have their arms around some of the parts, the very technical parts, confused them."
Mr. Wynn stayed in Las Vegas, Nev., for most of the talks, leaving Mirage's negotiating in Trenton to Richard Bronson, a former Connecticut developer who now heads the company's project development unit.
According to people involved in the talks, Mr. Bronson employed a classic good cop, bad cop strategy. Mr. Bronson would recount "these homespun 'aw shucks' stories about Steve Wynn and how Mr. Wynn has to see this project finished before he loses his eyesight," recalled one of the state's negotiators, who would speak only on condition of anonymity. (Mr. Wynn, 55, suffers from retinitis pigmentosa, a debilitating eye disease that could severely reduce his vision or cause blindness.) "Then he'd leave, and his lawyers would start undoing everything," the state negotiator said. "They'd rewrite the language to undo the deal. We did that for months, back and forth."
But Mr. Bronson and Mr. Wynn contend that the state's negotiators slowed the talks. Mrs. Whitman's lead negotiator was Frank J. Wilson, who had managed transit systems in San Francisco and Chicago before he was appointed Transportation Commissioner by Mrs. Whitman in 1994. Facing pressure from Mr. Trump, Mr. Wilson often said his purpose was to build a highway that was "fair and equitable" to everyone in Atlantic City.
But Mr. Wilson's devotion to parity led the Mirage officials to accuse him of going overboard to accommodate Mr. Trump. "Wilson was sympathetic to the other side," Mr. Wynn complained recently.
Mr. Bronson said Mr. Wilson shared the details of their negotiations with Mr. Trump. Mr. Bronson said he thought this was unfair, since the talks were between the state and Mirage. "It was obvious to us," Mr. Bronson said. "We thought we had concurrence on items, and he would come back and change. Obviously, he was talking to someone in the Trump organization."
Mr. Trump confirmed in an interview that state officials showed him the plans before they were announced. "It was shown and negotiated with us," Mr. Trump said.
Mr. Wilson, who recently left his job with the state, was reached at the private engineering firm where he now works, but he said he was prohibited by the firm's policy from discussing the negotiations conducted in his former position.
But Michael P. Torpey, the Governor's chief counsel, said it was important to discuss the talks with other casino owners. "This is not a project for Steve Wynn," Mr. Torpey said. "This is really a much larger economic development project."
One heated exchange between the negotiators took place last fall, when Mr. Wilson changed the highway plan, adding new cloverleafs, off ramps and traffic lights. The Mirage officials called the changes superfluous, and Mr. Bronson protested one of the traffic lights specifically, saying it would only create traffic jams.
 
A Stoplight Halts Negotiations
 According to Mr. Bronson, Mr. Wilson was in favor of the light as a less expensive solution to a traffic flow problem than additional ramps and highway. Since there were already traffic jams around the other casinos, Mr. Bronson recalled, Mr. Wilson reasoned that it was only fair that there be traffic jams around the Mirage. " 'That's for parity,' " he quoted Mr. Wilson as saying. " 'I want to even it up."
Mr. Bronson said he responded: "Who asked you to do that? Trump?"
To which, he recalled, Mr. Wilson said, "I resent that."
Mr. Bronson then stormed from the room and called Mr. Wynn in Las Vegas. The dispute over the traffic light went on for three weeks, until it was finally removed from the plans, Mr. Wynn said. "I'm sitting in Las Vegas, saying, 'What the hell is going on in good old New Jersey,' " Mr. Wynn recalled.
On at least one occasion, Mr. Wynn did fly to New Jersey, where he met the Governor at Drumthwacket, the executive mansion in Princeton. "I complained about why it had taken so long," Mr. Wynn said. "I said, 'Please give us someone who will take this to closure.' "
Mr. Bronson said he also complained to the Governor about Mr. Wilson. "Wilson would set up a meeting at 1, and he'd come sauntering in at 3 P.M.," Mr. Bronson charged. "It was obvious we were not going to get this thing done with Wilson."
Mrs. Whitman responded by putting two new staff members in charge of the talks: Mr. Torpey and Richard S. Mroz, who oversees state authorities.
Mr. Wilson, meanwhile, was preparing to leave for his new job and was preoccupied with accusations of conflict of interest over a discussion of employment opportunities with a company seeking to do business with the state.
Mr. Wynn contended that the change in negotiators led to the agreement. "One week after he left, it got done," Mr. Wynn said.
One of the major issues worked out in the final days was the cost overruns. The two sides had earlier agreed that Mirage would be the lead developer because a private company could avoid the onerous bid processes required for the state.
Mr. Wynn, who wanted the highway completed in time to open his casino in two to three years, went along with the arrangement, but fought accepting the responsibility that a developer normally assumes. "We don't build roads," said. "We're not the State of New Jersey."
To compromise, the two sides have said they agreed to pass the responsibility for cost overruns to the general contractor, which the developer must find. A general contractor, however, has not been selected, and the January agreement avoids discussing cost overruns, which could reach millions of dollars.
The agreement does stipulate that the state will be liable for no more than $220 million and Mirage for no more than $110 million. "We got our bottom line," Mr. Torpey said. "The Governor has always said the state would not be responsible for cost overruns."
But some critics of the deal said they did not see how a contractor could hold costs to $330 million and still build the road as planned. Even Mr. Torpey sounded uncertain about what would happen if the project ended up costing more. "At this point, it's contemplated the contractor will be responsible," he said.
As for the seemingly ambiguous resolution to the issue, Mr. Wynn said, "The state didn't give a damn, as long as they weren't on the hook, and we didn't give a damn as long as we weren't on the hook."
 
State Accepts More Responsibility
 In those final days, however, the state did accept more financial risk. It agreed to pay $4.5 million for highway plans that are now being developed -- an amount that could be lost if either side backs out before the transaction is completed in July. Mirage was also given the right to end the partnership if the state has trouble putting up its share of the money. The state would then be responsible for all expenses Mirage paid up to that point.
Mirage also insisted on having the South Jersey Transportation Authority sign the agreement. The authority, which runs the Atlantic City Expressway, will sell bonds to raise $60 million of the $220 million in state funds for the project. The bonds are to be repaid with the increased expressway toll receipts anticipated as a result of the Mirage resort. But to sell the bonds, the authority itself would probably have to guarantee investors that the project would be finished -- a guarantee that could leave the authority on the hook for additional costs. Authority officials recently said that the 25-cent toll on the expressway might have to be raised for the first time since 1969 as a result of financing the project.
Mr. Wynn insisted that he did not gain any advantage in the negotiations. The Governor "stuck to her guns," he said. He conceded, however, that any perception that the Governor folded during negotiations will provide fodder to those who opposed the project in the first place. "This was a learning experience for all of us," he said. "And a complex one."

HEADLINE: In Colorado, Ice Climbers Surmount Legal Hurdles

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TELLURIDE, Colo.

 BODY:
Negotiating icicles the size of trees, winter climbers had a hard enough time scaling the blue ice cliffs of Bridal Veil Falls without worrying about the police.
"The first time I tried this, I left with cuffs on," Joe Melley, a professional ice climber, said, recalling his two arrests for illegally climbing this old mining town's landmark in winter. "This time it was sweet, no paranoia." 
 In Telluride, where men used to risk their lives mining gold and silver, it became legal this winter for men and women to risk their lives climbing the 360-foot-high frozen falls at the east end of this town's box canyon. Off-limits ever since the first ascent two decades ago, the frozen waterfall was opened to climbers after lengthy negotiations exempted the land owners, the Iderado Mining Company, of any liability.
In a society where risk is systematically removed from work and play, high-risk, or "extreme" sports are gaining followers. Here in the southern Rockies, this Victorian mining town, long a center for conventional downhill skiing, has become a center for these high-risk sports: ice climbing, rock climbing, parasailing and wilderness skiing.
"Extreme sports make for a better society," argued Eric R. Jacobson, who leases the falls for a hydroelectric plant and was a party to the legal pact that opened them to climbing. "The experience of ice climbing gives you the feeling that you can control your own destiny -- and that improves the citizenry."
Stephen B. Johnson, a Telluride lawyer who worked for four years to win a winter easement for ice climbers here, said: "As rock climbing gets more popular, climbers want to go to higher, harder and wilder places."
"Climbers are attracted to the danger," said Mr. Johnson, ebullient after his first ascent of Bridal Veil Falls, in mid-February.
Roughly half a million Americans now rock climb, according to the Access Fund, a nonprofit climbing group that helped to negotiate the system of liability waivers and exemptions that opened up Telluride's forbidden ice. To keep in shape, and to keep the adrenaline pumping in winter, a growing minority of rock climbers have taken up ice climbing, which can be more physically and technically challenging.
"My friends who are ice climbers complain all the time that there are so many people on the cliffs," said Sally Moser, executive director of the Fund, which has 7,000 members nationwide. Based in Boulder, Colo., this climbing association is to have its annual convention, or "climbers' rendezvous," here in late May.
Much the way that snowmobiling has breathed new life into rural communities from Maine to Michigan, ice climbing now provides a year-round economy to Ouray, an old mining town on the far side of Black Bear Pass from here. Without a ski area, Ouray used to live off summer tourists who came for a scenic railroad that winds through the Rockies.
Four years ago, climbers worked out liability problems with local owners, then ran the overflow from a town reservoir through half a mile of plastic piping with an array of spigots along a mountain ridge. The result was Ice Park, a challenging ice mass that offers 70 ascent routes from a base parking lot next to a state highway.
"Ice climbers now account for more than half of our business," said Bill Whitt, an owner of one of the largest hotels in town, the Ouray Victorian Inn. "Ice climbers have jobs and money to spend. We get very few bottom feeders -- people who come and climb, and then sleep in their cars."
Making ice the way ski areas make snow, Ouray held an Ice Festival in January, attracting about 500 ice climbers and an additional 300 curious.
Here in Telluride, a main stop on the way to the ice is Telluride Mountaineer, a shop festooned with climbing hardware, including ropes, crampons, pitons and carabiners.
"It's becoming more mainstream to go ice climbing," said Cris Ann Crysdale, a saleswoman who climbs in her spare time. "In the past, it was only the hard-core macho men. Now all kinds of women are being involved in it. Not just being dragged up there by their boyfriends, but leading groups."
Although there have been no known accidents on Bridal Veil Falls, risk and danger are major attractions, Ms. Crysdale said.
On her first attempt on the Falls a few years ago, a snowcat vehicle approached below and a man bellowed through a megaphone, ordering her party to descend. By the time they reached the base of the falls, an avalanche had swept away the caterpillar tracks of the snowcat.
"The danger of falling ice is the biggest danger," Ms. Crysdale said, recalling a friend's aborted ascent of the falls last December. "He climbed the first pitch, had a bad feeling about the ice, and went back down. That night a huge, 50-foot chunk of ice broke off on the second pitch."
Beyond the usual hazards, Bridal Veil offers a special risk for climbers who stray off approved routes.
On a recent afternoon, as powder snow harmlessly cascaded down high mountain chutes, Mr. Jacobson pointed out that the Bridal Veil ice is created by the outflow of his hydropower plant, perched atop the falls, which supplies Telluride's electricity. Power cables, sheathed in metal, run alongside the falls, in an out-of-bounds area. But like the rest of the falls, they are encased in ice.
"We have notified people that the power lines are there," Mr. Jacobson said. "But if someone hammered it with an ice ax, or screwed into it with an ice augur, there is no telling that the metal conduit would resist."

HEADLINE: Keeping Human Contact in Economics Isn't a Renegade View;
The Popcorn Puzzle

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Alan Ehrenhalt's Op-Ed article of Feb. 23 uses one of our papers to attack the methodology of modern economics. We are accused of ignoring the "common-sense" truth that the price of concessions at movies is irrelevant, and that "all that really matters is the movie being shown and the location of the theater." If Mr. Ehrenhalt is right, what prevents movie theaters from charging twice what they currently charge? 
 If the admission price matters, is it not common sense that the cost of popcorn and other concessions, which can easily exceed the cost of admission, also matters? Popcorn in theaters is expensive not because that is "the price of leisure-time social harmony," but because it is a form of price discrimination that can be practiced even by competitive companies.
 
ALVARO RODRIGUEZ
LUIS LOCAY
Newark, Feb. 27, 1997
The writers are associate professors of economics, at, respectively, Rutgers University and the University of Miami.

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK CITY;
Court Backs Law to End Mob Control of Garbage

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
A Federal appeals court has given its approval to a new law aimed at eliminating what it called a black hole in New York City's economic life: the mob-controlled garbage collection industry.
The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit said the law permitting the city to regulate the garbage collection industry was "narrowly tailored to achieve the compelling governmental interest in terminating 40 years of criminal control of the carting industry in New York City." 
 The ruling upheld a decision last year in which Judge Milton Pollack of the United States District Court in Manhattan found that regulation of the garbage collection industry fell within the traditional powers of the police.
The appeals court rejected a legal challenge by 256 local carters who said that the law violated privacy and also denied due process because the commission can end licenses without a hearing.
The three-judge panel said in its unanimous decision that the Constitution did not permit a blanket prohibition against joining a trade association with both lawful and illegal goals. But it added that an association could not be shielded from "government action taken to root out the illegal activity."
"This targeted criminal cartel is a black hole in New York City's economic life," the court said.
The law was enacted after an indictment alleged that a mob-controlled cartel dominated the business and stole $500 million a year in inflated costs from city businesses. It requires haulers to reapply for licenses and disclose company finances and finances of close relatives of the company owners.
