HEADLINE: Sweden's Courteous Police Spoil A Hell's Angels Clubhouse Party

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: STOCKHOLM, March 2

 BODY:
This was a bad weekend for the Hell's Angels in Scandinavia.
With about 300 Swedish uniformed and undercover police officers keeping a vigil over "Angels Place," the motorcycle gang's new clubhouse here, nothing was allowed to get out of hand. 
 The large burgundy wooden shack under suffocating surveillance was where Hell's Angels from all over the world gathered to celebrate with loud rock music and rivers of beer the opening of their newest chapter in Scandinavia, the third to open in Sweden in five years.
The normally liberal, courteous, friendly Swedish police made sure the 250 to 300 international members of the brotherhood, as the Angels refer to themselves, had a miserable time.
One gang official was even arrested for neglecting to wear a safety belt in the back seat of a car. In Hell's Angels' parlance, that was a pretty humiliating put down.
But the gang's trouble here this weekend might have been only a minor setback in their expansion into new territory. Law enforcement officials and experts in motorcycle gangs say the alarm of the Stockholm police was well justified.
"When the Hell's Angels set up a chapter, it's like a dog watering a fire hydrant; it's marking territory," said Yves Lavign, who has written two books on the gang. "Increasingly they are looking at Scandinavia, with its open seas and sparsely populated spaces, as good territory for drug smuggling and manufacturing. They can set up a laboratory to process heroin, pills and cocaine."
But the Angels aren't the only American-based gang looking for new territory. They have been engaged in a deadly competition with the rival Bandidos, and in the last three years 10 gang members have been killed and 50 wounded.
Machine guns, grenades and antitank rockets have been used in gang violence in Oslo, Copenhagen, Stockholm and Helsinki, and many civilians have been wounded too.
Last March, the serenity of Copenhagen's airport was shattered in a gunfight as Hell's Angels came to "greet" leaders of the Bandidos, leaving one dead and two seriously wounded. Last October, a car bomb exploded outside the Angels' Oslo headquarters. Also last year, several homes were destroyed in Malmo, Sweden, when a Bandidos headquarters was bombed. As the cycle of attacks and revenge continue, a rocket-propelled grenade was shot at a Danish jail last month in an attempt to kill an imprisoned Bandidos leader. It missed him, but several inmates were wounded.
At least 100 gang members have been jailed across Scandinavia since 1991. The police here and in Norway, Finland and Denmark are operating with the United States Drug Enforcement Administration and the Treasury's Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. Theodore C. Baltas 2d, an agent from the bureau who was here this weekend, said a joint task force had been set up.
"It is the least we can do," Mr. Baltas said this afternoon. "After all, we exported the problem to them. Containing it has got to be a multinational effort."
Indeed, about 7:30 P.M. Saturday, law enforcement officials from the United States, Finland, Norway and Denmark watched from a distance as the Swedish police stopped scores of Angels, their wives, girlfriends and guests flocking to the party in a nondescript industrial suburb of Stockholm.
All were searched for weapons, drugs or anything illegal. Their identity papers were duly noted, yielding what Detective Inspector Finn Wurtz of Denmark described as a huge bonanza of "intelligence, information and data" about Hell's Angels members, supporters, and hangers-on who act as apprentices in the hopes of joining the ranks.
Denmark, the worst hit of all Scandinavian countries, has now banned Hell's Angels clubs and motorcycle gangs, detaining and searching known members on sight, Mr. Wurtz said. Sweden has passed provisions allowing a significant infringement on the bikers' freedom. Norway and Finland are heading in the same direction.
"The message is not just zero tolerance," said Detective Per Jaldung of the Swedish National Criminal Intelligence Service, who tracks motorcycle gang activities. "Increasingly what we are saying to motorcycle gangs is: we don't want you around Sweden or Scandinavia."
The Angels are based in California, while the Bandidos originated in Texas. Accompanying their arrival in Scandinavia in the early 1990's was a palpable increase in the supply of amphetamines, cocaine and other hard drugs as well as gang wars over territory, the police said.
With a worldwide membership of 1,200 to 1,500, Hell's Angels has an estimated 85 members in Sweden, 110 in Denmark, 70 in Norway and 25 in Finland. The police in those countries say the group is organized into 15 official chapters. They said thatalso applying for membership are a score of unofficial clubs filled with petty motorcycle criminals.
The Bandidos have 130 members across Scandinavian countries in at least seven chapters, police officials said.
For both gangs, here as in the United States, membership is restricted to white males 21 or older. An unofficial requirement is the possession of a criminal record including time in jail.
At the Hell's Angels' shack this morning, the mood was sour under the suffocating police surveillance.
"There is no one to talk to here," a surly, bearded, heavily tattooed Swedish man with earrings told an inquiring visitor. Glancing at one of a dozen police armored vehicles patrolling only yards away ever since the gathering began on Thursday, he slammed the steel door shut.
The shack is on Ranhamarsvagen, a gray, lifeless street, on which the police had set up two checkpoints. Police cameras recorded every movement. Every car that wanted to pass a checkpoint was stopped, and some passengers were searched.
Siw Persson, a Member of Parliament who is trying to stop the spread of motorcycle gangs here, said the immediate priority for Scandinavian Governments is to prevent people from getting hurt.
"When gunfire erupts in such a savage way, most of the time people stand there, just gazing in disbelief," she said. "They don't even take cover, because we are not used to this kind of violence in this part of the world."
She warned that the problem is growing as more Scandinavian youths drift toward gangs, driven by unemployment, family problems and the pressure of rising criminality emanating from organized crime in Russia and the former Yugoslavia.
"We have only three clubs now in Sweden, but there are dozens of prospect clubs who applied to become Hell's Angel chapters," she said. "For this they have to be tested, which means they have to elevate themselves to higher levels of criminality. This is how you qualify for Hell's Angels trust."
Mrs. Persson said the only way to counter the trend is force.
"We have to show them we are strong and willing to use our force," she said. She added with a laugh that before she undertook the task of fighting gangs with new laws in Parliament she consulted her husband and three daughters. "They were very supportive," she said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Swedish police officers put a cordon around the Hell's Angels' new clubhouse in a Stockholm suburb on Saturday. One member of the motorcycle gang was arrested for neglecting to wear his seatbelt. (Agence France-Presse) (pg. A8)
 
Map showing the location of Stockholm, Sweden: Gang experts say the alarm of the police in Stockholm is justified. (pg. A8)

HEADLINE: Teamsters Are Challenging G.E. Chief's Compensation

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
John F. Welch Jr., one of the most successful and highly compensated chief executives in corporate America, is about to be asked to defend how much he is paid to run the General Electric Company.
A shareholder resolution seeking to eliminate a form of deferred compensation for Mr. Welch, G.E.'s chairman and chief executive, will be in the proxy statement that G.E. is expected to mail to shareholders in the next few days. 
 The resolution, brought by a pension plan of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, calls for placing a $1 million limit on the base salaries of G.E.'s five top executives. It is intended to challenge a 1995 arrangement under which Mr. Welch deferred half of his $2 million base salary until retirement in return for a promise to receive generous interest payments on the balance.
G.E. directors will recommend that shareholders reject the proposal, which will be voted on on April 23 in Charlotte, N.C., at the company's annual meeting.
"We feel it would undermine our ability to retain and attract leaders in the future," said Vance Meyer, a G.E. spokesman. "We need the flexibility to develop competitive individual compensation plans."
The managers of the teamsters pension plan said they learned of Mr. Welch's deferred compensation agreement from an article in The New York Times that was part of a series late last year. The article detailed the ways many wealthy Americans manage to reduce, delay or avoid taxes, using sophisticated techniques not generally available to most people. The teamsters provided The Times with an advance copy of the shareholder resolution and a letter from G.E. confirming that it would appear in the proxy statement.
The union filed a similar resolution with Pepsico, whose chief executive, Roger A. Enrico, deferred $1.3 million in 1994. Another Pepsico executive made $199,967 in 1995 in above-market interest on deferred compensation. The teamsters said Pepsico should disclose the interest rate paid.
Pepsico, in a statement that will appear in its proxy in opposition to the resolution, said none of its executives' base pay exceeded $1 million and that the deferred amounts were entirely tax deductible.
Teamsters' officials said they filed the resolutions as part of a campaign to draw attention to executive pay, which the union considers excessive.
"As long as there are loophole lawyers, there need to be shareholder watchdogs and we still think a million dollars means something," said Bart Naylor, the union's director of corporate affairs. Mr. Welch, who owns G.E. stock worth more than $300 million, received total compensation over $22 million in 1995.
The teamsters' resolution says "deferred compensation is being used as a method of avoiding shareholder votes on compensation plans."
Under a 1993 Federal law, the maximum amount of base pay that a company can deduct from taxes for its top five executives is $1 million each. There is no limit on how much a company can deduct if the pay is based on a pay-for-performance plan that was approved by a shareholder vote. But base pay greater than $1 million qualifies for a tax deduction, even if it is not part of an approved pay-for-performance plan, if the money is deferred until retirement.
Mr. Welch deferred half of his $2 million base salary until retirement in return for being paid 14 percent interest, which will compound untaxed until he retires. Mr. Welch also received a $35,000 sweetener payment, which also earns 14 percent interest, to encourage him to make the deferral. If the deferral lasts five years Mr. Welch will have $263,600 more, after taxes, than if he had found an investment on his own paying 14 percent interest.
The General Electric resolution was proposed by the Teamsters Affiliates Pension Plan, which owns 13,800 shares of G.E. stock and covers top union officials. All teamster plans together own 7.2 million G.E. shares, the union said, or less than one-half of 1 percent of the nearly 1.65 billion G.E. shares outstanding.
G.E. sought permission from the Securities and Exchange Commission in a Dec. 20 letter to ignore the union's resolution. The S.E.C. denied the request, though it did require two minor changes.
Last year, at least 63 shareholder resolutions on executive pay were submitted, according to the Investor Responsibility Research Center, which tracks proxy and other corporate-governance filings at 1,500 companies. Shareholders voted on 37 of these proposals. All lost, on average receiving the support of 11.1 percent of the shares voted, the center said.

HEADLINE: Gore's Fund-Raising Casts a Political Shadow

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 2

 BODY:
On a September afternoon in 1993, eight months after the Clinton Administration had taken office, Vice President Al Gore used a borrowed room at a Los Angeles law firm to meet with about 30 members of the local Asian-American business community.
The 45-minute session had been requested and partly coordinated by John Huang, then an executive of the Lippo bank, which is part of the business empire of the Riady family of Indonesia. And the Vice President had taken the opportunity to cultivate a prosperous immigrant group for the Democratic Party. 
 Mr. Gore's aides describe that afternoon as a political outreach session. While it was not a fund raiser, a Gore aide acknowledged that one aim of such a meeting would be that those attending might eventually become donors.
Mr. Huang subsequently joined the Administration in the Commerce Department and then became a senior Democratic Party fund-raiser. Now he is at the center of several investigations into questionable and unlawful contributions to the Democratic Party, and whether money from overseas businesses or governments illegally found its way into Democratic campaign coffers.
And Mr. Gore, who throughout his political career has benefited from a reputation for integrity, is now coming under sharp scrutiny for his role as President Clinton's loyal political second, a role that threatens to undermine a man who has been waiting for his own turn to make a run for the Presidency.
Today two Democratic Senators, Paul Wellstone of Minnesota and Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey, criticized Mr. Gore in response to a report in The Washington Post that the Vice President had personally telephoned donors to ask for contributions in the 1996 campaign.
"I'm not going to be in the business of defending the undefendable," Mr. Torricelli said on "Fox News Sunday." "And what is more, I do not personally believe it is appropriate for the President or Vice President of the United States to directly solicit contributions through telephone calls." It is not illegal for the President or Vice President to solicit campaign contributions, but Federal officials cannot solicit or receive campaign money on Federal property.
It has long been the role of a Vice President to do the less glamorous political work of an Administration and devote himself to the backbreaking and time consuming task of raising money.
In fact, Representative Henry A. Waxman, a California Democrat, today produced a letter that Senator Don Nickles, an Oklahoma Republican, sent to members of a Republican fund-raising group, the Inner Circle, in 1990 inviting them to "meet the Vice President and his wife at their home," when Dan Quayle was Vice President. Mr. Waxman, the senior Democrat on the House Committee on Government Reform and Oversight, called for those activities to be scrutinized by the committee along with the Democratic fund raising.
Mr. Gore performed his task avidly, Democrats say, intent on building a loyal network of supporters and fund-raisers who would be at his side in 2000 in a probable Democratic primary fight. "When there's a good fund-raiser out there, Gore goes after him," said one Democrat who has been courted by the Vice President.
It was Mr. Gore's own political network that proved its mettle by holding the first $1 million fund-raiser for the Clinton-Gore campaign, a gathering of about 50 Gore supporters in Washington's lavish Ritz-Carlton hotel in June 1995.
The Vice President attended 8 of Mr. Clinton's White House coffees and acted as host himself at 23 coffees with donors, his sessions held in the Vice President's ceremonial office in the Old Executive Office Building next to the White House. One of his aides, David Strauss, sat in on the weekly White House meetings in which a core of Mr. Clinton's senior advisers huddled with the top echelons of the Democratic National Committee to map out weekly fund-raising goals.
And as the Clinton-Gore campaign urgently sought ever more money for television advertising in 1995 and 1996, Mr. Gore picked up the telephone and made personal appeals for donations, Democrats say, a task Mr. Clinton refused to do. It was not clear where Mr. Gore made his calls from. George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton's former special adviser said today on the ABC News program "This Week" that the White House reserved political work for special telephone lines paid for by the Democratic National Committee.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore succeeded to such an extent that they raised a record amount for their party and won re-election, while still being significantly outspent by the Republicans. But the fruits of their victory have been nearly weekly questions about the seemliness of their fund-raising drive as well as investigations into whether a small core of Democratic fund-raisers, including Mr. Huang, were illegally funneling money into Democratic coffers from foreign sources. Last week the Democrats announced that they were returning another $1.5 million, most of it raised by Mr. Huang and two other Asian-American businessmen.
Even as the controversy swirls around him, Mr. Gore has been trying to court donors as usual and to place his people in crucial positions for four years from now. Karen Skelton, who had been Mr. Gore's political director, has moved into the White House to become a deputy political director. Steven Grossman, the new national chairman of the Democratic National Committee, is a Gore ally. And Daniel A. Dutko, a Washington lobbyist who is considered by Democrats to be part of the Gore fund-raising network, has been put in charge of the Democrats' latest "Victory" fund to raise money for the 1998 off-year elections.
The Vice President's allies argue that he can survive the focus on campaign finance excesses. "With Gore you have an impregnable record of integrity," said Carter Eskew, a Democratic political strategist with ties to Mr. Gore.
But several other Democratic political strategists, speaking on the condition that they not be identified, said Mr. Gore was now in danger of looking like the ultimate inside player in a political system that appears ever crasser to the public. Mr. Gore declined to be interviewed for this article.
Mr. Gore began assembling his own fund-raising network when he ran for President in 1988, and he keeps his own database of donors and supporters at the Democratic National Committee.
The Gore network includes people like Howard Glicken, who runs a Miami consulting and merchant banking firm; Noach Dear, a New York City Councilman with fund-raising prowess among Orthodox Jews, and Mitchell W. Berger, a Fort Lauderdale, Fla., lawyer who was the Clinton-Gore finance chairman for Florida. Peter S. Knight, the Washington lawyer and lobbyist who was the Clinton-Gore campaign manager, was a senior staff member to Mr. Gore in the Senate and is considered his chief fund-raiser.
Mr. Gore has also had his own independent contacts with Mr. Huang, separate from Mr. Clinton's ties to him through his former employers, the Riady family of Indonesia. One year after his Presidential run, Mr. Gore, still a Senator from Tennessee, accompanied Mr. Huang and Maria L. Hsia on a trip to Taiwan that was paid for by the Fo Kwang Shan Buddhist organization.
Mr. Gore took with him Mr. Knight, then his senior staff member, and Leon S. Fuerth, who remains Mr. Gore's chief foreign policy adviser. During the visit Mr. Gore met the Taiwan's Prime Minister and visited the Venerable Master Hsing Yung at the Buddhist temple that paid for his airfare.
Lorraine Voles, Mr. Gore's spokeswoman, said the visit was partly economic, with Mr. Gore trying to sell Tennessee as a good place to do business. Ms. Voles said the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee had been instrumental in setting up the trip. Another longtime Gore adviser, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified, said that the campaign committee pushed Mr. Gore hard because it wanted a prominent senator to travel to Taiwan with California's Lieutenant Governor, Leo McCarthy, and his Asian-American financial supporters.
Mr. McCarthy, now in private business, said in an interview last week that he traveled to Taiwan that year in an effort to promote California trade in Asian markets. Asked why Mr. Gore went, he said: "I don't know. I met him over there. I'm not sure what his mission was."
Mr. Gore went on to meet with Mr. Huang at the 1993 session in Los Angeles. And last year Mr. Gore had contact with Ms. Hsia and Mr. Huang again. They were the organizers of a fund-raising lunch that he attended at a Southern California Buddhist temple, which is affiliated with the group that paid for his 1989 trip to Taiwan. The Democrats later termed the event inappropriate because of the temple's tax-exempt status, returned donations and reimbursed the temple for expenses.
Much of Mr. Gore's fund raising in 1995-96 was composed of the traditional Vice Presidential appearances before political dinners and lunches. Democratic Party records show that Mr. Gore headlined 39 party fund raisers that raised $8.74 million.
Mr. Gore, however, also held coffees at the Old Executive Office Building with fund-raisers and donors, which are more controversial because they step close to fund raising on Government property.
"Fund-raisers in the White House are illegal," Mr. Nickles, the Senator from Oklahoma, said today on "Fox News Sunday," hours before the Democrats produced his 1990 letter inviting Republicans to a reception at the Quayles' official residence.
The White House has insisted that no money was solicited at the coffees while acknowledging that those who attended could have already given money to the party or been asked some time after they were entertained. Democratic fund-raisers say that at his coffees Mr. Gore met primarily with members of the Democratic Business Council, who gave the party donations of $10,000 and $15,000. Mr. Clinton's time was reserved for bigger donors.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
A Colorful Family Made for Memoirs

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI 

 BODY:

 THE SUN AT MIDDAY
 Tales of a Mediterranean Family
 By Gini Alhadeff
 226 pages. Pantheon Books. $23. 
 Toward the end of this affecting memoir, Gini Alhadeff writes of the ability possessed by her uncle Piero and his lover to turn "life into anecdote, and anecdote into language, so that an expression we used at any time among ourselves, once remembered, could recall precisely the atmosphere of all that had surrounded it."
Ms. Alhadeff shares a similar storytelling gift, and in "The Sun at Midday," she uses it to conjure up the lives of her family members and the far-flung homes they came to inhabit in the course of a century, from the palatial house she grew up in in Egypt (its garden has since been replaced by three apartment buildings and a mosque) to the two-room apartment she now rents in Manhattan. It is a story of dislocation and exile, a story of one woman's search for her past in the interstices of familial memory.
The author, fluent in half a dozen languages, was born in Alexandria and has lived in Cairo, Khartoum, Tokyo, London and Chianti, as well as New York City. She describes herself as a kind of cultural Zelig. "I was sent to Florence and became Italian," she writes, "to England and became English, to New York and became a New Yorker, if not an American. I am the worst of the chameleons: I have swallowed several ethnic identities whole and no single one lords it over the others."
"I sometimes find it hard to distinguish between identity and mimicry," she goes on. "At this rate, it is easy to see that our origins will soon have become invisible."
The story of Ms. Alhadeff's family is a tale of multiple identities and metamorphosis -- and in a sense, the Jewish diaspora. Ms. Alhadeff's family on both her mother's and father's sides were Sephardic Jews who lived in Andalusia until the Inquisition. From there, her father's ancestors moved to Rhodes, where their business flourished: Salomon Alhadeff Fils, family legend has it, was at one time "the main commercial and banking firm in the Middle East," controlling 90 percent of the Rhodes economy, the export of cotton, sesame and figs.
Rhodes was then an Italian colony, and when Mussolini's racial laws were passed in 1938, the family relocated to Alexandria, where Ms. Alhadeff's father met and married her mother, herself the descendant of a distinguished family that had built (and lost) a fortune in cotton. The couple converted to Catholicism soon after having their first son, a decision no doubt shaped in part by the Nazis' internment of one of Mr. Alhadeff's brothers. By the 60's, the family was living in Tokyo and Ms. Alhadeff was sent to a Catholic girls school and taught to sing "Jesus wants me for a sunbeam." She says she had no idea she was Jewish until she was nearly 20 and arrived in New York.
Ms. Alhadeff does not relate these events in a straightforward manner but reveals them bit by bit through an oblique, fragmented narrative that loops backward and forward in time, doubling back on itself like a serpentine maze. Because the resulting book is so willfully elliptical, because there are so many aunts and uncles and great-grandparents, the reader frequently wishes that a family tree had been provided with the book to offer a cursory guideline to the author's myriad ancestors and their peregrinations.
Still, Ms. Alhadeff's portraits of her relatives are remarkably vivid, drawn with both the emotional insight of a novelist and a journalist's unforgiving eye. But while she does not flinch from disclosing painful secrets of her own -- including a longtime adulterous affair and the abortion of a fetus with Down syndrome -- there is a dignity and reserve to her revelations, a refusal to court self-pity that makes this book feel more like a Chekhovian rumination than one of those confessional inventories so popular in America today.
In the course of the book, Ms. Alhadeff introduces us to her cousin Pierre, who converted to Catholicism and became a priest: a priest who learned to shoot with William Burroughs and who played footsie with Robert Mapplethorpe, a priest who "drops names the way certain women put on too many jewels." We also meet Uncle Aldo's wife, Mariuccia Mandelli, who founded the fashion house Krizia in the 50's, built a business empire and acquired an island in the Caribbean.
There's Uncle Nissim, who spent a year in Auschwitz and Buchenwald and passed himself off as a Frenchman of Russian descent. There's Aunt Rachel, who calls Uncle Nissim -- now a gynecologist in Queens -- seven or eight times a day to discuss her medical complaints. And finally there's her grandmother's sister, Nelly -- a "woman whose bookshelves were lined with read and reread original editions of Corneille, Moliere, Racine" -- who moved in with the Alhadeffs and devoted herself to the care and maintenance of their underwear and socks.
Like Andre Aciman's stunning memoir "Out of Egypt" (1994), which also chronicled the life and exile of a well-to-do Alexandrian family, "The Sun at Midday" evokes a world of luxury and ease in pre-Nasser Egypt. "Everyone went to Europe in the summer and sent their cooks to the Cordon Bleu in Paris," Ms. Alhadeff's cousin Pierre recalls. Women spent their days shopping and getting fitted for new gowns; at night, they adorned themselves with jewels and furs to go to dinner. Each year, Ms. Alhadeff's maternal grandparents took friends and relatives by boat from Alexandria to Venice and back, holidays that often lasted three months.
That Alexandrian world of wealth and privilege, however, came to an abrupt end. After the 1956 Suez Canal crisis, growing anti-Semitism and the nationalization of more and more businesses forced Ms. Alhadeff's family to pack their bags once again. Her grandfather's cotton business went bankrupt, and he spent the last 20 years of his life dependent on a son-in-law and grandsons. As for the rest of the family, it dispersed to England, Italy and the United States.
Later, the 45-year marriage of Ms. Alhadeff's parents also came to a close when her father left home for a younger woman. In some respects, however, Ms. Alhadeff says their marriage isn't really over: "They had three children -- that is all that history will record: genetic continuity, and so, memory."
Memory, in this case, that has been articulated and preserved in an eloquently observed book that recreates, if not recaptures, the elusive past.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up as U.S. Rate Rise And Delay in Euro Are Seen

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most currencies yesterday, bolstered by mounting expectations for higher United States interest rates and continuing speculation that Europe's efforts to forge a single currency would be delayed.
A member of the Bundesbank's policy-making council, Ernst Welteke, told reporters that the stumbling German economy had prevented higher interest rates in Germany, but added that the weak German mark and the likelihood of higher United States rates ruled out a cut in German rates. 
 "The prospect of even more favorable interest rate differentials between the U.S. and Germany is very supportive for the dollar," said Seth Garrett, a director of foreign exchange at Credit Suisse First Boston.
In trading in New York yesterday, the dollar rose to 121.27 yen from 120.22 yen on Friday and to 1.6980 marks from 1.6903. The British pound fell to $1.6176 from $1.6295.
Many economists expect the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rate this spring, a view that gained supporters after Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, told a Senate committee on Wednesday that the rates could be increased even ahead of any inflation signs.
Mr. Welteke also said that further appreciation of the dollar against the mark was undesirable and that a delay in the proposed European economic and monetary union would bolster the mark strongly. His first comment hurt the dollar, but investors later pushed the dollar higher against the mark.
"Welteke made a couple of comments, the first of which was bullish for the mark and the second seemed to offset it," said Dennis Pettit, foreign exchange manager at the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan.
Another Bundesbank council member, Klaus-Dieter Kuhbacher, was quoted in the Berliner Zeitung as saying he was not sure the proposed European monetary union would begin in 1999 as scheduled. Those comments set off sales of Spanish pesetas and Italian lire for marks, and investors sold the mark against the dollar and the Swiss franc.
And traders in Europe said the central banks in Italy and Spain had entered the foreign exchange markets to sell marks in an effort to prop up their currencies.

HEADLINE: Campaign Hearings: Another Boondoggle?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Don't Sabotage the Hearings" (editorial, March 2) is mistaken when it assumes that the public is "weary and cynical" about campaign finance scandals. 
 Of course President Clinton rewards his friends and punishes his enemies, although not nearly enough. Yet if the President didn't raise money for his party, the other party would soon be in power. The public knows this and understands it; thus President Clinton's 60 percent approval rating.
In fact, the public is far more concerned about public schools that are deteriorating, a nonprogressive tax code that punishes labor and rewards capital, prisons that are overflowing, and an economy that continues to lay off workers making a decent living and replace them with hamburger flippers.
If Senator Fred Thompson gets the $6.5 million he's looking for to finance hearings into the Democrats' fund-raising practices, that will be $6.5 million down the tubes, right behind the untold millions wasted on Whitewater and other hearings. Here's one taxpayer who hopes that Senator Tom Daschle is able to scuttle this boondoggle.
 
RUSTY AUSTIN
Culver City, Calif., March 2, 1997

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Retreat As Economy Shows Muscle

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were battered again yesterday and remained near session lows as reports that manufacturing was showing strength added to persistent investor concern that the Federal Reserve was inching closer to an increase in interest rates.
The 30-year bond dropped 11/32, to a price of 97 14/32 to yield 6.83 percent, up from 6.80 percent on Friday, and the highest yield level since Jan. 30, when it was 6.86 percent. 
 To the relief of dealers and traders, the numbers in yesterday's economic reports did not set off a full-scale flight by investors nervously awaiting testimony by the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, to the House Banking Committee tomorrow. Last week he roiled the markets by telling the Senate that a pre-emptive policy move to avert inflation might be in order, and the markets have been on the defensive since.
Market participants are now preparing for the Labor Department's release on Friday of February's payroll data, including the number of jobs that were added to the economy last month.
Bond prices fell yesterday morning as investors sold on a report that American incomes grew an unexpected three-tenths of a percent in January, and consumer spending increased by a larger-than-expected seven-tenths of a percent. It suggested that the first quarter was picking up more strength than people had thought. Personal income was expected to be unchanged, with spending up half a percent.
The National Association of Purchasing Management's index of manufacturing activity rose to 53.1, from 52 in January, higher than the 52.3 forecast by some economists, suggesting that manufacturing was expanding. All components within the index were up, and that led to increased speculation that the Fed might move to push up rates at its monetary policy meeting on March 25.
Gary Thayer, senior economist at A. G. Edwards & Sons, St. Louis, said: "The numbers today, particularly the purchasing managers, still show we have a well-balanced economy, but there are potential problems down the road, including rising commodity prices, rising wages, which we have seen in previous reports. But the concern now is focused on the Friday payroll data."
Some market participants, discounting the prospect of a rate rise, have suggested that Mr. Greenspan used his testimony as the alternative to a tightening.
Mr. Thayer agreed that "Mr. Greenspan would like to maintain current policy as long as he can without raising rates," and said that "so far the Fed has been successful in promoting growth with very little inflation." But market participants are a pessimistic lot and have begun to price in the increased risk of an interest rate increase, he added.
Looking ahead to Friday, Mr. Thayer said he expected a healthy increase in the payroll number, which he said was not necessarily something to be alarmed about. "The unemployment rate may come down, and we may see high consumer confidence, usually a sign of a good employment situation," Mr. Thayer said. "We might see a 7 percent long-bond yield, but not too much higher in the short run, since foreign yields are still very low relative to ours and that may attract foreign money to our market."
Yesterday's Treasury bill auction was, as expected, a bit on the weak side, traders said. The three-month bills were awarded at an average rate of 5.10 percent, up from 5.01 percent last week, while the six-month maturity was awarded at an average rate of 5.19 percent, up from 5.03 percent a week ago. Rates have risen because of the risk of an interest rate increase by the Fed, which would affect short-term rate first, then ripple out to the longer maturities. The number of bids to cover were low for both maturities.
The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new three-month and six-month bills:

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Asia's Giant, After Detours, Takes Familiar Growth Path

SERIES: THE CHINA BUSINESS: Second of two articles.

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: SUZHOU, China

 BODY:
On what was a cow patch not long ago, young women in white gloves and jackets snap together pieces of plastic with a pop that announces the completion of a computer mouse, each a tiny symbol of China's growing strength as an exporter. About 40 percent of these devices are exported to the United States, including four of every five computer mice sold with Apple computers.
The women at this factory, run by a Taiwan subsidiary of Swiss-based Logitech International, earn an average of only $75 a month, but that is still more than they made on the farm. Logitech's business, by combining local labor with imported parts and management, is growing fast: Exports zoomed to $160 million in 1996, from $500,000 in 1994, the year the factory opened. 
 All along China's coast, and inland as well, thousands of companies are churning out simple electronics like the computer parts produced at Logitech, attracted by this kind of cheap, reliable labor. And these goods, along with the footwear and the toys in which China dominates global production, are fueling a tremendous surge in exports. That, in turn, has brought untold economic benefits and personal freedoms to ordinary Chinese citizens.
China's total exports reached $151 billion in 1996, a thirtyfold increase in 20 years. During some months last year, American trade figures show, China actually surpassed Japan as the nation with the greatest trade surplus with the United States.
To anxious Americans, it may seem ominously familiar. In Washington, where China is again a front-burner concern after the death of Deng Xiaoping, the question is heard over and over again: Is China becoming the next Japan, threatening American manufacturing jobs?
The tempting answer, often heard in Congress, is that America's trade problems with Beijing in 1997 look much like its problems with Tokyo in 1976.
American trade officials have contributed to such thinking by contending that China's economy operates with a host of protectionist trade barriers and by calculating that the American trade deficit with China has more than tripled in five years -- from $12.7 billion in 1991 to $39.5 billion last year. Only Japan's surplus with the United States -- $47.6 billion -- was larger last year.
Yet the differences with Japan are profound. And even the true size of China's trade imbalance with the United States is debatable. Chinese officials count it at $10 billion, and independent economists place the truth somewhere between the American and Chinese figures because each side fiddles with the way it counts goods that pass through Hong Kong.
Whatever trade statistics are used, they offer an incomplete picture of China's overall economy and its commerce with the rest of the world. China's emergence as an export powerhouse is as much a measure of broad economic trends throughout Asia as it is a consequence of Beijing's own trade policies. Unlike Japan, with years of stubborn and huge trade surpluses, China has alternated in recent years between surpluses and deficits.
Many goods once made elsewhere in Asia -- in Japan, Taiwan, Hong Kong and South Korea -- are now produced in foreign-owned factories, like Logitech's, that have been moved to Chinese territory. First it was toys and footwear, and now it is electronics. Even by American figures, the growing deficit with China is offset to a large extent by a declining American deficit with other Asian nations. Over the last 10 years, China's annual trade imbalance with the United States has risen by $36 billion as the combined annual American trade imbalance with Taiwan, South Korea, Hong Kong and Singapore has fallen by $26 billion.
Although Chinese products may compete on a broader scale with American goods in the future, the gains by China so far have generally not translated into job losses in the United States. China's leading exports are products that have not been produced in large quantity by American factories for more than a decade. Nor are the Chinese products competing with American goods to the degree that Japanese autos, steel and machine tools -- all industries nurtured by Tokyo -- have in the past.
"China is open to foreign direct investment and has low wages, so a lot of companies are moving production there," said Nicholas R. Lardy, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution. "They're not selling us high-technology goods that are produced in a hothouse set up by the Government. This is pretty low-spectrum stuff. It's mainly an assembly function."
China is still full of obstacles to free trade. In addition to contending with a maddeningly disorganized bureaucracy, foreign manufacturers must bow to Government demands that they share technological expertise. Foreign-owned companies are also required to export a certain percentage of what they produce and must ship goods overseas only through Chinese trading companies. And China provides huge subsidies to state-owned industries, which are shielded from competition.
Chinese officials have offered to reduce trade barriers in exchange for membership in the World Trade Organization, a step that would allow the country to enjoy low to zero tariffs. But in China there is always a vast gulf between changing a law and enforcing the change.
Still, over the long run the United States has enjoyed benefits from China's export boom, even if they are not as plentiful as American policy makers desire.
By granting "most favored nation" trade status and the low tariffs that come with it, the United States has steadily encouraged China to develop its economy, in part so that China would eventually open itself to American goods. And it has, as any visitor to China today can see: In recent years, Motorola has sold more beepers, Coca-Cola more soft drinks and Boeing more airplanes than have any of their competitors in China, foreign or domestic. Of those three products, however, only airplanes are reflected in trade figures because the beepers and soft drinks are produced within China.
China, in the process, has knit itself into the global economy to a greater extent than ever before in a trading history that reaches back to silk routes and Marco Polo. Logitech is an example: Each mouse that the company sells overseas is counted as a Chinese export, but profits go to its shareholders, including the Italian and Swiss founders who met as students at Stanford University. Logitech International has applied to sell shares in the United States later this year.
"China-U.S. trade has become all wrapped up in politics, and you can debate it this way and that," said Qiu Xiangrong, a Chinese economist. "Yet trade is basically about buying and selling, so it's always good for both sides."
 
Transformations
Opening Up Jobs And Workers' Eyes
Over the last two decades, steadily growing trade has helped transform what was an isolated Maoist state not long ago. Money making has become the priority of most government-run enterprises, replacing the traditional emphasis on feeding, clothing and housing workers. Opening China to trade, and the information that comes with it, has substantially improved the lives and liberties of hundreds of millions of Chinese, even if many are still poor and the Government remains authoritarian.
Outside Shanghai, Zhu Wenjun says her life has changed immeasurably since she quit being a schoolteacher earning $25 a month and joined the Nanhui Foreign Trade Corporation, where she is a $360-a-month office manager.
Blushing slightly as she admitted enjoying her higher income, Ms. Zhu, 45, said that working at a company that exports toys and garments has opened her eyes to people, ideas and fashions she did not know existed.
"Now I am talking with people overseas and thinking about economic issues," Ms. Zhu said. "It used to be that when you became a teacher, you were a teacher for life. Now you can switch jobs."
Asked about the downside to her more urban, more modern life, she said: "My son is 18, and he's so spoiled. He only wants to wear designer brands."
In a sense, the flowering of trade with China is an extension of American intentions in Asia that date to the 1950's and 1960's, when the United States threw open its markets to exports from Taiwan, Singapore and Hong Kong to help counter Communism through economic growth.
In 1972, when Richard M. Nixon became the first American President to visit the People's Republic of China, ordinary Chinese citizens risked imprisonment for communicating with foreigners. In 1975, the year before Mao Zedong died, China's combined imports and exports totaled just $4.75 billion, and its role in the world's trade was smaller than it had been 50 years earlier.
But after Mr. Deng began overhauling China's economy in 1978, foreign trade companies were set up to coordinate dealings with outsiders, and profit incentives gave Chinese companies a reason to make garments and toys that could be exported. At the same time, China began allowing imports of foreign cars, airplanes and consumer goods.
Washington took steps to assist China's economic development. Congress bestowed most-favored trade status on China in 1980, a year after President Jimmy Carter established diplomatic relations, even though China's restrictions on emigration violated the standards set for the granting of lower import tariffs.
By the early 1990's, China was attracting significant amounts of foreign investment, which totaled $170 billion by the end of 1996, though Western and Japanese companies have often found doing business in China dauntingly bureaucratic and unpredictable. They have moved slowly, and have been outpaced by investors from Hong Kong, and later from Taiwan, whose language and culture are as helpful as their modest-sized goals, like the assembly of toys and shoes in southern China.
Outside investment has improved China's ability to make export-quality products. As a result, the percentage of its exports made by enterprises with foreign investment grew steadily, from 1 percent in 1985 to 40 percent in 1996. And, because foreign operations are more closely regulated by Chinese authorities, the factories run by outside investors almost always have better working conditions than those in their lackluster state-owned counterparts.
Some Chinese trading companies have tried to sell goods made with prison labor, but the scale of such trade has always been hard to determine. American investigators have been unable to prove that prison-made products have actually been exported to the United States, in part because they have been routinely denied access to prisons.
Huge portions of China's imports, meanwhile, apparently go uncounted. Tens of billions of dollars worth of consumer goods, notably cars and cigarettes, are believed to be smuggled into China each year to avoid onerous import duties. Chinese officials admit that high tariffs led to cigarette smuggling so rampant that in 1994, out of 80 billion American and other foreign-brand cigarettes that were sold in China, not a single one was legally imported.
With the exception of a scant increase last year, China's imports from the United States have shown a strong and steady rise, mainly in such costly items as aircraft and power generation equipment. Beijing says its American imports hit $17 billion in 1996, although Washington says $12 billion. But because exports to the United States increased even faster -- Beijing puts them at $27 billion in 1996; Washington says $50 billion -- the trade gap has grown steadily. And Chinese exports are highly visible to ordinary Americans, whether they are buying clothing or electronics.
"Americans may feel like their stores are full of things made in China, but they're all small items like shoes and toys," said Ma Xuejie, a trade official in Shanghai. "We're buying airplanes and machinery from America, and think how many shoes we have to sell to pay for one airplane."
 
Transplants
Taking Factories From Others in Asia
The way exports are rising at Logitech in Suzhou, 50 miles west of Shanghai, an airplane should be affordable this year and perhaps two next year.
"All the manufacturing is coming over here from Taiwan now," said Chet Wong, plant manager at Logitech. "We're ramping up pretty fast."
Eager for foreign investment, local officials in Suzhou, an ancient city once known for its exotic gardens, staked out a chunk of farmland and promised high-technology companies a steady supply of reliable, inexpensive factory workers, and a minimum of bureaucratic interference.
Acer Inc., Taiwan's computer giant, opened a plant in Suzhou last year to produce computer monitors and keyboards that it once made in Taiwan. It began by making 200,000 keyboards a month last year, and expects to make 4 million a month by the end of this year.
"We would never have come here five years ago," said J. S. Pan, Acer's deputy managing director here. "The infrastructure was too weak. But now we can do it. Taiwan is too expensive."
With the movement of assembly-oriented production to China from other Asian countries, the changes for ordinary people are palpable.
Ye Xiuying, 26, runs a small clock shop in Dongguan, a city in Guangdong Province. Her fortunes have followed those of that area in southern China, which boomed in the mid-1980's but has slowed in recent years.
On a recent afternoon, business was slack enough that Ms. Ye, a cheerful woman with puffy cheeks and thin wire-rimmed glasses, could sip green tea as she told her story.
Assigned to a farm-machinery factory by her high school when she finished eight years ago, she found the work boring and the pay -- $35 a month -- "really pathetic." She married a fellow worker after persuading her father to lend them a few thousand dollars to start their own tiny clothing factory. They hired half a dozen seamstresses and started making cotton skirts that they sold to Hong Kong, for export to the United States and Europe.
"Everything was moving so fast, I learned new things every day," said Ms. Ye, recalling the excitement of running a business and of seeing her income climb to $1,200 a month.
She was able to buy her own home, for $10,000, and to travel overseas, something rare for Chinese until recently, but now available to millions. She went to Thailand last year on a six-day tour. Next she wants to visit the United States, though a three-week tour available to residents of Dongguan costs $6,000, too expensive for Ms. Ye.
More important, she was able to have a second child. That is forbidden under China's one-child policy, but enforcement varies from town to town and in Dongguan it takes the form of a one-time fine of $1,800, which Ms. Ye said was well worth it.
"I wanted a girl," she said. "I already had a boy."
When the economy here slowed in 1994, Ms. Ye and her husband had to shut their operation. He now manages a company making plastic shells for cigarette lighters that are exported, and she runs the clock shop. Still, they are far better off than they were as factory workers.

HEADLINE: Stock Market Posts Gains, Ending 3-Day Losing Streak

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks rose yesterday, snapping a three-session losing streak that followed a warning by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, last Wednesday about high stock prices and raising the possibility of higher interest rates.
The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 41.18 points, to 6,918.92 after losing more than 160 points the last three sessions. The 30-stock average, which set a record of 7,067.46 on Feb. 18, was led higher by Du Pont, which gained 4 1/8, to 111 3/8, after its board approved a 2-for-1 stock split. 
 In the broader market, advancing issues led declines 1,292 to 1,270, on moderate volume of 437.2 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.
Investors were also rudely surprised yesterday when the AT&T Corporation outlined plans to enter new local telephone and wireless markets that will require huge spending, eating into earnings; indeed, the company warned that its first-quarter earnings per share could drop about 10 percent below the fourth quarter's 76 cents. AT&T fell 3 1/8, to 36 3/4.
Weakness in the bond market, where the price of the 30-year bond dropped 11/32, to 97 14/32, coupled with AT&T's decline, made the stock market's moderate gains appear all the more impressive, analysts said.
"You had two major negatives today and the market was still able to basically reverse course," said Peter Cardillo, director of research at Westfalia Investments.
When buyers did emerge, they descended on the technology stocks, which had led the market to highs in mid-February and lately have led it back down. Intel rose 4, to 145 7/8, on optimism that chip makers may be on the verge of recovery with the worst of their inventory problems past. I.B.M. was up 1 3/8, to 145 1/8, and Microsoft rose 2, to 99 1/2.
Analysts called the rebound encouraging but stopped short of predicting an end to the market's recent weakness.
"It's going to be a while before these stocks regain their luster," said Joseph Barthel, chief investment strategist at Fahnestock & Company.
Analysts said that Mr. Greenspan's scheduled appearance before the House Banking Committee tomorrow and a key monthly employment report due on Friday were likely to preclude any meaningful rise in stocks in the meantime.
But with the broad market following technology stocks higher and shrugging off the AT&T surprise, analysts said it was clear that at least one major change had occurred on Wall Street.
"I'm not certain AT&T is viewed as a bellwether anymore," Mr. Barthel said. "Now we look to companies like Intel and Microsoft."
Among individual issues, Conrail Inc. surged 7 1/8, to 111 5/8, as expectation mounted that a four-month takeover battle for control of the railroad was nearing an end. Conrail said its board was meeting yesterday to discuss the company's options. Analysts predicted Conrail's assets would be divided between its rival bidders, the CSX Corporation and the Norfolk Southern Corporation.
CSX jumped 2 7/8, to 49, and Norfolk Southern rose 2 3/4, to 93 7/8.
BHC Financial Inc. soared 11 7/8, to 31 7/8, after the company agreed to be acquired by Fiserv Inc., which climbed 3 7/8, to 36 5/8.
COR Therapeutics Inc. slid 2 15/16, to 9 3/8, after a Food and Drug Administration advisory panel recommended against approving intrifiban, a derivative of rattlesnake venom the company hoped to market to treat some heart ailments.
The Nasdaq composite index rose 2.18 points, 1,311.18.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 4.49 points, to 795.31. The American Stock Exchange index edged up 0.58, to 594.82.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index of all listed common stocks rose 1.83, to 417.34.
The Wilshire Associates Equity Index -- the market value of Big Board, American and Nasdaq issues -- was 7,591.522, up 32.105 or 0.42 percent.

HEADLINE: Clinton Figures On the Budget Are Questioned

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 3

 BODY:
The Congressional Budget Office said today that President Clinton's budget plan would leave the Government with a deficit of $69 billion in 2002, rather than a surplus of $17 billion, as Mr. Clinton asserted last month.
Most of the discrepancy is caused by the Administration's having more optimistic economic assumptions. 
 In addition, the Congressional Budget Office said that Mr. Clinton's proposals to slow the growth of Medicare would not save as much as he has predicted. The program finances health care for 38 million people who are elderly or disabled, and the conflict over it was a large factor in the stalemate between Mr. Clinton and Congress in 1995 and 1996.
Commenting on the report, Representative John R. Kasich, the Ohio Republican who is chairman of the House Budget Committee, said, "The President should submit a new budget, one that is in balance in 2002."
Representative John M. Spratt Jr. of South Carolina, the ranking Democrat on the Budget Committee, said the new figures from the budget office, especially the Medicare numbers, were disheartening.
Mr. Clinton submitted his budget on Feb. 6. The nonpartisan budget office reviews the President's plan on behalf of Congress. It often disagrees with the White House.
On Feb. 13, the director of the office, June E. O'Neill, said the Administration's plan would produce a deficit of at least $50 billion in 2002. But that estimate was based only on differences in economic assumptions. Today's estimates reflect a more detailed analysis of the substance of the President's proposals.
With no change in law, the Congressional Budget Office said, the Federal deficit would rise to $153 billion in 2002, from $107 billion last year. Mr. Clinton's proposals would cut the deficit in that year by 55 percent, the office said.
Mr. Clinton has said that his Medicare proposals would save $34.6 billion in 2002 and a total of $100 billion from 1998 through 2002. But the Congressional Budget Office said that Mr. Clinton's proposals would save $29 billion in 2002 and $82 billion over all five years.
In his budget, Mr. Clinton proposed expanding Medicare benefits and cutting payments to doctors, hospitals and other providers. The Congressional office found that the new benefits would cost more than Mr. Clinton said, while the cuts in payments to providers would save less.
Without a change in law, the office said, the deficit would rise to $121 billion next year and under Mr. Clinton's plan it would be $145 billion.

HEADLINE: Report Shows Strengthening For Industry American Incomes And Spending Up

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Activity among American manufacturers improved in February from a month earlier as orders and production accelerated, the National Association of Purchasing Management said yesterday.
A separate report, by the Commerce Department, showed that Americans' incomes unexpectedly grew during January, prompting consumers to increase their spending. Much of the rise in incomes, however, was attributed to special factors. 
 The two reports showed enough economic strength to prompt concerns that the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates soon.
A third set of economic data issued yesterday showed that construction spending rose four-tenths of 1 percent in January.
The National Association of Purchasing Management's index rose to 53.1 last month from 52 during January. A reading of 50 or more means manufacturing is expanding, while one below 50 signals a slowdown. Analysts had forecast that the index would rise to only 52.3 in February.
 The closely watched price index, an indication of the inflation rate, rose to 55.1 in February from 51.4 in December. That suggested that more manufacturers were paying higher prices.
 In the report on income and spending, the Commerce Department said personal income rose three-tenths of 1 percent in January, slower than December's increase, which was revised to seven-tenths of 1 percent from eight-tenths of 1 percent. But it was in contrast to the expectations of analysts, who had forecast, on average, that January's report would show no change in incomes.
The Commerce Department said, however, that January's increase was inflated by special factors, including cost-of-living increases for Federal programs like Social Security and pay increases for civilian and military personnel. Without the special factors, personal income increased less than one-tenth of 1 percent, the department said.
Personal spending grew seven-tenths of 1 percent in January, faster than December's gain of two-tenths of 1 percent, which was revised downward from half a percent, and above analysts' forecasts for a January rise of half a percent.
Economists have said that Americans will continue to spend money and that their willingness is being fueled by more than rising incomes. The stock market's boom, job creation and near-record levels of confidence in the economy are also cited by economists.
In today's report, the Commerce Department also said that disposable income, or the money left over after taxes, increased six-tenths of 1 percent in January, while the savings rate -- savings as a percentage of after-tax income -- stood at 5.4 percent, unchanged from the previous month.
In the report on construction activity, the Commerce Department said spending rose four-tenths of 1 percent in January, to an annual rate of $589.8 billion. Spending declined nine-tenths of 1 percent in December as harsh weather in many regions kept builders indoors. December's decline was originally reported as seven-tenths of 1 percent. Analysts had expected a gain of one-tenth of 1 percent in January's construction spending.
In all of 1996, construction spending rose 4 percent, to $568.7 billion.

HEADLINE: Charles Dederich, 83, Synanon Founder, Dies

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
Charles E. Dederich, a reformed alcoholic who founded Synanon, the drug rehabilitation program that won widespread acclaim and amassed great wealth before it became associated with violence, died on Friday in Kaweah Delta Hospital in Visalia, Calif. Mr. Dederich, who lived in Visalia, was 83.
Mr. Dederich had several strokes beginning in the late 1980's. The cause of death was cardiorespiratory failure, said his wife, Ginny. 
 Founded in 1958 with a $33 unemployment check in a seedy flat in Ocean Park, Calif., Synanon eventually attracted thousands of drug addicts and dropouts from the social turbulence of the 1960's to therapeutic communities for a course of tough, innovative treatment.
"Crime is stupid, delinquency is stupid and the use of narcotics is stupid," Mr. Dederich once said. "What Synanon is dealing with is addiction to stupidity."
Synanon and its methods became the subject of books, articles, television documentaries and a 1965 film, "Synanon," which starred Edmond O'Brien as Mr. Dederich and Eartha Kitt as his third wife, Bettye.
By 1980, with millions of dollars in donations from American businesses, vast real estate holdings, overseas branches and its own lucrative enterprises Synanon, which was exempt from Federal and state taxes as a charitable trust, had compiled assets of $30 million to $50 million, according to the estimates of law-enforcement authorities.
But the organization, which claimed credit for thousands of rehabilitations, evolved from a renowned drug rehabilitation agency into what California officials described as a wealthy, authoritarian cult.
Accounts of violence and the insistence by Mr. Dederich on forced vasectomies for men in Synanon, mandatory abortions for women and the divorce of more than 230 of its married couples who were to switch to other partners led to investigations and unfavorable newspaper publicity.
In 1980, Mr. Dederich pleaded no contest to charges that he and two members of Synanon's security force had conspired to commit murder by placing a four-and-a-half-foot rattlesnake in the mailbox of a lawyer who had sued the organization.
The lawyer, Paul Morantz, who was acting on behalf of former Synanon members and relatives of members who maintained they were being held in the organization against their will, was bitten and hospitalized for six days.
Mr. Dederich, who said he was in poor health, was sentenced to five years' probation, fined $5,000 and ordered not to participate actively in running Synanon.
By the middle of the 1980's, when the organization declared itself a religion, was condemned by the Government for a corporate policy of "terror and violence" and was stripped of its tax-exempt status, Synanon was declining in influence and prestige.
Charles Edwin Dederich, who was named for his father and known generally as Chuck, was born in Toledo, Ohio, on March 22, 1913.
When he was 4, his father, an alcoholic, was killed in an automobile accident. He was 8 when a brother died and 12 when his mother, the former Agnes Kountz, a classical concert singer, married a man he loathed.
Mr. Dederich was drinking heavily before he graduated from high school. He dropped out of the University of Notre Dame after 18 months because of poor grades and lost good jobs and two wives because of his drinking. When he was 43, he joined Alcoholics Anonymous, and after a while he turned his apartment in Ocean Park into a sanctuary first for alcoholics and soon for drug addicts as well.
"I say this with as much humility as I am capable, which isn't very much, but when I sit down and start to talk, people start gathering," he said in a 1980 deposition. "It is inevitable. No matter where I do that, it just happens. I can't stop it."
Underlying Synanon's approach was the conviction that addicts were not adults, and it was futile to try to cure them with adult procedures.
Mr. Dederich discarded Alcoholics Anonymous's emphasis on religion and built a methodology around a therapeutic community, a tough, disciplined, drug-free environment with a dash of tender loving care.
Attack therapy was an essential component of the treatment. Three times weekly, members met in small groups, for violently outspoken discussions, called games or synanons, in which they released pent-up hostilities.
On Sept. 15, 1958, Synanon -- a name coined when an addict stumbled over the words "seminar" and "symposium," gave up and called them "synanon" -- was incorporated as a nonprofit California foundation with 40 members.
Mr. Dederich's widow said it was in the early days of Synanon that he created the saying, "Today is the first day of the rest of your life."
Mr. Dederich was married four times. Two of his wives left him because of his drinking. His third wife, Bettye, died in 1977. Besides his widow, the former Ginny Schorin, whom he married nearly 20 years ago, Mr. Dederich is survived by a son from his first marriage, Chuck, of Visalia; a daughter from his second marriage, Jady Dederich of San Francisco, and three grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Greenwich Declines to Put Its Manicured Hand Out

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER 

DATELINE: GREENWICH, Conn., March 3

 BODY:
Practically every town in America pines for Federal money to enhance its appearance, and local politicians campaign on their success in corralling grants. But the political leaders here have decided to thumb their noses at $500,000 in Federal money that would have brightened this town's main shopping street.
The money was there for the asking. But most of the town's leaders said they decided it would be unseemly for a town as wealthy as Greenwich to accept scarce Federal dollars for luxuries like wrought-iron benches, quaint street lamps and potted plants when there are far poorer towns in need of basic commodities like decent shelter. 
 It is more than a decision of conscience, Greenwich leaders say. They are also making a political point -- one they would like the nation to hear -- that too much Federal money is available for relative frivolities.
"If we're going to balance the Federal budget," said James G. Boutelle, who is a member of the town's legislature, the 240-member Representative Town Meeting, "you need to say no to pork. It's easy to criticize somebody else's pork, but when it comes to the bacon in your own backyard, you've got to be able to say no also."
The $500,000 was available under the Federal Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act, which pays for improvements to highways, streets and rail and transit systems. While some Federal money is geared to income level, the money from Istea (pronounced "ice tea") is available equally to the South Bronx and Greenwich. Recent Istea grants in the region have been used to restore the concourse ceiling at Grand Central Terminal and for Sleepy Hollow Landing in North Tarrytown, N.Y.
The streetscape money could theoretically help a rundown stretch of Tremont Avenue in the Bronx attract new merchants, but Greenwich does not need to attract new merchants. The tony mile-long shopping strip does not have a vacant store. As Greenwich leaders saw it, retail shops that sold $400 pocketbooks, and outposts of upscale chains like Ralph Lauren, could afford to do their own fixing up.
"If I as a citizen woke up and read that the Federal Government was going to spend half a million dollars on planting new palm trees along Rodeo Drive, I'd be angry, and I don't see this as being very different from that," said Mr. Boutelle, who was state chairman of Ross Perot's 1992 Presidential campaign.
The decision to rely on Greenwich's own resources was popular today along Greenwich Avenue. "It's good to see communities with a conscience," said Bill McCoy, a lawyer who lives in Queens but works at Price Waterhouse here. "Hearing this makes me feel a whole lot better about this community. However, it makes you wonder, what is the government criteria for handing out money?"
Angie Sall, who lives in Greenwich and was shopping for baby accessories at the Whitney shop, said, "I think the town should be responsible for its own improvements."
One dissenter was Trudi Fackler, a travel agent from Purchase, N.Y., who was shopping at Saks.
"I'm so sick of the sanctimonious attitude," she said. "I believe for life to be pleasant, there should be beauty. Anyway if this money doesn't go toward something beautiful, what will it go for? Are they being noble here in Greenwich or what?"
The project, of course, had its proponents, chief among them the Chamber of Commerce and Thomas Ragland, the First Selectman, the equivalent of mayor in Greenwich. Mr. Ragland, an architect, contended that Greenwich Avenue had experienced a 25 percent vacancy rate in 1990 and that its economy could be threatened again if it did not take the necessary precautions.
"The town sends $1 billion down to Washington, D.C., in tax revenues, and I don't think that getting $500,000 back is the end of the world," he said.
The idea for a $750,000 renovation of the shopping strip germinated in 1994, and officials soon obtained a promise from Federal and state officials that $500,000 in Istea money would be available.
All that was needed was approval by the town's legislature. Last May, it rejected the move. Then, two weeks ago, Mr. Ragland and other supporters tried to restart the project by asking for an initial grant of $60,000 of Federal planning money. But the town's Board of Estimate and Taxation immediately turned that down before the legislature even got a chance to vote it down again.
Now the only way the street can be beautified is with town and private funds. To make sure that everyone understands that the town is unalterably opposed to spending Federal dollars on beautification of an affluent boulevard, Marie Hertzig, a member of the Representative Town Meeting and chairman of its Budget Overview Committee, is composing a committee letter to Federal and state legislators.
"Lack of resources should be the first requirement of eligibility of funds," a draft of her letter says. "Unfortunately, the only requirement is a municipality's ability to get an application in on time. The result of which is that wealthy communities such as Greenwich have the ability to squander away funds for possible frivolous projects at the expense of more needy towns."

HEADLINE: Welcoming Arafat, Clinton Rebukes Israel

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 3

 BODY:
With Yasir Arafat at his side, President Clinton delivered a mild but relatively rare rebuke of Israel today, saying the Israeli Government's decision last week to allow construction of thousands of new homes for Jews in East Jerusalem had created "mistrust" and could damage the peace effort in the region.
The President made his remarks as he began an extended meeting this morning with Mr. Arafat, the Palestinian leader, who raised the subject of the new Jewish housing in a tone that Mr. Clinton's spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, later described as "very concerned and emotional." 
 Today's meeting was the sixth between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Arafat, but it had added significance as the first meeting held directly between the two men without the presence of other Middle East leaders, or, as Mr. McCurry put it, "in the context of some other gathering."
Mr. Arafat's meeting at the White House came on a day when Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, as well as in East Jerusalem, took part in a general strike to protest the Israeli decision to build the first of 2,500 of 6,500 homes on a hill in East Jerusalem known in Arabic as Jabal Abu Ghneim and in Hebrew as Har Homa.
Sitting beside Mr. Arafat in the Oval Office, Mr. Clinton said it was important for the Israelis and Palestinians "to be building confidence and working together" as the peace talks move forward and then lent his voice to the chorus of international criticism of the new housing.
"I would prefer the decision not have been made, because I don't think it builds confidence," Mr. Clinton said. "I think it builds mistrust, and I wish that it had not been made."
In meetings with Mr. Arafat and in public remarks, the White House seemed eager to lend its support and encouragement to the Palestinian leader -- in part to shore up the peace effort, which has lagged again since the brief burst of enthusiasm after the agreement in January that led to the withdrawal of Israeli forces from Hebron.
Mr. Arafat went on to meet separately with Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, as well as Secretary of Treasury Robert E. Rubin and the director of the Agency for International Development, Brian Atwood. At lunch at the State Department, the Americans and Mr. Arafat's delegations held lengthy discussions on increasing investments in the Palestinian territories.
The State Department then announced the creation of a joint committee -- like the ones the United States has with Russia, South Africa and Egypt -- that is to meet regularly to discuss diplomatic, economic and cultural concerns.
Neither the President nor his aides discussed what the United States would do -- or could do -- to reverse the decision by the Government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. The Clinton Administration, like those those before it, has opposed Jewish settlements in the territories captured by Israel in 1967. And Administration officials had quietly urged Mr. Netanyahu's cabinet beforehand not to move ahead with the housing project in East Jerusalem, which Israeli seized from Jordan in the 1967 war.
While he delivered a rebuke, Mr. Clinton also made clear that the United States' role was that of mediator, helping but not taking sides. In answering another question -- on whether the United States should, as many in Congress have demanded, recognize Jerusalem as Israel's capital -- Mr. Clinton said the United States should avoid staking a position on a matter that will be part of the "final status" talks between the Israelis and Palestinians.
"I think that would be a big mistake," he said.
But officials portrayed Mr. Clinton's remarks on the housing project, which echoed those made by White House and State Department spokesmen last week, as a subtle but significant warning to the Israelis not to take steps to provoke the Palestinians or throw up obstacles to the peace effort.
"We really rolled out the carpet for Arafat," an Administration official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. At the same time, the official said, the President's remarks were an effort to show "that we're a little frustrated with Netanyahu."
Mr. Arafat, for his part, said the new Israeli construction in East Jerusalem, which the Palestinians hope to make the capital of a Palestinian state, was intended "to squeeze and to isolate Jerusalem." But he stopped short of warnings by other Palestinian leaders that the housing in East Jerusalem could lead to violent protests.
Today's meeting with Mr. Arafat followed one the President had with Mr. Netanyahu last month. And it precedes a series of meetings with Middle Eastern leaders in which the Administration hopes to restore momentum to the peace effort. President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and King Hussein of Jordan are scheduled to come for meetings with Mr. Clinton and others later this month.
