HEADLINE: 4,100 New Rooms at the Inn? Barely Enough, Some Say

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO 

 BODY:
As New York continues to bask in a tourism boom, there has been a steady stream of announcements of new hotel projects. With last week's news that a French luxury hotel is planned for midtown, there are now about 4,100 rooms on the drawing board, and that's on top of the more than 500 rooms that were added in recent months with the opening of the SoHo Grand and the Trump International Hotel and Tower.
Despite the number of rooms planned, analysts say that New York, which now has the highest occupancy rate and the largest number of visitors in at least 30 years, could easily support an infusion of 5,000 to 10,000. 
 But according to industry officials and analysts, that many rooms will probably not open in New York. Because of the expense of developing hotels, the difficulty of financing, the shortage of sites and, perhaps most importantly, the potential for a quicker return on high-end apartment buildings, hotels are still not the first choice of many developers.
"If there is a land site, I would say people are more prone to do residential than a hotel right now because it's easier to finance," said Howard L. Michaels, chairman of the Carlton Group, a commercial brokerage firm in Manhattan.
The 4,100 rooms that are planned are spread across 10 projects. It will be five years before all are on the market, however, and the gain is diminished by the loss of a few major properties. The 428-room Dorset Hotel closed last summer after being bought by the Museum of Modern Art for its expansion, and the St. Moritz and the Mayfair, with 880 rooms between them, are to become luxury residential buildings. The city is left, then, with about 2,800 rooms in the pipeline.
"We're essentially flat," said John A. Fox, a senior vice president of PKF Consulting, an international hotel and real estate consulting firm. "When you're talking about a city that has 60,000 hotel rooms, that's a drop in the bucket. It won't have a material impact on the city's occupancy rate."
Given current demand, Mr. Fox said, the city could absorb as many as 10,000 new rooms. Such an infusion would depress the average occupancy rate though not to a point where the hotel industry stops turning a profit. But, he acknowledged, the economics of hotel development might not justify that kind of growth.
"Hotel investors were burned in the boom of the late 80's," said Richard M. Kielar, a senior vice president of the Tishman Realty and Construction Company in Manhattan, "and now they look very closely at the exact location and the overall potential for bookings."
Steven C. Witkoff, who is part of a development team converting an office building at 866 Third Avenue, at 52d Street, into a hotel, agreed. "People are a little gun-shy of developing ground-up hotels because of the inherently cyclical nature of the business," Mr. Witkoff said.
The cost of renovating an existing structure, he explained, can be almost half that of building from scratch, but there simply are not many good sites available.
Hotel owners, themselves, do not want a flood of more hotels. They feel they have fought hard to get to this point of profitability -- winning a reduction in both the state and city occupancy tax in 1994 and trumpeting New York City to Americans and foreigners alike. In addition to the average occupancy rate, which hit 81.8 percent last year, the average daily room rate is at an all-time high, having jumped to $175 last year from $135 in 1991, PKF Consulting said.
"New York is filling the rooms it has and does not need an influx of 3,000 or 5,000 more rooms," said Joseph E. Spinnato, president of the Hotel Association of New York City. "People say you can't get a room before Christmas. But that's a phenomenon going on even in bad years. To add 5,000 more rooms that are going to stay vacant the rest of the year is silly."
The hotel industry's current success came about quite quickly. In 1991, the citywide average occupancy rate sagged to 67.6 percent, the lowest point since 1975. Several major hotel projects conceived in the robust 1980's opened around 1990, just as the recession was bearing down on the New York region.
But at the end of 1993, the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau started to notice increases in airport arrivals and hotel occupancy rates. And the numbers kept rising, due to lower hotel taxes, reduced crime, an improving economy and favorable exchange rates, hotel and tourism officials say.
Analysts say it would be almost impossible for today's overall average occupancy rate to go much higher because of the business's seasonal nature.
"There's nothing within the New York lodging industry that's going to cause its demise because new supply is fairly modest," said Arthur Adler, a partner of the hospitality consulting practice at the accounting firm Coopers & Lybrand in Manhattan. "So given the demand levels, there would have to be something external, whether it's a recession or a war or crime wave, to burst the bubble."
Some analysts and tourism officials worry that New York is letting business slip away to other cities. Not only is the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center inadequate for the biggest conventions, but during peak months like October "room availability" becomes an oxymoron.
"The question on everyone's mind is, 'How do we keep this going?' " said Jeanine Moss, a spokeswoman for the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau. "You can be a victim of your own success. If no one can get a hotel room at Christmas, and word gets out, the next time the hotels may be empty."

HEADLINE: Rival Suitors May Split Up Conrail Parts

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Conrail is close to a $10.3 billion agreement with the CSX Corporation and the Norfolk Southern Corporation that would split Conrail's railroad network between the two carriers, bringing to an end a bloody four-month battle for control of rail freight in the East, people familiar with the negotiations said yesterday.
Under the tentative plan, CSX -- possibly with Norfolk Southern -- would buy Conrail for about $115 a share in cash and then sell about half of Conrail's rail lines to rival Norfolk Southern, giving both companies roughly equal freight routes throughout the Northeast and providing them each with access to New York, the largest market in the country. 
 Norfolk Southern would pay CSX about $4.2 billion. CSX, in turn, would be required to sweeten its existing offer for Conrail by almost $1 billion, thereby matching Norfolk Southern's $10.3 billion hostile offer for Conrail and allowing both companies to claim victory.
"All three sides came to the conclusion that a settlement was the only way to get this resolved in the near term," said Brian Routledge, an analyst with Prudential Securities. "You'll now have two balanced rail freight systems in the East and the West."
Conrail's directors, who had been meeting all day yesterday, issued a statement last night that stopped short of endorsing the deal, although they appeared to have given up on their longstanding desire to keep the company intact. The statement said the directors had authorized Conrail management to "negotiate an amendment" to the CSX merger agreement "that would assure that the Conrail shareholders receive $115 in cash per share at the earliest possible date."
Investors embraced the proposed agreement, driving shares of Conrail up $7.125 yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange to close at $111.625, less than the deal price but 57 percent higher than when the battle began last October. Norfolk Southern shares rose $2.75 to close at $93.875 and CSX rose $2.875, to $49. Word of the tentative agreement appeared on Sunday in The Washington Post.
The apparent breakthrough in the railroad war was a victory for Norfolk Southern, which had sought to break up the CSX-Conrail merger, contending that it was anticompetitive in that it would give the combined company virtual control over rail freight in the Northeast.
"We are pleased with today's announcement that CSX and Conrail are negotiating to resolve the issues facing the Eastern railroads," David R. Goode, chairman of Norfolk Southern, said in a statement last night.
The battle in the East began in October, when CSX announced a friendly $8.1 billion merger with Conrail, which had a virtual monopoly over freight traffic in the Northeast. Norfolk Southern, which had long sought a combination with Conrail, countered nine days later with a higher, all-cash offer that touched off a bidding war that sent the price up more than $2 billion.
Under the terms of the tentative agreement proposed by Mr. Goode in a letter to the other two companies, CSX would make a tender offer for Conrail, keeping most of the old New York Central line, a valuable track that runs up the Hudson River valley to Albany and then west to Buffalo and Chicago. Norfolk Southern would get the main line of the old Pennsylvania Railroad, which runs through New Jersey and Pennsylvania to Pittsburgh and points west, as well as the "southern tier," a slow-moving track through the less populated cities in upstate New York to Buffalo and beyond.
The proposed split of Conrail bears a remarkable resemblance to a partition of Conrail first proposed by Norfolk Southern to CSX during secret talks last November. The two sides failed to reach an agreement then and the discussions riled Conrail management, which had sought to preserve the integrity of the Conrail system.
But the deal ran into a barrage of criticism from shippers and port officials in New York and Baltimore, who feared that the lack of rail competition would inhibit economic growth. The plan also drew fire from Robert D. Krebs, the chairman of the Burlington Northern railroad, who told securities analysts last November that he would oppose any merger that produced a single, dominant railroad in the East.
Conrail had been able to use Pennsylvania's stiff anti-takeover statutes to protect its deal with CSX from Norfolk's sweeter, hostile offer. But the merger became deadlocked on Jan. 17, when Norfolk Southern persuaded Conrail shareholders to oppose a resolution that would have allowed CSX to complete the deal.
The three companies agreed to hold talks concerning a possible deal in January, after Federal officials signaled their desire to see a settlement that provided a competitive balance between the railroads. But after a brief initial meeting of the companies, nothing happened.
Sensing that CSX was more than willing to come to an accommodation, Mr. Goode in a Feb. 24 letter to Conrail and CSX proposed a deal that essentially carved Conrail in half.
"There weren't any other meetings," said one person involved in the negotiations. David LeVan, the chairman of Conrail, "wouldn't come to the table," the person said. "He went into a bunker. But enough dynamite will blast anybody out of their hole. The letter was the dynamite."
It is unclear what will become of Mr. LeVan, and his management team. Under the old merger agreement, Mr. LeVan was eventually to become the chairman of the combined company. But there may no longer be a place for Mr. LeVan in the new deal, according to people on all sides of the negotiations.
If approved by Conrail and by Federal regulators at the Surface Transportation Board, the deal to carve up Conrail and create two major railroads in the East would set the stage for what many rail experts say is the inevitable establishment of a transcontinental railroad system. With deregulation sweeping the railroad industry, some transportation experts have argued fewer and larger railroad companies would create a faster, cheaper more rational system that would better be able to capture the freight traffic now moving by truck on the nation's highways.
Indeed, railroads' share of freight traffic rose to 40.6 percent in 1995, from 36.4 percent in 1985. After a series of mergers in the West, the Union Pacific and the Burlington Northern Santa Fe have come to dominate the region.

HEADLINE: Budget Surplus Gives Albany New Questions

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 3

 BODY:
Legislative leaders agreed with the Governor today that New York State's coffers, swelled by the boom on Wall Street, would be awash in tax money for the next 13 months, although the state's overall economic growth continued to lag behind the nation's.
The forecasts vary only in their degree of optimism. Four days ago, Gov. George E. Pataki predicted that through March 31, 1998, the state would take in $650 million more than his budget office had forecast just six weeks earlier. Today, Senate leaders projected the extra cash at $922 million, and Assembly leaders put the figure at more than $2 billion. Whatever its true size, the bonanza will be added to the $1.3 billion surplus the state had already accumulated last April from higher revenues and lower expenses that had been expected. 
 For years, the Assembly has pushed for more spending than the Governor or the Senate, and it has justified that spending in part with higher revenue projections. In the last two years, its income predictions turned out to be the most accurate of the three.
The release of revenue estimates traditionally serves as the starting gun for serious budget negotiations. Under state law, the government must produce a budget by midnight on March 31, just four weeks away. But the state has not adopted a budget on time since 1984, and last year, the Governor and Legislature set a nationwide record with a budget that was 104 days late. This year, with lawmakers threatening to tie issues like welfare policy and rent regulation to the budget, it could once again go well past the deadline.
But for the first time in years, a different kind of debate is shaping up here, one less about what to cut than about where to spend. Mr. Pataki and the Republicans who control the Senate want more and faster tax cuts, both houses want more school aid, and the Democratic leaders of the Assembly want to rescind the Governor's proposed Medicaid cuts and college tuition increases. Of all the roles in the budget drama, no one in power has volunteered to play the voice of caution.
That there could be such a debate stems from the anomaly of a Wall Street boom's producing a glut of tax money for the state, even as longer-lasting signs of economic strength, like job growth, remain sluggish. In addition, New York struggles under what is by far the largest debt burden of any state and has a credit rating worse than for any other state but Louisiana.
So while the state's elected officials debate what to do with all that money, outside budget analysts warn that the bonanza should be used to fix long-term problems, and that the good times could evaporate in one bad day on Wall Street.
"New York's leaders are about to blow a historic opportunity to position ourselves for the next century," said Cynthia B. Green, vice president for state studies at the Citizens' Budget Commission, a private group that analyzes the city and state budgets. "The fiscally responsible plan would be to use all of this surplus to pay down outstanding debt."
New York owes more than $30 billion, and the debt is climbing rapidly. The state's heavy borrowing is one of the main reasons for its poor credit rating, and for analysts' concerns about the state's long-term financial health. Mr. Pataki's proposed $66.3 billion budget for the fiscal year starting April 1 allocates $3 billion just to making payments on that debt.
The two-year run-up in the stock market has produced profits for traders and investors alike; the brokerage firms are expected to pay out $8.1 billion in bonuses for 1996 performance. As a result, personal income and personal income-tax payments are rising much faster in New York than in the country as a whole, even as job growth lags well behind the national rate. Subtract Wall Street, and the state's economy is slogging along in fairly unimpressive fashion.
The same factors are producing similar effects on New York City's budget, though in exaggerated fashion, since the financial markets account for a much larger part of the city's economy. Last week, City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi released a report showing that in 1996, the city's economic performance lagged behind not only the nation's but that of other cities, with areas like manufacturing and health care actually shrinking.
Budget monitors argue that the state is relying more heavily than ever on one volatile industry, the investment business, to balance its books. "Clearly, Wall Street is driving the wage base, and clearly, that's something the state can't depend on in the long run," said Robert Kurtter, vice president for state ratings at Moody's Investors Service. Even if there were no recession, fiscal analysts say, a bear market on Wall Street could have nearly the same effect on the state's coffers.
In his first two years as Governor, Mr. Pataki pushed for painful spending cuts, somewhat lowering the state's structural imbalance, the tendency of expenses to rise faster in the long run than income. But by his own estimate, his proposed 1997-98 budget would worsen the imbalance slightly, postponing long-term fiscal discipline until 1998 and beyond.
"The difference between New York and most other states is that most of the states have used this economic recovery to firm up their balance sheets and reduce their structural deficits," Mr. Kurtter said. "They are much better positioned to meet the next downturn than New York."
Mr. Pataki's main bid for austerity this year was in Medicaid, the fastest-growing area of state spending, where he proposed a state reduction of $572 million, or 2.5 percent. But the effect of that cut would be much greater, because medical costs rise faster than inflation, and because the Federal and local governments match state spending. Over all, his budget would mean spending 8 percent, or $2.1 billion, less on Medicaid than if the formulas were unchanged.
The Governor also proposed $400-a-year increases in full-time tuition for the State University and City University systems, and deep cuts in tuition assistance for poor students.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Utility Sues to Block New Hampshire Plan
Northeast Utilities, which owns Public Service of New Hampshire, went to Federal court seeking to block a state deregulation decision that it said could cut the company's revenue by $341 million over two years and ultimately drive it into bankruptcy.
Regulators had moved to limit the utility's practice of passing on costs of past investments to customers. The dispute provides a taste of battles to come as the drive to deregulate utilities and bring down rates picks up speed. [Page D8.]
 
United Airlines in Labor Accord
United Airlines and its pilots' and machinists' unions reached tentative accords that provide for the largest possible salary and benefit gains allowed under an arbiter's ruling. [D22.] 

2 Reports of Economic Strength
Two strong economic reports were released, prompting concerns that the Federal Reserve would be more likely to raise interest rates. In the first, the National Association of Purchasing Management said its index of manufacturing activity rose, and in the other, the Commerce Department said that personal income increased unexpectedly. [D8.]
 
Ameritech and AT&T Settle Dispute
Ameritech and AT&T said that they had agreed to settle three legal disputes and battle each other in the marketplace. [D9.]
 
Sales Down for Chrysler and G.M.
Chrysler and General Motors said that their sales fell last month, hurt, in Chrysler's case, by comparisons with strong sales a year earlier and, in G.M.'s case, by a sluggish transition to redesigned models. [D7.]
 
Stocks End Losing Streak
A three-session losing streak for stocks ended. The Dow industrials jumped 41.18 points, to 6,918.92, propelled by DuPont. In the broader market, buyers, believing that chip makers' inventory problems might be waning, drove up technology stocks, led by Intel. [D12.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities fell, with the 30-year bond yield climbing to 6.83 percent from 6.80. [D19.]
 
China: Prodigy or Menace?
In Washington, where there is great anxiey about China's export boom, a question is heard over and over again: Is China becoming the next Japan, threatening American manufacturing jobs? [A1.]
 
CBS to Invest in Sportsline USA
CBS plans to invest $100 million for a one-third stake in Sportsline USA, a leading on-line sports service, according to people familiar with the talks. The move comes as Disney is negotiating for a stake in Starwave, which is behind the other leading sports site on the World Wide Web. [D11.]
 
Mexican Businessman Indicted
The Mexican Government has charged a leading businessman, who is a partner in a big cellular-telephone venture with Bell Atlantic, with criminal tax fraud. [D6.]
 
New Rules for Trade Missions
President Clinton's new Commerce Secretary, William M. Daley, overhauled the rules governing American trade missions abroad, attempting to insure that companies that donate heavily to political campaigns get no special help from the Government in breaking into foreign markets. [A19.]
 
HFS to Buy Value Rent-a-Car
HFS has agreed to buy Value Rent-a-Car from Mitsubishi for $175 million in cash. [D7.]

HEADLINE: Clinton Wants Deal With Congress on Cost-of-Living Adjustments

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 3

 BODY:
President Clinton gave his aides the go-ahead today to try to forge a deal with Congress to reduce cost-of-living adjustments for Social Security and other benefit programs, White House officials said.
The officials said the Administration had not decided on a specific proposal but would start consulting on Tuesday with members of Congress from both parties, as well as with outside economists, to find a bipartisan way of dealing with the issue, which could determine the success of efforts to balance the budget. 
 The decision is the Administration's response to a call last week from Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican majority leader, for a commission of experts to make a binding judgment on how big the cost-of-living adjustment should be each year for Social Security and other programs.
Although it does not irrevocably commit the Administration to backing a politically explosive effort to reduce increases in Social Security, the decision is the first overt sign that Mr. Clinton is willing to join Republicans in taking the inevitable heat over the issue from powerful constituencies like the elderly.
The officials said the Administration would float several ideas, including the creation of a commission to make nonbinding recommendations to Congress and the Administration.
They said the emphasis would be on trying to create a panel that would have technical credibility on a subject that is complex even for economists.
The Administration would prefer a panel whose members do not already have strong views on the subject so that their work did not appear rigged to find budget savings at the expense of benefit recipients.
The Government now relies on the Consumer Price Index, which most economists agree overstates inflation to some degree.
The index is used to set increases each year in Social Security and other Government benefit programs, and is also used to adjust tax brackets for the effects of inflation.
A panel of economists appointed by Congress reported last year that the index overstated increases in the cost of living by about 1.1 percentage points a year. By inflating benefit payments and decreasing tax revenue, an overstatement of that size would cost the Government tens of billions of dollars a year, money that could go a long way toward eliminating the Federal deficit.
Administration officials including Robert E. Rubin, the Treasury Secretary; Franklin D. Raines, the budget chief; Gene Sperling, the chairman of the National Economic Council, and Erskine B. Bowles, the White House chief of staff, will begin sounding out members of Congress about a deal, White House aides said.
Other officials, including Janet Yellen, the head of the Council of Economic Advisers, and Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, will solicit opinions from economists, they said.

HEADLINE: Time to Get Honest About Social Security;
More Accurate C.P.I.

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Joel Popkin (Op-Ed, Feb. 27) argues that Congress is attempting to correct the Consumer Price Index. That is wrong. He confuses the index with cost-of-living adjustments in Federal programs, but, to quote the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the index is not a cost-of-living index, although it is used as such. The purpose of COLA's is to insulate recipients of government programs and taxpayers from changes in the cost of living. 
 Mr. Popkin left the Bureau of Labor Statistics in 1973. Since then, there have been breakthroughs in research on index number theory and in methods for estimating the value of quality change and of new products; a third of the Federal budget outlays and part of the tax code have been indexed by the Consumer Price Index. These changes increase the urgency of adopting a more accurate index to adjust benefits and taxes.
It is appropriate for the President and Congress to adjust COLA's. The commission I headed concluded that the change in the index overstates the change in the cost-of-living by a little over one percentage point a year. We agree with Mr. Popkin that the Bureau of Labor Statistics should make the improvements in the nation's price statistics, but the commission also recognizes that this will take many years.
Mr. Popkin impugns the objectivity of commission members. In fact, they are experts in the technical area of economic statistics and index numbers. Professional experts not on the commission have stated publicly that they thought our estimates were, if anything, too low.
 
MICHAEL J. BOSKIN
Palo Alto, Calif., Feb. 28, 1997
 
The writer is a professor of economics at Stanford University.

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 6; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 149 words

HEADLINE: Time to Get Honest About Social Security;
Shoddy-Goods Factor

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your Feb. 25 front-page article "Majority Leader Proposes a Panel on Inflation Index" refers to Congressional and Administration moves to "fix" the Consumer Price Index, on the assumption that the adjustment would be downward. 
 Why shouldn't it be upward? For example, some urge a 0.8 percent adjustment to take into account improved products. But what about products that are worse than before -- inedible tomatoes, plastic tricycles, cramped air travel through inconvenient "hubs"? How about the shoddy manufactured items that because of design, materials and method of assembly do not last as long and cannot be repaired?
Or even improved products, like electronic equipment, that are too expensive to repair? Politicians think they have found a quiet way to cut Social Security, but let's not be fooled.
 
VITTORIO MAESTRO
Brooklyn, Feb. 26, 1997

HEADLINE: Time to Get Honest About Social Security;
For Different Folks

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Majority Leader Proposes a Panel on Inflation Index" (front page, Feb. 25): One aspect of the cost-of-living index I have not seen addressed is the different spending patterns of various income groups. To persons with per capita income under $15,000 or family income under, say, $30,000, increases in the cost of medical care, food and rent are paramount, and these costs are rising more rapidly than the Consumer Price Index. 
 If we are to base various government benefits on the C.P.I., perhaps we need more than a single index to reflect overall individual assets and income.
 
HULDA GROBMAN
Vero Beach, Fla., Feb. 25, 1997

HEADLINE: Time to Get Honest About Social Security;
Cut Corporate Welfare

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Is revising the Consumer Price Index (or "correcting" its impact on Social Security and other payments) a "better way" of balancing the budget ("A Rational Way to Reduce the Deficit," editorial, March 1)? 
 The members of the Boskin commission were selected by Congressional Republicans for previously expressed views that the index is greatly overstated, so their report is suspect. The index may not really be much of a problem. Changing its calculation (or its impact) could be.
A more rational way of appeasing the mania for zero deficits would be to slash corporate welfare, especially the multibillions in unnecessary military expenditures, before asking middle- and lower-income folks to take a hit.
 
JOHN GLASEL
Tenafly, N.J., March 1, 1997

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
Jobless Rate Dips Below 6%

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
New Jersey's unemployment rate dipped to 5.9 percent in January, the first time in six years that it has fallen below 6 percent, according to statistics released yesterday by the State Department of Labor. Melvin L. Gelade, who was sworn in yesterday as Labor Commissioner, said that 9,600 new jobs were created in January. 
 But the employment picture was not entirely rosy. The state's unemployment rate remained above the national average of 5.4 percent, and 1,800 fewer people were looking for jobs. Some Democratic lawmakers pointed out that more than half of the new jobs were low-paying service jobs.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: THE LONG WHITE LINE: A special report.;
Keeping Cocaine Resilient: Low Cost and High Profit

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

 BODY:
They have tried to stamp out cocaine for years. Governments have sprayed herbicides on fields of coca leaf. Police have raided the primitive laboratories that refine coca paste. Counternarcotics agents have seized and destroyed hundreds of tons of cocaine powder, arresting or killing thousands of smugglers.
Yet after 20 years and eradication programs totaling hundreds of millions of dollars, cocaine can be bought on every continent, in virtually every major city. The drug has even survived a market decline in which the number of regular cocaine users in the United States dropped, to 1.5 million in 1995 from 5.7 million a decade before. Americans are still snorting, smoking or injecting cocaine at the rate of 240 tons a year, almost all of it produced in Colombia and much of it smuggled through Mexico. 
 The debate that preceded the Clinton Administration's decision on Friday to certify Mexico as an ally in its war against illegal drugs while decertifying Colombia underscored how deeply entrenched the cocaine habit has become, enmeshing South and North America in an intricate web of corruption and violence.
The reasons for cocaine's resilience are a matter of simple economics, as interviews with the people who make, sell, use and try to destroy cocaine confirm. It is a sweatshop industry that taps a limitless supply of cheap labor, generates enormous profits for a few and enjoys a base of addicted customers.
And just as any large and diffuse commercial enterprise is ultimately dependent on the favor or cooperation of officials and regulators, the cocaine trade is well oiled by corruption along the way. A draft analysis by American intelligence officials estimates that Mexican drug traffickers earn up to $10 billion a year and then dole out as much as $6 billion on bribes for Mexican officials and police officers.
The most powerful symbol of cocaine's resilience is the trail that the drug follows from leaf to crack and powder, from farmer to addict, from the Andean jungles to the New York City streets.
"For a narcotics trafficker, the most valuable asset is his route," said Gen. Rosso Juan Serrano, commander of the Colombian National Police, referring not just to the physical trail, but also to the clandestine airstrips, the hidden warehouses and corrupt officials like air controllers and police along the way. And as with an octopus that grows new tentacles when old ones are damaged or cut off, the trail sprouts new paths, means of transport and markets when the old ones are attacked.
Donald Ferrarone, the special agent in charge of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration field office in Houston, has seen cocaine flowing in for years. "The only difference," Mr. Ferrarone said, "is the intensity is more ferocious now."
The trail starts in the Andean jungles, where peasants strip coca bushes of their oval leaves, dump the leaves in a plastic-lined pit, pour in kerosene or gasoline and water, and sometimes sprinkle on cement.
Barefoot, the workers stomp the mixture to press out the psychoactive alkaloids into a paste that resembles grimy snow. Across rural Colombia, thousands of laborers process the paste into a sludge that is dried to form the raw ingredient for powdered cocaine hydrochloride.
Every day, more than two tons of powder flows through Mexico and the Caribbean, with one-third of that ending up in the United States. Once cocaine was ferried by small planes. Now, to evade American radar surveillance, more and more cocaine floats north in the holds of freighters, fishing boats and yachts.
"How are drugs coming across the border?" asked Leon W. Guinn, special agent in charge of the Customs Service field office in Houston. "Probably in every imaginable way you can think of."
 
The Lab Workers
Double the Pay Of Cutting Cane
Altemar Restrepo could not earn enough cutting sugar cane to support his family. So Mr. Restrepo, a slender Colombian, followed other peasants and apprenticed himself to the making of cocaine.
For 4 of his 25 years, Mr. Restrepo said, he has worked in the tangled jungle of southeastern Colombia, fetching the gasoline used to leach coca leaves of their alkaloids. The "cocina," or jungle laboratory where Mr. Restrepo was interviewed, consisted of six wooden maturation pens, in which a ton of leaves soaked in gasoline and water.
Every week, he said, the laboratory produced more than 75 pounds of coca to be refined elsewhere into powdered cocaine.
"We do this because you can't raise cattle or corn in this region," Mr. Restrepo said as he fidgeted, shirtless and sweating, beside a waist-high pile of coca leaves. "There's no water, and transport is too expensive."
As a cane cutter, he said, he was lucky to earn $35 a week. For processing coca leaves he was promised $10 to $15 a day, plus a dormitory cot and food. He has not been paid for three months, he said, and he misses his family several hundred miles to the north. He wants to go home.
Mr. Restrepo gave his account minutes after having been seized by Colombian narcotics police commandos who raided the laboratory, sending co-workers bolting into the jungle. He admitted having been arrested before. "I don't know who owns the patch and I don't ask," Mr. Restrepo said. "When I did ask, they said, 'Just keep working.' "
The police ripped up the pens with a chainsaw and kicked over the metal drums, splattering coca base into the mud. When the officers tried to blow up what was left, the waterlogged leaves refused to ignite. The police retreated under the machine gun of a hovering helicopter, leaving Mr. Restrepo looking unperturbed.
"He said he had a family, so we couldn't leave his wife and children alone," Col. Leonardo Gallego, commander of the police unit, said. "I feel strongly about the plight of young men and children who get into drugs or fall in with drug-trafficking gangs."
Mr. Restrepo's employers got no such sympathy.
"They only commit crimes because of cruelty and personal gain," Colonel Gallego said. "There's no regard for the country or the views of the international community."
 
The Townspeople
Boom, Herbicides And Abandonment
Because coca pays much better than pineapples or bananas and is easier to market, the farmers who grow it express few qualms about working for what they see as, ultimately, the Yankee dollar, though one such "cocalero," Franklin Gonzales, said he would rather sing.
But pop singing pays little. So Mr. Gonzales, a wiry 24-year-old, left his wife and young son and traveled southwest to the river town of Miraflores.
"I left them because of the violence here," he told a reporter.
He was making $30 or $40 a day tending coca fields until the National Police sprayed them with herbicide last summer. Now, Mr. Gonzales said: "It's hard. There is no money. There are people here, but not as many as before."
Coca production in Colombia created boom towns out of many backwaters like Miraflores, a ramshackle settlement of whitewashed houses with metal roofs along the muddy Vaupes River. The drug lords do not bother to visit, sending commercial agents to buy the paste openly from growers.
After coca displaced rubber as the primary crop, Miraflores swelled to 10,000 inhabitants, 600 of them prostitutes, said the Rev. Manuel Mancera, the Roman Catholic priest in the town. Coca money built a new discotheque that glitters with mirrors. Fighting and whoring became nightly diversions.
"There were no values or principles," Father Mancera said. "People were too attached to money."
Since the spraying, Miraflores has shriveled to a few thousand residents. The farmers are hard put to make a living, because they have no roads to carry legal crops to market.
"It's the beginning of the end of Miraflores," the priest said. "Because if it isn't coca, there is just no other produce."
The National Police reported that they sprayed 55,715 acres and destroyed 938 cocaine laboratories last year. But when towns like Miraflores die, traffickers find others, making alliances with leftist guerrillas who charge a tax according to the weight of cocaine passing through their territory.
The Government cut off deliveries of gasoline and cement to the region after discovering that extensive quantities had been diverted to process coca leaves. Now, those materials are smuggled from Venezuela.
"You can't even get gasoline," said Estrela Contreras of Miraflores, who organized demonstrations against spraying. "We're all paying for the sins of a few."
 
The Mansions
Guns and Pools, Narco-Deco Style
The profits of cocaine are manifested in a two-story residence that rises like a fortress above an attractive neighborhood of Cali, a fashionable western city that is the home of the world's most prominent drug cartel.
The house, made of concrete, has no windows facing the street. But inside are marble floors, crystal chandeliers, furniture gilded and tasseled in Narco-Deco style and bowling lanes. The garden has an enormous swimming pool. A police specialist in a search party told an accompanying reporter that the house was worth $15 million.
The police and soldiers raided the house because its owner, Jose Orlando Henao Montoya, is suspected of being a rising drug trafficker. He was not home at the time.
The closets held barely a change of clothes. Family photographs had been stripped from silver frames. The maid said the family had left for its country ranch.
The searches began when the police, with discreet help from American agents, captured six leaders of the Cali cartel in 1995.
"They were very powerful," the commander of the search team, Lieut. Col. Ramiro Villalobos, said. "People were afraid of all the bodyguards, the extravagant cars and the display of guns. This no longer happens. Now we can go out at night without fear."
But with some cartel leaders running the business by telephone from prison and new independent traffickers taking up the slack, has the output of cocaine been stanched?
Colonel Villalobos paused and replied, "We can't say it's less, no."
 
The Transfer Point
Lucrative Fees For the Mexicans
The bulk of the cocaine that enters the United States passes through Mexico, with the help of Mexican crime federations that demand up to half the Colombians' cocaine and heroin in return, the Drug Enforcement Administration said. The Mexicans distribute their share through their own networks.
"The Colombian narcotraffickers have very comfortable relations with the Mexican mafia," General Serrano of the Colombian police said. "It's almost a natural relationship."
The cocaine increasingly arrives in Mexico on vessels like the Don Celso. The rusty fishing boat, flying the Ecuadorean flag, ostensibly carried shrimp and tuna between Buenaventura, Colombia, and Manzanillo, Mexico. But Colombian and American agents who boarded her off Ecuador in October reported finding 12 tons of cocaine.
Once in Mexico, the cocaine is trucked north to the United States border, with the connivance of corrupt Government officials, Federal agents said. One agent said 30 to 40 tons of cocaine were stockpiled in Mexico, awaiting delivery to the United States.
Mexico's economic problems and double-digit unemployment help in recruiting smugglers for a relative pittance. One smuggler was offered $500 to smuggle a load to Los Angeles and promised another $500 if he made it back, an antidrug agent said.
Lose a load, however, and a smuggler can be forced to work for nothing to make it up, or the smuggler can be disfigured or killed.
"The level of violence is like nowhere I've ever seen," said a Federal agent in Texas who insisted on anonymity.
The agent told of a woman who had been caught carrying drug profits back across the border. She agreed to turn informer and asked to go home to Juarez. She turned up garroted.
 
The Portal
Thin Line of Agents Reviews the Flood
J. J. Lopez stood on the concrete Bridge of the Americas in El Paso, watching the flow of automobiles from Ciudad Juarez, a few hundred yards away. More than one million cars, many driven by commuters, cross between El Paso and Juarez each month, giving United States Customs inspectors a scant 10 or 15 seconds to look over each car.
"We have to move the traffic," Mr. Lopez, the chief customs inspector at the bridge, said. "But we also have to address the threat that we have, which is narcotics."
Mr. Lopez was watched by a young man who cradled the receiver of the nearest pay telephone, about 50 yards away. Nearby, his accomplice talked into a two-way radio as he surveyed the heavy traffic.
They were spotters, Mr. Lopez said, hired by the syndicate of Amado Carrillo Fuentes to tell smugglers which lanes to use or avoid. Spotters earn $25 to $50 a day for working the bridge, far more than the $25 to $40 a week that they might earn in a Juarez factory.
Customs inspectors conduct two-minute blitzes in which they stop and check every car in one lane or walk through traffic with dogs trained to sniff out drugs.
"We've had people bail out of their cars and run back" to Mexico, Mr. Lopez said.
To reduce chances of losing a major load, traffickers now move cocaine in quantities of a few hundred pounds. After crossing the border, loads are deposited at stash houses for consolidation.
Mr. Lopez said drugs were concealed deep inside vehicles, often behind electronic trapdoors. Inspectors have found cocaine replacing trailer insulation, inside tire rims and poured in the fuel tank to form a sediment to be scooped out later. Sixty pounds of cocaine can fit behind some dashboards, he said.
Cocaine has even turned up in a baby's diaper.
"Think of the sensitivity of searching an infant," said George A. McNenney, a customs special agent in El Paso.
 
The Landing Zone
Tension Casts Pall Along Rio Grande
Before dusk erased the shadows across the sagebrush, cactus and mesquite outside Eagle Pass, Tex., the rancher coaxed his Jeep to the rim of a bluff overlooking the Rio Grande. Rifle at hand, he watched for the smugglers who walk their loads across the placid river and onto his 165-acre spread.
No fences or barriers define the border here. As a teen-ager nearly 50 years ago, the rancher himself waded into the knee-deep water to play baseball with Mexican youngsters who lived on the other side.
"You can't do that now," he said.
The rancher would not allow his name to be used, fearing smugglers might retaliate.
"They're not looking for trouble," he said. "But if you run into them, they're armed and you don't have a chance."
He used to call Border Patrol agents in nearby Eagle Pass, he said, but before they arrived, the intruders would melt into the darkness. So now, he said, "my neighbors and I watch each other's backs."
A neighbor on the Mexican side, he said, had encountered on his land unmarked vans and an armed stranger who barred the way. A neighbor in Texas found night-vision goggles on a trail that crossed his property.
"My gates have been torn down, knocked up and run over," the rancher said, adding that his wife went to church alone on Sundays, because they dared not leave the ranch unattended. "Our place is valueless now. You can't give it away. You can't rent it."
In fact, ranches along the Rio Grande attract buyers ready to pay -- in cash -- more than the properties are worth. One spread worth barely $300,000 was bought for $850,000 by someone who was later traced to drug smuggling.
"We've had dopers come out and look at this place," the rancher said.
A realty agent asked the owners to leave while the client inspected. They refused.
Even with the billions spent to fight drugs, the rancher said, "it gets worse every year."
"I don't know what to do about it," he said. "But what we're doing doesn't work."
 
The End of the Line
Crack's Losers: Victims and Society
When powdered cocaine began to lose its appeal in the 1980's, distributors in cities like New York created a new market by cooking the powder with baking soda and water to make crack.
"Crack is still out there," said John Galea, who runs the Street Studies Unit of the New York State Office of Addiction and Substance Abuse Services. "We've noticed that 13- and 14-year-olds are not using it anymore. But they're selling it."
Dealers in Brooklyn confirmed that the profits that built expensive houses in Cali did not trickle down to the sidewalks of New York. A teen-ager who was peddling crack said that he could take in $75 to $100 a day, but that he dared work just a few days a week, fearing he would attract the police.
Another seller said he made $25 for selling a bundle of 20 "nickel" bags for $5 each.
Crack's attraction for users lies in its instant high and cheap price. Powdered cocaine sells for $30 to $40 a gram in upper Manhattan. A pebble of crack costs $2 to $5.
Although crack is widely derided as a loser's drug, its customers include people like Thomas DeGrace, 35, who had a restaurant and a music company and whose five-year addiction wiped out all he had achieved.
"Crack is the only drug in the world where the more you take, the more you want," Mr. DeGrace said. "When you take your first hit, you're chasing that hit for the rest of the day."
Eventually, Mr. DeGrace lived on the street, bartering for crack by holding the drugs so the dealer could avoid arrest if the police swooped in.
"I came from a family that taught morals and standards, but that drug just takes them away from you," Mr. DeGrace said. "You see yourself diminish as a man."
He has entered a rehabilitation program run by Phoenix House.
If male addicts perform a dealer's stoop labor, women suffer worse humiliation.
"It degrades you to where you're selling your body," Cynthia McBride said. "That's where it started and ended with me."
Ms. McBride, 25, said she had begun sniffing cocaine as a 10-year-old to overcome stage fright when she sang soul music professionally. By the time she moved to crack, she said, "I was married, cheating on a husband and sleeping with men to get high."
Even after social workers had removed her five children, Ms. McBride said, she continued chasing crack.
"Physically, it shows on you," she said. "You're a walking skeleton if you're a crack head, and you think you look good."
Despite all the lipstick she smeared on, Ms. McBride said, she grew so scrawny that dealers refused to have sex with her. After she had slashed a rival prostitute, she, too, checked into Phoenix House.
"When the drug dealers start dissing you," she said, "when you can't get a $2 hit because they don't want you, that's when it's time to go."

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 1; Living Desk 

LENGTH: 1285 words

HEADLINE: Big Mac's Price Cut Won't Cut the Fat

BYLINE: By TRIP GABRIEL 

 BODY:
SO the price of a Big Mac is dropping to 55 cents. According to classic economic theory, the steep price cut will draw more customers, who will buy more Big Macs, which will fatten the company's bottom line.
But what of the fattening of American waistlines? What of the thickening of American arteries? 
 As news of McDonald's widely publicized Campaign 55 has spread, the ubiquity of the golden arches upon the landscape and the increasing centrality of burgers and fries in the American diet have led public health experts and even anthropologists to ponder some noncorporate consequences.
A new chapter is being writ for the Big Mac, which in its 30-year history has never been less than a culture-defining sandwich.
Predictably, many nutritionists were alarmed. McDonald's feeds 7 percent of the United States population each day. At company headquarters near Chicago, where the 55-cent offer was conceived to overcome declining sales, the mission is to build a restaurant no farther than a four-minute walk or drive from every man, woman and child.
"Hamburgers are already the worst food in the average American's diet," said Bonnie Liebman, the director of nutrition at the Center for Science in the Public Interest, a Washington advocacy group. "They contribute more artery-clogging fat than any other single food. This could make the problem worse."
Dr. Marion Nestle, the chairwoman of the department of nutrition and food studies at New York University, was blunter. "It's a nutritionist's nightmare," she said of the 55-cent price. "We will continue to see the amount of fat and saturated fat in the American diet go up. We would expect to see the trend of increasing body weights also."
Call it coincidence, but the increase of overweight Americans roughly tracks the era of McDonald's greatest empire building.
The number of overweight people, after holding steady at a quarter of the population in the 1960's and 70's, shot up to 33 percent in the 80's, according to the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta. McDonald's growth also went into hyperdrive starting in the 80's, from 5,213 outlets in the United States in 1980 to more than 12,000 today. There are 8,000 or so overseas.
The 55-cent offer, meant to recall the epic year of 1955, when Ray Kroc, the patron saint of franchisers, opened his first McDonald's, is good only when a Big Mac (530 calories and 28 grams of fat) is purchased with french fries (450 calories and 22 grams of fat for a large order) and a soda (310 calories for 32 ounces). The total meal is three-quarters of the Government's recommended daily allowance of 66 grams of fat.
But not all nutritionists expect inexpensive Big Macs to lead to ruin. Dr. Barry M. Popkin, a professor of nutrition at the University of North Carolina who also holds a doctorate in economics, said that research shows that people who eat high-fat foods at restaurants also eat high-fat foods at home.
"The total effect on fat will be a slight increase, not a huge increase," he said. "The away-from-home impact is not as major an impact on the diet of an individual as one would think."
Economists who follow the fast-food business say that its customers are highly cost-sensitive. By steeply discounting its flagship sandwich, now around $2, McDonald's is expecting an immediate and sizable increase in foot traffic. Sales at individual McDonald's that have been open more than a year have been falling for the last six quarters. The company is losing market share to other burger chains, and its pioneering Egg McMuffin-based breakfast has suffered the indignity of bagelmania.
McDonald's franchisees voted on Saturday to accept the new pricing, which will begin on April 26. The 55-cent offer will rotate from the Big Mac to the Quarter Pounder to other sandwiches over the next year.
But it is not entirely clear that increased traffic will translate into more people eating more fast food. Some experts said that the price cut could simply siphon off existing customers from other hamburger chains, like Wendy's and Burger King.
"Will we eat more hamburgers because of this?" asked Harry Balzer, a vice president of the NPD Group, a market research company that studies eating trends. "I don't think we know the answer."
Mr. Balzer said the only sure sign that overall burger consumption has gone up will be if rival burger chains do not retaliate with discounts of their own. That will be a sign that their businesses have not suffered because of McDonald's lower prices, he said. In other words, more people will be eating more hamburgers.
The latest edition of Mr. Balzer's annual survey, "Eating Patterns in America," seems to suggest that, indeed, Americans' appetite for takeout junk food is insatiable. Hamburgers, french fries and chicken nuggets were among the five fastest-growing foods ordered in restaurants, according to the study, which was released in October.
Takeout restaurants overtook table-service restaurants last year for the first time, accounting for more than 50 percent of the nation's restaurant business, the National Restaurant Association said.
The trend toward good-for-you foods appears to have hit a wall and may be experiencing a backlash. Restaurants from steakhouses to trattorias are filling plates to the very edge with outsize portions, many of them highly fattening. Last year, McDonald's abandoned its low-fat burger, McLean Deluxe, and now encourages customers to "super-size it" with a voluminous pouch of fries.
"The fat content of fast-food meals has been increasing, not decreasing," Dr. Nestle of N.Y.U. said.
As fast-food prices decline, who will feel the impact the most?
Dr. Nan A. Rothschild, a Barnard College anthropology professor, predicted that immigrant families used to dining cheaply at home on traditional foods would be hastened along the path of acculturation.
"In that segment of the population," Dr. Rothschild said, "the kids are always motivated to eat in American institutions, but up to now their parents may have said, 'We can't afford it.' I would think a price cut would free them to pursue more of the non-ethnic."
Inexpensive junk food, it is sometimes said, is more central to the diet of poor people than the well off.
An unusual study in the New England Journal of Medicine last year found that over the last three decades, poor people have made less progress in moving toward a low-fat, healthy diet than wealthier people.
In 1965, poor blacks, whose diet was rich in traditional foods like sweet potatoes, greens and black-eyed peas, ate the healthiest diet of all socioeconomic groups, the study found. Wealthier whites dined on marbled beef and high-fat cheeses.
But as the rich have gotten leaner, the poor developed a predilection for burgers.
"In the 60's, low-and middle-income America could not afford a rich high-meat diet that at the time was thought to be the good diet," said Dr. Popkin of North Carolina, the lead researcher on the study. "As their incomes went up, they consumed more and more of those high-status preference foods.
"Paradoxically, the rich today are trying to eat the diet the poor did 30 years ago."
Richard Klein, a professor of French at Cornell University and a self-described fat man, advised Americans to loosen up, literally.
In his book "Eat Fat," published last year by Pantheon, Professor Klein argued that America should lose its obsession with thinness and accept a new beauty esthetic based on the population's increasing portliness.
"A Big Mac going down to 55 cents: that's pretty hard to pass up," Professor Klein said last week, noting that he has not had one in years. "I might just try it."

HEADLINE: Beijing's Other Claim

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Thomas L. Friedman (column, March 3) writes that the only legitimacy China's leaders have is their ability to maintain economic growth. But China's leaders have another claim in reserve: they represent Chinese nationalism. Post-Communist nationalism in Eastern Europe is ugly; post-Communist nationalism in China would be more frightening still.
 
LARRY MILLER
Indiana, Pa., March 3, 1997
The writer is a professor of history, Indiana U. of Pennsylvania.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Rallying Dollar Reaches 3-Year High Against the Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar touched a three-year high against the German mark yesterday, rallying broadly on strong United States economic data, new hints of record German unemployment and more uncertainty over Europe's proposed single currency.
The gains bolstered a view that the dollar was likely to move still higher, particularly against the mark, based on the likelihood that interest rates would rise in the United States but remain static or fall in Germany, where the economy continues to languish. Higher rates tend to strengthen a currency. 
 Traders who had been caught unprepared for the dollar's surge past its prior three-year high of 1.7050 marks scrambled to buy dollars as the currency broke the 1.7100 level, heightening the rally's intensity.
"There was obviously a lot of momentum through that psychological barrier of 1.7000 marks," said Susan Stearns, director of foreign exchange at the Bank of Montreal's New York branch.
The dollar reached an intraday high of 1.7152 marks, the strongest since April 1994, before settling in New York at 1.7146 marks, up from 1.6980 Monday and up 13 percent so far for the year.
The dollar's gains against the Japanese yen were more muted, partly because the yen also strengthened against the mark. But the dollar still settled at its high for the day at 122.16 yen, up from 121.27 yen on Monday and its first close at more than 122 yen in six sessions. For the year, the dollar is up 5.4 percent against the yen.
The British pound fell to $1.6126 from $1.6176.
Demand for the dollar rose as United States economic reports showing unexpectedly strong housing sales in January and a surprisingly big surge in the Index of Leading Economic Indicators, the main forecasting gauge. The data further raised expectations that Federal Reserve policy makers who meet March 25 would raise interest rates to help thwart inflationary pressure.
The dollar also derived strength from a leaked report that the number of unemployed German workers hit another postwar high in February. The official figures are not due until tomorrow. February employment data for the United States, due Friday, are expected to be strong.

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
Fortification for Choosing Chintz

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
"Decoration and Design" are what the letters mean. But tenants in the D & D Building, 979 Third Avenue, might reasonably have wondered a few years ago whether the initials really stood for "Default and Disaster."
With its fortunes tied to a single industry -- home furnishings -- the 18-story showroom center at 58th Street in Manhattan was hard hit by the recession in the early 1990's, when the market for luxe momentarily abated. Tenants going out of business left one-third of the building empty. Rents had to be slashed for those who remained. 
 In 1993, the long-term leasehold was declared in default and the Travelers Insurance Company foreclosed on the mortgage. Then, two years ago this month, as the D & D was regaining its equilibrium under the management of Merchandise Mart Properties Inc. of Chicago, an electrical fire broke out. Although no one was injured and damage was minimal, the building had to be closed for a week, greatly disrupting designers and their clients.
Today, Charles Steven Cohen, president and chief executive of both the Decoration and Design Building and of Cohen Brothers Realty Corporation, almost cheerfully concedes that D & D was nearly "dead."
He can afford to be cheerful because the building is anything but dead these days. "We have no vacancies" among the 110 showrooms, declared Mr. Cohen, who bought the leasehold from the Travelers last September for $67 million. Rents are running from the high $30's a square foot to about $70, and Mr. Cohen said major tenants have committed themselves to 15-year leases.
Next month, Mr. Cohen plans to introduce a significant new amenity: a 14th-floor restaurant, Astra, that will be a kind of building commissary.
Quel commissary. It will be operated by Charlie Palmer, the chef and owner of Aureole, 34 East 61st Street, on which The New York Times conferred three stars in 1991 for "consistently captivating food." The architect of Astra is Ernesto Buch and the interior designer is J. Paul Terrace, both of New Haven.
"The idea is to keep the customer in the building," Mr. Cohen said, "to take the department store mentality from Bloomingdale's and bring it across the street."
Mr. Palmer said the food at Astra would be "simple and straightforward" and the service "expedited," accounting for the hectic schedules of designers who are between showroom visits. "For them, 30 to 45 minutes is a leisurely lunch," he said.
The developer and chef have entered into what Mr. Cohen calls a "licensing and occupancy arrangement" and what Mr. Palmer says is "in essence a partnership." Neither would elaborate but the point is that Mr. Palmer will pay no rent.
That amounts to a major savings in overhead. And Astra patrons will see the benefit. Soups will be priced at about $5, Mr. Palmer said, salads from $6 to $8, sandwiches from $6 to $8, pasta dishes from $8 to $12 and grilled dishes from $13 to $14.
In theory, Astra -- like the showrooms around it -- is for the trade only; designers and their customers. But the restaurant will not turn away the public.
The main room will seat about 145, and a 40-seat terrace that commands a 180-degree view, from the Sherry-Netherland Hotel to the Queensboro Bridge, will be open in fair weather. The view also takes in the Cohen Brothers' conical-peaked International Plaza at Lexington Avenue and 59th Street. Astra is to be open from 8 A.M. to 5 P.M., Monday through Friday. At night, the space will be available for openings, product launchings and parties.
Jeffrey G. Bonin, manager of the Donghia Showroom, which has expanded to 8,500 square feet from 6,000 square feet, said Astra would not be a "frivolous luxury" but rather a "viable, working, much-needed element."
The Decoration and Design Building was built in 1963 on a site assembled by Henry Hart Rice, chairman of James Felt Realty Services, who died in 1992. (The land is still owned by Mr. Rice's estate, along with others.) The developer was the late Aaron Diamond, whose name is now synonymous with the battle against AIDS because his foundation endows the Aaron Diamond AIDS Research Center in Manhattan.
Unlike the chintz within, the 570,000-square-foot D & D Building has a stark, industrial look: bands of white brick alternating with bands of metal-framed windows. The architects were David and Earl J. Levy.
Mr. Cohen said he hoped to open Astra with a black-tie dinner for the 25th anniversary of the annual Decorator Show House in 603 Park Avenue, at 64th Street, which benefits the Kips Bay Boys and Girls Club.
As it happens, the Park Avenue town house is owned by Mr. Cohen's father, Sherman. "It's on the market," the younger Mr. Cohen said. "That should help sell it. We're doing a little cross-pollination."

HEADLINE: New Life for Lowly Pallets;
South Bronx Company Recycles Overlooked Wood

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
"Just look at that grain," David M. Muchnick said, as he hefted an arm-size plank with the rich, swirly coloring of mocha fudge ice cream.
The board, a hunk of valuable rosewood, had recently arrived in New York with a shipment of imports from South America. But it was not part of the shipment. It was part of the creaky, splintery pallet on which the goods were loaded. 
 Like most of the six million pallets that carry goods in and around New York City every year, this one was slated to be chipped, burned or dumped after only a couple of trips. But Mr. Muchnick's South Bronx company, Big City Forest, salvaged it.
Soon the piece of rosewood -- along with thousands of feet of cherry, oak, mahogany, maple, and other valuable hardwood boards recycled from pallets -- would be turned into furniture, flooring, butcher block or other products by Big City Forest's home-grown work force of artisans.
The company's admirers and customers include Ben Cohen, one of the founders of Ben & Jerry's Homemade, the ice cream maker. Mr. Cohen bought slabs of Bronx-made butcher block for his Vermont home and also had wood panels installed in dozens of the company's shops.
"The idea of having the environmental benefit of keeping this useful wood from going into landfills, and creating jobs and job training for people in the inner city is fantastic," Mr. Cohen said. "It's a win-win-win-win situation. Lots of wins. And the stuff is great to look at. Nothing has the beauty and soul and warmth of wood."
By reclaiming more than 180,000 pallets a year, along with crates and other unwanted wood packaging, Big City Forest has tapped into a vast resource that most American businesses consider a costly liability. In New York City alone, businesses spend $130 million a year to dispose of millions of pallets and other wood waste, Mr. Muchnick said. His company cuts that cost by providing an alternative cheaper than carting pallets to landfills.
Typically, Big City Forest charges 75 cents for each pallet dropped at its doors at 1809 Carter Avenue in the Tremont section, substantially less than the fees of up to $5 each charged by carters, he said. Enjoying a rare luxury in the business world, it thus gets money not only for its products, but also from the companies supplying its raw material.
By transforming lowly pallets into valuable products in a single operation, Big City Forest is also creating dozens of new jobs, Mr. Muchnick said, giving previously unemployed people a marketable skill.
His goal is to franchise the company, setting up licensed copies in other cities where unwanted pallets are plentiful and jobs hard to come by. There is also a long list of environmental benefits, he said. By spreading the practice in the United States and overseas, deforestation could be reduced as more wood is re-used, and the flow of a valuable material to landfills, chippers or furnaces could be stanched, he said.
In the United States, several hundred million pallets go to waste each year, he said. Worse yet, Mr. Muchnick said, even as all that wood is wasted, nearly half of the wood from hardwood trees cut each year in American forests is used to build new pallets. "What a destructive cycle," he said.
Big City Forest is the latest of several recycling businesses spun off from Bronx 2000, a nonprofit economic development group that Mr. Muchnick helped found in 1979 to revive the long-suffering neighborhoods around Tremont Avenue.
In its third year, Big City Forest is preparing to triple its work space and expects to triple its work force of about two dozen people.
There are many larger pallet recycling businesses around the country, but most simply turn the incoming wood into chips, said Resa Dimino, an environmental specialist at Big City Forest. As chips, the wood is worth about $30 a ton. As flooring, the value rises to $1,200 a ton, and as furniture, the wood in pallets is worth $6,000 a ton, she said, with all that added value translating directly into South Bronx jobs.
Big City Forest uses about 60 percent of the wood from pallets flowing into its warehouse to make new pallets, with the best quality planks set aside for the most valuable products. These planks are run through a metal detector, and workers pull stray nails and staples.
The worst wood is used to build new pallets. Odds and ends are chipped and sold to a manufacturer of pressed-wood boards, Ms. Dimino said. The last scraps are burned in two large furnaces to heat the buildings. "All you'll see in our Dumpster is a little sawdust and leftover lunch bags," Ms. Dimino said.
One big potential market for the pallet wood is oak flooring, Mr. Muchnick said. Every year, 1.5 billion board feet of oak is wasted in pallets, he said, while 500 million board feet of lumber from newly cut oaks goes into floors. "If you reclaimed one third of the oak in tossed pallets, you would not have to cut a single growing oak to make flooring," he said.
Last year, the National Association of Home Builders, a trade group in Maryland, installed oak flooring from Big City Forest in two model town houses built to display materials that saved energy or had environmental benefits. Peter Yost, an economist at the association's research center, said "visitors are amazed" when they hear where the wood came from.
Butcher-block tables and benches with the company's logo are sold to institutional clients like foster-care centers and Cornell University -- "they're frat proof," Ms. Dimino said -- but are also showing up in chic shops like Terra Verde in SoHo.
Customers happily pay $750 for a five-foot table, said the shop's owner, Katherine Tiddens.
"They're like a rock," Ms. Tiddens said, "like a lesson in wood."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Housing Data Help to Push Bonds Lower

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices finished lower in choppy trading yesterday, hurt by a housing report that was stronger than expected.
The market was also weighed down by the prospect of more testimony from Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve. Mr. Greenspan will speak today before a House banking subcommittee in the second leg of his semiannual Humphrey-Hawkins report on the state of the economy. The bond market has been nervous about the Fed's next move on interest rates since Mr. Greenspan said last week that a pre-emptive move might be needed to keep inflation from accelerating. 
 Traders said a strong dollar kept Treasury prices from falling further yesterday, as the dollar touched a three-year high against the German mark. The dollar's rally raised expectations that foreign investors would continue buying Treasury securities because of the potential gains from conversion.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 14/32, to 97. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.86 percent from 6.83 percent on Monday.
Analysts said that traders initially sold after the Commerce Department said that sales of new homes in January rose 8.6 percent to the highest level in 10 years. Expectations had been for a 4 percent decline.
The housing report added to the evidence that economic growth is strong enough to push prices higher. That, in turn, could make it more likely that the Fed will raise short-term rates at its monetary policy meeting on March 25.
The release of the LJR Redbook survey of retail sales, which showed sales rose 2.4 percent in February from January, added to losses.
Individually, yesterday's reports did not affect the market that much, according to Greg Jones, an economist with Briefing.com, a market analysis firm in Menlo Park, Calif.
But together, he said, they contributed to the view that the economy is stronger than had been expected. And coming before Mr. Greenspan's testimony and Friday's release of February employment data, the reports kept investors anxious.
Bonds were also hurt, traders said, by word that Western Asset Management, a money management company, was selling some corporate bond holdings. "We have been trimming our exposure in corporate bonds and this is another part of that strategy," said Scott F. Grannis, chief economist of Western Asset, which is based in Pasadena, Calif.
About 25 percent of the company's holdings are in corporate bonds. Mr. Grannis said that sale proceeds would be used to buy Treasury securities of about the same maturities.
"I can't see how this would have affected interest rates today," he said. "In the corporate market, this is not a lot of money."
But Treasury prices were bolstered somewhat by purchases in the market by the Federal Reserve, in what is known as a coupon pass. The Fed's purchase of Treasury securities was mostly within a thin two-year range, with maturity dates ranging from 2000 to 2002.
In the corporate market, the Chrysler Credit Corporation sold $1.25 billion of asset-backed securities through Premier Auto Trust 1997-1. Underwriters, led by Merrill Lynch, said that $250 million of the class A-1 securities was retained and not reoffered to the public.
The class A-2 issue is $600 million in securities, with an average life of 1.01 years and a yield of 6 percent. The class A-3 issue is $393.75 million, with an average life of 2.16 years and a yield of 6.338 percent. The class A-4 issue is $200 million in securities, with an average life of 3.09 years and a yield of 6.481 percent.

HEADLINE: New-Home Sales Jumped 8.6% in January

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 4

 BODY:
The Government reported today that sales of new homes had risen 8.6 percent in January, but private analysts reacted with caution, suggesting that several factors might have skewed the figures.
In a second report, the Conference Board said that its index of leading indicators, designed to predict turns in the economy, climbed three-tenths of 1 percent in January, its biggest advance since May. 
 If the report on home sales is accurate, it would imply a renewed boom in housing -- a marked contrast to the prediction of Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, who told Congress last week that home building this year was unlikely to repeat its buoyant 1996 performance.
But private analysts, most of whom had expected a modest decline, were skeptical of the figures, released jointly by the Commerce and Housing and Urban Development Departments.
"We think it's probably too good to be true," said David F. Seiders, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders. Everett M. Ehrlich, Under Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs, defended the agency even as he acknowledged that special factors had played a significant role.
"The magnitude and direction are correct," Mr. Ehrlich insisted.
Two factors were responsible for the private analysts' skepticism about the housing report.
They contended that the seasonal adjustment process had been thrown out of kilter by the January 1996 blizzard and the exceptionally cold weather of January 1995.
Abnormally low sales in those two months may have resulted in an exaggerated increase this year, said Stuart G. Hoffman, chief economist at PNC Bank in Pittsburgh.
In addition, they pointed to a footnote in the Government's release disclosing that its data collection had been computerized, perhaps producing "some upward bias in the estimates."
Mr. Ehrlich said he was uncertain whether the upward bias would prove a one-time phenomenon or would show a permanently higher level of sales.
The long-term result would depend on whether the new process was merely capturing data faster or was picking up data that had previously been missed.
Compounding the uncertainty is the fact that the home sales figures always have a huge margin of error, plus or minus 11 percentage points. This means that the actual result for January, now reported at an annual rate of 870,000, may have ranged anywhere from 20 percent higher than in December to 2 percent lower than in December.
That seasonality was a big factor seemed to be reflected in the regional figures that showed, among other things, that sales in the Northeast -- where the blizzard struck a year earlier -- boomed 63 percent, to an annual rate of 134,000. The South was up 11.9 percent, to a rate of 403,000.
Sales of single-family homes declined in the Midwest and West, by 10.2 percent and 5.9 percent, respectively.
The median sales price climbed $2,000, to $145,000, for the month, which ended with builders holding an inventory of 4.5 months, compared with 5 months in November and December.
Home sales for October, November and December were all revised upward, the department also reported.
The rise in the index of leading indicators was driven mainly by an increase in new factory orders for consumer goods and materials and a decline in first-time claims for unemployment insurance, the Conference Board's report showed. The two main drags were faster deliveries by suppliers and a shortening of the average workweek.
The indexes of coincident and lagging indicators moved up one-tenth of 1 percent and down two-tenths of 1 percent, respectively.
