HEADLINE: Renault Layoffs Test French Commitment to European Unity

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, March 4

 BODY:
Europe, the French kept saying, was not like the United States, and never would be.
Strong social legislation, early retirement plans and consultation between labor and management protected European workers from brutal American-style downsizings and made Europe a more humane place to live than the United States or competition-crazed East Asia -- and a united Europe would make sure things stayed that way. 
 But the push for unity, particularly the plan for a single currency, has required increasing fiscal discipline in Europe's governments and large industries, sometimes making unity and the social safety net seem like conflicting ends. When the French automotive giant Renault S.A., which was nationalized in 1946 and is still 46 percent owned by the French state, decided that slumping car sales and mounting losses necessitated layoffs and dismissals, it picked an assembly plant across the border in Belgium, one that employs 3,100 mostly Flemish-speaking workers, to bear the brunt of them. It announced last Thursday that it would close the plant in July.
The decision has caused a storm of protest in Belgium and has raised questions -- even at home -- about France's commitment to the idea of European unity when its own economic interests are at stake.
"Beyond Renault and its image, it's France and her credibility that are in doubt," the staid Paris daily Le Monde wrote of the rising clamor, as workers occupied the plant at Vilvoorde, near Brussels, and Belgian labor unions called for a boycott and distributed bumper stickers saying, "This is my last Renault, what about you?"
Today, Renault, which has 140,000 workers worldwide, disclosed that it would also eliminate 2,764 jobs in France this year. Though those cuts will be more widely dispersed than in the Belgian move, French unions have reacted angrily, planning a work stoppage for later this week, and the announcement does not appear to have mollified the Belgians.
Renault is not the only European auto maker that has felt the need to improve its productivity and competitiveness. But its attempts to do so seem singularly awkward.
Though the Vilvoorde plant is in the election district of Belgium's Prime Minister, Jean-Luc Dehaene, Renault apparently did not inform him or his French counterpart, Prime Minister Alain Juppe, that it had decided to close the plant before making the announcement last week.
Taken by surprise, Mr. Dehaene called the closing unacceptable and said on French television that he would insist on an alternative.
"The Government is concerned and stupefied," he said after Renault's chairman, Louis Schweitzer, broke the news to the plant's employees on a visit to Belgium last week.
The Belgian Government and regional Flemish authorities said this week that they would ask the European Union's executive body in Brussels, the European Commission, to rule on whether Renault had violated European labor guidelines.
They also said they would take the company to court, accusing it of violating a Belgian law requiring management to consult labor before major decisions on issues affecting employees. "It is largely symbolic, but at least it's something we could do," a Belgian Labor Ministry spokeswoman said, noting that Renault would face a maximum fine of $850,000 if it was found to have broken the law.
In the face of increasing global economic competition, Europe's highly regulated labor markets are often blamed for the Continent's double-digit unemployment, and nowhere is the competition sharper than in the automotive industry.
"Renault's closure is not against Belgium," the French Minister of Labor and Social Affairs, Jacques Barrot, said. "Competition is raging. We realize that to be a player in this globalization of the economy we have to fight."
But some of Renault's Belgian workers see a further motivation in the company's plan to close their plant, contending that Renault might have treated them differently if they had been French-speaking Walloons. Workers occupied the plant after the announcement, keeping 4,000 new Clio models under assembly from being shipped out. Those not holding the cars hostage took to the streets of Brussels in protest on Monday.
Others said they had expected better of Mr. Schweitzer, a nephew of Albert Schweitzer, the famous Alsatian physician and missionary, and a member of France's Socialist Party. The party's leader, Lionel Jospin, today called on the French Government to intervene and called the decision to close the plant "financially, industrially and socially aberrant."
"Trying to play off workers from one country against those of another is not worthy of a great French and European enterprise," especially one in which the state owns such a large stake, he said.
Mr. Schweitzer went ahead with the decision to close the plant after the Government turned down a plan proposed by Renault and its main French competitor, PSA Peugeot Citroen, to help the companies retire 40,000 automotive workers early. A leading member of Parliament from President Jacques Chirac's conservative party, Michel Pericard, said today that the Government might reconsider in light of what he called a "sudden and brutal" plant closing decision.
So far, Mr. Chirac and Mr. Juppe have had nothing to say about the controversy. Unions have called a one-hour work stoppage for Friday in the company's 26 plants in France, Belgium and Spain to protest the plant closing. Belgian union leaders have called on Mr. Schweitzer to attend a meeting with them in Vilvoorde and have announced plans to picket a Renault plant in Douai across the border in France.
Renault reportedly expects losses of $700 million for 1996, when it produced 1.57 million passenger cars, 216,000 vans and other commercial vehicles and 63,000 trucks. The company said that switching production from Vilvoorde to other plants in France and Spain would produce yearly savings of $149 million.
Under French and Belgian labor laws, employees cannot be summarily dismissed. Those at Vilvoorde will receive severance pay and some could be eligible for early retirement on the Government-supported pension system. A company spokesman said that discussions with the unions about the cuts in Belgium and France would begin on March 13.

HEADLINE: Seattle Superintendent to Hold Off on Allowing Ads in Schools

DATELINE: SEATTLE, March 4

 BODY:
Responding to strong community opposition, the head of the Seattle public schools has proposed that the school board suspend its new policy to seek advertising revenue from corporations, postponing action while the issue is studied.
The district's chief financial officer, Joseph Olchefske, had speculated in January that the policy might result in "the cheerleaders, brought to you by Reebok," or "the McDonald's gym." District officials estimated that the district might have raised $1 million a year from such sponsorships. 
 But some parents and teachers opposed the plan, leading Superintendent John Stanford to ask the board to reconsider it.
"I think Mr. Stanford is sending a strong signal that we may be desperate for money, but the Seattle school district cares more about kids than it does about corporations," said Brita Butler-Wall, a spokeswoman for the newly formed Citizens Campaign for Commercial-Free Schools. "It's bad enough to allow corporations access to a captive audience, let alone get a kickback for it."
The board is expected to suspend the plan at its meeting on Wednesday, and Mr. Stanford is expected to appoint a committee to review the policy.
Lisa Bond, president of the Parent Teacher Student Association, a leading opponent of advertising in the schools, said that group would probably recommend that advertising be banned inside schools. The group may consider allowing advertisements outside school buildings -- with restrictions.
"Any kind of advertising message should be directed to adults and not to the students," Ms. Bond said, "and there should not be materials that try to influence student behavior. It should be clearly separated from what's taught children."
The board decided in November to pursue advertising to make up for a $35 million shortfall projected over the next three years, the result of a shortfall in state financing, caused because the state no longer adjusts the level to account for inflation, and a new cap on property taxes. The system's annual budget is $322 million.
"The traditional funding sources are defunding us," Mr. Olchefske said, "so we have to look to nontraditional sources."
Mr. Stanford has also asked the board to review the advertising already in the schools. Currently, 12 or 13 schools use a commercial television news program called Channel One, said a district spokeswoman, Chris Case.
David Fisher, who teaches math and upper-level marine biology at Cleveland High School, said he welcomed the move by Mr. Stanford.
"It's not education -- it's advertising," he said. "It's psychological warfare. They're trying to basically steal these children's minds and get them to spend their money on these products."
Ms. Butler-Wall said children were sometimes unwittingly bombarded with advertising, something she had seen recently while volunteering in her daughter's third-grade reading class. The teacher had made flashcards to test the children on vowel sounds. One said "Coke," and the teacher remarked that all the children knew that one.
"It showed me that commercialism is so much a part of the white noise of the school that even an absolutely fabulous teacher like this one really didn't hear the words come out of her mouth," Ms. Butler-Wall said.

HEADLINE: Moves Continue on Price Index Changes

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 4

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration and Congress continued today to dance around one of the most sensitive issues they face this year -- whether to reduce cost of living adjustments for Social Security.
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, urged the House Banking Committee today to tackle the issue head on by appointing a commission that would provide a better estimate of increases in the cost of living than the Consumer Price Index, which most economists believe overstates inflation. 
 The White House began sounding out Congressional Democrats and Republicans about whether there was some middle ground on the issue, including the creation of a commission. But Administration officials confronted divisions within each party as well as between them.
Republicans privately admitted that they are sorely tempted to slow cost of living adjustments to pay for the big tax cuts they have proposed. But, still stinging from the pounding they took over the last two years for proposing reductions in the growth of Medicare, they fear that Democrats will depict them in the next election as taking money from Grandma to give a break to the wealthy. "Accurate statistics should not be demagogued, but they are," said an aide to one top Republican.
Congressional Democrats, meanwhile, were torn between their traditional commitment to protecting entitlement programs and the need to come up with money to protect spending priorities.
A group of conservative House Democrats has proposed reducing the Consumer Price Index by 0.8 percentage points in calculating cost of living adjustments as a way of helping to eliminate the Federal deficit. But the House Democratic leader, Representative Richard A. Gephardt, said today that such adjustments should be removed completely from the budget process.
"That simply drives a decision to cut, cut, cut, to replace the resolve that some lack in making the tough calls on how to balance the budget," Mr. Gephardt said. "If Alan Greenspan believes there is a 100 percent probability that the C.P.I. is exaggerated, I believe that politicians appointing a commission will lead to a 100 percent probability that the decision will be politicized."
Support for reducing the adjustments is strongest in the Senate, where the leaders of both parties, Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, a Republican, and Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, a Democrat, both support a commission.
But in the House, Republican leaders including Speaker Newt Gingrich and Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the majority leader, want the White House to settle the issue with the Bureau of Labor Statistics and are wary of any commission that would put Republicans on record as having voted for a reduction in the payments. Aides to Mr. Gingrich said he did not want to rush a decision just for the sake of balancing the budget.

HEADLINE: Terse Congressman Questions Greenspan's Market Motives

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 4

 BODY:
A lot of people on Wall Street have been asking in the last few days why Alan Greenspan thought it was his place to judge that stock prices might be too high, and today a Republican member of the House Budget Committee put that question to him, directly and somewhat testily, suggesting that the Fed chairman should quit meddling when it comes to the financial markets.
"My question to you," Representative Jim Bunning of Kentucky said, "is why have you, on two occasions, taken to jawboning the U.S. stock market and the U.S. bond market with your comments to affect a free and open market as head of the Federal Reserve Board, which is in charge of setting monetary policy?" 
 Mr. Greenspan replied that he had not intended to talk the markets down when he warned last week that investors might have too rosy a view of the risks in the market. Moreover, he said, he never would have succeeded if that were his intent.
"These are very thick, elaborate international markets which are driven by decisions of millions of people," Mr. Greenspan said. "Nobody can affect them in a fundamental way. There is no way you can divert extraordinary forces of supply and demand in those markets."
Mr. Greenspan acknowledged that his remarks could move the markets temporarily, but he attributed such moves to a small group of speculators.
"The reason why that happens is that there are numbers of people on the fringes of the markets who move in and out and are very often trading on the basis of information which as best I can judge is rather faulty," Mr. Greenspan said.
Mr. Bunning was clearly not satisfied with Mr. Greenspan's protestations of innocence and impotence. Breaking the established pattern of deference to Mr. Greenspan by members of Congressional committees, Mr. Bunning abruptly cut Mr. Greenspan off several times, saying, at one point, "I've only got five minutes, and I've got some other questions."
Mr. Bunning noted that Mr. Greenspan had declined to answer several questions from other members of the committee about sensitive political topics because they were not directly related to monetary policy.
"Why have you chosen not to stay on the sidelines as far as the open New York Stock Exchange, American Stock Exchange, Nasdaq stock exchange and the bond market, and for that matter, other markets around the world?" Mr. Bunning asked.
Mr. Greenspan replied that the markets had a direct influence on monetary policy.
"The fact of the matter is that they do because in order to make the appropriate judgments as to what degree of monetary tightening or loosening in which we engage, it is very important to look not only at the structure of how we produce goods and services but also to have very good insight into the financial markets as they are evolving," Mr. Greenspan said.

HEADLINE: Congress Again Kills Budget-Balancing Proposal

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 4

 BODY:
For the eighth time in 15 years, Congress has defeated a Constitutional amendment to require the Federal budget to be balanced.
Today, as expected, the Senate buried it in a shallow grave, by just a single vote, as it did two years ago. The vote was 66 in favor and 34 opposed, or one short of the two-thirds requirement for a constitutional amendment. All 55 Republicans voted yes; 34 Democrats voted no and 11 voted yes. 
 Proponents of the amendment insisted they would try again, probably in the next Congress, and blamed political pressure for their defeat.
"Those who have twisted the last arm," said Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, "are those who are frightened by the concept of less government, rather than more." Mr. Domenici, the Budget Committee chairman, argued that the amendment "is about freedom." He said: "To the extent that government grows and grows, freedom diminishes and diminishes. To the extent that we tax and tax, our freedom diminishes."
Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, the senior Democrat in the Senate, said the amendment "would rudely disrupt the carefully balanced powers of the three branches, so assiduously planned by the framers. It would, for the first time in our history, write a specific fiscal policy into a Constitution intended to accommodate the ages."
"It would subjugate every endeavor, every need, every aspiration of the people of this nation to one goal -- the goal of perpetually maintaining budget balance," he said.
President Clinton praised the Senate action, issuing a statement saying that the amendment "could have caused or worsened recessions, permitted a minority of legislators to hold the nation's creditworthiness hostage, involved unelected judges in spending and tax policy, and threatened Social Security and other vital benefits."
The amendment would require receipts to equal outlays in every year unless Congress, by a three-fifths majority, voted to suspend the requirement. A major argument against it was that it would threaten Social Security payments.
Senator Orrin G. Hatch, the Utah Republican who heads the Judiciary Committee, complained, "Every time they are losing, they try to bring up the Social Security argument." He added: "I'm tired of it. It's not right for them to continue to hide behind this phony issue. It's about time to get rid of the demagoguery."
But when the votes were cast, the amendment was defeated in the Senate, as it was in 1986, 1994, 1995 and 1996. The Senate passed the amendment on a 69 to 31 vote in 1982, but it was defeated in the House that year, as it was in 1990, 1992 and 1994. The House passed it in 1995, but the Social Security issue has tied it up in committee this year.
Mr. Hatch promised to try again. "It's not over," he said. "I never quit. I'll look for a wishbone in a soft-boiled egg, and there's a lot of soft-boiled eggs out there." He then said, "Maybe I ought to be looking for some backbones instead of wishbones."
The closing debate was arranged in an unusual way, not with speakers alternating in support and opposition, but with sizable chunks of time given first to one side and then the other. That freed senators from the risk of hearing the arguments voiced by the other side.

HEADLINE: Bikini Journal;
An Atomic Age Eden (but Don't Eat the Coconuts)

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: BIKINI, Marshall Islands

 BODY:
After the 23 nuclear explosions that the United States conducted on this remote coral atoll in the 1940's and 50's, one almost expects to visit today and find just a few charred islets surrounded by brackish water emitting an eerie glow.
So the amazing thing about Bikini is how alive it is: a white sand island full of coconut palms swaying over a perfect turquoise sea, fish and sea turtles swimming languorously by the beach. There are also a few tourists, and many more are expected, because Bikini is now once more open to the public. 
 The paradox is that the same atomic bombs and hydrogen bombs that once caused immense tragedy to the Bikinians, even vaporizing some of their islets, have now made the island an unusually valuable tourist property.
Aside from its worldwide fame and relics like a bunker that once had a hot line to the White House, Bikini has the appeal of an untouched island and coral reef, as well as a lagoon offering some of the best scuba diving in the world.
Divers often like to explore shipwrecks, and there is no place with wrecks like the lagoon here in Bikini, one of the specks of islands scattered in the Pacific between Hawaii and Japan. Some 19 ships, including the only divable aircraft carrier in the world, lie at the bottom of the lagoon, where they sank after the United States tested what would happen to big ships when an atomic bomb exploded nearby. (They sink.)
Most atolls in the Pacific are barely viable in a modern economy. But Bikini, because of its fame and the bombed-out shipwrecks, might emerge as one of the few that can thrive on tourism. The heartbreak of the Bikinians would become their sustenance.
Six scientific surveys have declared that the island is now basically habitable, so long as residents do not eat too many local coconuts. So the people of Bikini -- who have been wandering about the Marshall Islands as "nuclear nomads" ever since the United States evicted them from their island in 1946 -- are now considering whether to return.
"It's so beautiful here," said Edward Maddison, a Bikinian who is helping to run a new scuba diving program for foreigners on Bikini. "Sometimes I bring my family here, and my kids love to swim in the lagoon because it's so clean.
"Every time I go back, people ask me what it's like, if it's safe to come back to Bikini. If it's safe, we'll be coming back."
The Marshall Islanders were in effect guinea pigs during the nuclear testing, and Western doctors still examine them to determine the delayed effects of radiation. But this time, the Bikini islanders say with a smile, it is they who are conducting the experiment: they stand back and monitor the results as wealthy Western tourists visit the island.
"We're very curious about the effects on those people," said Johnny Johnson, a Bikinian now living in Majuro, the capital of the Marshall Islands.
Bikini became a household name around the world in 1946 when the United States announced that it would test nuclear weapons on the atoll. The countdown for the first explosion was broadcast around the world, vast supplies of film were used to record the mushroom cloud, and Godzilla was said to have risen from Bikini lagoon after being disturbed by the explosions.
A skimpy new bathing suit for women was just coming on the market then in France, and its makers called it the bikini, advertising it as the world's smallest and hoping perhaps to suggest the shocking effect of a nuclear blast.
Over the next 12 years, 22 more atomic or hydrogen bombs were detonated here. One hydrogen bomb dropped over Bikini in 1954 was the most powerful explosion ever detonated by the United States, equivalent to 750 Hiroshima-type bombs. It vaporized one islet and part of two others, and it showered radioactive particles on Marshallese living on other atolls.
So the testing left Bikini deserted.
"It was really bad for the Bikinians, but anything bad can be turned into something good," said Fabio Amaral, a Brazilian who runs the Bikini dive program along with Mr. Maddison and an American, Scott Herman. It is precisely the enforced desertion of Bikini, Mr. Amaral noted, that has made it such a gem today.
"This is a wilderness," he added. "This place hasn't been touched in 40 years."
A large sea turtle made the point a moment later, lazily swimming in shallow water a few feet off the beach. Schools of fish dart about the coral, and Bikinians are also trying to set up a sports fishing program to attract Americans interested in catching bonefish and other game fish.
"I went out with two rods at first, but I had to go down to one because I had double-hookings too often," said Roderick Bourke, 26, an Australian who runs the diving resort and catches the fish that are served to guests.
Despite nervous jokes about how the Bikini landing strip has no need for runway lights, the sea and wind have long since dispersed almost all of the radioactivity, according to extensive testing. Indeed, Bikini now has less background radiation than some American cities. The problem is that the ground still contains cesium-137, a radioactive substance, and this is concentrated in fruits and coconuts grown on Bikini.
A small group of Bikinians sent back to Bikini in the early 1970's had to be evacuated in 1978 because their diet of coconuts resulted in an alarming buildup of cesium in their bodies.
There has been talk of scraping off the entire top layer of earth and sand of Bikini to get rid of the cesium, but the scientific studies agree that the simplest and cheapest way of dealing with this problem would be to spread potassium fertilizer. Plants prefer potassium to cesium, so if potassium were available they apparently would take it and leave the cesium alone.
But the Bikinians are still profoundly wary, and they say they want an assurance from President Clinton that it is safe to go back.
"I see what's going on there on Bikini, and I'm very envious of the people there," said Jason Aitap, the acting mayor on Ejit, a bleak little island accessible only by boat and inhabited by some of the 2,200 Bikinians now living in exile. "I'd love to go back. But you've got to understand that we really want assurances from the U.S. that it's safe."
A few other Bikinians, sitting on the broken white coral outside a home and listening to Mr. Aitap, agreed and nodded their heads. One after another, the Bikinians on Ejit repeated the mantra: the United States has a responsibility, after poisoning their soil, to declare that it is safe for them to return.
The American Ambassador to the Marshall Islands, Joan M. Plaisted, said the United States would look into the possibility of issuing some kind of a statement about whether it is safe to return to Bikini. She added that the United States feels a legal, and perhaps moral, responsibility to the Bikinians because of the nuclear testing.
"The United States Government certainly remains committed to the return of the Bikini people to their original homeland," she said.
The United States seems a bit flummoxed, though, by the way President Clinton has been effectively made the king of Bikinians. There is a long tradition of Marshall Islanders having an outside king, or iroij, and these days many Bikinians say Mr. Clinton is the man.
Traditionally, the king receives fealty from his people but also has a responsibility for them. The Bikinians insist that by moving them off their island and promising to care for them, the United States entered that relationship so that the American President is their king and is responsible for their welfare.
"That's exactly what he is," Mr. Aitap said after being asked if Mr. Clinton was their king. "And we expect him to act like an iroij and look after his people."
One reason the Bikinians want Mr. Clinton as their king is that they are worried by the efforts of Imata Kabua, the President of the Marshall Islands, to declare himself their king -- and claim one-third of their revenues.
Mr. Kabua notes that he comes from a family of chiefs on an atoll near Bikini, and he says he is rightly the king of Bikinians and entitled to the money.
So far, he has not gotten any money from them, but in January he demanded that the Bikinians build him a fine new house in the capital. At a time when many Bikinians themselves are still living in plywood shacks, they saw no reason to use their money to build a mansion for a millionaire like Mr. Kabua.
Asked about the Bikinians' attitude, President Kabua responded with an expletive. His tongue was loosened and he appeared to be drunk (he was interviewed in the hotel bar that he frequents), and he said he would go to court to get access to some of their money. He also said that if they resisted he would expel them from the islands where they have been living, in some cases for decades.
"I'm going to sue them," he said, and then he repeated the expletive.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Buy steel stocks? Which side of the crucible do you stare at?

BYLINE: By Claudia H. Deutsch 

 BODY:
PARDON the takeoff on an old cliche, but is the crucible half-full of molten steel or half-empty?
Most steel-industry analysts are high on scrap recyclers who provide the raw material for efficient mini-mills like Nucor, and on the service companies like Olympic Steel or Worthington Industries that turn steel into parts for the eventual user. But when it comes to old-line manufacturers like Bethlehem Steel or National or USX, Wall Street cannot seem to reach a consensus. 
 The naysayers note that old steel mills break down constantly. And they warn of an impending glut of steel, as new plants come on stream, old ones are fixed and labor unrest at Wheeling-Pittsburgh is resolved. They also predict that, even though it costs more than $50 to ship a ton of steel, foreign producers will continue to underprice the Americans.
"I'm just not too keen on this industry right now," said Scott Morrison, an analyst with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
Jordan Estra of Bankers Trust was blunter. "I unabashedly tell investors to sell the steel producers' stocks," he said.
But the cup-half-full contingent is just as vocal in telling its clients to buy big steel stocks. Some note that the industry's productivity has been increasing 7 percent a year, compared with just 2 percent for the overall economy, and that it keeps finding cheaper ways to make steel.
Others just cannot resist a bargain. A few months ago Warren E. Spitz, a portfolio manager at Prudential Investments, bought chunks of USX, which kept its earnings up even during the worst of the recession; LTV, which emerged from bankruptcy in 1993 with a clean balance sheet and high cash flow, and Bethlehem Steel, which, at $8.375, Mr. Spitz sees as simply undervalued.
"In this market, steel stocks really look inexpensive, and with little downside risk," he said.
Indeed, having risen so little, steel stocks will not have far to fall whenever the bull market turns bearish. "Steel stocks were second only to truckers as the worst-performing group over the last two years," said Richard Aldrich of Lehman Brothers, who, while neutral on most companies, expects LTV and AK Steel, the industry's lowest-cost producer, to outperform the market.
But most of all, steel's new fans cite the law of supply and demand. They note that demand for steel in the United States is at a 25-year high, and that even the influx of foreign steel did not stop prices from rising 15 percent last year. Orders from construction and automotive companies, driven by the strong economy, have been too robust. "There's been a 'temporary' shortage of steel for five years now, and the reason is rising demand," said Michelle Galanter Applebaum, a Salomon Brothers analyst, who has strong buy recommendations on LTV, AK Steel and USX.
Even if supply, not demand, becomes the main factor, steel investors need not prepare to wear mourning threads any time soon. Numerous steel plants, particularly overseas, have been announced and delayed as foreign governments stop subsidizing commodity industries and banks choose not to pick up the slack.
Kenneth W. P. Hoffman, a Prudential research analyst, notes that the Asian nations together have canceled planned capacity for 60 million tons of steel because they could not find financing. "There's a 50 percent likelihood that world steel tightness will send steel prices up 60 percent over the next two years," Mr. Hoffman predicted.
Industry executives readily agree. "Demand for steel is not in question, but supply is," said Keith Busse, president of Steel Dynamics, a mini-mill operator in Butler, Ind., that went public in November.
Prices are creeping up already. In August a ton of steel sold for $274 in the United States; today the price is $315.
But the share prices have been erratic. Steel Dynamics opened at $16, and investors immediately drove the stock to $24. It has since dropped to $19.75.
The stock of Commercial Metals of Dallas, which processes scrap and operates mini-mills, hit a peak of $33.50 twice last year, but now seems stuck around $29. "We have to keep beating the drum about our conservative accounting, and the benefits of processing scrap and steel," said Stanley A. Rabin, its president.
Both those companies are turning up on many Wall Street buy lists primarily because they use new technologies. If there is any pattern to the steel analysts' picks and pans, it is a preference for companies that still view steel as ripe for productivity gains through technology.
Steel Dynamics is adding operations at Butler that can produce processed steel at a fraction of the 3.7 worker-hours a ton that most producers require to make steel. The company is also exploring methods to substitute melted iron ore for more expensive scrap in its mills.
Some of the primary producers are exploring new technologies, often through joint ventures. AK is putting in new finishing plants, and LTV is licensing German technology to reduce iron ore to molten iron, which it can sell to mini-mills as a cheaper substitute for scrap steel.
Some industry pessimists expect that several years down the road, the most modern steel companies will do just fine, particularly if Europe pulls out of recession and demand picks up accordingly. Even Mr. Estra says that "we might see steel stocks go up again a year or two from now."
But on Wall Street, that is a millennium away.

HEADLINE: Town With Bad Luck Waits Out New Flood

BYLINE: By RICK BRAGG 

DATELINE: SHEPHERDSVILLE, Ky., March 4

 BODY:
Good luck seems to trickle into this old river town. Bad luck pours.
In 1854, a cholera epidemic killed 18 people here in Shepherdsville, the Bullitt County seat. In 1862, Confederate cavalry led by Brig. Gen. John Hunt Morgan burned down the railroad bridge, the town's economic lifeline, in what people here call the "Christmas raid." 
 In 1909 the Salt River overflowed its banks and swallowed the downtown district. In 1917, at Christmastime again, a Cincinnati-to-New Orleans freight train slammed into a passenger train here, killing 49 people. In 1920 it was a fire.
In 1937 it was another flood, and floods again in 1961 and 1964. In 1977 it was a derailment, and in 1989 it was still another flood.
The way Linda Neidlow saw it, as she waited at a shelter here for the flood waters to recede from the living room of her mobile home, "I guess it was just my turn."
"I've been lucky for many years," said Mrs. Neidlow, one of hundreds of Bullitt County residents forced from their homes this week by the Salt River and its tributaries. "The other people haven't."
This town, about 20 miles south of Louisville, is just one of dozens of small towns in Kentucky, Indiana and Ohio that have seen their streets run brown with water that has washed some homes off their foundations and washed away keepsakes and memories from others. More than 3,000 people in the three-state area have been evacuated or are now picking through the damage.
Shepherdsville, born around a salt lick in the late 1700's, is special only in its history and, say the people who live here, in its resilience.
"My trailer isn't insured for floods, just fires," Mrs. Neidlow, a tiny woman in big glasses, said in a worried voice. She paused, then added: "Well, at least I never had a fire. I'm lucky."
Like the rest of mostly rural Bullitt County, Shepherdsville is not a wealthy place. Most people here either earn their living by working with their hands or exist on some kind of government check. It is hard enough to make a life here without having nature sweep in and take what little bit the people have away from them.
"This is a poor county, and poor people," said Charlie Weber, a laid-off masonry worker who has lived here off and on most of his life. "They'll survive because they're used to it."
Mr. Weber stood in front of Bullitt County High School where people were sleeping, eating and worrying about what they will find when the police finally let them back into their homes. Mr. Weber sounded almost angry, but prideful, as he put a face on the people here.
"They'll take their kicking," he said. "They'll come out of it and be thankful for whatever's left. Our Government, they go overseas and rebuild countries that hate us."
He shook his head. "It don't do much for them," he said motioning to where women and children walked through the parking lot with their belongings stuffed into garbage bags.
People here said that a massive backwash from the flooding Ohio River is expected to slow significantly the receding of the flood here.
Mrs. Neidlow does not have a lot, and the flood could take all of that. "I got out in a boat," she said, "so there was not even time to grab, or space to carry, precious keepsakes.
"My photo albums, I remembered to put them way up high," she said, in the hope that the water would not reach her highest shelf.
She is worried about her records. "Hank Williams Sr., Elvis, Johnny Cash," she listed them off.
"They've been playing Johnny Cash a lot" on the radio, said a friend, Dennis Anderson, a union welder before he had open heart surgery. The song the stations play is Mr. Cash's ballad about a flood, in which a small boy asks his father, "How high's the water, Papa?"
"I like him," Mrs. Neidlow said.
But if it is all gone or ruined when she goes home, she will just live with it, she said, adding, "We was brought up to take it."
In the shelter, Betty McGavie sat on a cot and worried about baby pictures. In the hallway of her trailer she has a row of photographs that chronicle the life of her 16-year-old son, Josh, who now lives in Florida with his father. "Every year, I put a new one up there," she said.
Outside Shepherdsville, it was the same story. People waited in the muddy water, and used boats to check on the damage when they could, but the police discouraged it.
People helped one another. They brought food and clothes and something more important, word. That is how Mrs. Neidlow found out that her two dogs were rescued.
No one had to wonder about Elmer Chris Kappell's whereabouts. After enduring major floods in nearby Lebanon Junction, he decided in 1989 to move his house to high ground -- but on the same lot.
Mr. Kappell hired a house mover to jack up the building some three feet. Some people thought he was crazy to spend money just to make it a little safer. But on Tuesday, with hundreds of flooded, abandoned homes all around him, he and his 79-year-old mother, Myrtle, were high and dry.
"I'm real happy," Mr. Kappell said. "We're surrounded by water and I still have a foot to go."
Friends left a small boat tethered to his house, just in case. "If it starts raining again, I'll get the boat and get Mom out of here," he said. "But I think we're going to ride it out."
Back in Shepherdsville, there was nothing to do but wait. A woman in the shelter walked up to Rita Sparks and said, in tears, "My trailer, all my stuff is gone."
"Well, at least you got out," Mrs. Sparks told her.
The flood did close down the KFC, which everyone here still calls the Kentucky Fried Chicken, advertising campaign or no advertising campaign. But the Shoneys was open; so was the White Castle. There was no flood sale on cars at Bullitt Auto Sales. The proprietor was still trying to get $2,100 for a 1964 Ford.
And in the door of the Burger King, a sign announced that, yes, there would be bingo games there Tuesdays and Thursdays from 9 to 10 A.M.
Maybe someone will get lucky.

HEADLINE: Survey Finds More Children Being Offered Marijuana

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

 BODY:
The rising popularity of illegal drugs among teen-agers is trickling down to their younger brothers and sisters, who are becoming more tolerant of drug use and are starting to try marijuana themselves, according to a survey released yesterday by the Partnership for a Drug-Free America.
The annual Partnership Tracking Study for 1996, which focuses on children 9 through 12 years of age, found those children to be influenced by teen-agers' use of drugs, primarily marijuana. 
 Nearly one-fourth of the younger children interviewed said they were offered drugs last year, the survey said, an increase of five percentage points from the 19 percent who reported the experience in 1993. Only 7 percent of the parents thought their children were offered drugs.
In the same period, the number of pre-teen-agers who said they had friends using drugs rose to 13 percent from 7 percent. Those who admitted experimenting with drugs themselves rose to 4 percent from 2 percent.
The survey of 2,569 children in the fourth, fifth and sixth grades was interpreted as a worrisome harbinger of even more drug use once they enter high school.
The study is consistent with other reports of drug use among adolescents, especially by the latest Monitoring the Future Survey, released annually by the Survey Research Center at the University of Michigan.
The survey yesterday reported that 8 percent of the sixth-grade students interviewed said they had tried marijuana, while 23 percent of the seventh graders and 33 percent of the eighth graders said they had done so.
"With children less resistant to drugs as they leave the relative safety of elementary school and enter middle school, where their peers are older and drugs are much more a reality, the implications for the future are not encouraging," Richard D. Bonnette, president of the Partnership for a Drug-Free America, said in a statement.
Children consider parents a reliable source of drug information, yet parents are less likely to discuss the hazards of drugs with younger children. The survey found that 42 percent of the parents interviewed said they talked regularly with their teen-agers about drugs, but that only 29 percent did so with their younger children.
The Partnership for a Drug-Free America, a coalition of advertising and marketing specialists, solicits free television time and print space to run its own advertisements about the hazards of drug use. The Clinton Administration has set aside $175 million in its new Federal drug budget for a mammoth advertising blitz intended to discourage drug use by adolescents and children.
The new study was released at a news conference in Washington.
The latest study was conducted by Audits and Surveys Worldwide Inc., a research group in New York City that used anonymous questionnaires to ask 12,292 children, teen-agers and their parents about drugs.
It reported more tolerance of drugs among white children but less tolerance among black children.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Intrastate Air Fares Are High, Study Says

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
New Yorkers are being charged prohibitive air fares, especially for travel within the state, according to a report by a member of the State Senate Investigations Committee.
Catherine M. Abate, Democrat of Manhattan, found that, despite recent fare reductions nationally, many New York air fares have remained high or have increased. 
 "An analysis of air fares in the Empire State found that something pricey is in the air," she said.
Among the report's findings were that, on average, airlines charged New Yorkers twice as much per mile for travel within New York than for travel outside the state. New York City travelers are charged three times as much for travel within the state.
It costs an average of $1.19 per mile to fly from one New York city to another, compared with 60 cents to out-of-state destinations. Flights originating from New York City cost $1.35 a mile for in-state flights and 24 cents for out of state.
"If we want to invigorate the economies of our cities, we must insure that the cost of getting to and from them is reasonable," Senator Abate said. The report also found customers flying from Syracuse, Buffalo and Rochester paid 366 percent more per ticket than New York City customers for travel to Los Angeles, Orlando, Washington and Boston.
For example, flying from Buffalo to Los Angeles costs $1,691, or 40 cents per mile, while the same flight leaving from New York City costs $877, or 21 cents per mile, the report found. Airlines offer upstate cities little or no competition, the report found. About 77 percent of all upstate markets surveyed offer no competitive pricing. In many cases, different airlines offer identical prices for flights to and from the same major destinations.
The report surveyed American Airlines, Delta Air Lines, Trans World Airlines, Continental Air Lines and US Air.

HEADLINE: U.N.'s Costs Are Leveling Off, Chief Financial Officer Reports

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, March 4

 BODY:
The senior financial officer of the United Nations said today that spending for 1998 and 1999 would come in under budget if the dollar remained relatively stable and inflation subdued.
The officer, Joseph E. Connor, a former chief executive at Price Waterhouse who is Under Secretary General for Administration and Management, said the United Nations could spend less than the $2.48 billion it has budgeted for the two years, which is already $123 million below the $2.6 billion the United Nations plans to spend in 1996 and 1997. 
 Because most expenditures are in dollars and member states are assessed in dollars, swings in the dollar's value can increase or reduce the organization's costs outside the United States.
The new Secretary General, Kofi Annan of Ghana, plans additional streamlining this summer.
Such measures are intended to persuade the United States to pay its arrears, which Congress will agree to only if it is satisfied that the United Nations is becoming leaner.
Mr. Connor pointed out that after peaking at more than $3 billion a year in 1994 and 1995, spending for peacekeeping is falling sharply. This year it is likely to total some $1.2 billion, Mr. Connor said at a news conference here.
But he said the finances of the United Nations remain crippled by member states' failure to pay their assessments; the total unpaid at the end of last year was $2.2 billion, slightly less than the record $2.3 billion at the end of 1995.
The United States accounts for an increasing share of those bills. In 1985 the United States was responsible for only 17 percent of arrears, and between 1992 and 1994 its share hovered between 25 and 30 percent. But in 1995 it increased sharply to 54 percent, then reached 61 percent last year.
Of the $1.02 billion the Clinton Administration has asked Congress to appropriate to pay off the American debts to all international organizations, Mr. Connor said, the United Nations' share is $712 million, compared with total unpaid American arrears that he estimates at $1.3 billion.
Washington says the arrears is lower because of a number of financial disagreements with the world body.

HEADLINE: Earnings Outlook for Stocks Gets a Tougher Look

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
While the surprising downgrade in earnings expectations at the AT&T Corporation may be just bad news for the telecommunications giant, it is raising questions about the overall earnings outlook for the stock market.
Moderate earnings growth -- in the 6 to 10 percent range for the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks -- is the key to many positive forecasts for the market this year. But if earnings begin to disappoint, it could make it more difficult for the Dow Jones industrial average and other key indexes to push well beyond the record levels they have already reached this year. 
 "AT&T just signals AT&T," said Donald H. Straszheim, chief economist at Merrill Lynch. "But I think it's reasonable to expect people may generalize from this circumstance."
Charles Hill, director of research at First Call, a company that tracks earnings estimates, said that analysts' earnings estimates for the stocks in the S.& P. index have already come down about a half of a percentage point from forecasts earlier in the year.
Yesterday, shares of AT&T fell for the second consecutive session -- down 7/8, to 36 -- along with a number of other blue-chip issues. The Dow fell 66.20 points, closing at 6,852.72, down nearly 215 points in just the two weeks since it set its closing high of 7,067.46 on Feb. 18.
Broader market indexes were mixed. The S.& P. 500 lost 4.36 points, to close at 790.95, while the Nasdaq composite index gained 6.19 points, to 1,317.37, as technology issues rebounded.
 As for declining stocks, AT&T -- which said on Monday that earnings for 1997 could fall as much as 30 percent -- is not the only recent indicator that profit expectations might drop.
The McDonald's Corporation said last week that it would slash prices of certain menu items in the face of increasing competition. The drop in its share price as well as those of several of its fast-food competitors indicated that earnings may disappoint. And the General Motors Corporation this week reported declining auto sales.
"To me, it's a warning that Wall Street is too optimistic about earnings in general," said Michael Metz, who is the chief investment strategist at Oppenheimer & Company and a longstanding bear. "We can have a very good economy but that doesn't mean it's going to be accompanied by strong earnings."
But Laszlo Birinyi, a market analyst at Birinyi Associates in Greenwich, Conn., said that while investors often react to news like that from AT&T, it is generally not a signal of future earnings disappointments. In other words, the market often over-reacts to news that is particular to one company or industry.
 "The whole idea of individual stocks being proxies for others is one of the mistakes analysts are making," Mr. Birinyi said. "One company comes in early and says we're going to have earnings problems and it's seen as being across the board. It happens every quarter and every quarter we find out that it was a problem that was restricted to company A."
In his testimony before the Senate Banking Committee last week, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, warned about the impact of disappointing earnings in the current market environment.
"We should keep in mind," he said, "that at these relatively low long-term interest rates, small changes in long-term earnings expectations could have outsized impacts on equity prices."
 Already, estimates for AT&T have been revised downward by more than 20 percent since Monday's announcement, according to First Call.
But some analysts argued that the damage would not spread beyond AT&T. "I wouldn't extrapolate anything from the larger picture from this," said Marshall Acuff, a market analyst at Smith Barney. "This simply means that AT&T is going to have to redirect itself at a time when the competitive environment is going to become more acute."
 Mr. Straszheim at Merrill Lynch, though, warned that the stock market may be facing two difficult prospects this year. If earnings grow by about 6 percent this year, he said, there would probably be many earnings disappointments that would hurt stock prices.
 Nevertheless, he argued, that is preferable to a "red hot" environment of 14 or 15 percent earnings growth in which inflationary pressures and rising bond yields tip the balance away from stocks.
 "If we get that kind of economy, this market's going to fall to pieces," Mr. Straszheim said. "That would be bad news for interest rates and equities. But if there is a moderate growth, low-inflation environment, there will be a whole string of earnings disappointments."

HEADLINE: Raises Tied to Inflation Weighed in Albany

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 4

 BODY:
Without admitting that they were supporting or even seriously negotiating the idea, legislative leaders said today that they have begun discussing a proposal to give legislators, the Governor and other state officials periodic pay increases tied to the rate of inflation -- much the way Social Security recipients get automatic cost-of-living adjustments.
The plan is the latest permutation in the awkward minuet the leaders have been dancing for months, namely how to raise the salaries of the state's 211 legislators for the first time in eight years. In December, a proposal to give the legislators a raise died amid squabbling among the leaders and Gov. George E. Pataki on a variety of other issues. 
 But the disenchantment among the lawmakers about their $57,500 base annual salaries runs so thick that the leaders have reopened discussion of the issue as part of budget negotiations that are just now getting under way, even though no pay increase, even a cost-of-living adjustment, could take effect until 1999. Only California's Legislature is paid better than New York's, with legislators receiving $75,600 a year.
The New York Senate's Republican majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, was the first to float the cost-of-living-increase idea today, saying it would allow legislators' salaries to rise periodically in tandem with the inflation rate. He said many details, like the size and frequency of pay increases, had not been worked out.
But in an indication of just how sensitive the leaders are to openly debating a pay raise, which became an election issue in many legislative races last fall, Mr. Bruno refused to take credit for the idea, did not make a commitment to supporting it and refused to say that he, Mr. Pataki and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver were actually negotiating it.
"I am not advocating any cost-of-living increase," Mr. Bruno said. "I'm not proposing one. We are not presently discussing one. I am answering a question that if it comes up, there's where I will be."
He insisted that it would not be the same as a raise, saying it would simply allow legislators to "keep even" with their rising expenses.
Asked which of the leaders originally proposed the idea, Mr. Bruno said: "I can't recollect. I'm getting early senility. I can't remember."
He said that in addition to being given to legislators, the cost-of-living increases should be extended to the governor, lieutenant governor, attorney general, state comptroller, some state commissioners and judges.
Asked how he felt about the idea, Mr. Silver said, "Fine with me." But he said he would not accept any pay raise plan if it were offered in exchange for budget proposals that the Assembly Democrats found onerous. Legislative officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, have recently said the leaders might approve raises if the Legislature could enact the state budget on time, by April 1, for the first time in 13 years. "I am in favor of anything that is fair and reasonable and is not linked to anyone doing something that they wouldn't normally do," Mr. Silver said.
Like Mr. Bruno, Mr. Silver said the idea was not being seriously discussed but received only "passing mention" in talks among the leaders. "I think the media has given too much attention to it," he said. He added that he supports the idea of naming a commission to study legislative raises, then debating its proposals before voting on the matter.
Mr. Pataki also insisted that there had been little discussion of a pay raise. "To the extent there is any discussion, I think it should be done in the light of day," he said.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
From Hip Talk-Show Host to Just a Regular Guy

BYLINE: By JOHN J. O'CONNOR 

 BODY:
Like Bill Cosby, Arsenio Hall uses his own name for the title of a sitcom in which the character he plays has an entirely different name. One problem: Mr. Cosby has solidly established himself in superstardom, while Mr. Hall is still trying, and noticeably struggling.
In "Arsenio," the new ABC series having its premiere tonight, Mr. Hall, once of considerable talk-show fame, plays Michael Atwood, a genial, somewhat square announcer for a sports cable channel in Atlanta. Like Mr. Hall, Michael is youthfully charming and, like a warm puppy, eager to be loved. His wife, Vivian (Viveca A. Fox) is a lawyer with a big firm. She serves as the backboard for Michael's slam-dunk routines. 
 This evening's pilot is a surprisingly listless enterprise. Even the laugh track sounds halfhearted. Vivian fails to get a promotion, and Michael fails to console her properly. That's not so surprising for a man who will take photos of his wife sleeping to prove that she is hogging the covers. As Vivian so aptly puts it, "This is your idea of a mature relationship?" And then for the younger crowd, there is Matthew (Alimi Ballard), Vivian's younger brother, an unemployed Harvard graduate who has moved in with the Atwoods while preaching, "Anyone can take a job but it is only the truly courageous who will not take a job."
In short, "Arsenio" just sits there. There have been widely reported troubles on the set. New writers and producers have been brought in. It's impossible at this point to predict if the series, an expensive one for ABC, can find a truly innovative groove. But don't underestimate the aggressively engaging Mr. Hall.
 
'Temporarily Yours'
CBS, tonight at 8:30
You like Fran Drescher as "The Nanny"? Meet Debi Mazar as Deb DeAngelo in the new CBS series "Temporarily Yours." Irrepressible product of an Irish mother and an Italian father, Debi hails from Brooklyn and, having gone through 27 jobs in two years, is determined to find a "more success-friendly environment" in Manhattan. Her solution: a temporary-employment agency, the kind of place that saves businesses fortunes by evading pension and health-care costs. These days, you take your laughs wherever you can find them.
Debi arrives at "Everything's Temporary," an agency run by Joan Silver, played with raised-eyebrow sleekness by Joanna Gleason ("Into the Woods"). Although appalled by Debi's terminal gregariousness, Joan is persuaded by her flaky son, David (Seth Green), to give her an assignment, which turns out to be applying cosmetics to a corpse in a funeral home. "So cold in here, you could hang meat," observes the unsinkable Debi.
Welcome to the always cute world of New Yawk gumption. Like Ms. Drescher, Ms. Mazar has the neighborhood accent down pat. Viewers will remember her perfect regular-gal turns as Denise Ianello in the series "Civil Wars" and "L.A. Law." Sitcoms thrive on personality. Ms. Mazar has enough to spare.

HEADLINE: ON COLLEGE BASKETBALL;
With Stars Gone, It's a Free-for-All

BYLINE: By Malcolm Moran 

 BODY:
Steve Lappas needed just two games to know what kind of league the Big East had become this season. After two conference games, those early December meetings made necessary by the 1994 expansion, his Villanova Wildcats had a conference record of 2-0. Lappas looked over his shoulder in search of other successful starts, and he found . . . no one.
No one? 
 When each of the 13 Big East teams had played two games, one team had two losses and 11 teams had one. "That's almost mathematically impossible," Lappas said. "I think it said something right then, in December, that this is unbelievable. But that's the kind of league it is."
Months later, as everyone comes together at Madison Square Garden, little has changed. Villanova and Boston College shared the best record at 12-6, a loss total that tied a Big East record. Eight teams lost six to nine conference games. Last Saturday morning, with six games left in the regular season, there were 56 possibilities for seeding in the Big East tournament; by late Sunday afternoon, Syracuse's 2-point loss to Pittsburgh dropped the Orangemen from No. 4 to No. 8.
But the league is not as weak as computer printouts want us to believe. It is not nearly as awful as the Big East became four years ago, when the failed six-foul experiment permitted players to assume they could clutch and grab, resulting in interminable end-game situations. This transition season became inevitable when six first-round draft choices, including three first-team all-Americans, moved on to the National Basketball Association. The talent pool is young, not depleted. The competition is earnest, not ugly.
But with the N.B.A. rewarding early departures and the National Collegiate Athletic Association doing little to hold on to its most visible players, the league's best teams, the Wildcats, the Eagles and the Georgetown Hoyas, would be fortunate to stay within 15 points of the Georgetown, St. John's and Villanova groups of 1985.
The achievements during the era of Patrick Ewing, Chris Mullin and Ed Pinckney, three four-year players who completed their college-level development while current players were in elementary school, took place in an economic galaxy far, far away. Connecticut's run of five league losses over three seasons, culminated by its 17-1 record a year ago, now appears an impossible achievement. The early-entry temptations of the N.B.A., combined with the archaic amateurism standard perpetuated by N.C.A.A. members, has altered the landscape forever.
A year ago, the Big East's strength came from its ability to keep its marquee players. Kerry Kittles, John Wallace, Ray Allen and Allen Iverson chose to stay -- albeit Iverson only through his sophomore year -- and the Big East had three top-10 schools, plus the Syracuse team that Wallace led to the national championship game. This week, the Atlantic Coast Conference, anchored by Tim Duncan's decision after last season to remain at Wake Forest, has the three top-10 teams. And successful Big East coaches are asked if their achievements this year are less significant.
"You don't appreciate it," Boston College's Jim O'Brien said of Big East basketball, "until you have to play in it or coach in it."
O'Brien very nearly lost his job trying to pull the Eagles upward in an unforgiving conference. Once he reached the top -- this season Boston College shared first place for the first time since 1983 -- the Eagles were considered underachievers. By the old standard, they were. But in this landscape, survival is an achievement.
"I ask this question," O'Brien said. "Would people prefer to have four teams at the top that are in the top 20, and have all the others be also-rans, and have the rest of the conference be less than competitive?"
The answer, unfortunately, is yes. The mismatches that took place often throughout the 1985 season are now remembered as a time of anticipation for the heavyweight championship. The rivalry between the Ewing and the Mullin teams had four years to develop. Now those plot lines can be compressed into four months.
The new standard for a league is its ability to replace lost talent and experience with new stars. The A.C.C. recovered from the premature loss of Joe Smith, Jerry Stackhouse and Rasheed Wallace within two years. Even with the expected departure of Villanova's Tim Thomas, seven of the Big East's top 13 players would be back if -- and this is a major if -- Victor Page returns for a junior season at Georgetown.
Without Page, top-15 teams could emerge at Connecticut, Pittsburgh, St. John's and Syracuse. The continued development of new stars -- including Pat Garrity of Notre Dame, Tim James of Miami, Vonteego Cummings of Pitt, Richard Hamilton of Connecticut and Shaheen Holloway of Seton Hall -- would renew an identity that inspires comparisons to the old days.
For now, the once-dreaded 8-versus-9 matchup is worth paying Garden prices for breakfast, and when Syracuse or Notre Dame faces top-seeded Villanova tomorrow afternoon, there are no guarantees.
"We just went to Memphis and beat Memphis," said Georgetown's John Thompson, "and they beat Cincinnati."
Thompson's logic is as sound as his team. If you think the Big East is terrible, go tell him.

HEADLINE: Trade vs. Rights: A U.S. Debate With a Burmese Focus

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 4

 BODY:
Despite pressure on Capitol Hill and a new appeal by a Nobel Prize-winning dissident, senior members of the Clinton Administration are sharply divided over whether a new law requires the United States to impose tougher sanctions on Myanmar, Administration officials say.
The law, signed by President Clinton five months ago, states that the Administration must ban all new American investment in Myanmar, formerly known as Burma, if its military steps up repression of the democratic opposition, particularly the dissident Daw Aung San Suu Kyi. 
 The law has forced the Administration to confront the issue of whether concern for human rights is outweighed by economic ties.
If the Administration imposes sanctions, it risks criticism that it is singling out Myanmar while ignoring others, including China.
If the Administration does not impose sanctions, it becomes vulnerable to accusations that its policy of economic engagement supersedes its concern for rights.
One faction -- including the new United States representative to the United Nations, Bill Richardson -- has concluded that the conditions requiring sanctions have been met. But an equally influential group argues that sanctions would have little effect on the military Government.
This latter group -- including the President's economic and trade advisers and the Secretary of Defense, William S. Cohen, who as a Senator was one of two sponsors of the law -- has recommended instead that the United States continue to apply diplomatic pressure.
The divisions reflect a larger debate over sanctions as a tool of foreign policy. In the case of China, for example, the Administration has argued that economic engagement will lead to greater political freedom. And just last week, the Administration appeared to sidestep sanctions against Mexico in connection with the drug trade because of its economic importance.
Myanmar, with relatively little American investment, is a more likely place to take a stand in the name of human rights.
The Administration's divisions became clear at a Cabinet-level meeting two weeks ago, according to Administration officials who spoke on condition of anonymity. The issue is now expected to be taken up by President Clinton.
A spokesman at the White House, David Johnson, declined to discuss the wrangling, except to say, "We are now considering what course of action supports the law and the purposes of the law."
The military Burmese Government -- the State Law and Order Restoration Council, or Slorc -- continues to suppress the political opposition. In the last week, it also intensified its attacks on ethnic Karen rebels and refugees, prompting renewed criticism by the State Department. "The United States is increasingly frustrated by the policies of the Slorc," said the State Department spokesman, Nicholas Burns.
Rights organizations and members of Congress see the debate as a test of the Administration's willingness to wield sanctions. "The longer they hold off, the more credibility they lose," said Mike Jendrzejczyk, the director in Washington for Human Rights Watch Asia.
The Burmese Government, which is dominated by Gen. Khin Nyunt, seized power in 1988. It held elections in 1990 but rejected the results after losing to the National League for Democracy, which is led by Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi, who later won the Nobel Peace Prize. While she was released in 1995 from six years under house arrest, the Government has continued to harass supporters.
The United States has already imposed some sanctions against Myanmar, not only for its rights policies but also for its lack of cooperation in fighting drugs. In September Mr. Clinton also barred the military rulers from entering the United States and banned arms sales.
The United States is one of the largest investors in Myanmar, after France, Britain, Singapore and Thailand, with most of the investment coming in the oil and gas sector. But investment has declined since 1991, when it was $80 million, in part because some American companies have responded to rights protests.
But the largest American company operating there, the Unocal Corporation, announced in late January that it had signed an accord to explore and develop offshore gas fields.
A bipartisan group of seven Senators -- led by Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, and Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky -- has circulated a letter calling on Mr. Clinton to impose the sanctions. The law calls for a ban on new investment if the Burmese Government has "physically harmed, rearrested for political acts or exiled Daw Aung San Suu Kyi or has committed large-scale repression of or violence against the democratic opposition."
The Senators cited instances in which Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi had been harrassed and detained in her home as recently as December, while members of the National League for Democracy had been arrested.
"Since the bill was signed into law, the situation has gone from bad to worse," the Senators wrote.
Last month Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi herself appealed for international sanctions, saying there was a "large-scale repression of the democracy movement" under way. In a rare meeting with reporters today, she complained of new arrests and intimidation tactics, saying, "The situation is getting worse all the time."
What has made the Administration's debate more interesting is the fact that members of Mr. Clinton's foreign policy team have been publicly intertwined with Burmese policies.
Mr. Richardson and the new Secretary of State, Madeleine K. Albright, have each met with Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi. And Mr. Cohen joined Senator Dianne Feinstein of California in drafting the law, which was a compromise that headed off calls last year for immediate sanctions.
Ms. Feinstein's office declined repeated requests for comment, but in an interview last month in The Los Angeles Times, she said the conditions laid out in the law had not been met.
Ms. Albright has indicated a willingness to impose sanctions but has advocated a third option: giving Myanmar 60 days to improve conditions.
Marc A. Phiessen, a spokesman for Senator Jesse Helms, Republican from North Carolina, who signed Mr. Moynihan's letter, said the Administration should simply follow the law.
"It's mind-boggling," he said, noting that a State Department report on human rights in January showed that the conditions for sanctions had been met by the continued pressure on Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi. "Does she have to be assassinated before they will impose sanctions?"

CORRECTION-DATE: March 6, 1997, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
Because of a transcription error, an article yesterday about a debate in the Clinton Administration over whether to impose economic sanctions on Myanmar, formerly Burma, misspelled the surname of a spokesman for Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina. He is Marc A. Thiessen, not Phiessen.

HEADLINE: Music and Meatloaf Served a la Elvis

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD ROTHMAN 

 BODY:
TAKING a cue from the Hard Rock Cafe and Planet Hollywood, the estate of Elvis Presley is packaging the legacy of the rock-and-roll icon as a new restaurant and entertainment complex called Elvis Presley's Memphis. The estate hopes this will be the start of a worldwide chain.
Lansky's, the Memphis department store where Presley spent his early record royalties on fancy clothes like the plaid jacket he wore on the Ed Sullivan show, is being gutted and remade into a 250-seat, two-story restaurant and bar, to open in late May. It will have a stage visible from both floors for multimedia and live entertainment. 
 Jack Soden, the chief executive of Elvis Presley Enterprises, said the $4 million venture would not be a "plastic shrine."
"It's going to be a jumping joint," he said by telephone from his office at Graceland, the Presley mansion-turned-tourist-mecca in Memphis. "Raw, gritty, authentic, like Elvis."
"We're going to showcase musicians Elvis worked with. Like Scotty Moore, the lead guitarist from the Sun Studio days; D. J. Fontana, who played drums, and J. D. Sumner and the Stamps, the gospel group that were part of his concert shows," Mr. Soden added.
The new club may also offer the closest thing to a real Elvis sighting. The developers plan to introduce a three-dimensional virtual Presley. Other high-tech productions will include multimedia fusings of live acts with taped or filmed Presley performances. "The Jordanaires, who backed up Elvis on the Sullivan show, could be singing live on stage, for example, while accompanying Elvis on film," Mr. Soden said.
Keith Youngquist, an interior designer with the Chicago-based Aumiller Youngquist, said the restaurant would reflect Presley's tastes: "We said, 'What would he do if he had built a place on Beale Street, literally within blocks of where he grew up?' "
The memorabilia on the walls will go beyond white jumpsuit and gold records to mine Presley's own memorabilia collection, Mr. Youngquist said, adding, "We have, for example, flatcars he played with as a kid."
The menu will reflect Presley, too, said Michael Graves, chairman of the Dakota Company, which will operate the restaurant. He said the dishes would include meatloaf, "which Elvis loved, a pulled pork shoulder sandwich and an Elvis favorite: fried peanut butter and banana sandwich."
Mr. Soden said sites being considered for branches are 42d Street in Manhattan, Southern California and Orlando, Fla.
Memphis officials hope the flagship complex will continue the revitalization of downtown begun in 1984 and in particular of Beale Street, the home of the jazz trumpeter W. C. Handy. It will join a strip of clubs that includes Rum Boogie Cafe, Alfred's and B. B. King's Blues Club, the recently opened restaurant and club of the legendary jazz singer.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Stocks can't continue marching upward, an economist says.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
WITH the stock market outpacing the wildest expectations in the last few years, can the good times roll on much longer? Don't ask the dismal scientists. In what amounts to a rare instance of collective professional humility, economic forecasters are loath to predict changes in equity prices.
That's not quite the end of the story, however. Dean Baker of the Economic Policy Institute, a Washington-based liberal group, claims no special insight into the workings of the equities market. But he does argue that the trend in stocks cannot be sustained. The 7 percent real return enjoyed by investors over the last 70 years, he suggests, is simply incompatible with mainstream forecasts of growth of less than 2 percent in the gross domestic product over the long haul. 
 His analysis, in a report just issued by the Twentieth Century Fund, takes direct aim at pension specialists who have been promoting stocks as a painless fix to Social Security's problems. But it is also relevant to individual investors, who have grown accustomed to thinking of the market as a perpetual motion machine.
Make no mistake: the equities-are-better argument is seductive. Since the mid-1920's, the average annual return on stocks has exceeded the return on Government bonds by more than five percentage points. Of course, stock prices are volatile. But according to the conventional wisdom, anyone socking away assets for the long term would have to be nuts to pass by the rewards from this persistent "equity premium."
Many stock analysts explain the high-flying Dow Jones industrial index as belated recognition that recessions -- and accompanying dips in corporate earnings -- are a thing of the past. But number-crunching types don't bother with the "why." If the equity premium has endured for seven decades, the reasoning goes, the best guess is that it will endure for many more. Hence the enthusiasm for investing retirement money -- public and private -- in stocks.
Mr. Baker's pessimism is not rooted in some esoteric theory of stock pricing. Rather, he argues that optimistic extrapolations of stock prices are inconsistent with modest projections of economic growth. The total value of traded stocks today, he notes, is about 20 times corporate profits. If profits remain a relatively stable share of national output and output per worker continues to grow at about 1 percent a year, the stock market's price-earnings ratio would have to rise to 34 by 2015 to sustain a 7 percent average return.
Conceivable, you say? Perhaps. But this is a Ponzi game: for the assumption to hold, the market's price-earnings ratio would have to reach 485 to 1 by 2070.
Of course, profits might grow more rapidly than G.D.P. if the share of income going to capital grew at the expense of labor. But here, too, the unlikely soon becomes the implausible: to sustain a 7 percent return and a price-earnings ratio of 20, average wages (not labor's share of income) would have to fall by one-third over the next four decades.
There is a way corporate income could rise more rapidly than G.D.P. without exacting a pound of flesh from labor. "The stock market bulls say corporations will earn an increasing share of profits in emerging markets," says Burt Malkiel, an economist at Princeton University. But the numbers would work only if foreign corporate earnings rose into the trillions by the middle of the next century -- a far-fetched prospect.
If standard assumptions about future productivity gains and the division of the pie between capital and labor do hold, Mr. Baker calculates that the return to stocks will average a bit more than 4 percent over the long term. And if capital's share of income should fall, or price-earnings ratios revert to averages of earlier generations, it could be as low as 3 percent. "If I had to bet, I'd guess we'll see a major adjustment in stock prices in the next two years," Mr. Baker concludes.
Perhaps rapid productivity growth, which made 7 percent returns on stocks possible for so long, will reward investors for their giddy optimism. If that is the case, though, there would be no need to look to equity investments as a way to cover generous promises to future retirees. Rapidly rising productivity would almost certainly lead to rapidly rising wages, which in turn would yield a tsunami of revenue from the payroll tax.
Equity investments may still make sense for long-term investors. So may the creation of privately held accounts to supplement Social Security, if only to make higher, mandatory savings more palatable to Americans. But the message in Mr. Baker's calculations is still a slap in the face: no amount of optimism can repeal the laws of arithmetic.
