HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Retreats After Climbing To 3-Year High Against Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar briefly touched a three-year high against the German mark yesterday but ended slightly lower against it and other currencies, weakened by trade tension between the United States and Japan and the renewed prospect of rising Japanese interest rates.
Traders said the dollar also retreated a bit because of uncertainty over employment reports to be released this week in the United States and Germany. Germany's unemployment rate has surged this winter, while the employment situation has remained solid in the United States, which would be expected to help the dollar, but speculation in the market has gone both ways. 
 "I think we're really in a wait-and-see situation until we get the data," said David Becker, senior dealer at the New York branch of Bank Austria. "Any surprises away from what we're expecting will be important."
The dollar reached an intraday high of 1.7172 marks, the strongest since April 1994, before falling back to settle in New York at 1.7121 marks, down from 1.7146 on Tuesday. Against the yen, the dollar settled in New York at 121.21 yen, down from 122.16. The British pound cost $1.6137, up from $1.6126.
Traders sold the dollar against the yen in early Asian dealings after Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin suggested that Japan's current economic policies might not be sufficient to stimulate domestic demand.
His remarks were taken to mean that the Clinton Administration was increasingly restive about Japan's trade surplus with the United States, which could increase sharply if the yen's weakness continues. A cheaper Japanese currency makes Japan's exports more affordable abroad.
Mr. Rubin's remarks coincided with Japanese data that showed a 53 percent rise in Japan's trade surplus during the first 20 days of February compared with a year earlier.
Some traders said the dollar's retreat was understandable in view of the run-up over the last few months. Since Dec. 31 the dollar has appreciated about 13 percent vs. the mark and more than 5 percent vs. the yen.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday, were: 1.4821 Swiss francs, down from 1.4861; 5.7750 French francs, down from 5.7805, and 1,704.75 Italian lire, down from 1,707.35.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Rethinking China, Part II

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Madeleine Albright just visited China. On her next trip, here's what she should say to President Jiang Zemin.
Albright: We usually come to these meetings with a list of dissidents you've imprisoned. If we're lucky you toss us a bone, let someone out of jail and we pretend human rights in China have improved. We tell the U.S. press "We bluntly raised our human rights concerns, but we have other interests and can't hold the U.S.-China relationship hostage to human rights alone. And blah, blah." 
 Let's stop this sham. You know that neither our allies nor our own business community will allow us to impose the sort of biting economic sanctions on you that would really get your attention. We could only muster such sanctions in times of war, and we're not in a war. But we have other tools. We have our own spotlight and we have the pressures building up inside your own country to move toward a more law-based society, and we intend to use both.
We're going to use our spotlight to highlight those areas where you've progressed in implementing rule of law instead of arbitrary Communist party rule, and to highlight those areas where you've not. That is going to be the thrust of our human rights policy from now on -- rule of law. Get used to it. Rule of law. We're no longer going to treat human rights as simply winning the freedom of some dissident, or as an isolated issue that my State Department human rights office deals with and no one else. No, no. The President has directed the State Department, Pentagon, Commerce, Trade Representative and every other U.S. agency dealing with China to formulate all policies vis-a-vis China with the long-term objective of encouraging you to replace arbitrary, unaccountable, opaque operations with rule-of-law procedures.
Now, you deserve recognition for introducing more rule of law in the areas of administrative procedure, copyright, even criminal justice -- though your officials still have too much discretion in whether they implement these new laws. We know you're not making these changes for our sake. You're making them because you've concluded that without a more predictable, accountable rule of law you will never be able to get to that next stage of economic development, and since you have no ideology anymore -- other than "to get rich is glorious" -- if you can't deliver that next stage you're toast.
But we are going to keep pushing you, because there are still too many areas you haven't moved in: You still restrict freedom of association. You still use your laws to criminalize all sorts of peaceful activities, from political dissent to environmental advocacy. You still sentence people to "re-education through labor." We're going to draw attention to these practices in every international forum, with as many allies as we can, so it is clear to your people that this is not the U.S. versus China -- which only brings out a nationalist backlash -- but China versus international norms.
And we are going to look for every vehicle -- whether it's funding legal-education programs, helping to train Chinese criminal defense lawyers or intensifying our demands that you implement real commercial and intellectual property laws -- to promote rule of law within China at large.
Mr. Jiang, when our human rights policy toward China focused on freeing dissidents, we could be 100 percent for it and you could be 100 percent against it. But when our human rights policy still cares about dissidents but makes its primary focus promoting rule of law in China, you can't be 100 percent against it, because you're instituting rule of law for your own reasons and betting that you can do it in some sectors while never letting it apply to you at the top. That's fine. We'll take that bet.
Mao said "We will never accept foreign capital." Then Deng came along and said "We will accept foreign capital, but never foreign norms." Now you come along and say "We will accept foreign capital and some foreign norms, but not others." O.K., we'll wait for the next guy. But in the meantime we'll have a human rights policy toward China that helps make it a better place for the Chinese people and that lays down some rule-of-law foundations for whatever comes after you.
Jiang to Albright: What does it mean to be toast?

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Higher On Hopeful Rate Outlook

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Trading in the bond market turned positive yesterday after Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, indicated in testimony to Congress that the Fed would not raise interest rates simply to snuff out growth, but only if imbalances appeared in the economy.
Few analysts had expected Mr. Greenspan, in his appearance before the House Banking Committee, to deviate from the speech he delivered to the Senate last week, in which he sounded a cautionary note to the financial markets. 
 But they had been worried about what Mr. Greenspan might say in the question-and-answer period after the speech. Afterward, however, analysts said that Mr. Greenspan appeared to back down slightly from his comments last week, when he warned the financial markets that the chances for a "pre-emptive policy tightening" -- in other words, an increase in interest rates -- should not be dismissed.
Treasury securities prices rose after yesterday's comments, with the 30-year bond rising 16/32, to a price of 97 16/32. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.82 percent, from 6.86 percent on Tuesday.
But it is unclear whether the gains will be sustainable. With the Government report on employment for February coming tomorrow, and traders concerned about possible inflationary signs in it, many investors saw yesterday's higher prices as a selling opportunity, traders said.
Furthermore, some of the gains yesterday were enhanced by speculators who were betting on more negative news from Mr. Greenspan. After his comments, they were forced to cover short positions, which occur when market participants sell borrowed securities, hoping to buy them back later at lower prices, thereby pocketing the difference. If prices begin to rise instead of fall, these participants still have to cover their short positions to limit their losses, which accelerates the upward momentum of the market.
Like other analysts, Scott F. Grannis, a director and chief economist of Western Asset Management, a money management firm in Pasadena, Calif., said it appeared to him that Mr. Greenspan was a little less aggressive this time around in his comments about the economy. But Mr. Grannis said he still thought that the Fed chief, in looking for signs of economic growth as possible signals of inflation, might be sending investors the wrong message.
"Evidence suggests Greenspan has done a terrific job in monetary policy and in fighting inflation, perhaps the best in a long time," Mr. Grannis said. "Recently though, he has placed a huge emphasis on economic growth. He has convinced the markets that growth causes inflation, and it just doesn't. He causes inflation, not wages and not growth, and has really steered the markets in an unfortunate direction."
Similarly, Mr. Grannis said that the markets -- particularly in their anticipation of the monthly employment reports -- were looking at the wrong indicators of inflation. "The economy grows best when inflation is generally low or is falling," he said. "Good indicators are commodity prices, the dollar and gold; these indicators tell you there is a monetary imbalance which could lead to a general rise in all prices."
David Cole, a fixed-income securities analyst for Technical Data in Boston, said he thought there was little news in the Fed chairman's speeches. And while some short-sellers were forced to cover their positions yesterday, "this does not reflect a change in market sentiment, just a realization that new information will be needed before the next leg down can be initiated."

HEADLINE: Government Broke Law in Barring U.S. Jews From Saudi Project

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 5

 BODY:
The Commerce Department has settled a lawsuit in a highly unusual case in which it charged the Justice Department and the Air Force with violating a law that prohibits American companies from respecting an Arab boycott of Israel and Jews.
The settlement papers, filed recently at the Commerce Department, show that officials from the Justice Department and the Air Force ordered a private contractor to exclude Jews and "Jewish-surnamed personnel" from a Government project in Saudi Arabia in deference to the Saudis. 
 The papers said there was no evidence that the Government of Saudi Arabia had played any role in the exclusion. The idea was initiated by an Air Force colonel and approved by a Justice Department official, the papers said.
The Air Force and the Justice Department have apologized and said they would take steps to insure that their behavior would not be repeated.
The Commerce Department, which enforces the anti-boycott law, recently reported that violations had become increasingly rare as companies had come to understand the law. Department officials said they believed that until now no Government agency had been found in violation.
Jess Hordes, the Washington director of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, who had asked the Commerce Department to investigate, said today, "It is astounding that two Government agencies were complicit in illegal discriminatory behavior."
Mr. Hordes also noted that there was a written project proposal, explicitly excluding Jews, that apparently was reviewed through several drafts at the Justice Department.
"This seems to underscore a certain systemic blindness in an important Government agency," he said.
The problem began in 1991 when the Air Force and the Justice Department began to work together when Boeing brought a lawsuit against the Government having to do with military sales abroad. In preparation for the lawsuit, the Government needed to copy thousands of microfilmed documents in Saudi Arabia, a job for which it hired an outside contractor, CACI Inc., of Virginia.
As a result of comments made by the Air Force officer, Col. Michael J. Hoover, the proposal included the provision: "No Jews or Jewish-surnamed personnel will be sent as part of the Document Acquisition Team because of cultural differences between Moslems and Jews in the region."
At least one Jewish worker was denied employment on the project and received a cash settlement from CACI, people familiar with the case say.
In the settlement, which was first reported today by The Journal of Commerce, the Commerce Department imposed a fine of $15,000 against CACI, which signed a statement that it was mistaken "to follow orders from two Federal Government agencies" on the assumption that the orders were legal.
A $15,000 fine against a company official was suspended, as were fines of $20,000 against Colonel Hoover and the Justice Department official, Jane Hadden Alperson.
Frank W. Hunger, the Assistant Attorney General in charge of the civil division, said in a letter to the Commerce Department that Ms. Alperson had been unaware of the law.
Arab countries cut most economic links with Israel when it gained independence in 1948. In 1954 the Arab League adopted a resolution calling on Arab countries not to trade with Israel. The Arab League drew up regulations in 1972 to administer the boycott, and in 1979, Congress passed legislation that barred compliance.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Calms Market and Stocks Soar

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 5

 BODY:
After giving Wall Street a bad case of the jitters last week by suggesting that financial markets might be overvalued, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, offered slightly more soothing comments today, and investors latched onto them to drive stock and bond prices sharply higher.
In a speech to a group of economists this morning and in testimony before the House Banking Committee this afternoon, Mr. Greenspan said he did not know which way stock prices were headed and that the market would be overvalued only if analysts' projections for substantial earnings increases in the next few years proved wrong. 
 "There is a valid argument as to sustaining the level of prices," Mr. Greenspan said in a speech to the National Association of Business Economists.
Mr. Greenspan's comments helped push stocks higher. The rally accelerated after his afternoon testimony, and the Dow Jones industrial average closed up 93.13 points, or 1.36 percent, at 6,945.85.
Although Mr. Greenspan repeated his warning of last week that the Fed might have to undertake a "pre-emptive" tightening of monetary policy to head off inflation before it infected the economy, the bond market appeared relieved that he did not provide any new indications that the Fed would raise rates anytime soon. Rising bond prices drove the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond down to 6.82 percent from 6.86 percent. Bond prices and their yields move in opposite directions.
Mr. Greenspan did not back off his comments from last week raising questions about whether the rapid run-up in stock prices over the last two years was sustainable. Indeed, he repeated them, word for word, in his appearance before the banking committee, saying "history counsels caution," especially in looking at "the sharp rise in equity prices during the past two years."
But Mr. Greenspan appeared to be going out of his way to make sure that investors heard the main caveat to his message: that if the current mood of economic optimism in the markets proved warranted, then his warning would prove to be nothing more than the musings of someone who, by his own admission, was paid to be a worrywart.
Responding to questions from members of the banking committee, Mr. Greenspan acknowledged knowing that his comments last week and his comment about "irrational exuberance" in the markets several months ago would probably send the market down temporarily. But he continued to insist that not even he could fundamentally alter the direction of stock and bond prices and said that was never his intention anyway.
"I was merely raising a broad question," Mr. Greenspan told the banking committee. "And today in my prepared remarks you will find that I take a look at the various factors affecting the stock market and conclude that if profit margins continue to rise as analysts in Wall Street expect them to, then the market is properly priced as best we can judge on the basis of the level of where interest rates are."
Mr. Greenspan immediately reiterated the other side of that equation, that if profit margins "fail to rise further, then the market will run into some difficulty."
But he said that "in the process of evaluating" which way the market was likely to go, "we don't know what is likely to happen."
Moreover, Mr. Greenspan said, he does not consider monetary policy a tool to "prick the stock market bubble."
Mr. Greenspan's conduct of monetary policy came under intense attack from several Democratic members of the banking committee and from the lone independent in Congress, Representative Bernard Sanders of Vermont, who is often described as a socialist. They questioned whether he was too quick to raise interest rates, choking off growth along with inflation and creating more unemployment in the process.
Mr. Greenspan repeated that he has many doubts about the widely held academic theory that there was a definable unemployment rate below which wages and inflation inevitably began to accelerate.
In one telling exchange, Representative Barney Frank of Massachusetts elicited an acknowledgment from Mr. Greenspan that he had been too pessimistic about his outlook for the economy over the last four or five years.
"I think what some of us are worried about when you talk about pre-emptive strikes is that you might be a little too pre-emptive because there has been this historic mis-estimate," Mr. Frank told Mr. Greenspan. "A lot of people missed it, and you did as well as anyone could. But that's part of our problem -- where you have a history of a little bit more pessimism than turned out, we just hope that correction gets factored in" to future monetary policy decisions.
Questioned about his support for reducing cost-of-living adjustments for Social Security and other benefit payments because of problems with the Consumer Price Index, Mr. Greenspan told Democrats on the panel that he had no objection to setting a special cost-of-living index for the elderly. Some economists believe that retirees are subject to greater annual increases in cost of living because of their high levels of medical expenditures, and that any adjustments to benefit payments should reflect that disparity.

HEADLINE: Frustration on All Sides At the Budget Struggle

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 5

 BODY:
Nearly a month after a highly publicized meeting on Capitol Hill between President Clinton and Congressional leaders, negotiations on a balanced budget plan have made virtually no headway, and today growing frustration on both sides broke into the open.
In the last several days, Mr. Clinton's budget has come under a sustained attack from Republican leaders, who demanded that he submit a whole new proposal after the Congressional Budget Office said his budget would not eliminate the deficit by 2002. 
 Today the Democrats responded with a coordinated effort.
Accusing the Republicans of "politicizing" the budget process, the Democratic leaders -- Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri -- demanded that the Republican leadership begin immediate consideration of a budget resolution and offer their own amendments to the Administration's proposals that they find objectionable.
"There appears to be the same sort of political approach now to budget consideration that we saw two years ago," Mr. Daschle, the Senate minority leader, said at a news conference today where he was joined by his counterpart in the House, Mr. Gephardt. "And I believe that, unless something changes, that political approach is going to lead to the same political result, which is a shutdown of Government and complete chaos again, which all of us have pledged to try to avoid that this year."
An equally pointed attack came from the Administration's senior budget negotiator -- Franklin D. Raines, the director of the White House Office of Management and Budget.
"We think the time for stalling is over," Mr. Raines said in a speech before the National Association of Business Economists. "If they want to cut taxes, let them tell us how they will pay for this."
But the comments angered one of the major Republican negotiators, Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the chairman of the Senate Budget Committee.
"I don't appreciate insinuations that I am not going to do my job," Mr. Domenici said. Then, referring to the C.B.O. report, he added: "We were asked to work with the President off his budget and we are doing our best. But it is getting progressively difficult when we get reports like this."
Until now, leaders of both parties had mostly avoided public bickering over the budget, worried that protracted fights like the ones of the last two years might cause political damage and a public backlash. Both Democrats and Republicans pledged to work together this year, with Mr. Clinton's budget plan as the basis of negotiations.
But since Mr. Clinton's ceremonial good faith visit to Capitol Hill on Feb. 11, the work on the budget has been limited to low-key meetings between White House negotiators and mainly Senate budget writers, who have focused more on establishing rapport than on budget substance. Now the rapport appears to be unraveling.
Members of Congress from both parties say that the Administration has, on some important proposals, provided little more than a rough sketch of what it wants. But there have been internal party problems, too -- a Republican leadership in the House that is under attack from its members for not charting a clear legislative course and infighting in both parties, especially the Democrats, over the middle ground in which Mr. Clinton and Republican leaders want to anchor the budget.
Leaders moved today to try to resolve both those issues.
Mr. Clinton held a late afternoon meeting at the White House with Democratic budget leaders to try to agree on a common strategy. And House Speaker Newt Gingrich's office said that the Georgian Republican would hold a news conference on Thursday to lay out his agenda.
The building rancor erupted this week when the Congressional Budget Office released on Monday an appraisal of Mr. Clinton's budget that said it would leave the Government with a deficit of $69 billion in 2002 instead of the $17 billion surplus the Administration forecast.
Representative John R. Kasich, the Ohio Republican who is chairman of the House Budget Committee, demanded that the President submit a new budget, "one that is in balance in 2002."
And on Tuesday, as bitterness between Democrats and Republicans increased over the constitutional amendment requiring a balanced budget, which failed by one vote in the Senate, Mr. Gingrich and Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Senate majority leader, fired off their own salvos at the President and his budget.
That has put the Democrats on the offensive.
"The idea that somehow the President should submit a second budget, not only is delaying the process, but is politicizing it way beyond anything we have seen in some time," Mr. Daschle asserted.
A senior Republican aide with the Senate Budget Committee dismissed the flareup as "institutional rhetoric" and said private discussions between White House officials and Senate Republicans are continuing on pace.
Chastened by the previous fights, the Republican leaders have refrained from introducing an alternative to Mr. Clinton's budget, despite the clamoring of some of their members who worry that the Democratic Administration is setting too much of the agenda.
On Tuesday, a White House official expressed irritation that Congressional Republicans had not put forth a detailed budget proposal.

HEADLINE: Auto Retailing's New Behemoth;
Republic's Huizenga Wants to Dominate the Market

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 5

 BODY:
When Republic Industries announced here today that it had bought a dozen New Jersey new car dealerships in one of the automotive retailing business's biggest deals to date, nobody in the auto industry was even remotely surprised.
Led by H. Wayne Huizenga, the billionaire who has already made two fortunes, Republic is in the middle of an extraordinary buying and building binge. The company is following much the same formula that Mr. Huizenga pursued in consolidating first the garbage hauling business as the head of Waste Management Inc. and then the video rental business through the Blockbuster Entertainment Corporation, which he sold to Viacom in 1994 for more than $7 billion. 
 Mr. Huizenga has snapped up two car rental companies, Alamo and National, and many of the nation's biggest auto dealers. Republic is setting up two chains of used-car superstores: Autonation for recent models and Valu Stop for older models. It is building huge service centers to recondition trade-ins and rental cars for sale and to compete in the car repair market. And Mr. Huizenga is preparing to set up a finance subsidiary for Republic so that it can make its own loans and leases -- and keep track of who might be able to afford another car in two or three years.
In an interview today, Mr. Huizenga said that Republic would cater to anybody who wants to rent, lease or buy a car that is brand new or used. "When they think of transportation," he said, "we want them to think about us."
The question now is: Can Mr. Huizenga hit another home run or will he strike out this time?
"He sees an opportunity to revolutionize automotive retailing, and he's doing it through a consolidation strategy," said J. David Power 3d, the automotive quality consultant.
Republic's strategy carries enormous risks for everyone involved. Auto makers are torn between frustration at the inefficiency of their bloated dealer networks and worry that they may be losing control over distribution. Some consumer advocates see a danger that Republic may monopolize the mostly Southeastern and Southwestern metropolitan markets that it has picked as targets, eventually pushing up prices. And while many dealers are excited that Republic has been using its soaring stock to pay stratospheric prices, others are terrified at having to compete with a rising corporate powerhouse.
Some of the biggest risks, though, are for Republic and its shareholders. Dealerships struggling to survive in one of America's most cutthroat businesses have had mixed success in the past handling the extra expenses needed to offer the touch-screen computers, children's play areas, attentive staffs and no-haggle prices that Republic has adopted. Executives at smaller chains of dealerships question whether the economies of scale from bringing a number of already successful new car dealerships under one umbrella are strong enough to offset the cost of the corporate bureaucracy that Mr. Huizenga needs to oversee his mushrooming empire.
Moreover, financial analysts say, Republic is relying on a controversial accounting practice known as pooling of interests. Without it, some say, its earnings -- already meager -- might shrink.
Mr. Huizenga, who owns a tenth of Republic's stock and is the company's chairman, and Steven R. Berrard, Republic's president, reply that all of these difficulties have parallels in their experience at Blockbuster and will be overcome. Combining late-model used-car superstores and rental car companies under the same corporate roof, for instance, will allow Republic to rent unsold used cars when rental demand is high on weekends and in late summer, Mr. Berrard said.
The sheer size of Republic's operations has already allowed the company to drive down advertising rates by as much as 46 percent, saving $150 a car, while its huge centers for reconditioning used cars so that they look like new should nearly halve the usual $850 expense, he added.
Mr. Huizenga said that Republic was designed to cater to an American public that was becoming less enamored of cars. The answer now in automotive retailing, Mr. Huizenga said, is to let customers buy, lease or rent whatever meets their needs while involving the least expense and difficulty.
"Americans don't have a love affair with cars anymore," Mr. Huizenga said, adding that as a young man, "I waxed my car every Saturday for Pete's sake."
Since late November, Republic has acquired or reached agreements to acquire 52 huge new car dealerships, including the dozen New Jersey dealerships purchased for $55 million in stock. Already, with roughly $3.8 billion in combined annual sales for the acquired dealers, Republic is the nation's largest retailer of new cars and light trucks.
But does Republic, for all its success in building a huge dealer network virtually overnight, represent a more efficient and profitable way to sell, rent and service cars? On the plus side, Mr. Huizenga should be able to combine accounting, legal and advertising staffs, impose a consistent marketing strategy and trade cars among company-owned dealers so they do not all have to maintain huge and costly inventories of every model.
Still, Ramsay H. Gillman, the president of the National Automobile Dealers Association and the owner of 21 Texas dealerships through his family business, said that most of the benefits had already been captured by existing dealer chains. "The economies of scale have kind of already taken place," he said.
To help him in his quest, Mr. Huizenga clearly has a powerful ally in Detroit. Auto executives have fumed for years at the poor service at many dealerships, but have been unable to do much about it because state laws shelter dealer franchises from interference. In Mr. Huizenga, they have finally found someone willing to invest heavily in new showrooms, consistent displays and signs, and other amenities.
Robert Lutz, the Chrysler Corporation's vice chairman, said it was now up to traditional dealers to prove their worth. "I don't believe that there are economies of scale in the automotive retailing business if the dealers do their job well," he said during a recent flight aboard the company's Gulfstream II jet, a martini in his right hand and a cigar in his left. "If they don't do their job well, there are."
Only three important car lines have refused to give Mr. Huizenga permission to buy their dealers: Saturn, Toyota and Lexus. All three already have efficient networks with high customer service ratings.
The unknown equation in Mr. Huizenga's calculated gamble is whether auto makers will ever start selling new cars to him for less than they charge other dealers, much as big retailers like Wal-Mart have been able to demand volume discounts for television sets and other products. While the evidence is mixed on whether Republic's emphasis on premium service actually pushes up prices -- Republic denies it -- discounts on new cars would clearly allow the company to charge less while offering good service, making it a threat to every competitor.
Mr. Huizenga said that his business plan did not depend on such discounts, and auto makers have vowed never to give Republic and other big chains better prices than their existing dealers. "We are not going to treat Autonation any differently," said Ross Roberts, general manager of the Ford Motor Company's Ford division. "There will not be any volume discounts."
But will the Big Three stick to that position in the next economic downturn, when they may be desperately trying to sell large numbers of unwanted cars again? Lawyers for auto dealers insist that volume discounts would violate the Robinson-Patman Act, a Depression-era law that bars price discrimination. But antitrust experts say that it is extremely difficult to make a case under the law.
Auto dealers would have to prove that discounts lessened competition and were not justified by cost savings the auto makers achieved by dealing with a single large customer. A Federal appeals court ruled 15 years ago that Chrysler could offer prices to its dealers that were indirectly linked to volume. Although Chrysler has not tried to make use of that decision, the ruling, said James Rill, a former Justice Department antitrust chief, "is kind of a landmark decision in the Robinson-Patman lore and it's in the automotive industry."
Mr. Power, the quality consultant, said that he thought Mr. Huizenga would inevitably obtain discounts. "You can't tell me if he's buying 50,000 cars a month, he won't get a better price than the guy in Cheyenne, Wyo., ordering five cars a month."
Whatever the future holds, investors are clearly betting that Republic will make Mr. Huizenga -- and them -- another fortune. The stock closed at $35 today, up $1.25, far above its price of $2 less than two years ago. The market's insatiable demand for Republic's stock has allowed Mr. Huizenga to issue more stock to pay for each acquisition. In addition to companies in the auto business, Republic has bought a number of smaller garbage hauling companies, which have provided most of its profits so far, and a few electronic security companies.
Mr. Huizenga has been paying in stock 7 to 10 times the after-tax earnings for his new car dealerships, considerably higher than previous deals. Yet with Republic's stock trading at a lofty multiple of 51 times the 69 cents a share that analysts expect it to earn this year, the acquisitions have increased rather than diluted earnings.
Some experts remain astonished by the performance of Republic's stock. Martin L. Anderson, a specialist in dealer finances at Babson College in Wellesley, Mass., said that he believed Republic's business model would ultimately prove successful, particularly in controlling inventory costs. Still, Republic's stock price multiples "are crazy right now," he said. "They're going to come down to something more normal."
Moreover, Republic's multiples would be even more outside the norm if it did not use a somewhat controversial but perfectly legal accounting method known as pooling of interests that helps it report higher earnings. Republic has adopted this approach in half its deals, avoiding accounting for much of the cost of its buying spree as so-called good will. Because good will must be written off over a period of up to 40 years, Republic's earnings appear larger by not including it.
Michael J. Karsner, Republic's chief financial officer, said that it was not possible to calculate how much good will had been avoided because the valuation of physical assets is also different under a pooling of interests than under conventional purchase accounting. Mr. Berrard said that the pooling of interests involved extra legal costs that outweighed, in the short run, the effect on earnings from reduced good will.
Mr. Huizenga's many admirers on Wall Street argue that none of this matters as long as Republic keeps growing. "From a stock market standpoint, you almost discard the normal, almost mathematical calculations," said Maryann N. Keller, an auto analyst at Furman Selz. "Right now, we're in the building phase."

HEADLINE: U.S.-Canadian Split on Cuba Tangles Wal-Mart's Pajamas

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 5

 BODY:
The battle to undermine the only Communist regime in the Western Hemisphere -- Fidel Castro's Cuba -- has spread to the pajama department at the Wal-Mart in Winnipeg, Manitoba.
Late last week, a Canadian customer rummaging through the store's racks discovered that the Arkansas-based retailer was trafficking in Cuban-made pj's. A politically alert store manager pulled the pajamas off the shelves, fearful that the chain could find itself in violation of the Helms-Burton Act. That is the American law that tries to force foreign companies and governments to join in the American embargo of Cuban products. 
 Yet no sooner had Wal-Mart announced that it was also clearing the pajama shelves of its 135 other stores around Canada than the Canadian Government opened an inquiry into whether the retailer had violated a Canadian law that bars companies operating in Canada from obeying the American statute or "observing any directive, instruction, intimation of policy, or other communication" from the United States that furthers the Cuba embargo.
In public at least, Canada is taking its Cuban pajamas as seriously as cigar aficionados take their Cohibas. "We expect Canadian companies and the Canadian subsidiaries of American companies to obey Canadian law, full stop," a spokesman for the Canadian Ministry of Foreign Affairs and International Trade said this afternoon. If prosecuted and found guilty, he added, Wal-Mart could be fined as much as $1.5 million (Canadian), or a bit more than $1 million (United States) at current exchange rates.
No one thinks it will come to that. But if Wal-Mart is the first to be caught in this maw of conflicting laws and contradictory national policies, it is almost certain not to be the last. Mexico and the European Union have recently adopted similar "blocking" legislation, which makes it illegal for companies doing business within their borders to obey the American legislation, which they are challenging at the World Trade Organization.
The United States vowed two weeks ago to block that challenge. In Washington, Stuart E. Eizenstat, the Under Secretary of Commerce, declared that rather than allow the organization to judge whether the Helms-Burton Act violated international trade accords, the United States would invoke a "national security exemption," a claim that Helms-Burton is not a trade action but a law to curb the Cuban threat to the United States.
That declaration was sharply criticized in Europe and Canada and came up earlier this week in a meeting here between Lloyd Axworthy, the Canadian Foreign Affairs Minister, and Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright.
The Wal-Mart store where this controversy began is in Winnipeg, Mr. Axworthy's political base. It is not clear whether he has ever shopped for pajamas there.
It is also not clear whether the store manager who started it all may have overreacted. Helms-Burton is aimed at foreign companies that traffic in property Mr. Castro seized from Americans and American companies when he took power nearly four decades ago. It applies, for example, to the Mexican and Italian corporations that have a stake in the Cuban phone system, which was built by American companies.
In this case, Wal-Mart bought the pajamas from a Canadian distributor, who in turn had imported them from Cuba. Other American retailers operating in Canada or Mexico could easily run into the same problem. But if Wal-Mart knows anything about the factory that produced the Cuban-made pajamas, it was not saying yesterday.
"We were concerned that the sale of these goods might violate the Helms-Burton Act," Edward Gould, a spokesman for the company, said today, explaining why store managers from Nova Scotia to British Columbia were told to remove the Cuban jammies. "We're still not sure. Counsel is looking into it."
The diplomatic no-man's land in which Wal-Mart now finds itself was created by two differences between the United States and Canada. One is an honest difference of strategy. The other is a dispute over America's effort to use its economic power to achieve its foreign policy goals.
The question of strategy is this: Do you bring down Mr. Castro faster by preventing him from exporting pajamas, and almost everything else, around the world, or by flooding Cuba with trade, investments and capitalism? The Canadian position is that a 30-year American embargo has failed and that economic engagement -- the phrase Washington uses to defend its policies toward China -- is the only strategy that makes sense. Many in the Clinton Administration say privately that they agree.
But at this point the White House is so committed to Helms-Burton, which was signed in the heat of the Presidential campaign after a Cuban attack on two planes piloted by Cuban exiles, that dissidents in the Administration dare not utter their view in public.
The second issue, which really riles Canada, Mexico and Europe, is more politically charged: Does Congress have a right to extend the reach of American law beyond the borders of the United States? European officials have called the measure "arrogant" and "bullying." At the heart of the European case in front of the World Trade Organization is the argument that the United States is free to impose an economic embargo on a foreign nation but not to force foreign companies, operating outside United States territory, to join that embargo.
That has been a particularly sensitive issue in Canada, which is always touchy about any suggestion that is policies or culture are being dominated by the United States, its biggest trading partner. That was captured this morning in a political cartoon in The Financial Post, a major Canadian newspaper. An overweight Wal-Mart was shown disrobing from its striped Cuban pajamas, in response to the demands of an Uncle Sam character who was yelling, "Take 'Em Off."
But then a burly Canadian intercedes and growls, "Not in my house, you don't."

HEADLINE: Two Koreas and the U.S. Talk About Talks on Declaring Peace

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

 BODY:
A delegation from North Korea met yesterday with American and South Korean officials in New York to discuss the possibility of negotiating a formal end to the Korean War.
The meeting stopped short of full negotiations but offered the chance to lay out details of the proposal made last April by President Clinton and President Kim Young Sam of South Korea to hold peace talks involving the two Koreas, the United States and China. 
 Although officials from North and South Korea have met before, the meeting yesterday was the first to address directly the idea of replacing the armistice of 1953 that ended the fighting with a formal peace.
There were no breakthroughs. And afterward, the leader of North Korea's delegation, a Deputy Foreign Minister, Kim Gye Gwan, remained noncommittal about his Government's willingness to talk. "We need further study of the proposal," he said, echoing the position Pyongyang has held since the proposal was put forward.
The Administration nonetheless declared it significant that North Korea, one of the world's most isolated governments, had agreed to attend a meeting at all, particularly with its reviled enemy to the south.
As a nod to that, the United States announced at the start of the meeting that it would not conduct its periodic military exercises with the South this year, an Administration official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The exercises have long antagonized the North. And although the United States has postponed them in the past, the timing of the announcement yesterday was deliberate, the official said.
The meeting came after fits and starts caused by the grounding of a North Korean spy submarine full of commandos off the coast of South Korea, a food crisis in the North and the defection of a prominent North Korean official.
In recent weeks North Korea has been rocked by the defection of one senior minister, Hwang Jang Yop, and the deaths of two others. It has also faced a food shortage that prompted an emergency appeal for aid from the World Food Program, which the United States answered by pledging $10 million in relief.
A senior State Department official said those issues were not the focus of the meeting. But he said the delegations from the United States and South Korea had made clear that a move toward peace would include economic cooperation.
It is unclear when North Korea might respond or how, but in Washington the State Department spokesman, Nicholas Burns, described the meeting as "quite serious and sincere."
North Korea agreed to attend after expressing "deep regret" for the incursion of the spy submarine into South Korean waters. But it twice postponed the meeting.
In a sign of the sensitivities of the North Koreans, as well as the desire of the United States not to alienate the South, almost every detail of the meeting was subject to intense negotiation -- from finding a neutral location (the New York Hilton in midtown Manhattan) to arranging the tables and chairs: first a circle, then a triangle and finally a circle again.

SEOUL, South Korea, Thursday, March 6 (Reuters) -- South Korea and the United States have cancelled joint war games this year in a gesture to ease tensions on the Korean peninsula, the Defence Ministry confirmed today.
The cancellation "is part of efforts by our two governments to build confidence and to create an atmosphere conducive to the reduction of tensions," the Defence Ministry said.

LENGTH: 1230 words

HEADLINE: Market Place;
New Models Of Growth On a Hot, Hot Stock Index

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
Growth stocks -- the shares of companies whose profits Wall Street expects to rise rapidly -- have been the darlings of the stock market during the 1990's. But they lagged late in 1996, and have recently been downright poor performers.
The best measure of the performance of the stocks that analysts love is a new index, the Montgomery Securities Growth Stock Index, which is based on the 500 stocks for which Wall Street expects the greatest profit growth in the coming five years or so. 
The index is new, but Montgomery, a San Francisco-based brokerage firm that specializes in growth stocks, traced it back to the beginning of the 1990's, and found phenomenal performance. Had you invested $100 in index stocks at the beginning of 1990, it would have risen to $310 at the end of January. In contrast, a similar investment in the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks would have been worth $222, and one in the Russell 2000, the best-known index of small stocks, would have risen to just $220. All figures ignore dividends and transaction costs.
But since then, things have not been as friendly for many growth stocks. The index is down 11.7 percent since the end of January, a period in which the S.& P. 500 is up 2 percent and the Russell 2000 is down 1.5 percent.
The search for growth has been a staple for many investors. Finding the next Xerox or Microsoft -- companies that rose from tiny to supreme in an important business -- is a dream, and finding one can provide gains to offset a multitude of failures.
But many companies that are expected to grow instead run into problems, whether from competition or changing technology. And such stocks can be vulnerable to concern that the economic environment is turning less friendly.
"Growth investors are looking to the future and paying for future earnings," said Michael Moe, Montgomery Securities' director of growth stock research. Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, discussed the possibility of "irrational exuberance" in the stock market and, some think, sent out warning signals that he might feel required to push up interest rates.
"When you are discounting future earnings, people have a greater fear of interest rates going up," Mr. Moe said.
Perhaps, but it may also be that as stock prices have been bid up, so too have analysts' expectations. A review of the Montgomery index, and where it stood at the end of each year, shows just how much more pricey growth stocks have become. It also shows that the nature of what Wall Street means by growth has changed. A few years ago, many investors looked for companies that would grow consistently, whatever the economy, such as Coca-Cola. Now they are often looking for the next Microsoft.
The recent slipping of stocks in the index matches recent performance problems of some mutual funds that have done well in the past by picking growth stocks. The American Century 20th Vista Fund, once a star, has lost more than 8 percent of its value so far in 1997.
The inclusion of companies in the Montgomery growth index is based on the forecasts of analysts collected by IBES, the firm formerly known as Institutional Brokers Estimate Service. While it asks for earnings-per-share figures for coming quarters and years, it also asks for longer-term profit forecasts.
That way, Mr. Moe said, Montgomery hopes to capture in its index "not only yesterday's heroes," whose earnings have risen, "but also tomorrow's stars," which may or may not be making money now but are expected to see profits zoom.
To compile the index, Montgomery each year takes the 500 stocks with the highest anticipated long-term growth rates, though it includes only companies with a market capitalization of at least $200 million. By focusing on long-term expectations, it can include stocks that are now losing money, or whose growth is not robust now but is expected to become so.
How much more optimistic have analysts become than they were? At the end of 1990, a company with expected long-term annual earnings growth of 11.6 percent could get into the index.
Now, after several years of economic recovery, joining the select 500 requires that analysts expect earnings to rise 24.2 percent, more than double the rate required six years ago. The figure has risen in every year since 1990.
In the early part of the decade, the list of the 500 stocks for which Wall Street expected the most growth was filled with reliable consumer goods companies that had performed well year after year. At the beginning of 1991, it included venerable names like Procter & Gamble, Coca-Cola, General Electric, Kellogg, Borden and Campbell Soup.
Now, such companies are largely passe to the growth investor, although some have done very well in the stock market. Consumer goods companies make up a dwindling portion of the current list of hot stocks, replaced by a large number of technology companies, and none of the stocks named above is on the 1997 list. Technology companies now make up 40 percent of the 500 stocks, and account for 46 percent of the market value of stocks in the index.
The technology portion would be even greater but for the fact that for the first time, Microsoft no longer makes the cut. Analysts project its long-term growth rate as 23 percent. Not bad, but not enough now to make the top 500.
What companies do make the list? Among the technology names are Netscape Communications, Yahoo, Iomega and Pixar. And while Coca-Cola may no longer be deemed a fast grower, Boston Beer is on the list.
Another way to measure just how speculative the index has become is to see how many companies on it are expected to lose money in the next year, or to make so little that their current price-earnings ratios are more than 60 to 1.
Back in 1990, there were 33 such companies. The next year, scared by the recession, analysts saw hot growth prospects in just 30 companies. The number rose over time, but at the beginning of 1995, it was still just 56, or a bit more than 1 in 10 of the 500 companies about which analysts were the most optimistic.
But at the beginning of 1996, that figure was up to 123, and at the beginning of this year, to 173 companies -- or more than one in three. That included 72 that are expected to lose money this year, and 101 that are trading at more than 60 times the consensus earnings forecast for 1997.
More than half the companies now on the index are losing money or trading at price-earnings multiples above 40. At the beginning of 1991, that figure was less than one in 12.
Such companies have room for thrilling moves if things go right. They also have a lot of room for disappointment. Consider the following two lists, each of stocks currently in the index. The first is Yahoo, Optical Data Systems, Target Therapeutics, Vivus, E-Trade and Playboy Enterprises. The second consists of Citrix SystemsXL Connect Solutions, RTW, Atlas Air, Clintrials Research, Jayhawk Acceptance and Chicago Miniature Lamp.
All the stocks in the first list are up at least 50 percent so far this year. The others are down by at least that much.
The first list shows that, even in an environment that has turned at least a bit hostile, there is money to be made in growth stocks. The second one, alas, shows that picking the wrong ones can be disastrous. And so far in 1997, the bad performers have outmatched the good ones.

Colombia Halts Eradication Of Drug-Producing Crops
Colombia suspended all aerial eradication of drug-producing crops and began an overall review of its cooperation with the United States in fighting drug trafficking. It appeared to be a response to Washington's decertification of Colombia as a cooperating partner in the fight against drugs. A1

Yasir Arafat sailed through New York, Georgia and Texas, seeking to put pressure on Israel to halt plans to build a Jewish settlement in East Jerusalem. The Palestinian leader said agreements between Israel and the Palestinians might unravel without some change in the settlement decision. His trip was not without some unexpected theater, including a misunderstanding over where his plane would land. A3

President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt said he would not intervene in the case of an Israeli accused of spying and scheduled to stand trial in Cairo, despite an appeal from the visiting Israeli Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu. Security officials said prosecutors would ask for the harshest possible sentence. Mr. Mubarak meets with President Clinton on Monday. A3
 
Swiss Propose Holocaust Fund
President Arnold Koller of Switzerland proposed creating a $4.7 billion fund and using its interest earnings to aid victims of the Holocaust and other calamities. The proposal, under which Switzerland's gold reserves would be revalued, would offer longterm commitments to Holocaust survivors. The Swiss National Bank also offered to donate $70 million to a separate fund set up for short-term help. Both ideas require Parliament's approval. A6

A senior delegation from North Korea met with United States and South Korean officials in New York City to discuss the possibility of negotiating a formal end to the Korean War. HEADLINE: New York City Has Sharp Rise In Jobless Rate

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
New York City's unemployment rate shot up in January to 9.9 percent, the highest monthly level in nearly three years, the State Department of Labor reported yesterday. More New Yorkers were unsuccessfully looking for work, the agency said, than at any time since early 1994, when the city was still slowly climbing out of a deep recession.
The new rate, which rose more than a full percentage point, from an adjusted level of 8.8 percent in December, does not in itself signal another economic downturn, economists said. Indeed, the Labor Department also said in a separate report that New York City created about 13,000 more jobs in 1996 than preliminary counts had indicated. 
 What makes the January development more significant is partly the sudden acceleration, a full percentage point above the rate in January 1996, and what it says about the level of economic frustration in the city. The New York economy is slowly growing, economists said, but expectations are rising even faster as people enter the labor market.
The high unemployment rate during the recession, by contrast, which peaked at 11.9 percent in January 1993, was caused largely by job losses in New York. The new higher number is caused largely by thousands of people entering the job market and failing to find employment.
"The economy doesn't have enough steam in it to accommodate all the job seekers," said John L. Wieting, the regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. "People perceive the job market as being very strong, and they're out there testing the waters."
New York City's Deputy Mayor for Operations, Randy M. Mastro, said he believed that the average unemployment rate for the city in 1996, at 8.6 percent, provides a better measure of the city's economic condition than any one-month total.
But he added that having a higher number of job seekers was also in itself a measure of growing strength.
"It's a reflection of an improving local economy that not only private-sector jobs increased, but more people want to enter the job market," he said.
New York State's unemployment rate also rose, the Labor Department said, to 6.9 percent in January from 5.9 percent in December. But on a year-to-year basis, the state rate remained unchanged.
The United States unemployment rate of 5.9 percent was also up, from 5 percent in December, as measured by the snapshot monthly numbers, which are not seasonally adjusted, but was down from the previous January, when it stood at 6.3 percent.
The state report also highlighted the sharp variations in job hunting success within the New York region. Nassau County, for example, had an unemployment rate of only 3.5 percent in January -- tied with Monroe County for the second-lowest rate in the state, and beaten only by Putnam County, at 3.4 percent.
New York City, by contrast, had two of the three highest unemployment rates, by county, in New York: the Bronx, at 12 percent, and Brooklyn, at 11.4 percent. Manhattan had the lowest unemployment rate of the city's five boroughs, at 8.2 percent. Hamilton County in the Adirondacks had the single highest in the state, at 16.2 percent.
Economists caution that monthly numbers fluctuate and that they often rise in January, as seasonal workers in the retail industry are dismissed after the holidays. But they also said the unemployment totals could be aggravated through this year as the welfare overhaul takes effect.
Under the new welfare laws, 25 percent of the city's welfare caseload must be involved in a job or related activity by Sept. 30. That labor participation rate is to climb by 5 percent ever year after that, to 50 percent of the welfare population by 2002.
State economists said that the higher number of people looking for work -- a number that includes people who said in state telephone surveys that they were looking for jobs or who had applied for benefits -- might be partly explained by the long shadow of the city's recession.
From 1989 to 1992, the city lost about 300,000 jobs, as real estate, financial services and construction and other areas contracted. Many of the people who lost those jobs disappeared from the economic periscope when they gave up and stopped looking.
That, in addition to the city's gradual recovery and growth of new jobs since then, helped the employment rate go down beginning in 1993.
The return of at least some of those people to the labor market is believed by economists to be what is fueling the unemployment increases that began last year.

HEADLINE: Trade Membership for China

 BODY:
If China is prepared to honor international fair-trade rules, it should be admitted to the World Trade Organization. It makes no practical sense to complicate this issue with other considerations about China, including its poor record on human rights. Those important questions can be better handled in other ways.
China wants membership in the new trade organization to establish its place in the international community even though it will win few tangible economic benefits. Countries like the United States have already extended low tariffs and other trade privileges to China. But membership can force the Chinese to take steps toward a fully functioning market economy. Trade organization rules require that foreign investment and trade be conducted on commercial terms, with no subsidies for exports or restrictions on imports. 
 Washington demands, for instance, that China make explicit any subsidies the Government provides state-owned factories that allow them to sell goods below cost. Membership would also require China to drop restrictions that force foreign investors there to export products they make in China. China will have to honor patents and copyrights.
Membership, then, can be useful to the West as a catalyst for reform in China. It would give leverage to Chinese officials who are pushing for political and market reforms. Policies that put more power in impersonal markets remove power from government bureaucrats. Membership will also ease needless tension between China and the United States. Rather than clashing directly over trade disputes, the two countries could turn to an impartial international jury to resolve commercial tensions.
Technically, the United States cannot block China's entrance into the World Trade Organization. But some members of Congress want to force the Administration to get its approval before coming to agreement with the Chinese, fearing China will win favorable terms. Such an intrusion is unnecessary. The Administration has no reason to go easy on China, knowing Congress already has the authority to prevent the Administration from extending trade privileges to China even if it gains membership in the World Trade Organization.
Others in Congress recoil at inviting China into the trade organization because of its human rights abuses and contempt for democracy. Those concerns are warranted, but Chinese membership in the trade organization will not preclude America from pressuring China on these issues. The World Trade Organization, which Washington worked hard to establish, should not be used for political and diplomatic ends, however worthy they may be.
The important task for the Administration is to negotiate commercially fair terms, phased in quickly enough that China must initiate reform immediately. Congressional interference serves no good purpose.

HEADLINE: Colombia, in Rebuff to the U.S., Halts Drug Eradication Program

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, March 5

 BODY:
Colombia, the world's largest producer of cocaine, today suspended all aerial eradication of drug-producing crops in a sharp rebuff to the United States.
The move was an unexpectedly swift and forceful reaction to the Clinton Administration's decision to include Colombia on a list of nations that are not fully cooperating with the United States in the fight against drugs. In suspending the flights, Colombia shelved what American officials viewed as a cornerstone of its anti-drug programs. 
 Joaquin Polo, Colombia's anti-drug czar, announced the decision in a radio interview this afternoon in which he said Colombia was reviewing any further cooperation with Washington on the programs.
"The work of fumigation is temporarily suspended while, as the Government announced, the entire subject of international cooperation with the Government of the United States is reviewed," Mr. Polo said.
In a television interview tonight the American Ambassador, Myles Frechette, said he was "really surprised" by the suspension. He described it as a temporary "interruption" rather than an end to joint eradication, which he said "would have been a disaster" for Colombia.
United States Government figures showing an increase in coca cultivation "were not the fault of the police," Mr. Frechette said. "The drug dealers are planting more."
Tension is mounting over Washington's decision last week to "decertify" Colombia in the war against drugs.
Earlier in the day, unions workers staged a protest at the United States Embassy and the Interior Minister, Horacio Serpa, said the American decision had "poisoned the atmosphere" for a bill that would allow the extradition of drug traffickers to the United States.
But the suspension of aerial eradication of drugs also drew protests here. Carlos Lleras de la Fuente, a former Ambassador to Washington, said the decision by President Ernesto Samper was a gift to drug traffickers, and Chief Prosecutor Alfonso Valdivieso, who sits on the National Council on Narcotics, said he had not been consulted.
Clinton Administration officials have said the decision to label Colombia uncooperative was largely a repudiation of President Samper, who has been linked to drug traffickers. For his part, Mr. Samper has consistently framed the American rebuke as a national insult.
The aerial spraying of fields growing coca and poppies is a risky tactic in which helicopters escorting the planes must sometimes fire at the ground to deter attack from the growers. The United States has continued to finance virtually the entire fumigation effort, even though it also decertified Colombia last year. Washington supplies all of the planes and helicopters and pilot training.
When a country is denied certification as the United States' ally in fighting drugs, it loses access to most American military and economic aid and may face trade sanctions. But the law exempts humanitarian and anti-drug aid.
Some pilots and gunners in Colombia's last eradication flight today in the mountains of southern Colombia appeared discouraged by the poor marks the United States had given their country.
"We're out here every day, fumigating and putting our lives at risk, and the U.S. says we're not doing enough," said one pilot.
In its report, the United States criticized both Mr. Samper and the Colombian Congress, which cleared the President of charges he took $6 million in campaign contributions from Cali drug lords. The report said coca crops last year had increased by 32 percent, despite fumigation efforts. The United States also estimated that Colombia had fumigated 40,000 acres, rather than the 47,000 acres Colombia claimed.
While the disparity seemed minor, Mr. Polo said this afternoon that it was the main reason for breaking off all eradication efforts. "They work with our police hand in hand all year long, and then when it comes time for an evaluation, there's a total ignorance of what we've done," he said in a telephone interview.
"I honestly hope that all of these difficulties between our Governments can be overcome," Mr. Polo said. "The only ones who this benefits are the drug dealers."
According to State Department figures, more than half the cocaine-processing laboratories and 90 percent of the coca eradicated in Colombia since 1990 were destroyed during the adminisration of Mr. Samper, who took office in August 1994. But experts described the suspension of aerial spraying as a thinly veiled retaliation for Washington's decertification and a way to divert attention from criticism of Mr. Samper.
"Suspending fumigation is mainly a way to turn what is really just a problem of Samper into a problem of the country," said Fabio Castillo, a Colombian drug expert and author of "The New Horsemen of Cocaine." He said the President's gesture confused Colombians by giving them the message that the way to confront the United States was to adopt a measure that benefited the drug cartel.
While Colombia had warned that it would review the terms of its anti-drug cooperation with the United States, few here expect a decision so quickly. A spokesman said President Samper and a close circle of his associates had decided to suspend the flights at a meeting earlier today.

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths
FINK, STANLEY

 BODY:
FINK-Stanley. In Memory of the Hon. Stanley Fink, Esq. The faculty, staff, administration and students of Kingsborough Community College join all residents of the City and State of New York in mourning the untimely passing of the Honorable Stanley Fink, Esq., former State Assembly Speaker and City University of New York Trustee. Speaker Fink retired as New York State Assembly Speaker in 1986 after a distinguished record of service to the people of the Borough of Brooklyn, the City of New York and the State of New York. Stanley Fink, a longtime resident of Brooklyn, earned his baccalaureate degree from Brooklyn College in 1956 and his law degree from New York University Law School in 1959. After serving in the Judge Advocate General's Office of the United States Air Force, he returned to Brooklyn to practice law & began what would become a distinguished career in civic and public affairs. In 1968, he ran for the State Assembly & was elected to represent the Canarsie Assembly District. He became Assembly majority leader in 1977 and, in 1979, he was elected Speaker of the Assembly, a position in which he served with distinction until his retirement in 1986. In 1989 he was appointed to the Board of Trustees of The City University of New York by Governor Cuomo. As a trustee he continued his commitment to the students of the City of New York. He championed the cause of access to higher education for all New Yorkers and was a strong advocate of Kingsborough Community College's emergence as an educational force in the Brooklyn community. Speaker Fink's contributions to the College were recognized when he was awarded the Kingsborough President's Medal for his devotion to the cause of higher education, in general, and open admissions specifically. Known as a forceful leader capable of fostering bi-partisanship in the legislature, Stanley Fink leaves a record of legislative innovation in the areas of criminal justice reform, highway safety, school aid & primary, secondary, and higher education. Both as Speaker of the New York State Assembly and as a Trustee of the City University of New York, he was a strong voice for the educationally and economically disadvantaged, women returning to the workforce, and education for new immigrants. He took particular pride in the development of new programs at Kingsborough Community College to serve these populations. His commitment to access through open-enrollment became the public policy of New York State and, for this, he will be long remembered and held in the highest regard. Stanley Fink's contributions in government, in the business sector and in higher education are many. He will always be remembered, however, for his extraordinary intelligence, his great sense of humor and his innate ability to cut through rhetoric and get to the heart of the matter. His energy and magnetic personality merged to form a commanding presence wherever people gathered. Stanley Fink was a loving husband to his wife, Judith, a devoted father to his son, Marc and daughter-in-law, Laura Kirschstein, his son, Keith and daughter-in-law, Caryn, and an adoring grandfather to his granddaughter, Alexandra. His legacy of excellence as a public servant, his passion for justice, his devotion to his family and the joy he derived from their love, serve to help us remember Stanley Fink as a man who made a difference. Leon M. Goldstein, President Kingsborough Community College

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW;
What's the Meaning of Life? You Can Ask the Tea Leaves

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN 

 BODY:
How much fun can a madcap urban comedy be when there's no humor or buoyancy behind the crazy antics? Adrienne Shelly's absurdist romp "Sudden Manhattan" is crammed with zany characters colliding giddily on the streets of lower Manhattan in their search for meaning in life. But acting frantically offbeat isn't the same thing as being funny.
Donna (Ms. Shelly), the film's narrator and central character, is an aimless, unemployed 20-something woman who moans about having no job, no love, no reason to get up in the morning. Her life isn't really so horrible. She is fortunate enough to live rent free in a building owned by her writing teacher, Murphy (Roger Rees), an eccentric Englishman who is so smitten with her that he leaves a bouquet of red roses on her doorstep each morning. 
 While staring into her breakfast eggs at a neighborhood diner one day, Donna hears ominous rumbling noises that no one else notices. Minutes later, while wandering the streets of Greenwich Village, she witnesses a murder. Or thinks she does. The police laugh off her story. Almost simultaneously, she strikes up a friendship with Adam (Tim Guinee), an unemployed actor, who prefers reading Russian literature out loud in bed to making love.
Donna attends a birthday luau for her mopey best friend, Georgie (Hynden Walch), who has just been jilted. She also begins consulting Dominga (Louise Lasser), the most pessimistic psychic ever to hang out a fortunetelling shingle. Staring into her clients' tea leaves, Dominga informs them that the only things awaiting them are misery, pain and death. Nobody plays neurotic nags with more intensity than Ms. Lasser, who gives her character a nasty edge that cuts through the film's airy surrealism like a bad smell.
The hysteria escalates once Georgie recovers her spirits and introduces her two new beaus to Donna. Together with Adam, they all repair to Dominga's parlor, where the men put on Indian war paint and feathered headdresses and parade around goofily. Eventually, Donna and Adam visit the lair of the supposed murderer, who may or may not be suffering from a multiple-personality disorder. "Sudden Manhattan," which opens today at Sony Theaters 19th Street East, aspires to be a downtown answer to a Woody Allen comedy, with dashes of "Desperately Seeking Susan" and "After Hours" thrown into the mix. But Ms. Shelly's screenplay doesn't contain a single pithy apercu. As the actors breeze through their parts, they appear unaware of the fact that their characters' situations and daffy behavior might be anything but the last word in hip, uproarious whimsy.
This feels like a movie trying to work its way out of a chronic depression by snapping its fingers and pretending to be having fun. Few in the audience are likely to be fooled.
"Sudden Manhattan" is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). It has profanity and sexual situations.

Written and directed by Adrienne Shelly; director of photography, Jim Denault; edited by Jack Haigis; music by Pat Irwin; production designer, Teresa Mastropierro; produced by Marcia Kirkley; released by Phaedra Cinema. At Sony Theaters 19th Street East, at Broadway. Running time: 85 minutes. This film is rated R.

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
Discovering the Real Americas

BYLINE: By HOLLAND COTTER 

 BODY:
ONE of the frontier areas of study in art history is the interaction between Europe and the Americas five centuries ago at the beginning of the colonialist period.
Museum shows devoted to the subject have been few but notable. "Converging Cultures: Art and Identity in Spanish America" at the Brooklyn Museum of Art last spring, despite its dry-as-dust title, was one of the finest American exhibitions on any subject in recent years. Visually exhilarating, intellectually stimulating, it changed forever the way an epoch will be viewed. 
 Among the dazzling objects included, one in particular stood out: a 16th-century Roman Catholic priest's vestment made by native Mexican artisans and embroidered with hummingbird feathers, a decorative medium traditionally reserved for the robes of Aztec kings. Materially gorgeous, symbolically ambiguous, it stood as a symbol of cross-cultural tensions that marked the colonial encounter.
That marvelous garment was on loan to the Brooklyn show from the Hispanic Society of America, one of New York City's great underknown institutions. And now the society is adding its own contribution to the critical mass of information on New World culture with a small exhibition of prints, rare books and maps drawn from its own collection.
Here again, a ponderous title -- "Defining the Americas: Accounts and Images of Latin America From the European Encounter Through Independence" -- could keep attendance low. And the show itself, which demands almost as much reading as looking, isn't exactly user-friendly. But a little hard work is a small price to pay in exchange for the story it tells of how impressions of a culture were shaped by art, both from inside and out.
One of the oldest objects on view, an edition of Columbus's account of his trans-Atlantic voyage, probably published in Basel in 1494, gives a sense of how the Americas were first imagined in Europe. The explorer writes of a fabulous tropical Wonderland, but the book's illustrator, who presumably didn't make the trip, doggedly sticks to the everyday world he knows, turning the distant Caribbean into an alpine landscape replete with a walled and turreted town.
Gradually, however, more accurate information filtered in. It is true that fantasy still ran high: a book printed in Amsterdam as late as 1682 carried pictures of Brazilian insects that bizarrely resemble dinosaurs. But scientific accounts published in Spain include closely observed depictions of iguanas and armadillos, for which imported taxidermic specimens may have served as models.
It is in the portrayal of the people of the New World, though, that fact and fiction most tellingly, and often disturbingly, blend. For some Europeans, "Indians" were savages, plain and simple (in one engraving they are shown torturing a Spanish soldier). But for many, they were something else, a bright antediluvian remnant, the last inhabitants of a Paradise on earth.
Depictions of this state of innocence recur. In one late 16th-century engraving from Nuremberg, a statuesque, near-naked Indian couple are fitted out with plumed headdresses like actors in a court masque. In another, titled "Allegory of America" (1581), the continent is symbolized as a languorous classical nude reclining by a riverbank.
Such emblems were ways for Western illustrators to deal with cultures they didn't know first hand. But eventually other artists, American-born, provided an insider view of colonial life.
Some of their images are promotional, like Francisco Saverio Clavijero's depiction of slender Indian women baking bread. Others, which detail a colonial pecking order based on permutations of racial and cultural blending, are documentary in nature, and perhaps even discreetly critical.
Cultural blending can certainly be found outside the perimeters of the exhibition itself. It is there, for example, in the fascinating objects crowding the Hispanic Society galleries: an earthenware fountain, Spanish in style but Mexican-made, a genealogical chart tracing the economic rise of a family from Indian roots to colonial artistocracy. (Alas, the feathered robe seen in Brooklyn is deemed too fragile to be kept on view.)
And the mix is vibrantly alive in the predominantly Spanish-speaking neighborhood just outside the society's doors on West 155th Street. That neighborhood didn't exist when the impressive classical facade, engraved with the names of Cortez, Pizarro and Ponce de Leon, was built at the turn of the century. But it does now, and its presence gives an immediate pertinence to the new world of historical research that "Defining the Americas," in its modest way, represents.
"Defining the Americas: Accounts and Images of Latin America From the European Encounters Through Independence," organized by Mitchell A. Codding and Patrick Lenaghan, remains at the Hispanic Society of America, 613 West 155th Street, Washington Heights, through May 30.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A large detail from Jan Sadeler's engraving "Allegory of America" (1581), at the Hispanic Society of America. (Hispanic Society of America)
