HEADLINE: 2 Newspapers Each Are Winners Of 2 Polk Awards for Journalism

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER

 BODY:
Two newspapers, The New York Times and The Los Angeles Times, each won 2 of the 11 George Polk awards for journalism announced yesterday by Long Island University.
The New York Times won an award for economics reporting for its series "The Downsizing of America." And one of its correspondents, John F. Burns, won the foreign reporting award for his articles on the takeover of Kabul, Afghanistan, by Taliban, the militant Islamic group. 
 The Los Angeles Times won the prize for political reporting for "Money From Asia," about suspect contributions from Asian sources to the Democratic National Committee. The paper also won the cultural reporting award, for Chuck Philips's articles about the inner workings of America's $12 billion music industry.
A reporter for The Plain Dealer in Cleveland, Elizabeth Marchak, won the award for national reporting for her articles raising questions about the Federal Government's handling of air safety violations. Her series of articles, "The F.A.A. and Valujet Airlines," focused on the Federal Aviation Administration's weak response to its inspectors' reports on unsafe aircraft, improper maintenance and inadequate training at Valujet and other cut-rate airlines.
The awards, which are administered by Long Island University, were established in 1949 in memory of George W. Polk, a CBS correspondent who was killed in 1948 while covering the civil war in Greece.
Yesterday, Bryan Acohido of The Seattle Times won a Polk award for transportation reporting for "Safety at Issue: the 737," a series linking questions about the rudder controls of Boeing 737 planes to several deadly crashes and the F.A.A.'s resistance to acknowledging the problem.
Honors for local reporting went to Kevin Collison of The Buffalo News, who linked the death of a teen-ager, run over on a highway while on her way to work at a shopping mall, to a policy denying access to city buses to discourage minority customers.
The prize for magazine reporting went to Anne-Marie Cusac of The Progressive for "Stunning Technology," which exposed the life-threatening dangers of security devices used in American prisons and exported to repressive foreign regimes.
These were other prizes:
 FOREIGN TELEVISION REPORTING: Christiane Amanpour and Anita Pratap of CNN for "Battle for Afghanistan," an examination of the armed struggle for control of the country, with revealing interviews of key figures in opposing camps.
NATIONAL TELEVISION REPORTING: Matt Meagher and Tim Peek of "Inside Edition" for "Door to Door Insurance," an undercover investigation of the exploitation of poor Americans by some insurers.
CRITICISM: Blair Kamin of The Chicago Tribune for an examination of issues in Chicago architecture that encouraged public debate and influenced its outcome.

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths
WALL, EDWIN CRAIG

 BODY:
WALL-Edwin Craig, Jr., age 59, died on Wednesday, March 5, 1997 in Charlotte, NC. Mr. Wall was born in Conway, the son of May Howard Wall and the late Edwin Craig Wall, Sr. He was a resident of Conway and a lifelong member of Kingston Presbyterian Church where he served as a trustee. Mr. Wall graduated from Davidson College with a BA in Economics, & received his Master's of Business Administration from the Harvard Business School. He was Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Canal Industries, Inc., and also served as Board Chairman of New South, Inc., and a director of the Pelican Companies, Inc. Mr. Wall served as a member of the Board of Directors of a number of local, affiliated, and national companies. Among the local and affiliated companies are Dargan Construction Company, Chicora Development Corporation, Waccamaw Clay Products Company, Inc., Litchfield Enterprises, and Power Sources, Inc. Among the national companies are NationsBank Corporation, Blue Cross/Blue Shield of South Carolina, Sonoco Products Company, Ruddick Corporation, SCANA Corporation, and RTO, Inc. He also served on the Board of Advisors of Carousel Capital, Inc. Mr. Wall was extensively involved in numerous civic and charitable organizations. These activities included service as a trustee of The Duke Endowment, chairmanship of the Davidson College Board of Trustees, serving in several roles for Coastal Carolina University, including membership on the Board of Trustees, and chairmanship of the Board of Trustees of Brookgreen Gardens. He was a member of Clemson's President's Advisory Council, the Palmetto Business Forum, a director of the Palmetto Seed Capital Fund, and a trustee of the Conway Hospital Foundation. Mr. Wall was active in a number of roles for the Horry County United Way. He was instrumental in founding this charity which is so important to our community and served as its President and as a member of its Advisory Council. Among other civic and charitable organizations that Mr. Wall has served are the Horry County Mental Health Association, the Governor's Economic Task Force, the State Chamber of Commerce, the Belle W. Baruch Foundation, Coker College, Converse College, South Carolina Mental Health Association, Presbyterian College, the South Carolina Foundation of Independent Colleges, and USC Development Foundation. His service to the Pee Dee Area Council of the Boy Scouts of America led to his being recognized with a Silver Beaver Award. Among other awards received by Mr. Wall are a Distinguished Service Award for the Conway American Legion Post III, recognition as the South Carolina Chamber of Commerce Businessman of the Year and as an Outstanding Alumnus of the Conway High School Hall of Fame. Mr. Wall was honored as the recipient of an Endowed Professorship Chair in the Humanities at Davidson College and received honorary degrees from both Coastal Carolina University and Coker College. Surviving in addition to his mother of Conway are: his wife, Judith Atkins Wall of Conway, two sons, Edwin Craig Wall III of Charlotte, NC and Benjamin Rutledge Wall II of Davidson, NC; one daughter, Judith Atkins Wall of New York, NY; 3 sisters, May Ervin Wall of Hartsville, Harriet Wall Martin of Chapel Hill, NC and Nell Wall Otto of Greenwich, CT. Services will be held Friday, March 7th at 2:00 P.M. at Kingston Presbyterian Church in Conway. Interment to follow at Lakeside Cemetery. Memorials may be made to the E. Craig Wall, Jr. Fund, C/O Robinson, Bradshaw & Hinson, 1900 Independence Center, 101 North Tryon Street, Charlotte, North Carolina 28246.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains Against Mark After German Jobless Report

BYLINE: By The Associated Press By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar touched a three-year high against the mark for the third consecutive day yesterday after Germany reported record unemployment, but the dollar later retreated to end mostly lower.
Profit taking on the dollar's gains and uncertainty about the impact of United States employment data due today all weighed on the dollar as the day progressed. 
 The employment report is expected to disclose more evidence of a healthy economy and raise the likelihood of higher United States interest rates, which should help the dollar. But an excessively strong report could aggravate concern about inflation, unnerve the stock and bond markets and push the currency lower.
"The dollar may just have run out of steam for the time being," said John McCarthy, foreign-exchange manager at ING Capital Markets Inc. in New York. "People are going to wait for that unemployment data."
In European dealings, the dollar reached an intraday high of 1.7208 marks, the strongest since April 1994, before falling back to settle in New York at 1.7155 marks, up from 1.7121 marks on Wednesday.
The dollar settled at 121.13 yen in New York, down from 121.21 yen. The pound rose to $1.6155 from $1.6137.
Speculation that Germany would report a postwar unemployment record for February had pushed the dollar higher against the mark for most of this week. Although the report released yesterday showed 4.672 million jobless, less than the most pessimistic projections, the dollar still advanced.
"This is a classic bandwagon for the upside on the dollar," said Earl I. Johnson, foreign-exchange economist at the Bank of Montreal's New York branch. "Sentiment is still bullish for the dollar."
Against the yen, the dollar remained weak throughout the trading day, first falling in early Asian dealings after the Japanese Finance Ministry reported its broadest measure of trade for January showed a 362.3 percent increase in the surplus compared with the year earlier.
The dollar also fell after Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin told Congress that "a sustained increase in the Japanese surplus isn't in anybody's interest."

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Apartments Rising on Site Of Fillmore East and Saint

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
A seven-story brick rental apartment building is rising on part of the site at Second Avenue and Sixth Street in the East Village that was once home to the fabled rock concert hall the Fillmore East and later to the Saint, an elaborate disco that was a center of gay night life in the 1980's.
With 86 studio to three-bedroom apartments, including some duplex units, the structure rising at 225 East Sixth Street underscores Manhattan's strong rental market and the changing character of the area, which brokers say is in the throes of becoming an appealing address for young renters who have been priced out of such neighborhoods as SoHo and the West Village. The $14 million Hudson East project is being developed by the Hudson Companies Inc., based in Brooklyn. 
 Eighty percent of the 438- to 1,556-square-foot apartments will be rented at market value. The remaining 20 percent will be leased at reduced prices to tenants whose annual incomes are $13,700 to $22,050, depending on family size.
The new rental is the latest in a spate of so-called 80-20 projects just finished, under way or planned in Manhattan. In return for having 20 percent of the apartments reserved for low-income tenants, the city or state issues tax-exempt bonds to provide permanent financing to the builders, who are also eligible for a 20-year tax abatement from the city.
To protect bondholders, developers must also obtain what is called a credit enhancement -- mortgage insurance from a state or Federal agency or a letter of credit from a bank or pension fund.
Beyond the 80-20 projects, more than 2,600 rental units are in various stages of development and planning in downtown Manhattan, where office buildings are being converted to apartments with the aid of city-sponsored tax incentives. Among the larger conversions, 45 Wall Street, with 441 apartments, is expected to open for leasing next month.
Both programs are helping to increase rental production in the city. They also reflect the reliance of new residential construction on public benefits.
Alan R. Bell, a principal of the Hudson Companies, said the East Village project would not have been economically feasible without the tax incentives. It received $11.75 million in bond financing from the New York State Housing Finance Agency and mortgage insurance from the State of New York Mortgage Agency. Construction financing is coming from Chase Manhattan Bank and equity from the company.
The production of apartments is rising at a time when some brokers say rents in Manhattan are flattening after three years of increases, which pushed many tenants to buy.
With the new supply, "rents will soften in 1997," said Nancy Packes, president of Feathered Nest, a rental brokerage. But as rents ease, so will demand in the sale market, causing people to rent again and limiting the rental price decline, she said.
Hudson East is distinct because of its site's history, which dates from the late 1920's. Over time, the building was the Loew's Commodore movie palace, a Yiddish theater and a concert hall. In 1968, Bill Graham, the rock music impresario, turned the theater into the Fillmore East, which became a mecca for music fans. Among the acts that played at the Fillmore East before it closed in 1971 were B. B. King, the Grateful Dead, Janis Joplin and the Allman Brothers.
During the 1980's, the building was refurbished as the Saint, which for eight years drew crowds of several thousand gay dancers a night. And earlier this decade, there were plans to turn the empty structure into a six-screen movie theater. But that project went into bankruptcy.
The Hudson Companies bought the property for $1.6 million in 1995 from its mortgage holder, the National Bank of Canada. "We believed the East Village was turning around," resulting in a demand for more rentals, said Mr. Bell, who recalled attending a concert at the Fillmore.
A few groups rallied unsuccessfully to save the building for conversion to a recording studio or other performance use. Now, only the theater's Second Avenue entrance has been retained as part of a four-story commercial building that the Hudson Companies sold to Emigrant Savings Bank. A bank branch occupies the one-time theater lobby. The rest of the theater was razed to make way for the new apartment building.
It joins a few rental projects, including the 30-unit Information Building at 42-46 Avenue A at East Third Street, that have sprung up in recent years in the East Village. And the old Anderson Theater, at 66 Second Avenue between Third and Fourth Streets, is being developed into 98 apartments.
Mr. Bell said monthly rents at Hudson East are expected to be $1,400 to $2,500 for the market-rate apartments. Rents for the low-income units will be $332 to $510. Leasing is to start in July.
A plaque will be placed at the building's entrance telling passers-by of the storied night spots that once occupied the site -- despite the fact, Mr. Bell said, that the people who will rent apartments here will probably be too young to remember them.

HEADLINE: Cheddi Jagan, Guyana's Founder, Dies at 78

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER By LARRY ROHTER

 BODY:
Cheddi B. Jagan, the firebrand who led Guyana to independence and was one of the Caribbean's most contentious political leaders for half a century, died yesterday in Washington, where he had been hospitalized after a heart attack. He was 78.
Dr. Jagan had undergone heart surgery at Walter Reed Army Hospital after being flown to the United States on Feb. 15. 
 A dentist by training, Dr. Jagan rode the aspirations of Guyana's downtrodden Indian majority to power at a young age. But he was also a Marxist-Leninist of the pro-Soviet mold, which led to clashes with Churchill, who thought him a Communist puppet, and John F. Kennedy, who feared he aspired to install a "second Cuba" on the northern coast of South America.
Both those confrontations ended badly, with Dr. Jagan losing the post of Prime Minister to which he had been elected. But his popularity in his small country never faded, and he returned to power in 1992, nearly three decades after Washington engineered his ouster, with a softened outlook of his own and, ironically, the support of the United States.
Prime Minister Samuel Hinds, 53, was sworn in to succeed Mr. Jagan until elections can be held, probably this year. Mr. Hinds proclaimed six days of official mourning for "the greatest son and patriot that has ever walked this land."
Cheddi Jagan was born on March 22, 1918, on a sugar plantation near Port Mourant, in the eastern part of what was then British Guiana. His grandparents had migrated there from India as indentured laborers, and his father worked as the foreman of a work crew on the estate, giving the boy early exposure to poverty and exploitation.
The eldest of 11 children, he studied first at his village school, which was the extent of the education available to most young Indians at that time. But his parents made considerable financial sacrifices in order to send him to secondary school in the capital, Georgetown, where he excelled as a student, debater and cricket batsman.
At the age of 18, armed with his family's $500 life savings, he enrolled at Howard University in Washington, and entered the pre-medical program, majoring in dentistry. To help meet expenses, he worked as an elevator operator and, during the summers, as a patent medicine salesman in Harlem, experiences he would later say taught him bitter lessons about racism and inequality in capitalist societies.
By 1943, he had graduated from the Northwestern University Dental School in Chicago, where he met the American woman who became his wife and chief political partner and adviser. Janet Rosenberg was a student nurse active in left-wing causes, and she encouraged his interest in political science, economics, sociology and philosophy.
The couple returned to Georgetown, with Dr. Jagan dividing his energies between his dental practice and labor organizing, becoming a leader of the sugar, rice and wood workers' unions. In 1947, he was elected to the British Guiana assembly, and in 1950 he and his wife founded the People's Progressive Party, the first modern political organization in the colony.
Elections held under a new constitution providing for universal suffrage and increased home rule resulted in Dr. Jagan being elected chief minister in April 1953, at the age of 35. But his fondness for Marxist oratory and a program that called for sweeping social and economic reforms quickly aroused the suspicion of Churchill, who was serving his last term as Prime Minister, and six months later London sent troops and warships to depose him, charging that Dr. Jagan and his party "were completely under the control of a Communist clique."
Dr. Jagan responded with a civil disobedience campaign modeled on the one led by Mohandas K. Gandhi against British rule in India, but he was quickly arrested and jailed for six months. Nonetheless, his party again emerged triumphant in elections 1957, and both Dr. Jagan and his wife won Cabinet posts.
In 1961, the party fared even better, and Dr. Jagan (pronounced to rhyme with pagan) was sworn in as Prime Minister, vowing to achieve independence from Britain and install a socialist economy. That platform had the unwavering support of the colony's long-suffering Indian majority, but at the height of the cold war, Dr. Jagan's enthusiasm for the Cuban revolution of Fidel Castro and his threats to turn to the Soviet Union for aid immediately made him suspect to the United States.
"Events had convinced us that Jagan, though perhaps not a disciplined Communist, had that kind of deep, pro-Communist emotion which only sustained experience with Communism could cure," Arthur M. Schlesinger, the historian who was a special assistant for Latin American affairs to President Kennedy, wrote in his 1965 book "A Thousand Days." Dr. Jagan "was unquestionably some sort of a Marxist," he added, but also was "plainly the most popular leader in British Guiana."
Soon after Dr. Jagan's return to Georgetown, the Central Intelligence Agency undertook a destabilization campaign against him. United States Government documents that only came to light in the 1990's indicate that Washington was behind much of the Guyanese labor unrest, sabotage and disinformation efforts that led to race riots between East Indians and blacks that left nearly 100 dead.
The United States also pressured Britain to delay Guyana's independence until constitutional changes could be carried out to make it more difficult for Dr. Jagan to retain power. Although Dr. Jagan's party led the voting in elections in 1964, two opposition parties formed a coalition government that was headed by Forbes Burnham, a black lawyer who had once been an ally of Dr. Jagan but who split with him. Mr. Burnham later proved to be, as described by Mr. Schlesinger, "an opportunist, racist and demagogue intent only on personal power."
For nearly 30 years, Dr. Jagan led the oppositon. But once Mr. Burnham was in power, he installed what the State Department later described as a system of "wiretaps, mail interceptions and physical surveillance" designed to "monitor and intimidate political opponents," and won one rigged election after another until he died in office in 1985.
It was only in 1992, with Guyana near economic collapse as a result of years of misrule and corruption, that Dr. Jagan's years in the political wilderness ended. He won 54 percent of the vote, and once sworn in as President proved to be more mellow and less ideological than in the past.
Though Dr. Jagan said he had not abandoned his commitment to Marxism, he sought to attract foreign investors and embraced some free market policies. "I was a Gorbachev even before Gorbachev, in the sense of what we were doing and not adopting the traditional dogmas of Marxist parties," he said.
With the cold war over, Washington's attitude by then had also changed, and Dr. Jagan's relations with the Clinton Administration were cordial.
In addition to his wife, Dr. Jagan is survived by two children, Cheddi Jr. and Nadira, and five grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Ruth Clark, 80, Pollster Who Changed an Industry

BYLINE: By KAREN FREEMAN By KAREN FREEMAN

 BODY:
Ruth Clark, a pollster who left her mark on the newspaper industry with a landmark newspaper study that encouraged editors to offer more information that readers could use in their daily lives and who helped define changing American attitudes on issues from the political to the personal, died on Feb. 20 in her home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. She was 80.
The cause was lung cancer, said her son, Andrew. 
 The newspaper study "Changing Needs of Changing Readers," published in 1979, had "an electrifying effect on the news business," said Lee Stinnett, executive director of the American Society of Newspaper Editors, which commissioned it in an effort to assess why circulation was declining.
The concept, which came to be called "news you can use," appealed to editors nationwide as they experimented with reports on family issues and other articles of a type that they began to refer to as soft news.
Mrs. Clark was also widely known for directing many of the surveys that defined American public opinion during a time of great social and political turmoil in the 1970's, and she was part of the team that introduced exit polls into American politics and journalism.
She had no formal training in marketing or polling. She learned the business on her own, starting as a door-to-door questioner and gradually rising as a survey designer for marketing companies and eventually to prominent positions in the industry. She was a vice president at Louis Harris & Associates in the 1960's, and she was a senior vice president at Yankelovich, Skelly & White until 1983, when she left to start her own firm, Clark, Martire & Bartolomeo.
Arthur H. White, vice chairman of Yankelovich Partners, said that in her surveys Mrs. Clark always made sure she included the opinions of all segments of American society, not just those of the economically comfortable or affluent, because of her concerns for the downtrodden.
Born Ruth Fine in New York City, Mrs. Clark graduated from Hunter College in 1936. The following year, she married Joseph Clark, who later became the foreign editor of The Daily Worker.
The Clarks moved to the Soviet Union in 1950 but became disillusioned with what they saw there, returning to the United States in 1953, Andrew Clark said. Mr. Clark publicly renounced the Soviet system and left The Daily Worker in 1957.
Mrs. Clark entered the field of market research as an interviewer, going door to door and asking opinions about commercial products, often accompanied by her infant son.
But in 1960, she was ready to move up. She obtained a job with Lou Harris that kept her in the marketing survey segment of the business at first. In 1964, she was part of the Harris team that conducted an exit poll for CBS News in the tightly contested California Republican primary between Nelson A. Rockefeller and Barry Goldwater.
On the basis of the poll's results, Mr. Harris called the race for Mr. Goldwater. He said the two next weeks until the official vote tallies were complete was "the loneliest time of my entire political career." But the official results proved the Harris team right.
Mrs. Clark got a chance to address political issues more broadly when she moved to Yankelovich, Skelly & White around 1970. She was in charge of the firm's public opinion research, and she proved to be adept at turning out high-quality surveys that newspapers and magazines could get into print quickly, Mr. White said.
A survey for the American Cancer Society helped persuade the organization to focus on encouraging nonsmokers to stand up for their rights, said John H. Bartolomeo, a partner in her firm, who also worked with her in the 1970's.
"She told them that she had picked up an undercurrent of militancy among nonsmokers," Mr. Bartolomeo said, "and she told them that the most important thing they could do would be to encourage that militancy."
He said that Mrs. Clark, who did not smoke, "told me once that she considered that the most important thing she had ever done."
In 1983, Mrs. Clark's daughter Judith, who was in the radical Weather Underground, was convicted of helping to rob a Brink's armored car in Rockland County, N.Y. In that incident in 1981 two police officers and a guard were killed. Judith Clark was sentenced to three consecutive life terms in prison.
At Yankelovich and at Clark, Martire & Bartolomeo, Mrs. Clark conducted market surveys for many media companies, including The New York Times, The New York Daily News and The Chicago Tribune.
"Changing Needs of Changing Readers," which Mrs. Clark updated in 1984, was a small study but it helped to change an industry, Mr. Stinnett said. Her influence on newspapers can be seen today in the creation of life style sections, consumer news and entertainment guides published by many newspapers as well as lists of resources for readers that often accompany feature articles.
Besides her son, of Portland, Ore., and her daughter, Mrs. Clark is survived by four grandchildren. Her husband died in 1988.

HEADLINE: U.S. Factory Orders Rise 2.5%, and Joblessness Gauge Falls

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News By Bloomberg News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6

 BODY:
Orders placed with American factories rose 2.5 percent in January, the Commerce Department said today, while a Labor Department report showed more strength than expected in the labor market.
The rise in factory orders brought them to a record $323.2 billion and was the first increase in three months. December's decline was revised to 1.5 percent, from 1.3 percent. Analysts had expected the January report to show a 2.1 percent gain. 
 January's manufacturing strength was driven by the largest increase in orders for big-ticket goods since September. Factory inventories, meantime, increased one-tenth of a percent after having decreased three-tenths of a percent in December.
"The bottom line is the manufacturing sector still has plenty of momentum," Mark Vitner, an economist at the First Union Corporation in Charlotte, N.C., said before the report was issued today.
In its report the Labor Department said the number of workers applying for the first time for state unemployment benefits fell unexpectedly last week by 6,000, to a seasonally adjusted 310,000. The four-week moving average, a less volatile measure of employment conditions, declined to 310,000 -- the lowest level in almost eight years -- from 313,500 the previous week.
"These tight conditions in labor markets are going to finally start feeding into the wage pressures," said Richard Koss, an economist at Maria Fiorini Ramirez Inc., a New York investment advisory firm. That in turn could push the Federal Reserve Board to raise interest rates. Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, warned Congress again Wednesday that a pre-emptive rate increase might be needed to forestall accelerating inflation.
On Friday the Government is expected to report growth in February's payrolls.
"Today's report is mildly bearish," Douglas Porter, senior economist at the investment firm Nesbitt Burns Inc., said of the jobless claims statistics. "This type of low level of claims is consistent with quite strong job growth."
As for factory orders, the overall 2.5 percent increase was unchanged when even the volatile category of aircraft and other transportation equipment was included. Excluding the defense industry, orders climbed 3.1 percent.
By category, orders for durable goods, big-ticket items made to last three or more years, advanced 4 percent after having decreased 1.7 percent in December. In an advance report on Feb. 27, the Commerce Department said durable goods orders increased 3.6 percent in January. Orders for nondurable goods like food and clothing increased seven-tenths of a percent after falling 1.2 percent in December.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Decline as Investors Await Data on Jobs

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities dropped yesterday, with investors showing clear anxiety ahead of today's report on employment figures.
Economic statistics released earlier this week have all been on a one- way street heading higher, and yesterday's data were no exception. 
 Factory orders during January rose 2.5 percent -- somewhat higher than expected-- led by new orders for durable goods, which jumped 4 percent, an upward revision.
"Furthermore," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, "the backlog of unfilled orders continues to climb, providing a base for future production."
Initial claims for state unemployment fell unexpectedly in the latest reporting week, and chain store sales were stronger than analysts had expected.
All eyes, of course, are now focused on today's labor market statistics, with traders worried that if those figures, too, show a robust economy, it could tip the scales toward a Fed rate increase on March 25, when the Federal Open Market Committee meets.
The 30-year bond dropped 20/32 , to a price of 9627/32 to yield 6.88 percent, up from 6.82 percent on Wednesday.
Mr. Fine said that Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, had made it clear during the second round of his Humphrey-Hawkins testimony before the House on Wednesday "that risks, not forecasts, will drive monetary policy, and that the F.O.M.C. would tighten pre-emptively to prevent the economy from overheating and causing an acceleration in inflation conditions."
The recent downward trend in initial unemployment claims suggests the unemployment rate will drop to 5.3 percent or even 5.2 percent, Mr. Fine said, while the index of aggregate hours worked should bounce back quite noticeably following its surprising plunge in January.
But the market's attention will be centered on the payroll number. Although the range of projections for the change in nonfarm payrolls is wide, extending from a modest gain of 125,000 to a robust surge of 350,000, the consensus view is for an increase of 225,000.
"If market projections are close to reality," Mr. Fine said, "the upside risk that Greenspan alluded to will certainly have increased, and the bond market will become even more wary of a Fed tightening at the next F.O.M.C. meeting."
Volume was thin as many buyers, having already positioned themselves, moved to the sidelines. One reason was the decline in the unemployment claims, which drew attention to the tightness of the labor market. Initial claims decreased 6,000, to 310,000 last week, with the four-week moving average dropping to an eight-year low of 310,000, from 313,500 a week earlier.
David Ader, managing analyst with Technical Data in Boston, said: "The market is trying to get in front of the Fed at this point. The lows did not bring out more sellers."
In the corporate market, the Hershey Foods Corporation led a number of companies that sold $1.2 billion of debt yesterday, locking in rates in case yields move higher after the employment report.
Hershey priced $150 million of 10-year notes through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company at a price to yield 6.992 percent.
The notes are noncallable by the company, and are rated A1 by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by Standard & Poor's, with a yield spread over a comparable Treasury of about 40 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point.

HEADLINE: Wall Street Leads, but New York's Economy Doesn't Follow

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
Over the last year, New York City's unemployment rate has climbed even as Wall Street was cheering repeated record highs. Brokers earning seven-figure bonuses shopped for summer homes while about one in 11 people looked for jobs.
Through much of New York's history, those kinds of contradictions did not occur. The economic rule of thumb was that when Wall Street celebrated, New York celebrated. But there has been a fundamental shift in that chemistry in the 1990's. Because the city, the state and the securities industry are not producing jobs in ways that they used to, the good news of Wall Street has not been enough to bring overall prosperity. 
 Economists say that this new and still evolving pattern is more volatile, is less equitable in the distribution of wealth, and may be unable over the long term to produce the kinds of entry-level jobs on which New York has historically depended.
That represents a major change. Since the days of the trusts and the railroad barons, Wall Street has been both a barometer of New York's economic health and a powerful job engine. What has happened in the 1990's, economists say, is that those two historical roles largely fell away. Despite the blizzard of bonuses and profits and taxes, the fortunes of the industry and the fortunes of New York diverged.
Through most of the 1980's in particular, securities industry profits acted like a lever on the economy: in most years when profits were up, the rate of growth of personal income in New York State surpassed the national average, and in years when profits declined, New York was dragged down and trailed the nation. It was a calculus that echoed the industry's roots in lower Manhattan and its power as an employer.
Since the 1987 market crash, and particularly in the last few years, however, the lever has simply not worked. Securities industry profits reached record levels, but state growth in personal income still lagged.
In short, Wall Street's health is no longer enough to compensate for erosion in other areas. The windfall of tax revenues that washed through the city and state budgets made politicians smile, but was inadequate to the task of uplifting the overall economy.
"When I look at Wall Street, I don't think of it as a major growth sector for employment," said Rae Rosen, a senior economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. "I look at high-paying jobs, and income, but not so much employment. We're going to want to look elsewhere for a job engine."
Another result of changes in the city and in the securities industry is a heightened disparity of wealth. Between 1989 and 1995, according to the State Comptroller's office, total real wages for New York City's 3.2 million workers went up 8.4 percent when adjusted for inflation. But the majority of those gains came from one place: Wall Street.
With the securities-industry contribution stripped out, wages in New York rose a paltry 3.8 percent in those six years. If the securities industry and banking are both removed, wages rose only 2.5 percent after inflation.
In this new economic mix, contrary indicators have become common. Just this week, the state reported that in January, New York City's unemployment rate reached its highest level in three years. The following day, the City Comptroller's office said that the city had created more jobs in January than in any month for a decade.
H. Carl McCall, the State Comptroller, said his central worry was that New York's fortunes rest on a narrower and narrower economic base that does not, in the end, provide for all New Yorkers.
"New York's economic problem is the creation of a wide variety of jobs," he said. "We have to look to other sectors where we will get a wider job penetration."
The forces that underlie these changes are complex and still evolving. Certainly, the health of the securities industry as a whole is not in question. What has changed is the mix of jobs, and New York's greater dependence on them.
In the 1990's, perhaps more than at any other time in its history, Wall Street work means white-collar work. Ten years after the 1987 market crash, there are fewer midlevel, entry-level and union jobs, and more salaried workers eligible for bonuses. Some firms have changed nearly everything about whom they employ in the city, what kind of work they do, and what they're paid.
At the same time, continued declines in manufacturing, government and banking have left the city with a smaller work force, which is ever more reliant on Wall Street.
In 1987, for example, the nearly 163,000 people employed in New York City securities firms made up a total of 5.1 percent of the private sector work force and earned 12.6 percent of the total private sector wages, according to state figures. By 1996, industry employment had fallen to 150,000, but that accounted for 5.3 percent of a smaller work force and 16.9 percent of the wages.
Certainly, some elements of the new dynamic are unequivocally good for New York. Stock trading volume is higher than ever. The city has solidified its place as a center of global finance. Soaring stock prices have created wealth and willingness to spend money that has spilled over into retailing and real estate.
After shedding more than 30,000 jobs in the city between 1987 and 1991, the securities industry has rebuilt itself: hiring about 20,000 people in the years since. New York State received $1 billion in taxes from the industry last year.
And some of the changes could be positive in the long term. More high-end jobs means that New York is headquarters for the industry's glamour and brain power. Economists say upper-level jobs may be more stable, too: Wall Street usually cuts from the bottom in bad times.
But the sunny headlines about the Dow Jones average or budget-saving tax infusions have also obscured the less visible changes that leave the future of the regional economy and the industry much less certain.
Between 1987 and 1995, for example, New York State lost more than 13,000 securities industry jobs, while other states gained 85,000 jobs. In that same period the state's national share of securities jobs fell from 38 percent to 30 percent, as New York became less and less the center of the universe for the business.
Three major forces were at work, the first being that this decade is the era of the mutual fund investor, and the mutual fund companies are mostly not in New York. New technologies, partly driven by higher stock-trading volumes, have also kept labor needs down, while cost control pressures have pushed firms to relocate workers.
Entry-level industry jobs familiar since the days of Rockefeller and Morgan have disappeared. When the $10.2 billion merger between Morgan Stanley and Dean Witter Discover was announced last month, for example, some of the first people to hear about it were the messengers and runners who shuttle documents through the organizations.
But those workers are not employees of either firm. They work for Choice Courier Systems, a contractor that does in-house delivery and mailroom services. Morgan Stanley got rid of its 60 in-house messengers two years ago. Dean Witter signed on with Choice in January.
Those kinds of outside arrangements -- common across corporate America -- clearly create new opportunities, but they also eliminate entry-level spots from which people might once have been promoted. Choice's founder, president and chief executive officer, Edward Katz, conceded that the health benefits for his employees were probably less generous than a giant Wall Street firm might offer. But the lower cost is also largely why he is doing well, he said.
For New York politicians the implications are delicate. The city and state have spent hundreds of millions of dollars in recent years wooing and subsidizing Wall Street firms that threatened to leave the city. The apparently growing gap between rich and poor has become, at the same time, a centerpiece of the debate about government's role. In the adminstration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, caution reigns.
"I don't think you can define it either as a positive or a negative," said Fran Reiter, the city's Deputy Mayor for Economic Development and Planning, of the changes in the securities industry. "It just is."
Ms. Reiter said that specific efforts were under way to try to bring back some lower-wage securities jobs, but that it was also important for the city to wean itself away from dependence on one industry.
Some securities companies are also nervous. A spokesman at one large investment firm in New York, declining to comment on the record, said that the firm did not want to alienate New Yorkers by admitting that the growth of jobs was faster in areas of the firm outside New York.
He also did not want to alienate people in those other places by giving the impression that New York gets only the highest-paying jobs. But as a generalization, the spokesman said, both trends are true.
At Smith Barney, the transformation of jobs has occurred entirely within the city. In two years, the firm has created about 150 new technical jobs in computer programming, technical support and communications. It also eliminated about the same number of "mundane clerical functions," said Melvin Taub, a senior executive vice president.
Mr. Taub said that some of the displaced clerks got training and made the transition or found other jobs, so that no layoffs resulted. The new jobs are more highly paid than the old ones, he said, and are all eligible for bonuses as well.
At Bowne & Company, a 222-year-old financial printing company, the changes are even more stark. Ten years ago, the firm's offices on Hudson Street had clattering presses and lots of union jobs. It was a place where prospectuses and legal filings got printed.
That's all gone now. During the recession, when many of the company's competitors went out of business, Bowne retooled. Its printing is now done in Secaucus; the staff has been upgraded. The Federal Securities and Exchange Commission changed to electronic filing.
Between 1987 and 1996, the number of white-collar occupations at Bowne's New York office went up 127 percent while blue-collar positions fell by 69 percent. The company used to recruit at the New York High School of Graphic Communication Arts. That just won't do now, said David L. Rosenstein, a company spokesman.
"They couldn't do this kind of work," Mr. Rosenstein said. "Our trainees are college graduates."

HEADLINE: Retailers' Sales Gained at High And Low Ends In February

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER By JENNIFER STEINHAUER

 BODY:
If there was ever a month that told the story of Americans' divergent shopping habits, February was it.
Retail same-store sales, or sales in stores open at least one year, were strong last month, particularly among two sectors of the industry: the extremely expensive and the rock-bottom priced. 
 General merchandise stores like Dollar General and Family Dollar, which cater to low-income shoppers, and high-end shops like Saks Fifth Avenue and Neiman Marcus, stood out along with retailers like Ross Stores, which offer clothing bargains for anyone willing to hunt for them.
Retailers in the middle of the market, with the greatest number of stores serving the most overwhelmed consumers, continue to struggle, as they have for several quarters.
While most retail experts agree that there are still far too many stores for far too few shoppers, economists and analysts also say that the thrill of a bargain hunt has become a deep-seated part of the American shopping culture, even as wealthy people drop thousands of dollars on imported cigars and Armani dresses.
According to the Goldman, Sachs & Company same-store sales index, which compares stores open at least a year, retail sales in February were up 3.8 percent compared with figures from a year earlier. In February 1996, they had risen 4.9 percent.
Same-store sales gains had been strong in February 1996 for many retailers largely because of huge sales for unsold Christmas merchandise and because many shoppers had been snowed in during January. Still, stores that enjoyed healthy same-store sales gains this year stood out as particularly successful because of the comparison with a strong month a year earlier.
Among discounters, the Consolidated Stores Corporation, which is based in Wilmington, Del., reported same-store sales increases of 9.1 percent, compared with a 10.6 percent gain in February 1996. The Dollar General Corporation gained 11.1 percent, compared with last year's 14.1 percent gain. Wal-Mart Stores Inc. gained 6.7 percent in sales, and the Kmart Corporation gained 3.9 percent.
Wal-Mart also said yesterday that it would buy back an additional $2 billion of stock over the next 12 to 18 months and increase its quarterly dividend 29 percent.
Off-price stores that sell designer goods at a discount continue to do well. Ross Stores reported a 14 percent gain, and the TJX Companies, which owns T.J. Maxx and Marshalls, reported a 5 percent gain.
The strong sales among discount stores show that American shoppers will go out of their way for a deal, some analysts said. "Value consciousness first became apparent in the late 80's and is not going away," said Stephen S. Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. "There is enough wealth being created to drive high-end retailing, but Joe Six-Pack is still shopping for value. He would rather buy low and put some money in a mutual fund or something."
If the results at department and specialty stores were any indication, Americans have satisfied their desire for full-price clothing after a quarter of restocking their closets last year. Federated Department Stores reported a mere 2.2 percent gain in same-store sales for February, and the Dayton Hudson Corporation squeaked in with a 1.2 percent gain, though its Target discount division gained 6 percent in sales. Ann Taylor lost 1.2 percent, the Limited sales were down 2 percent, and sales at the Gap Inc. and Talbots Inc. were flat.
The exceptions among department stores were the J. C. Penney Company, which gained 11.4 percent, largely because of huge promotions, and luxury retailers like Saks Fifth Avenue, a unit of Saks Holdings Inc., which gained 6.4 percent, and Neiman Marcus, a unit of Harcourt General, which reported a 4.5 percent gain.
"In terms of apparel," said Richard N. Baum, a retail analyst at Goldman, Sachs, "we are coming off of four straight quarters of accelerating sales. So the apparel cycle may have peaked or may be peaking and the rest of the year may be only so-so."
Sales of consumer electronics continue to be weak: The Best Buy Company lost 3 percent in same-store sales, and Circuit City Stores reported a 4 percent loss.
Good sales last month were not generally a result of drastic markdowns, some analysts said, because retailers have generally kept their inventories tight for the last six months. As a result, the earnings outlook for the first quarter may be good.
"This was not a promotional month," said Jeffrey M. Feiner, an analyst at Salomon Brothers Inc. "This gives us a good lead-in for the first quarter."
Other analysts and economists were less enthusiastic, largely because the issues that have dogged the industry, namely oversupply, continue.
"We anticipate that investors may jump on the sector based on the same-store sales, only to be disappointed in the second quarter when the underlying weakness is more evident," wrote Peter N. Schaeffer, a retail analyst at Dillon, Read & Company. "As we have said many times before, the basic economic scenario and secular changes which have stymied retail growth for several years remain."

HEADLINE: It's Showdown Time on Wall St.;
For Brokerage Houses, a New Class of Suitor Rides In

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL By PETER TRUELL

 BODY:
When executives from Citicorp and American Express met secretly late last year to discuss merging their businesses, it sent a strong message to the investment bankers at Morgan Stanley that the financial world's heavies were about to descend on Wall Street.
Citicorp, which was advised by Morgan Stanley in its exploratory discussions with the American Express Company, pulled back from the deal, at least for the moment. But even though those merger discussions did not go anywhere, executives say, they spurred Morgan Stanley Group and Dean Witter, Discover & Company to move quickly to forge their own $10.5 billion merger, which they announced last month. The two are not alone. Rather than leave themselves vulnerable to the big American and foreign banks on the prowl or one of the large corporations that want a piece of the action, a number of Wall Street firms are circling the wagons, too. 
 Paine Webber has stepped up its search for an asset management firm, in part because size may help it evade some hungry predator. Salomon Brothers signed an innovative marketing deal with Fidelity Investments, the FMR unit, intended to broaden its equity franchise through better access to private investors. Most Wall Street firms are also zealously encouraging their employees to buy their own shares, hoping that a lot of insider ownership will increase employee motivation and also give their firms more protection from unwanted would-be acquirers on the prowl. And some executives at Dean Witter and Morgan Stanley are still jumpy, fearing that another party, perhaps even American Express, might try to derail the union with a more lucrative offer.
If Wall Streeters are going to make any deals for their own firms, says Richard K. Strauss, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company who covers the brokerage industry, their first choice is one of their own. "These targets," he said, "would much more prefer to be matched up with a like company in a like culture."
There also is a palpable concern about the damage that unwanted gunslingers from outside the tight-knit world of Wall Street may do if they come blundering into the securities business.
"The history of acquisitions in the brokerage industry by outsiders has been so bad," said Regina Dolan, Paine Webber's chief financial officer. The General Electric Company, for example, had an awful experience with Kidder, Peabody & Company, the Wall Street firm it sold to Paine Webber in late 1994.
As the barriers that once kept banks, insurance and the brokerage business apart crumble, the bankers and insurers are riding into town. the BankAmerica Corporation, the Chase Manhattan Corporation, the Nationsbank Corporation, American Insurance Group, Travelers Group and foreign behemoths like Dresdner Bank, the Swiss Bank Corporation and Hongkong and Shanghai Banking, a unit of HSBC Holdings, are already scouting around.
Their prime targets are likely to be attractive smaller firms on Wall Street. Among them are Alex. Brown & Sons; Bear, Stearns & Company; Oppenheimer Group; Legg Mason Inc. and Lehman Brothers.
But other firms could also fall victim, including some that already have ties to outsiders. These include Prudential Securities, Salomon Brothers and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. At the very least, big financial institutions want to cherry-pick Wall Street's best talent to build up their own investment banking and brokerage operations.
Some past Wall Street alliances have not worked well, leaving a cautionary legacy for those now contemplating defensive maneuvers. Shearson-Lehman, a brokerage combination tried by American Express fell short of expectations and ended with Lehman being spun off in 1993 and Shearson being acquired by Travelers.
But while "there won't be an avalanche" of mergers and acquisitions on Wall Street, says Milton R. Berlinski, a partner at Goldman, Sachs who advises big financial firms, he sees another round of deals -- perhaps half a dozen in the next year or two -- as all but inevitable. Several are likely to be mergers aimed, in part, at building up enough critical mass to avoid unwanted takeovers.
What has made Wall Street particularly vulnerable to commercial banks that are eager to expand their reach is that the Federal Reserve has relaxed its rules governing what they can own. Banks can now own securities operations that account for up to 25 percent of their revenues, up from 10 percent last year.
For the first time since the Depression-era Glass-Steagall Act separated the banking and securities businesses, big banks can, in theory, buy virtually all but the largest Wall Street brokerage houses. Some banks, eager to recapture a portion of the funds that have leaked from low-interest savings accounts into more attractive mutual funds and brokerage accounts, would clearly like to.
At Chase Manhattan, for example, a recent management shuffle gave James B. Lee Jr. and Donald H. Layton joint responsibility for running its investment bank. That left William B. Harrison Jr., a vice chairman and director, free to focus on potential acquisitions in the brokerage business, executives at that bank say. In some crystal ball gazing research published last month, Dean P. Eberling, an analyst at Prudential Securities, speculated that Chase might eventually acquire the merged Morgan Stanley-Dean Witter.
In recent months, Chase has also hired several senior executives from Salomon, including Mark C. Davis, a takeover specialist, and John P. Lipsky, who is now Chase's chief economist. From Donaldson, Lufkin, the bank also picked up Wilfred A. Finnegan, who heads Chase's high-yield bond business, and from Furman, Selz, John Steinhardt, who leads its American securities business.
This kind of interest in the brokerage business has investors hopping. The share price of Donaldson, Lufkin, for example, rose more than 7 percent on Feb. 10 on speculation that it might be sold. The firm, which is 73 percent owned by the Equitable Companies and Axa, its French parent, said it was happy with its current ownership.
"I think people are rotating among the securities stocks," said Sam G. Liss, a managing director and analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston, "trying to speculate about where the action is coming next."
Many potential takeover targets, though, remain deeply suspicious of the outsiders that are eying them so covetously. Donald B. Marron, chairman and chief executive of Paine Webber, cautioned in an interview that Wall Street is a business that is largely foreign to commercial banks. Compensation in the securities business, he said, is higher and much more erratic. And talented traders, brokers and investment bankers, by far the most valuable asset in most brokerage firms, can readily walk out the door and find jobs elsewhere if they are unhappy.
Something like that happened, for instance, after Credit Suisse began acquiring First Boston in the late 1980's. Its record is at best mixed, as the firm has been beset by defections and considerable in-fighting.
Everyone involved is aware that several past commercial banking forays into the securities business have failed miserably. When Britain deregulated its securities industry in 1986, American banking companies like Chase and Citicorp ambitiously gobbled up local firms, buying some of the best-known names in the London brokerage business.
Citicorp acquired both Scrimgeour Kemp Gee and Vickers da Costa, two established London brokerage houses, which it combined in hopes of bringing together a strong corporate finance business with an envied Asian equities franchise. But much of the talent was offended at Citicorp's commercial banking culture and its rough attempts to build an international securities business virtually overnight. Several longtime employees of Vickers da Costa later gathered to establish Peregrine, an investment bank based in Hong Kong.
Some foreign banks, now trying to build investment banks of their own on Wall Street, are already discovering just how protean Wall Street can be. Deutsche Bank A.G., the German banking giant, for example, has been trying to construct an investment bank in the Morgan Stanley mold, hiring whole teams of bankers from that firm, as well as from Merrill Lynch & Company and Goldman, Sachs. As soon as Deutsche Bank had spent billions on the project, Morgan Stanley itself started to metamorphose, first by buying the Van Kampen/American Capital mutual fund family, then by merging with Dean Witter.
In this fast-changing milieu, it is not clear which strategies are likely to prove most successful. But Wall Street firms like Salomon and Donaldson, Lufkin, which deal mostly with institutional customers, are clearly interested in building better access to the private investor. That strategy was advanced by some influential recent research from Sallie L. Krawcheck, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, showing the profit margins in traditional investment banking and securities trading businesses are declining, while returns on the dwindling number of Main Street businesses with nationwide branch networks remained strong.
"The institutional firms are walking around playing musical chairs, eyeing the chairs carefully, so if the music stops there'll be a chair for them," said Paul V. Scura, the head of investment banking at Prudential Securities.
The brokerage firms may not have a lot of time to make their choices. Their potential suitors at the big banks and insurance companies have fat wallets these days, and some are prepared to dip deeply into their capital to offer prices that may be hard to refuse. And if the stock market drops significantly, pulling down the market values of securities firms, that could be just the opening many banks are waiting for.
Even the biggest firms on Wall Street could be vulnerable. Merrill Lynch, the largest American brokerage firm in terms of capital until the Morgan Stanley-Dean Witter deal is completed and still the firm with the most extensive branch network and the broadest business, has about $16 billion in market capital. That is not much compared with Chase's $46 billion or the $58 billion at American Insurance Group, which has reportedly been sniffing around Merrill Lynch.
David K. Schafer, president of Schafer & Cullen, a New York investment adviser and mutual fund company, argues that the recent Morgan Stanley-Dean Witter merger "may be the trigger to a number of other moves." Mr. Schafer, whose funds have invested in Morgan Stanley, Merrill Lynch and Paine Webber, says that for bigger Wall Street firms, like Merrill and Goldman, Sachs, it is now a matter of "keeping up with the Morgan Stanleys."
Even Goldman, the only major private partnership and perhaps the most prized jewel in the Wall Street crown, may have to act. It lacks the Main Street distribution that Merrill has had for decades and that Morgan is about to obtain. Goldman's leaders, who declined to comment publicly on the matter, agreed privately that they might have to change but said no immediate decisions were necessary.
As for Merrill, it maintains that it has already built the Wall Street model for the 21st century, in part through its successful acquisitions years ago of White Weld and A. G. Becker. But many analysts expect that David H. Komanksy, its new chief executive, will want to make a big acquisition to secure once again his firm's claim to being No. 1 in the American and overseas securities business.
Mr. Komansky, of course, is mum about his specific plans. But he said that Merrill's "strategy is to be the leading financial management and advisory company for a broadly diverse global client base."
That will be achieved, he added, through "superior service, internal expansion and selective acquisitions."

HEADLINE: Clinton Aides and a Proposal to Build a Chinese Power Plant

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6

 BODY:
For American companies eager to crack the vast but frustrating Chinese market, it was a big deal when Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown announced on a trade mission to China in 1994 that he had secured an agreement for the Entergy Corporation of New Orleans to help build a $1 billion power plant 250 miles north of Beijing.
"The public sector-private sector partnership envisioned by President Clinton is working well," Mr. Brown said at the time, hailing his department's willingness to use its muscle to pry open opportunities for American business abroad. 
 The deal collapsed, unheralded, six months after Mr. Brown's announcement, yet another victim of the political, economic and cultural difficulties that plague foreign companies trying to obtain a toehold in China.
China never bought the $450 million worth of parts and supplies from the United States that the deal called for, and Entergy never received its 20 percent, or $37.5 million stake, in the power plant, in Datong.
The project has another legacy. Entergy's partner in the project was the Lippo Group, the company controlled by the Riady family of Indonesia, which has been at the center of questions about whether the Clinton Administration traded access and influence over policy for campaign contributions.
Around the time that the Commerce Department was working to win agreement on the deal from the Chinese Government, businesses controlled by the Riadys employed Webster L. Hubbell, the former Associate Attorney General and a close friend of Mr. Clinton.
Mr. Hubbell had left office to face criminal charges that stemmed from the Whitewater investigation. The Whitewater independent counsel is now examining Mr. Hubbell's 1994 income to determine whether his employment by the Riadys and others with ties to Mr. Clinton were intended to discourage him from cooperating with investigators looking into the Clintons' finances.
Mr. Hubbell, who recently completed an 18-month prison sentence, has denied that his employment after leaving the Administration played any role in his dealings with prosecutors during the case. And Mr. Clinton has said he does not think that there was any improper influence on Mr. Hubbell or the White House from the Riadys.
Entergy, which also owns the electric utility that serves Mr. Clinton's home state of Arkansas, has been among the most active American companies in China. It is involved in another power plant in Taishan, in Guangdong Province in southern China, and it is considering other investments.
A spokesman for Entergy, Patrick Sweeney, said the Commerce Department's involvement in the deal had been minimal. He said the company had been ready to sign the formal memorandum of understanding before the trade mission led by Mr. Brown in August 1994, but held the signing ceremony with Chinese officials during the mission because the chairman of Entergy, Edwin A. Lupberger, had signed up to travel with Mr. Brown.
"The trade mission was coincidental," Mr. Sweeney said. "There was nothing that happened because of the trade mission that would not have happened anyway."
Commerce Department officials said the Entergy project had not been high on Mr. Brown's priority list on the trip, which centered on trying to help bigger companies like the Chrysler Corporation and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation.
Entergy's involvement in the failed Datong project dates from well before Mr. Hubbell announced his resignation from the Justice Department on March 14, 1994.
Entergy said it signed a nonbinding agreement to work on the project that month, and Commerce Department officials said the nonbinding pact was reached a month earlier.
A spokesman for the Commerce Department, Jim Desler, said the American Embassy in Beijing had provided some help to Entergy before Mr. Brown's trip. But Mr. Desler said he did not know whether the assistance began before the signing of the nonbinding accord in March 1994.
Mr. Brown died in a plane crash in Bosnia a year ago.
Within months of the signing, the deal went awry. Mr. Sweeney said the main problem was that not enough water was available to cool the plant, causing the project to collapse for engineering reasons. Commerce Department officials said their understanding was that the Chinese authorities did not feel that the deal would be profitable.
"The project is dead," Mr. Sweeney said, "and as far as Entergy is concerned it's dead for good."

HEADLINE: 2 Newspapers Each Are Winners Of 2 Polk Awards for Journalism

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER

 BODY:
Two newspapers, The New York Times and The Los Angeles Times, each won 2 of the 11 George Polk awards for journalism announced yesterday by Long Island University.
The New York Times won an award for economics reporting for its series "The Downsizing of America." And one of its correspondents, John F. Burns, won the foreign reporting award for his articles on the takeover of Kabul, Afghanistan, by Taliban, the militant Islamic group. 
 The Los Angeles Times won the prize for political reporting for "Money From Asia," about suspect contributions from Asian sources to the Democratic National Committee. The paper also won the cultural reporting award, for Chuck Philips's articles about the inner workings of America's $12 billion music industry.
A reporter for The Plain Dealer in Cleveland, Elizabeth Marchak, won the award for national reporting for her articles raising questions about the Federal Government's handling of air safety violations. Her series of articles, "The F.A.A. and Valujet Airlines," focused on the Federal Aviation Administration's weak response to its inspectors' reports on unsafe aircraft, improper maintenance and inadequate training at Valujet and other cut-rate airlines.
The awards, which are administered by Long Island University, were established in 1949 in memory of George W. Polk, a CBS correspondent who was killed in 1948 while covering the civil war in Greece.
Yesterday, Bryan Acohido of The Seattle Times won a Polk award for transportation reporting for "Safety at Issue: the 737," a series linking questions about the rudder controls of Boeing 737 planes to several deadly crashes and the F.A.A.'s resistance to acknowledging the problem.
Honors for local reporting went to Kevin Collison of The Buffalo News, who linked the death of a teen-ager, run over on a highway while on her way to work at a shopping mall, to a policy denying access to city buses to discourage minority customers.
The prize for magazine reporting went to Anne-Marie Cusac of The Progressive for "Stunning Technology," which exposed the life-threatening dangers of security devices used in American prisons and exported to repressive foreign regimes.
These were other prizes:
 FOREIGN TELEVISION REPORTING: Christiane Amanpour and Anita Pratap of CNN for "Battle for Afghanistan," an examination of the armed struggle for control of the country, with revealing interviews of key figures in opposing camps.
NATIONAL TELEVISION REPORTING: Matt Meagher and Tim Peek of "Inside Edition" for "Door to Door Insurance," an undercover investigation of the exploitation of poor Americans by some insurers.
CRITICISM: Blair Kamin of The Chicago Tribune for an examination of issues in Chicago architecture that encouraged public debate and influenced its outcome.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises Against the Yen But Closes Lower vs. the Mark

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the Japanese yen yesterday after a report on United States employment pointed to strong economic growth with little inflation.
"The strong employment report is buoying the dollar," said John Trammell, who helps manage a $100 million portfolio of global securities for A. Gary Shilling & Company, a money management firm. "The numbers mean continued strength in the economy, and that in turn should lead to a higher dollar." 
 The report showed that the economy added 339,000 jobs last month, more than most analysts expected. But the report also said that average hourly earnings rose just 3 cents, indicating little inflationary pressure. Stocks and bonds rallied on the report, helping to bolster the dollar.
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar settled at 121.82 yen, up from 121.13 yen on Thursday. The dollar rose as high as 1.7210 German marks -- its fourth consecutive three-year high -- but retreated to 1.7145 marks, down from 1.7155 marks.
The dollar's weakness against the the mark came after a member of the Bundesbank's policy-making council, Ernst Welteke, said the dollar had risen far enough.
The dollar has gained 28 percent since bottoming out in March 1996 at 1.3455 marks, a postwar low.
"I would not be pleased if the dollar continued to rise at the same pace," Mr. Welteke said in an interview with the German news agency VWD. "We see the correction process as over."
The remarks led to speculation that the German central bank did not want the dollar to surpass 1.72 marks, said John McCarthy, manager of foreign exchange at ING Baring Capital Markets. "That's holding the dollar back a bit."
The dollar was also restrained against the mark by the mark's rise against the yen. Transactions involving marks and yen are typically executed using dollars.
The pound fell on speculation that Britain would refrain from raising interest rates. Talk of higher rates -- which would make pound-denominated deposits more attractive -- has bolstered the pound recently. In New York trading, the pound dropped to $1.6013, from $1.6155 on Thursday.

HEADLINE: Take Hospitals Off the Dole

BYLINE: By Lloyd M. Krieger; Lloyd M. Krieger is a resident physician at the U.C.L.A. Medical Center.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
I am a resident physician. My job is exciting and challenging. But it could be much improved with one simple change: Take me off the Government dole.
Through Medicare, hospitals receive about $100,000 each year for every resident they employ -- about $7 billion nationwide. As a resident, this subsidy pays my salary and defrays the costs of my training. But it also has bizarre effects that undermine my education, my ability to eventually find a good job, even my quality of life. 
 Many hospitals receive more money from the program than they actually need to cover the training. So residents are the cheapest possible hospital labor, and are asked to perform many non-medical tasks that ordinarily would be done by other personnel that the hospital must pay out of its own pocket.
As hospitals cut back in this age of cutthroat competition, these chores increase. That means residents work ever longer days but spend less of their time treating patients and learning skills from experienced doctors.
Residents are often asked to do paperwork for hospital bureaucracies and to fill out insurance forms. We transport patients to the radiology lab for studies or to the operating room. If nurses are busy, we turn patients in their beds to prevent bed sores. We are frequently asked to draw blood samples.
Such tasks -- which at non-teaching hospitals are usually done by clerks, nurses and orderlies -- do more than put a drain on our time. As residents have become a cash cow for hospitals, there has been incentive to bring in more and more of them. The result is that we are training too many young doctors, meaning that it will be much tougher for us to find work when we finish our residencies.
In New York State, Federal regulators have come up with a novel solution to ease the glut of new doctors: Pay hospitals not to train residents, just as those much-maligned agriculture subsidies pay farmers not to grow wheat. This is an interesting proposal, but it does not go far enough. Patients and the residents themselves would be better served by ending all Federal subsidies for training doctors.
If the Government stopped subsidizing residents, we could focus our energies solely on learning to be good doctors and on giving patients better care. Taxpayers would save billions of dollars. And, after some initial struggle, hospitals would be stronger for their independence from Federal handouts.
Who, then, would pay for resident training? The costs should be borne by insurers and managed-care programs whose patients benefit from the advanced care provided by teaching hospitals. Nearly 20 percent of hospital patients are treated with the latest and most sophisticated techniques and equipment, and almost all such work is done at teaching centers. These hospitals will simply have to charge more for their specialized services, either through a standard daily surcharge or through additional hourly billing for the specific services of resident doctors.
Yes, insurers and managed-care plans would balk at first. But they would have little choice but to pay up. As competition in the managed-care industry matures, health maintenance organizations are finding that they have to provide coverage for the newest and best treatments if their customers demand it.
Hospitals would probably struggle at first without subsidized cheap labor. Managed-care plans and insurers might see their short-term profits fall. My salary would undoubtedly go down.
But in the long run medical centers would be stronger, doctors would be better trained, and patients would receive higher quality care.

HEADLINE: Credit Unions' Outdated Tax Breaks

 BODY:
A relic of legislation from the 1930's makes the nation's credit unions, which started out as mutual societies among members who shared a common employer or neighborhood, exempt from Federal taxes. The idea behind the tax break was to give a boost to working folks who wanted to escape the clutches of their local bankers by forming their own savings and lending groups.
For the credit unions that have remained relatively small, the tax break can be justified as a reasonable way to help a group of closely affiliated, perhaps low-income people provide themselves financial support through cooperation. Indeed, the tax break offsets part of the financial disadvantage of small size. 
 But many credit unions have expanded well beyond the 1930's notion of a "common bond." Some include more than 100,000 members and control billions of dollars in assets. They offer a full range of financial products, including mortgage loans, insurance and savings accounts. Their members earn above-average incomes. These large credit unions are just like banks.
That is the rub. Bankers are crying foul because the credit unions use the tax break to offer higher deposit rates and lower loan rates. The bankers demand an end to the tax break. For the large credit unions, the bankers' case is compelling. Competition, not a tax break, ought to decide where Americans want to bank.
