HEADLINE: Vero Beach Journal;
For the Dodgers, a Fit as Tight as a Ball and Glove

BYLINE: By KEVIN McKENNA 

DATELINE: VERO BEACH, Fla.

 BODY:
The navel oranges have been shipped; the Valencias and the Ruby Red grapefruit are making their way from grove to market. But here in Indian River County, the real season has now begun, and the crop, as it has been for half a century, is baseball players.
Of the 18 Florida cities that play host to spring camps, no other town has an identity and an economy so intertwined with a baseball team as Vero Beach has with the Los Angeles Dodgers. 
 This is the Dodgers' 50th season here, an association that began a decade before Walter O'Malley moved the team to Los Angeles from Brooklyn. His predecessor, Branch Rickey, set up camp here in 1948 on the site of an abandoned naval training station in the days of Jackie Robinson and Pee Wee Reese. Whatever the upheaval since then, including the recent announcement that the Dodgers are for sale, Vero Beach has been a symbol of continuity.
"I don't believe Vero Beach would be known anywhere outside of Vero Beach except for the presence of the Dodgers," said Vin Scully, the Dodgers broadcaster, who has been coming here since 1950. "When I first arrived, we stepped off the train and, my gosh, it was a tiny, tiny, somewhat dusty little Southern town. But as the Dodgers settled in, as the word went out, the Dodgers truly put Vero Beach on the map."
Indeed, it is difficult to separate Vero Beach from baseball, and not just in the spring. The Dodgers maintain their 468-acre camp year round, with a Class A minor-league team, fantasy camps, training for football teams and foreign baseball clubs, two golf courses and a commercial citrus grove. After spring training, a 90-room inn for players serves as an executive conference center. All that activity makes the Dodgertown complex one of Indian River County's biggest private employers, with an annual payroll of $4 million and a work force reaching 450 in the spring. It is the only camp where a ball club is the owner, not a tenant.
"We're not just a baseball team that flies in Feb. 1 and leaves on opening day," said Craig Callan, a Brooklyn native who has spent 19 years at Dodgertown, nine as director. "We're year-round, tax-paying members of the community."
The team has left its mark on the city's 18,000 residents.
When Tommy Lasorda, the motivational former Dodger manager, spoke at a Little League opening day last year, "some of the mothers were in tears," said Chuck Sultzman, a local biologist for the Federal Fish and Wildlife Service and the father of a 13-year-old center fielder for the Seald-Sweet Growers team. "The Dodgers' being here has a profound effect on these kids."
Local teen-agers serve as bat boys; families house minor-league players during the season. And it is a rite of spring to happen upon stars like Mike Piazza and Eric Karros at the next table at a pizza parlor.
At the local newspaper, The Press Journal, deadlines are pushed back during the season to include West Coast scores because "so many people follow the Dodgers," said John Schumann, whose family published the paper for 70 years. At Hyatt Fruits, the owner, Tom Jones, draws in customers for his gift boxes by giving away two tickets a day to spring training games.
When Dodgers players talk about training here -- on fields bordered by streets like Don Drysdale Drive and Sandy Koufax Lane -- the word "mystique" is often invoked.
"There's something definitely unique about it," said Todd Zeile, a third baseman spending his first spring as a Dodger after eight major league seasons. "You get to talk to fans up close."
Chip Hale, an infielder joining the Dodgers this year from Minnesota, said, "It's almost like the Dodgers own the whole town." (He conceded that players sometimes called it Zero Beach, but affectionately. Lacking big-city distractions, it offers "more of a chance to concentrate on baseball," he said.)
This spring, however, a cloud hovers over Vero Beach. Since the O'Malley family's announcement in January that the Dodgers are for sale, there has been anxious speculation here that a new owner might be wooed to more lucrative spring pastures. And Vero Beach is determined not to become another Brooklyn.
"If the Dodgers were to leave, it would be a calamity, a catastrophe -- economically, socially and psychologically," said Mayor Jack Grossett, a Pittsburgh Pirates fan before moving here 10 years ago. "People are saying they wouldn't leave Vero Beach, couldn't leave Vero Beach, but you and I know they could."
Maurice McEvoy, a 72-year-old fan from Quincy, Mass., with a winter home in Vero Beach ("baseball is the reason we came"), recoiled at the prospect. "People think about Vero Beach with the Dodgers like Kleenex with a tissue," he said. "This place will always be Dodgertown, no matter who buys it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Dodgers are a spring training fixture in Vero Beach, Fla., where fans are as common as citrus trees and flock to players like Hideo Nomo. (Andrew Itkoff for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: NEW JOBS SURGE, BUT GAINS IN PAY ARE ONLY MODEST

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 7

 BODY:
The job market grew at an unexpectedly brisk pace in February, buoyed by unusually favorable weather for construction, as the unemployment rate slipped a tenth of a point, to 5.3 percent, the Labor Department reported today.
While payrolls expanded by 339,000, much more than was generally expected, many economists described the overall job market as only modestly tighter than in January. They said it probably still did not pose a big enough risk of wage inflation to prompt the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates at its next policy meeting scheduled for March 25. 
 "I think it's still a close call on the Fed," said Rosanne M. Cahn, an economist with Credit Suisse First Boston. She said the central bank faced the issue of an economy that continued to expand at an unsustainable clip while inflation, on the other hand, remained essentially in check.
Reaction in the financial markets reflected that view. After an early fall, bond prices rose on the report and stocks surged. The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 56.19 points at 7,000.89. Investors focused on figures in the employment report showing a modest rise in hourly earnings. [Page 39.]
But a growing number of experts, while still in the minority, now argue that the economy's continued strength may well persuade the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates, perhaps as early as March 25 or at its next meeting in May. "The countdown to Fed tightening continued this week," economists for Salomon Brothers told their clients today. "Fed officials will be hard pressed to postpone action any longer when they meet again in two weeks."
President Clinton hailed the job growth, which he said reflected the priority he had given to deficit reduction, and took the occasion to ask for an agreement with Congress that could bring a balanced budget, albeit temporary, in 2002.
"We must cut the deficit to zero while investing in our people," he said in a statement. "I look forward to working with the Congress to get the job done by passing a balanced budget plan."
Besides the modest rise of 3 cents an hour in average hourly earnings, signs that the labor market is not yet overheating included a decline in the number of people who quit their jobs to look for other employment. This indicator, which had shown increases in the last few months, was cited by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, in recent Congressional testimony in which he warned that a "pre-emptive" strike against inflation may be necessary.
Other evidence of presumed comfort to the Federal Reserve was a downward revision in payroll growth for January, a lack of growth in factory jobs and quirks of statistics and weather that exaggerated employment in department stores and in construction.
Much of a 46,000 rise in retail trade jobs reflected the fact that department stores laid off workers hired for the holiday shopping season earlier than usual, confounding the process by which the Bureau of Labor Statistics adjusted for recurring seasonal variation.
And although officials could not quantify the effect, a large portion of a 109,000 surge in construction jobs, nearly one-third of total payroll growth, was a result of mild weather last month. The advance, concentrated in such outdoors work as heavy construction, masonry, concrete and roofing, was the biggest in a year.
"It's not as strong as it looks," said Irwin L. Kellner of Kellner Economic Advisers, a consultant in Port Washington, L.I. "Today's numbers will not cause the Fed to raise interest rates come March 25."
Still, James F. O'Sullivan, an economist with Morgan Guaranty, said the report provided further evidence of a situation that the Federal Reserve could not allow to continue: the economy growing for years above its long-term trend. He said the unemployment rate, which has been essentially steady since summer, would likely drop to a new level should solid job growth persist and predicted the Federal Reserve would this month raise rates by a quarter-point.
The so-called quit rate, cited by Mr. Greenspan, drew particular scrutiny today as it retreated to 10.9 percent after climbing to 12.3 percent in January. A decline is taken as reflecting less confidence that a better job will be available but officials warned against overinterpretation.
"This is a very volatile series," said Janet L. Yellen, a former Federal Reserve governor who recently became head of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. She described the job market as "extremely strong" but without "any evidence of inflationary pressures."
This sanguine view was disputed, however, by Cathy E. Minehan, who as president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston participates in meetings of the Federal Open Market Committee even though she does not have a vote this year. "These signals of labor market tightness in the face of above-trend growth clearly sound inflation alarm bells," Ms. Minehan said at a forum on the economy at Middlebury College in Vermont.
The department's survey on households, on which the unemployment rate is based, showed a decline of 150,000 jobs in February that followed a 725,000 leap in January. But the labor force contracted a bit more, enough to trim a statistically insignificant one-tenth of a point off the jobless rate.
There was a sizable 210,000 decline in workers idled for less than five weeks, a confirmation of figures showing that first-time claims for jobless benefits had reached their lowest level in eight years.
By region, unemployment in the Northeast eased two-tenths of a point last month, to 5.6 percent, the department also reported. The Midwest improved to 4.3 from 4.4 percent while the West improved to 5.7 from 6 percent. The South's jobless rate, however, climbed five-tenths of a point, to 5.5 percent.
The Federal Reserve said today that consumer credit grew at an annual rate of 8.4 percent, or $8.4 billion, in January. The increase was greater than analysts' expectatations of a rise of about $5.5 billion.

HEADLINE: Sobering News for Bacchus;
Europe's Wine Industry Is Facing Serious Challenges

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: ROME, March 7

 BODY:
It's not that Paola Nuvola doesn't like wine. She simply enjoys Coke more.
"It's just tasty, and I like it," said Ms. Nuvola, who works with a publishing company in Rome. While her parents, like most older Italians, are big wine drinkers, and a bottle stands on the table at the evening meal, she and her brother, Daniele, don't share the enthusiasm. In fact, she says, he prefers milk, soft drinks, mineral water -- almost everything except wine. 
 While Europe still is to wine what Saudi Arabia is to crude oil, the drinking habits of Europeans in their 20's, like Ms. Nuvola and her brother, are causing wine makers in big wine-producing nations like Italy, France, and Spain to sober up.
In recent years, per capita consumption plummeted, as younger people hooked on Coke and beer deserted wine in droves. By 1995, the average Italian drank only 16 gallons a year. True, that is a lot more than the 1.8 gallons consumed by Americans, yet it is well below the 19 gallons, on average, Italians drank in 1989. In France, average consumption dropped to 16.8 gallons, from 19.4; in Spain, to 9.6 from 12.4.
With too much wine chasing too few drinkers, prices for rieslings and Riojas, Chiantis and cabernets are often well below what it costs to produce them.
This spells long-term trouble for Europe's wine industry, with the only bright spots being upscale wines and some cheaper ones. And while some wineries are adjusting, many others are not.
 Exports do take up some of the slack, and in recent years Europe's wines have traveled to markets as far-flung as Japan, India and Russia.
More recently, though, countries not traditionally associated with wine, like Australia, South Africa, and Chile, are crowding in, transforming the trade from a largely European monopoly into a global business. In Europe, the strain is beginning to be felt.
Europe's traditional recipe is to prop up prices by paying wineries to destroy vineyards and to distill excess wine into industrial alcohol. Each year, the European Commission spends about $1.6 billion to keep supplies down.
But as global competition mounts, so does resistance to such profligacy. "Instead of spending for price supports," said Achim Blau, an economist at the German Federation of Wine Growers, a trade group in Bonn, "we should be investing in the promotion of European wines."
And Franco Zuffellato, director of marketing at Zonin, Italy's largest privately owned winery, fears that while Europe bulldozes vineyards, "in Australia, Chile, Argentina, California's Napa Valley, they're planting."
"I ask myself if it's right," he added.
Not that the picture is totally bleak. Consumers in Asian countries are discovering wine, and in the United States and Germany, always big customers for southern European wines, recent revelations about the positive health effects of moderate wine drinking are lifting sales, particularly of red wine.
Last year, the wineries of France, the world's No. 2 wine-producing nation after Italy, lifted global exports by 13 percent; Spanish wineries, using aggressive marketing and pricing, elbowed their way into lucrative markets with cava, a sparkling wine. And French and Italian wineries are buying vineyards in Eastern Europe and the United States.
In dollar terms, in fact, exports rose 7 percent as buyers shifted to higher-priced wines, and some industry officials found consolation in that. "For us, the export challenge has only been good," said Allegra Antinori of Marchesi Antinori, one of Italy's leading Chianti producers. "Wine today is quality wine."
Yet the more closely watched numbers are those for volume, and those do not look good. Italy, at 1.5 billion gallons a year, is the world's largest wine producer. But in 1996 the volume of Italian wine exports plummeted by 25 percent.
So the storm warning is clear: For every thriving European winery that is able to build on a quality image, thousands of mom-and-pop operations survive only thanks to subsidies. In Spain's Castile-La Mancha region, south of Madrid, where roughly half of Spanish wine is produced, vineyards yield only about 288 gallons an acre, compared with about 1,390 in the vineyards of Germany and Luxembourg. In Apulia and Sicily, in southern Italy, tens of thousands of unproductive two- to three-acre vineyards only cost the Government money. Last year, part of the problem became evident when Spanish wine merchants, forced by a poor harvest to import wine, snubbed Europe's expensive wines in favor of Argentina's.
"Europe doesn't have a recipe," complained Pietro Caviglia, director of the Italian Union of Wines. "In the coming years, this will explode."
What aggravates the problem, experts like Mr. Caviglia say, is that many regions heavily dependent on wine growing are among those hardest hit by high unemployment. In Spain's Castile-La Mancha, for instance, unemployment is 24 percent, double the European average.
In February, evidence of the tension appeared when wineries in Spain and France pressured the European Commission to earmark fresh funds for the distillation of wine to alcohol. Their action was prompted by large surpluses in France's Charentes region, where sales of wine to local cognac distilleries are hurting because of flagging liquor sales, and in Spain's La Mancha region, where good weather last year produced a bumper grape crop. So in the next several months, almost 63 million gallons of wine will be converted to alcohol, with the wineries paid up to 80 percent of the wine's market price.
In 1994, Rene Steichen, then the European Commission's senior agriculture official, sought to put an end to such market manipulation by proposing that Europe's wineries eliminate almost 20 percent of their production -- roughly 4.1 billion gallons -- by accepting payments to bulldoze thousands of acres of vineyards. When angry Spanish wine-growers took to the streets of Madrid to protest, the commission dropped the plan. Gerard Kiely, the commission's agriculture spokesman in Brussels, said there is "no enthusiasm around at the moment" to revive it, since several thin harvests and some notable export successes have recently helped buoy prices.
Yet some industry officials say the day of reckoning has not been avoided, only postponed. Wine-drinking trends, they say, tend not to favor European producers of inexpensive table wines, which increasingly dominate the global market.
In Italy, while roughly a third of all wines are sold in supermarkets, many wineries go after only the elite drinkers. "There's a snobbism among the producers," says Claudio De Viti, who follows wine-drinking habits at A. C. Nielsen in Milan. "They spend to bring people to their castles in Tuscany, and prefer to invest in journalists who write for wine magazines, rather than buyers for the half-dozen supermarket chains that sell the volume." That formula promises success for those with strong name recognition, but does little to help the vast bulk of European wine producers.
Last year, a string of poor harvests in California reduced wine output there just as reports of red wine's possible health benefits caused consumption to rise. Imports to the United States rose sharply, but the main beneficiaries were Europe's competitors.
Thus, while imports of French wine rose 31 percent, Italian wines 13 percent, and Spanish wines 2 percent, imports from Australia jumped 33 percent. Brazilian wine imports soared 45 percent, and imports from Chile jumped 60 percent.
Market experts say that as wine drinking trickled down from the elite to a broader public, successful wineries reacted by redesigning labels to stress the grapes that go into the wines, like chardonnay, merlot, or pinot noir, rather than fanciful pedigrees. "This is an American look, as opposed to a European look," said Eileen Fredrikson of Gomberg, Fredrikson & Associates, a San Francisco-based company that tracks the wine market.
European wineries are adjusting to these new realities in a variety of ways. Earlier this year, the producers of Chianti, the traditional red wine of Tuscany, agreed to alter the complex blend that was codified in the 19th century and changed only a few times since. Now it no longer contains both red and white grapes, but only one red variety, the sangiovese. "It reflects the growing need for quality," said Ms. Antinori, whose family has produced wine since the late 1300's. "Some of our newer wines are 100 percent red."
Such innovations are helping a handful of wineries like Antinori stay ahead of the market. In 1991, Antinori widened its global reach by joining several European partners to make wine in Hungary; two years later, it acquired Atlas Peak Vineyards, a 460-acre winery in California's Napa Valley.
French wineries and wine merchants have also engaged in national export campaigns recently. Last year, French exports to Germany, whose wine-producing regions suffered several weak harvests, rose almost 50 percent.
"We've had good results in virtually all categories," exulted Christian Melani, a spokesman for Onivins, a wine industry group in Paris.
Some of Italy's best wineries are seeking to imitate the French success. Zonin, for example, has dropped the Italian custom of local denominations on its labels and emphasized grape varieties. Zonin also sought to meet increased demand by aggressively enlarging its domains, buying up aging vineyards in premier Italian locations, then sinking large sums into replanting to increase yield and permit less expensive mechanical harvesting. In the last five years, Zonin doubled the size of its vineyards under cultivation to 47,000 acres.
But the gains do not come easily. Sales rose only 5 percent last year, to $71 million, about 30 percent through exports. Gianni Zonin, the group's owner and president, likes to count Europe's fresh competitors on his fingers. "Australia, Argentina, Chile, South Africa, Eastern Europe," he says, "they're all exporting now, and last year Spain even imported wine from Argentina." Still, he added, "I'm an optimist."
Mr. Zuffellato, Zonin's marketing director and Mr. Zonin's brother-in-law, explains why: "The old producing countries are learning how to compete. The newcomers are forcing us to get better."

HEADLINE: Colombia Says It Will Resume Aerial Spraying to Destroy Coca

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, March 7

 BODY:
Colombia, which surprised the United States by suspending the aerial spraying of its coca crops, will resume eradication of the plants, which are used to make cocaine, Justice Minister Carlos Medellin said today.
The aerial spraying program was suspended Wednesday, apparently in reprisal for Washington's decision to "decertify" Colombia for a second year as an ally in the drug war. Mr. Medellin said the program would resume next week. 
 "Aerial coca eradication operations in Colombia will restart as of next Wednesday," he said after a meeting of the national antidrug council. He added that the operation had been suspended only temporarily while the police and Government officials review its effectiveness in light of what the United States has described as a 32 percent increase in the cultivation of coca last year.
That jump made Colombia the world's second-largest grower of the raw material for cocaine. It was one of the reasons Washington cited last week in deciding to leave Colombia on a list of countries that are failing to cooperate fully with the United States in antidrug efforts.
The suspension of aerial spraying caught American officials off guard and drew a rebuke from a State Department spokesman, Nicholas Burns, who said Washington reserved the right to levy economic sanctions on Colombia.
The American Ambassador, Myles R. Frechette, urged a quick resumption of the operations, warning Colombia that the suspension could spell disaster for Colombian-American relations.
Colombian officials have questioned the United States figures on coca production. They have argued that the numbers do not take into account areas sprayed as part of an American-backed program that has taken the lives of 35 pilots and anti-drug fighters since 1995.
To insure that no such disputes will occur in the future, Mr. Medellin said, he and the head of the anti-narcotics division of the National Police are to ask the French Government this month for assistance in monitoring Colombia's illicit drug crops with a spy satellite.
In clear criticism of the United States, he said it was very important to obtain independent verification of Washington's crop estimates. He also said no decision had been made on efforts backed by the United States to replace the liquid herbicide currently in use in Colombia with a more effective granular variety.
American contract pilots began working with the Colombian police in the drug fumigation program last year. One was killed in January when his crop-duster aircraft crashed in a guerrilla-controlled area in southeast Colombia.
Colombia's leading leftist guerrilla group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, obtains much of its funds through protection of rural drug farms and laboratories.
Colombia also accounts for 1.5 percent of the world's opium production. Mr. Medellin said aerial spraying of opium poppies had not been halted when spraying of coca was stopped this week.

HEADLINE: Treasury Bond Prices Move Up Amid Mixed Views on Jobs Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities surged yesterday despite the release of February employment figures that were much stronger than expected. While 339,000 jobs were created last month -- exceeding analysts' forecast of 231,000 -- the report offered a mixed picture.
The 30-year bond rose 25/32, to a price of 97 19/32 to yield 6.81 percent, down from 6.88 percent on Thursday. 
 The jobs data showed an economy that was still strong, but with inflation pressures remaining in check. Even so, the question on everyone's mind is what will happen at the March 25 meeting of the Federal Reserve's policy-making panel.
While there are those who say that yesterday's data will bring a response from the Fed this month, the prevailing opinion in the market seems to be that the policy panel will not act until its May meeting.
"We think it's quite simple," said William C. Dudley, chief United States economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "The economy is continuing to grow above trend and showing no signs of faltering and Greenspan has said in his Humphrey-Hawkins testimony that he's going to be pre-emptive."
"Put the two together and it implies a March tightening; otherwise Greenspan runs the risk of losing credibility," Mr. Dudley said of Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman. "I don't think he wants that."
Another view came from Anthony Chan, a vice president and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio. He said that though the employment report "revealed continuing firm labor cost pressures, it failed to produce additional wage pressures that were above and beyond those that have been seen over the last two months."
"We shouldn't forget that the nonfarm payroll numbers were revised downward by a total of 54,000 during December 1996 and January 1997," Mr. Chan said, "which means that after adjusting for these factors, the 339,000 rise in nonfarm payrolls really becomes a less menacing net increase of only 285,000."

HEADLINE: State Nears Agreement On Lilco Debt

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:
The Pataki administration and the Long Island Lighting Company are close to completing a complex $5 billion deal for the state to take over debt from the defunct Shoreham nuclear plant, an agreement that would address some of Gov. George E. Pataki's thorniest political problems as he looks to the 1998 campaign, according to people close to the talks.
The state and the utility have apparently resolved one of the last major impediments to the agreement, a billion-dollar property tax dispute that threatens to bankrupt local governments on Long Island's East End, though one state official said no final commitment had been made. The pact would relieve Lilco, once and for all, of its remaining Shoreham debt and lower the island's electric rates, the highest in the continental United States, according to officials who spoke on condition of anonymity. 
 They said a few remaining issues should be settled fairly readily, and the deal could be announced in the next two weeks.
State officials refused to comment for the record on any potential accord. "It's speculation at this point," said Zenia Mucha, the Governor's spokeswoman.
A state official said that just one important obstacle remains: the utility's capital gains tax liability arising from such a state bailout, which it has been estimated could reach $2 billion. Lilco, which has a merger with the Brooklyn Union Gas Company pending, and state officials have petitioned the Internal Revenue Service to forgive the liability, or at least postpone it for many years, and the I.R.S. has not ruled on the matter. Some people close to the talks said there had been hints of accommodation from the I.R.S., but others said there had been no such indications.
Lilco officials have said that no state takeover of the Shoreham debt was feasible without that tax relief, and Wall Street analysts said that the tax liability threatened to kill the merger with Brooklyn Union.
Under the proposed agreement, as described by state officials and business leaders close to the talks, the Long Island Power Authority, a state agency, would pay Lilco a little more than $5 billion to buy the utility's electric transmission and distribution system and settle the property tax case. The authority would then hire Lilco to operate the system for six years. Lilco, which is awaiting a merger with Brooklyn Union Gas Company, would lower its electric rates by 10 to 15 percent.
That would allow Mr. Pataki to claim victory after two years of promising "double digit" rate relief to a region that will be key to his re-election hopes, and to take credit for the resolution of the Shoreham quagmire, which long eluded his predecessor, Mario M. Cuomo. Long Island's electric rates -- nearly double the national average, with the average household paying about $100 a month -- are a perennial source of fury from residents and businesses and, officials say, a damper on the local economy.
The Power Authority would pay for the transaction by selling $5 billion in tax-exempt bonds -- the largest municipal bond issue in history -- that would be repaid through a surcharge on ratepayers' bills for the next 20 to 30 years. Business and consumer groups charged that the state should have forced Lilco to swallow some of the cost.
As part of the deal, officials said, the Long Island Power Authority will pay Lilco to settle the utility's lawsuit against Suffolk County, the town of Brookhaven and the Shoreham Wading River School District. That lawsuit charges that the untility was overcharged on property taxes since the early 1980's. Last year, the utility won a judgment against the governments that is potentially worth $1.1 billion, raising the prospect of bankruptcy if they were forced to accept even a large fraction of the judgment.
A state official close to the talks and business executives said the settlement would be more than $500 million, but another state official said there was no agreement yet. The settlement would be paid not by the local governments, but by the Power Authority, to be repaid by the businesses and the 2.7 million residents of Long Island and the Rockaways through higher rates for many years.
The agreement amounts to a bailout of the local governments, which derived the benefits of overcharging Lilco for more than a decade but will not be obliged to repay the debt.
Politically, this feature of the deal is crucial to Mr. Pataki. The Governor gained much of his narrow 1994 victory margin with an unusually strong showing in Suffolk County, and John Powell, the Suffolk Republican leader and an important ally of Mr. Pataki, has insisted that settlement of the property tax dispute be a part of any state deal with Lilco.
"What is really the catalytic agent in this deal is the concern on the part of the Governor that he can't get re-elected without Suffolk County," said Jack Kulka, a construction company owner and a prominent critic of the plans to relieve Lilco of the Shoreham debt.
To settle complaints from Nassau County officials that residents there should not have to help repay Lilco for Suffolk's good fortune, the agreement provides for either slightly lower electric rates in Nassau than in Suffolk for the next generation, or for Suffolk to make cash payments to the neighboring county.
Lilco and its shareholders also have reason to be pleased, because the agreement indirectly relieves the utility of its $4.5 billion Shoreham debt. The merger with Brooklyn Union provides a higher price per share for Lilco with a state takeover of the debt. The debt is already being paid off by ratepayers, not the company, but the state could theoretically change that arrangement. Transferring it to the Power Authority makes it permanently the ratepayers' obligation.
Consumer and business groups contend that the company should be held liable for a large portion of the debt. "There's no way customers should be held responsible for all, or even most, of this," said Larry Shapiro, an attorney with the New York Public Interest Research Group.
In addition to Lilco's power lines, the Power Authority would buy Lilco's minority stake in the Nine Mile Point 2 nuclear plant upstate. The merged Brooklyn Union-Lilco would retain ownership of the rest of Lilco's generating plants, and its natural gas system. The price paid for the utility's assets would be about $4.5 billion.
The Power Authority can pay off the debt more cheaply than Lilco because it can borrow money at lower interest rates. That translates to lower rates for consumers.
