HEADLINE: In the Heart of America, A Quiet Place for Music

BYLINE: By BERNARD HOLLAND 

DATELINE: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa

 BODY:
ALAN LAWRENCE, 40, PLAYS the timpani in the Cedar Rapids Symphony, and not for a lot of money. Top players -- and he leads his section -- can expect $85 each for five rehearsals, $110 for the Saturday evening concert at the Paramount Theater that follows, and $110 more for a repeat performance on Monday. For a lot of his colleagues, the numbers go from $40 to $60.
The orchestra plays seven pairs of subscription concerts a year, eight pops performances, three chamber and eight children's programs, and the occasional special event. You do the arithmetic; it doesn't add up to much. 
 From the offices of the Chicago Symphony or the New York Philharmonic, lives like these look small and far away; the rewards are pocket change next to big-city pay scales that approach $85,000 a year for newcomers and twice that for principal musicians. From the streets of this modest Iowa city, on the other hand, it is we who appear vague, distant and perhaps irrelevant.
Mr. Lawrence's orchestra, 75 years old and one of up to 300 professional institutions in the United States, is actually somewhere in the middle of this hierarchy. It shares the turmoil and economic fears of its colleagues. It spends nowhere near the $43 million the Boston Symphony needs each year, though with its $1.4 million budget, it is more prosperous than neighbors who make do with a quarter of that amount.
Christian Tiemeyer is the orchestra's music director, and next to the better conductorial contracts in classical music, not for a lot of money either. Mr. Tiemeyer, 56, comes from Catonsville, Md., and studied the cello with Pablo Casals in Europe and Zara Nelsova at the Juilliard School.
Mr. Tiemeyer caught the conducting virus commonly known as "stick fever" at the Dallas Symphony, where he was principal cellist and eventually associate conductor. Later he played and conducted under Maurice Abravanel at the Utah Symphony. At one point in his career Mr. Tiemeyer was working 100 nights a year and doing it in a lot of different places. He has been in Cedar Rapids since 1982 and rarely stirs from home.
Jeff Smith, 35, is the board president of the orchestra and is about to turn the job over to James Hoffman, 43. Both men have gilt-edged futures in major corporations. Kathy Hall juggles the jobs of principal bassoonist and executive director with the dictates of a teen-age son. Her days and nights are long. If she (improbably) held those jobs in New York or Boston, her two salaries might approach a half-million dollars a year.
What are these people -- indeed, what is an orchestra of such solid accomplishment -- doing in a town like Cedar Rapids? Well, they are living their lives. Mr. Lawrence, the timpanist, is a little out of the ordinary in a community of 110,000 and an orchestra of 75 players. He is from Midland, Tex. A majority of his fellow musicians are Iowans or went to school here.
Ms. Hall, for example, who has an advanced degree in music and is highly thought of in both of her present jobs, comes from Donnellson, 100 miles south of here, where her father operated a feed and fertilizer business. Most orchestra managements would be horrified by the prospect of Ms. Hall's negotiating with herself at contract time, but Cedar Rapids is not New York or Boston.
Mr. Lawrence is also different in that he may be moving on. He takes auditions; the most recent was in San Antonio. On the other hand, after nine seasons he has abandoned apartment life and found a house to rent, has bought himself some modestly priced health insurance, works part-time as assistant manager for classical music in a record store and tries not to worry about retirement. Most of all, he teaches. It took him time, but he has come upon values here that he is starting to like and may not be as footloose as before.
Mr. Tiemeyer, in his former life, found himself with three small children and little time to give them. From Abravanel he learned the music director's loyalty to place, as opposed to the traveling conductor's yearning to be engaged and then re-engaged. Cedar Rapids offered him a full-time job and a home. His wife, Patti, a cellist, plays in the orchestra, too.
The president-elect, Mr. Hoffman, after a high-profile stint in Washington at the MCI Corporation, has come back home to Cedar Rapids and put his children in the city's admired public school system. Iowa's fleeing population has reversed direction, and many of the newcomers are actually people who grew up here, left to make their fortunes and are returning to raise their children.
The Paramount Theater, where the orchestra plays, is one of those movie palace and vaudeville theater restorations found growing hopefully in downtown grids of troubled urban America. Nearby, the Cedar River runs through town. So does the Union Pacific Railroad, with its mournful horns sounding pleasantly from the tracks behind the Five Seasons Hotel.
The city's river, its tree-lined outer boulevards and the surrounding farmland promise pleasing green in another season, but downtown's dowdy 1920's office rectangles and glassy high-tech high-rises are bleak in winter. On a cold Monday evening, the Paramount marquee reads "Physicians for the Arts," acknowledging one of a number of coalitions in this city that help pay for concerts. Nine hundred ten people have come to hear Brahms and Beethoven. One thousand thirty-five heard the same program two days before, but the Monday concert has a few tricks up its sleeve.
Mr. Tiemeyer, microphone in hand, pitches his program with the fervor of an upscale car salesman. Video cameras trained on different parts of the orchestra show up-close the workings of music-making by way of screened projections on each side of the stage. On Monday, intermissions are usually done away with and the programs shortened, but the mighty Brahms B flat Piano Concerto and the Beethoven Seventh Symphony, on the program for this evening, demand a breather for all concerned.
MANAGEMENT IS TRYING mightily to capture a new listenership, and the audience on Monday did have more than the usual share of young people. Why don't more come?
"A lot of people feel uncomfortable," said Mr. Smith, the president. "They don't know what to wear, when to clap. They are afraid of feeling out of place." Volunteers have formed a pre- and post-concert system of parties: a combination welcome wagon and singles bar for new people. Because many have no friends who come to concerts, a block of general-admission seats allows newcomers to pair off and sit with new-found acquaintances.
Cedar Rapids has advantages other places do not: a relatively stable society, established and generous companies like Quaker Oats, a growing high-tech industry that brings in young and educated employees, surrounding colleges and universities, and -- wonder of wonders -- a public school system that has not abandoned the arts.
Yet this is no Middle Western idyll of good will and plenty. The orchestra treads the same fragile, dangerous path as its colleagues large and small: with shrinking and aging audiences, higher costs, reduced government grants and competition for philanthropic gifts that are shifting everywhere in this country from arts to medical and humanitarian projects.
The parsimony runs across the board. The National Endowment for the Arts grant this year is $12,500, down from $18,000; the Iowa Arts Council grant is $18,000, down from $24,000, and the Iowa Community Cultural Grant is $13,000, down from $15,000. Corporate and private gifts run about a half-million dollars a year for a budget of $1.4 million and an endowment of about the same amount.
Single-ticket sales, the backbone of popular-culture events here, have grown stubbornly but help to offset a gradual trickling away of subscriptions. Gifts are hard won.
"Every budget we make is an act of faith," said Ms. Hall, the executive director. "We don't know how many tickets we are going to sell or how much money people are actually going to give us." The orchestra earns only 38 percent of its income. (Forty percent is considered acceptable in this business.) But few cities of such modest population have an orchestra of this size and solidity.
In concert, the Cedar Rapids Symphony does not make a sound like, say, the Philadelphia Orchestra, but it is not playing in Philadelphia and is not supposed to. What it does offer is tight, well-tuned ensemble, perfectly adequate principal players and sometimes very good ones, and sound musical direction. (The elusive rhythm of the Beethoven finale was correct and clear.) The Brahms concerto, at least as difficult, was made more difficult for the orchestra by Grant Johannesen's extremely slow tempos in the piano part. Brahms's exposed horn and cello parts were thoroughly professional and sometimes quite beautiful.
Where experienced players in major orchestras flirt with salaries of six figures, all the while complaining of artistic deprivations, this mix of old and young musicians plays with palpable delight. Some talked about their feelings the next day. They are wistful about money, they have the usual complaints about conductorial tyranny, but they love their jobs. They also seem to like where they live.
Two contradictary impulses inform the life of this orchestra, and the combination is peculiarly American. One says that growth is good, that because this country began as a few people in a big place, survival still equals expansion. The second impulse is mistrust of central authority. In the pyramidal politics of Europe, absolute control was exercised from faraway capitals by the few over the many: those many being our ancestors. The American Revolution told central power to go away: "We can take care of ourselves; leave us alone." If the facts have changed, the impulse remains.
So Cedar Rapids measures bigness and movement against smallness and boundaries. Asked whether the orchestra's season might grow beyond its seven classical weekends, Mr. Smith said, "There is no reason for growth." In Cedar Rapids, survival equals enclosure: a finite audience served finitely.
Growth of another kind, however, is inner necessity. At a loss to pay its musicians much more money, the orchestra board must find them more work: more students to teach, more run-outs to rural communities, more festivals, fairs and special events. Idealistic as these musicians appear to be, they have pushed for more money and are settling, if only for a 2.5 percent raise in their present per-service contract. The president-elect, Mr. Hoffman, says he does not know how he can pay much more and at the same time keep up with the orchestra's bills.
WITHOUT STUDENTS TO teach, most members of the Cedar Rapids Symphony could not live. For Mr. Lawrence there is Coe College in town; for others, Cornell College, 20 miles away. Wayne Thelander, a bass player in the orchestra and an employee of the public schools, could be found one recent morning rehearsing a string ensemble of 14-year-olds for a communal citywide concert.
The more common outlet for player-teachers is the Symphony School, founded 10 years ago and run by Stephanie Wagor. It is an unusual coalition between schools and the symphony by which two independent parties -- each with its own agenda, its own shortcomings and its own needs -- contractually agree to exchange services. An intensive third-grade string program in the schools has become as much a part of schoolwork as multiplication tables. Students get vouchers for concert tickets. Symphony musicians teach classes and after-school private lessons. Jocelyn Langworthy, the recently hired principal clarinetist, says she already has 40 pupils a week.
Two doctors play in the Cedar Rapids Symphony, along with an engineer, some school teachers, many freelance professionals and professors and graduate students from nearby universities and colleges. The principal flutist, Jane Walker, is a 25-year member. She and her husband operate a music store specializing in woodwind and brass repertory in nearby Iowa City. Blanche Lawrence has played in the violin section since 1931, when she was 14. Ms. Lawrence can remember a time in the orchestra's 75-year history when a fall concert would feature the first two movements of a symphony and the spring concert the third and fourth.
The parents of William Preucil, the concertmaster of the Cleveland Orchestra, have been longtime members. There are more and more young players on the move and passing through, happy for employment. So hair-raising is the competition for orchestra jobs nationally that recent auditions for principal clarinet attracted candidates from music schools as lofty as Yale's.
A lot of this clarinetist's Yale classmates probably never heard of the Cedar Rapids Symphony, and those who have probably do not include it in their daydreams of success. If so, these calm farmland people of eastern Iowa don't seem to care. Their orchestra has neither record labels nor Carnegie Hall on its mind. Its musicians live in a place, and they are about that place. Prosperity lies not over the next mountain but next door.
"New York has no more relevance for Cedar Rapids, Iowa, than Cedar Rapids has for New York," said Mr. Tiemeyer over dinner one evening. "Each life is important, and Cedar Rapids is our life. This is real for us."

LENGTH: 1481 words

HEADLINE: L.I.R.R., Riders and Local Officials Square Off on Parking

BYLINE: By STEWART AIN 

 BODY:
WHEN Maureen J. Hirsch left her house in Bay Shore at 7:30 to catch the 7:46 train at Deer Park on Feb. 26, she turned on her car radio and learned of a derailment in Westbury.
"They said there would be 60-minute delays on the Main Line to Penn Station," Ms. Hirsch said. "I thought of driving in. But even with a 60-minute delay, the train would still be faster than driving." 
 The train arrived on time, but then sat outside the Hicksville station for nearly two hours.
Ms. Hirsch, a legal assistant, fumed.
"They said on the radio that people who take this line should use the Babylon line instead, but what are you supposed to do with your car?" she asked. "There is no place to park in Babylon, even for people who take that train on a regular basis. And you must be a town resident and have a permit to park in the station's tiny lot."
To prevent commuters from parking on nearby streets, she noted, parking is limited to two hours.
"The railroad says to use another line, but there is no other option," Ms. Hirsch continued. "I would have loved for them to tell me where else I could park my car to catch a train. And now that I'm on this train I'm stuck."
To critics of the Long Island Rail Road -- as well as of the towns that control parking -- the problems represented another instance of a lack of understanding of commuters' needs and a lack of appreciation for what the commuter brings to the local economy. Town officials, by and large, work on the Island and rarely ride the railroad.
They do not experience walks from distant parking spaces, sometimes poorly maintained stations, delays, breakdowns, misinformation or lack of information and other indignities or quirks, like getting change from ticket machines in Susan B. Anthony coins.
Commuters generally earn higher salaries in New York City than on Long Island, but they are likely to shop in local stores and patronize higher-priced stores.
Ms. Hirsch's train pulled into Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan at 11:25, more than two and a half hours late.
A spokeswoman for the railroad, Susan McGowan, said: "Most customers know that parking is governed by the municipalities."
The L.I.R.R., Ms. McGowan added, suggested the Babylon Line just for riders who could be dropped off there, and radio stations may not have made that clear.
Another commuter from Bay Shore who was sitting with Ms. Hirsch, Gerry S. Cincotta, said that Babylon had few all-day meters and that "they are all taken by 6 in the morning."
The difficulty in finding available parking at other stations has been compounded by a steady increase in ridership over the last five years. Ridership has increased from 70.2 million morning passengers in 1992 to 74.4 million last year, the highest since 75.4 million in 1989.
"It's wonderful that the Long Island Rail Road has increased ridership," Supervisor Lewis J. Yevoli of Oyster Bay said. "But we are the ones required to maintain the parking lots." Although "the commuters are our taxpayers," Mr. Yevoli said, "we are enabling the railroad's ridership to increase by taking care of the lots without any help from the railroad."
He said the town was trying its best to cope with problems at the most crowded stations, including Hicksville, Syosset and Massapequa.
Because of insufficient space at Massapequa, he said, the state began allowing commuters to park along Sunrise Highway last year. "I guess you must have close to 75 cars or more parked on Sunrise Highway each day," he said.
The town is restriping the lots for spaces with 1,800 square feet instead of 2,000.
"We picked up 75 spots in Syosset and 70 in Hicksville," Mr. Yevoli said. "We're working on Massapequa now."
If the Metropolitan Transportation Authority made money available, Mr. Yevoli said, additional space could be bought in Massapequa and an additional parking level built in Hicksville. "Hicksville is a hub," he said. "They are going to have to do something there."
Supervisor May W. Newberger of North Hempstead said: "It's an endemic problem. It's all over, like spreading fungus."
At Port Washington, Ms. Newberger said, the town bought a lot on Van de Ventor Avenue that it is paving for 114 spaces.
"We were prepared to condemn the property if we could not come to an agreement on the price," Ms. Newberger said. "It cost us a good amount of money."
The M.T.A., the parent of the Long Island Rail Road, did not pay any of the cost.
The chairman of the L.I.R.R. Commuters Council, Larry Silverman, said the railroad was responsible for building "as much parking as is needed for its riders."
"At our April meeting," Mr. Silverman said, "we've asked the railroad to send us an expert about the parking situation to speak to us. Our impression is that the railroad doesn't deal with it adequately at all. We scheduled this meeting because of numerous complaints from riders.
"With the growth in ridership, the railroad has to plan and believe in its future. But it doesn't have a vision of the future and just patches things up. There is no long-term planning in place."
Another spokesman for the railroad, Sam Zambuto, said it had earmarked $24 million to improve and expand parking over two years.
Mr. Silverman pointed out that when electrification was expanded on the Main Line in 1987, the railroad was unprepared for the surge in ridership at Ronkonkoma, taking years to plan and build additional parking.
He is concerned, he added, that the advent of dual-mode diesel engines next year will again catch the railroad flat footed. The new engines will enable commuters on nonelectrified tracks to ride to Penn Station without changing trains at Jamaica.
"That will take the pressure off the Syosset and Hicksville stations," Mr. Silverman said, explaining that riders will no longer have an incentive to forgo diesel trains on the Oyster Bay Line for faster electric trains.
Mr. Zambuto acknowledged that the new diesels might "shift riding patterns" and that the railroad was evaluating parking needs. "That's part of our plan for the future," he said. "We are evaluating possible changes in ridership on the Port Jefferson branch east of Huntington, on the Main Line east of Ronkonkoma, on the Montauk branch east of Babylon and on the Oyster Bay branch."
Mr. Zambuto said the railroad expected to begin receiving next year 116 bilevel coaches that will be pulled by 23 new diesel and 18 dual-mode locomotives. The coaches will replace 40-year-old cars that have "outlived their useful life," he said, adding that the L.I.R.R. is also taking into account that refurbishing old parking lots would attract additional riders.
Supervisor Richard H. Schaffer Jr. of Babylon said he hoped that the M.T.A. became "more serious about making access easier."
"It can't continue to rely on under-the-trestle parking," Mr. Schaffer said. "People are now parking everywhere and anywhere at some stations. The railroad has to take the money it got from increased fares and put it into parking. It has to make serious infrastructure improvements."
Although no vacant property is available near heavily used stations in Babylon, Mr. Schaffer said, the M.T.A. should try to buy nearby buildings because of the demand for parking at stations like Copiague.
Several town supervisors said they were unaware that the M.T.A. had set aside money to expand parking.
A spokeswoman for Hempstead, Marlene Kastleman, said the M.T.A. had given $800,000 to help buy property to add 30 spaces at Merrick.
Mayor Eugene E. Scarpato of Lynbrook said his village had discussed with the railroad the "haphazard" parking under the railroad trestle.
The L.I.R.R., Mr. Scarpato said, has agreed to add 50 metered spaces to the 150 spaces at the station.
Aware of concerns in Huntington, Supervisor Frank P. Petrone said the town was building two bridges across New York Avenue to improve accessibility to 450 spaces in two lots west of the station. The bridges, he added, are to be completed by the fall, before construction of an affordable housing complex on a 400-space site.
"One person fearful that there will be no spots" after the two lots are closed has distributed leaflets, Mr. Petrone said, but the town will conduct "a study to make sure there are spots."
The town, he added, is "looking at additional lots across the street."
Mr. Silverman said Mr. Petrone assured him in December that "they were doing this count."
"How much do you have to study to go out and count cars one day?" Mr. Silverman asked.
In a letter to Mr. Petrone on Feb. 13, he said his group's assessment had convinced him that "the remaining lots will be woefully inadequate."
"People will have to park in the boondocks a quarter-mile from the station," Mr. Silverman said. "That is inadequate planning on the town's part and on the part of the railroad."

SECTION: Section 9; Page 9; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1199 words

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
A New State Code for Remodeling Projects Is Near

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
NEW JERSEY is putting the final touches on its first statewide code of standards that will govern the rehabilitation of residential and commercial buildings.
It is being crafted as the result of a 1995 state law calling for a more efficient and cost-effective way for property owners to restore buildings without compromising safety. It is also expected to address concerns over the possibility of a double standard of safety for new and existing structures. 
 The 1995 law charged the New Jersey Department of Community Affairs to adopt new controls to govern the state's 2.3 million residences and 500,000 commercial structures.
The new rules are being drawn up by the department's division of codes and standards together with the Center for Urban Policy Research at Rutgers University in New Brunswick and a 30-member advisory board. The board is made up of local code officials, developers, architects, preservationists and advocates of housing for low- and moderate-income people to make sure that all interests are represented.
Renovations are now governed under the state's construction codes for new buildings. Those codes in many cases require owners to upgrade older structures to new construction specifications governing such technical requirements as stairwell and corridor widths, number of exits and mechanical systems. Compliance is mandated when the cost of the renovation exceeds 50 percent of the overall value of the property, or if there is any change in its use.
Concern that such requirements increase costs and are often unwarranted for many rehabilitation projects led to the call for change.
Another factor is the aging of the state's building stock. David Listokin, a professor at the Center for Urban Policy Research at Rutgers who is directing the university's efforts on the code, said the time to institute change was now because the state's buildings, like its population, were reaching middle age. In terms of housing alone, half the residential units in the state were built before 1959, census figures show.
"This is a new approach to the existing construction code that provides a detailed set of measures to protect public health and safety without inhibiting rehabilitation," said William M. Connolly, director of the division of codes and standards in the Department of Community Affairs. The division will supervise the new controls.
New Jersey's effort has caught the attention of the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, which is advocating rehabilitation standards as a provision in the national construction codes that could be voluntarily accepted by states. In doing so, the department is modeling its work on New Jersey's rehabilitation standards.
Essentially, the new code will set up more flexible standards for rehabilitations based on safety risks, what the building will be used for and the extent of the rehabilitation itself.
The level of work ranges from repair and renovation to alterations and reconstruction. The code will also permit alternative safety methods, including the installation of sprinkler systems instead of the reconfiguration of a building for an additional exit. In addition, there will be a separate section dealing with historic structures.
Professor Listokin said the new code "specifically spells out" what is needed to accomplish renovations. For instance, if a building is being changed from a private residence to a public use such as a restaurant the renovation would have to meet more stringent safety requirements. If there is no change of use, safety improvements will grow with the extent of the renovation.
E NCOURAGING the "renewal and restoration of the buildings we have" promotes other public benefits, Mr. Connolly said, and advocates of the new code agree. The benefits include preserving open space, providing housing affordable to lower-income people and revitalizing older urban and suburban centers, where much of the aging building stock is situated.
Those goals are in line with the aims of the state's Development and Redevelopment Plan, which encourages growth where roads, utilities and mass transit are in place and discourages it in less-developed areas.
From the municipal standpoint, said William G. Dressel Jr., executive director of the New Jersey League of Municipalities, "we have to look at the new standards more closely." He said the league was concerned that the standards not "infringe on local prerogatives, increase costs and possibly jeopardize health and public safety."
Mr. Connolly said the issue of local control had been settled 20 years ago with the passage of the New Jersey Uniform Construction Code Act, which set standards for housing construction.
The current draft of the rehabilitation code generally has been well-received by builder and nonbuilder groups involved in renovations. Of the estimated $6.4 billion in construction activity reported last year in New Jersey, alterations and additions accounted for 46.4 percent of that total, according to state figures.
Making the process more efficient will make renovations less costly to do, said Andrew C. Cattano, director of technical services at the New Jersey Builders Association in Plainsboro. "It is a necessary change that can only help," Mr. Cattano said of the new standards.
William C. Asdal, who runs a company bearing his name in Chester that concentrates on remodeling and rehabilitation projects, agrees. "The new standards," he said, "will create opportunities to take a second look at buildings that under the old system were incompatible with current codes and economically infeasible to restore." Without the change those buildings would not be improved or improved without the proper permits, he added.
Affordable housing groups -- including the Affordable Housing Network of New Jersey, based in Trenton -- see the new standards as removing a regulatory barrier to recycling older building to residences for low- and moderate-income families. "Reducing the cost of renovation allows the public subsidies for projects to go farther and in turn more projects can get done," said Diane Sterner, executive director of the housing network.
A survey by the nonprofit group, which lobbied for a separate rehabilitation code, found that applying new construction standards to housing rehabilitation increased costs by an average of $9,000 a unit, or more than 10 percent of the total project cost.
The new code will be "another tool," added Peter Kasabach, housing director at Isles Inc., a nonprofit development group in Trenton. If its "effectiveness is not diluted in the implementation," Mr. Kasabach said, his group will revisit buildings it was forced to walk away from because of lack of public funds or the high cost of rehabilitation under the old rules.
Among them is a cluster of rowhouses on Passaic Street in the Canal Banks Redevelopment area of Trenton. Mr. Kasabach said Isles had renovated six of the three-story brick buildings on the block. Now they sit next to ones that are vacant and battered.
Though the discussion and tinkering continues, Mr. Connolly said he expected the code to be adopted by the end of the year.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/A Tilt to Landlords;
Lag in New Construction Tightens Midtown Market

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
HAS the balance of power changed? Is the great tenant market of the 90's in midtown office buildings finally coming to an end, with the balance of power shifting to landlords after a few years of steady economic recovery with virtually no new construction?
To some the answer is an unequivocal yes. "I think it has shifted from the tenant side to the owner side," said James S. Meiskin, the president of Plymouth Partners, a brokerage specializing in tenant representation. 
 He said the reason was that vacancy rates -- particularly in prime midtown space -- were declining as expanding companies occupy the available space.
Others say the shift in the upper hand is a peculiarity of the New York market, which is focused on Manhattan. "New York is the only market I know of where it becomes a landlord's market while there are double digit vacancy rates," said Peter Friedman president of the Friedman Realty Group. "In New York, when the vacancy rate goes below 12 percent, it's a landlord's market."
Although the overall vacancy rate may still be in double digits, space in the most desirable buildings has become scarce, according RE/Locate, a real estate research firm. It reports that vacancies in the 180 Class A buildings between 34th and 61st Streets is just under 8 percent. For an elite group of 30 buildings built after 1980, the rate is just over 6 percent.
Asking rents have not climbed sharply, at least not yet, but brokers say the shrinking concession packages being offered by building owners to entice tenants are the best indications of a changing market.
"Two or three years ago, landlords were offering 18 months of free rent," Mr. Meiskin said. "Now it is 6 to 8 months on a 10-year deal."
Owners are also cutting back on the money they will contribute toward finishing or renovating the interior of buildings. "Those cash allowances were as high as $75 a square foot," Mr. Meiskin said. "Now it is $30 to $40 a foot and that's it."
"There has been a seismic shift from tenant to landlord," said Orna Shulman, executive vice president of the Intertech Corporation, which bought the office tower at 1500 Broadway at 43d Street in September 1995. Because of the reduction in concession packages, she said, effective rents are 15 to 20 percent higher than the company's expectations at the time of purchase.
Others say the situation, while it has generally changed in favor of building owners, is more complex than one side or the other having the clear upper hand.
"I'm not about to raise a flag and claim absolute victory," said Bruce Mosler, president of the Galbreath Company. 'It seems to me that the market is bifurcated. If you are looking for blocks of space under 50,000 square feet, there are a lot of choices. But if you are looking for over 300,000 square feet, it's very tough."
Mr. Mosler cautioned that mergers, such as the combination of Morgan Stanley and Dean Witter, will continue to have real estate implications, as staffs are trimmed and space becomes available. And as new buildings -- such as the Durst Organization's 1.6 million-square-foot building now under construction at what will be 4 Times Square -- fill up, the space being vacated may be hard to fill.
"New product is sexy and fills up quickly," he said. "But if 4 Times Square and other new buildings go up, there may be difficulty in backfilling the older space."
To Mary Ann Tighe, a broker at Insignia/ Edward S. Gordon Company, the market is more tenant-specific than anything else. "If the tenant is somebody who had to be in Midtown or Midtown South, needs 50,000 square feet or more of space, has a high level of technical requirements and needs floor plates of 25,000 square feet, that tenant is in a landlord's market."
MORE generally, Ms. Tighe said, landlords have more options today than in the early part of the decade, when vast amounts of space stood empty and rents were falling. "You can feel it in the market," she said. "Today there is always a deal in front of you or right behind you. If you decide to play hardball with an issue, the landlord has alternatives."
"There is no question that landlords are negotiating with multiple tenants in the better locations," said Andrew H. Roos, executive vice president of Williams Real Estate Company. "But there are still some good values out there for tenants who are willing to compromise."
In addition, Ms. Tighe said, the era of tenants' sending out requests for proposals from building owners and managers is over. "Today," she said, "you have to make an offer."
Mitchell Steir, an executive vice president of Julien J. Studley, acknowledges that tenants have less leverage than a few years ago, but argues that this is not a completely bad development. "My opinion is that we are in a 'fair play' market, where landlords have the ability to make a living," he said.
He said that while free rent and other concessions were smaller than they were a few years ago, they are larger than the last real estate boom. "Concession packages are still 150 to 200 percent of what they were 10 years ago," he said.
And while landlords have more options than they had when space was going begging, that has not translated into arrogance, according to Mr. Steir. "We don't see situations where the landlord says to a tenant, 'This is my renewal deal -- take it or leave it,' " he said. "There is still a strong desire to keep existing tenants to avoid the costs of getting new tenants."
But some have encountered signs that indicate some owners foresee much higher rent levels on the horizon. "We represent some tenants who are subleasing in the General Motors Building," Mr. Meiskin said. "The sublease is due in one year and the tenants are interested in renewing for 10 years at a rental rate of $50 to $55 a square foot. But the owners are not interested in renewing, apparently because they think they can get $70 a foot in a year."
Renewing existing tenants means the space would not have to be remodeled and there would be no down period while construction was taking place and no rent was being paid, Mr. Meiskin observed. "This is a perfect example of how the market has changed."
Patrick J. Brennan, the rental agent for the building, said the situation was more complicated than Mr. Meiskin described, because the space is under lease to a third party. He declined to comment further.
Some market participants observe that the increased tendency for properties to be financed by equity and debt raised on Wall Street is changing some of the rules of the game. Even if the vacancy rates decline, they say, a tenant with strong credit will still be able to engineer a favorable deal.
"Credit is king and the credit tenant is in control," said Joseph A. Farkas, manager of the New York office of the Koll organization. "Buildings are being taken through securities markets where the rating agencies are critical. And one of the things that they look at is the credit of the tenants involved."
Mr. Farkas cited the example of the contest between the Fuhrman Selz brokerage concern and Xerox Corporation for space in 280 Park Avenue, the Bankers Trust Building. "They both battled over that space and Xerox got it because of its credit," Mr. Farkas said, citing Xerox's enormously greater size. "This type of tenant will keep the market from being completely dominated by landlords."
WHENEVER vacancy rates decline and effective rents begin rising, talk of new construction begins. Douglas Durst, whose building at 4 Times Square is 87 percent rented even though excavation is not yet complete, said he perceived a "large pent-up demand for large blocks of high technology space."
He said the rapid leasing of 4 Times Square "was a surprise to us" and predicted that "future development will take place on the large sites that are available," such as the half a block on Madison Avenue between 46th and 47th Streets, the block on Seventh Avenue between 49th and 50th Streets and additional sites in the Times Square area. "The requirement is for large footprints," he said.
"We are flirting with the viability of new construction," said Mr. Friedman of Friedman Realty. "Some people say if we are within 10 percent of the rentals to justify new construction, it is time to buy dirt and get going, because it will take two to three years to get the project out of the ground."
He said the availability of financing, much of it from foreign sources seeking a stable investment climate, would stoke new development, even if traditional financing sources, like banks and insurance companies, stay on the sidelines. "Because of this flight capital there is a tremendous availability of funds to finance building in New York and its suburbs," he said.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.;
Room for Improvement, Bank Survey Shows

BYLINE: By KIT R. ROANE 

 BODY:
The working poor had a harder time obtaining loans in New Jersey last year than in almost any other state, according to recently released Federal data. Only California and South Dakota ranked lower.
The data, published in January in Inside Fair Lending, the banking trade paper, gauged each bank's compliance with the 1977 Community Reinvestment Act, which prohibits bias in the offering of loans. Although the act sets no specific quota for these financial institutions, it makes their lending policies subject to annual review by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and three other Federal agencies that oversee the industry. 
 Banks were rated by the total number and the size of loans to low- and moderate-income applicants. The agencies also looked at the number of bank branches or automatic teller machines available in poorer areas, according to the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency.
Consumer advocates said the state's dismal ranking showed that banks and thrifts in New Jersey were more interested in public-relations gimmicks than in lending to those most in need.
"What this shows is, our banks are more interested in sending a bank officer to volunteer for Habitat for Humanity than they are in supplying a mortgage for someone to own their own home," said Andrea Luquetta, a consumer lobbyist for New Jersey Citizen Action. "Volunteering is all well and good, but what people really need are mortgages and loans to start businesses. That's what a bank is supposed to provide."
Timothy Doherty, a spokesman for the 73-member New Jersey Bankers Association, defended his constituents, saying that the ranking system was rigged against states with many small banks like New Jersey. He added that the state had improved its overall rating from 1995, when New Jersey ranked at the absolute bottom of the list. Last year, 4.4 percent of the state's banks and thrifts were assessed as being out of compliance or in need of improvement, compared with 14.3 percent in 1995.
"We have come up overall, and certainly that is a positive sign," he said. "But we will never achieve the level of larger markets like the Philadelphia and New York City regions, which have an extremely large volume of loans. And I think it's hard for regulators sometimes to see this."
States can improve drastically between surveys, as New York has proved. After being ranked the third worst state in 1995, it moved up to the middle only 12 months later, largely because of new lending practices.
While only 52 New York banks had satisfactory lending rates in 1995, the number jumped to 97 the following year. Those in the "outstanding" category rose from 19 to 31.

LENGTH: 1612 words

HEADLINE: IN PERSON;
The Healing Professions

BYLINE: By DEBRA GALANT 

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
ERIC MUNOZ must have been destined to become a doctor. Who else from the 1961 graduating class of Atlantic Elementary School in Colts Neck would have saved and framed his eighth grade diploma? But there it is, right behind his desk at University Hospital here, jostling for wall space with real sheepskins and dozens of framed mementos, which together tell the crazy-quilt story of his life.
Any one of them can cause the burly, white-haired trauma surgeon to break into a story. There, for example, is a framed front page from the Sept. 28, 1995, Montclair Times -- "Post Office Slayer Will Never Go Free" -- signed gratefully by the only survivor of those shootings, David Grossman, whose life Dr. Munoz saved. "I was on the night that happened," said Dr. Munoz, recalling the phone call that told of a developing hostage situation in Montclair. "Five were coming in by helicopter. Then the call changed." Only Mr. Grossman made it to the hospital; the four others were already dead. 
 On his door is a photograph of a dark-haired Dr. Munoz launching a toy sailboat in Central Park in 1979. Its story is of a freshly minted surgeon, young and single, "living the good life in Manhattan." On another wall is a black-and-white photo, circa 1960, of Dr. Munoz's father at a Hispanic political rally in Monmouth County. Dr. Munoz, too, has become involved in politics, as has his son, William, whose campaign poster for the presidency of his sixth grade class, a post he won last year, hangs nearby.
Dr. Munoz's resume is 23 pages long. In addition to patching up knife and gunshot wounds at the state's busiest trauma center, Dr. Munoz, 50, regularly writes on managed care, teaches surgery at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey-New Jersey Medical School, is a councilman in Summit, a player in both Hispanic and Republican politics, and the father of five school-age children. He was recently appointed medical affairs liaison at the hospital, making him the official link between the hospital and outside institutions.
All this, and more, makes for a breathless schedule. One recent Thursday, Dr. Munoz went on the annual New Jersey Chamber of Commerce train trip to Washington along with 2,000 political and business leaders, flew back to attend his children's school talent show that night, popped over to a town meeting on preventing drug and alcohol abuse, returned to the talent show and then took his children and his wife, Nancy, out for Slurpees. (He missed his daughter's performance but caught the acts of two sons.) The next night, Dr. Munoz was back on duty in the emergency room, dealing with -- as he puts it -- a "variety of urban types of trauma."
Squeezing everything in isn't easy. "Time is the enemy," he jokes. "My family is worked in -- since it's a priority -- just like work."
At first, the man seems like an hodgepodge of contradictions: a deacon in the Presbyterian church raised by a Polish Jewish mother and a Puerto Rican father; a Republican who believes in gun control; a doctor who also holds an M.B.A.
But talk to him long enough, and certain patterns begin to appear. Dr. Munoz grew up above the Colts Neck General Store, which his parents, William and Frances, ran and which served, in a way, as the nerve center for the town. Anybody who needed to report a fire called the store, which in turn called the firehouse. His father established the town's first ambulance squad, which may have primed Dr. Munoz for his fast-paced medical career.
"When you're in an ambulance, people move out of your way," Dr. Munoz says. He recalls one specific motorcycle wreck right in front of the general store, that turned him from a bystander into an active participant. "I ran in, yelled for my father," Dr. Munoz remembers. "I went out to the street to try to administer first aid." The motorcyclist died anyway.
But even the more mundane chores of making sandwiches and serving strangers in a small-town general store was, in its own way, excellent training for emergency room work, Dr. Munoz says. Not only did he have to work fast and use his hands, but he was also "exposed to the entire population of America, migrant workers to millionaires, the entire spectrum." By the time he was 15, he points out, he had had "thousands of encounters with thousands of different people."
But the most exciting career can become humdrum, and even saving lives can turn routine. "After you do it 10,000 times, it's not as exciting as the first time," Dr. Munoz says. "You have a lot of burnout." If managing his time has been one of the basic challenges in Dr. Munoz's life, fighting boredom has been another.
So, in the early 1980's, Dr. Munoz took an unusual step for a practicing emergency room surgeon. Noticing that the health care system was beginning to undergo profound shifts, he decided to enroll in business school. "I didn't know exactly what was happening, but I knew there would be changes," he says.
Certainly, getting a master's degree in public health would have been a more predictable path for a doctor interested in the economics and politics of health care. But Dr. Munoz wanted to learn a completely different system of thought: "how the stock market works and why people buy soap," as he puts it. And despite the extra cost and work of grafting an M.B.A. program onto his surgical routine, Dr. Munoz was encouraged by one of his mentors from Yale, where he had done his internship and residency. "I don't know what this is going to do for you, but I guarantee that it's going to change your life," his old teacher, Dr. Hastings Kamuria Wright, said.
Dr. Munoz's 1983 M.B.A. from Columbia University indeed gave him the tools with which to understand managed care, and soon he was writing academic articles on titles like "Economic Cost of Trauma" and "Surgonomics." Some of the changes Dr. Munoz has witnessed over the last decade and a half were, in his view, necessary. Americans have now learned that "you can't give everything to everybody all the time," he says. But managed care has also, in Dr. Munoz's opinion, gone too far, and he sees it disappearing altogether 20 years from now. "Medicine's always been a business," he says. "What's different is that these companies have come in and made it brutally clear that profits are profits. They're in the business of not giving you medical care."
And that, in turn, has led Dr. Munoz into politics, the sphere in which he believes medicine will ultimately be saved. His background as a doctor, business school graduate and Hispanic political figure has led him into numerous public roles. He is a member of the New Jersey State Health Planning Board, and he has served on various health task forces and committees in Washington and New York City.
But Dr. Munoz also serves in the sphere of local politics, as councilman at large for the city of Summit, where he lives. Although he is interested in moving from local to state politics, he enjoys the intimacy of the political process at the local level. "It's wonderful," he says. "You learn from it. It's directly connected."
The connection was made even more direct earlier this year when Dr. Munoz, chairman of the public safety committee in Summit, noticed a suspicious character walking down a street in town late one night and called the police from his car phone. It turns out the man had just committed an armed robbery, and Dr. Munoz's vigilance led to a quick arrest.
He loved that moment, doing something directly for the public safety of his town, catching a robber. But it's just one small piece of a very busy life. Another piece is a $250,000 grant from Robert Wood Johnson Foundation to identify teen-agers at risk for violence and lead them, through church-run mentor systems, away from drugs and guns and, with any luck, from his emergency room. To Dr. Munoz, that's just one more way of giving back, and remembering where he comes from.
"What you realize as a trauma surgeon is, you can patch people up one at a time, but unless you get at the root forces, you're not going to solve the problem," Dr. Munoz says. "We're not going to get rid of violence, but we don't have to be the most violent country in the world."

HEADLINE: Quick Bite/Middletown;
Hungry for a Cheese Sandwich? Try This Soup

BYLINE: By JOE BRESCIA 

 BODY:
The buzz was everywhere at the mini-mall on Route 35 South.
"Did you try the cheese soup at Benjamin's?" the man behind the counter enthusiastically asked a customer at Steve's Motophoto, a film developing shop. 
 A few doors away, at Rose Garden Gifts, a couple of other shoppers were also raving about their lunch: "The cheddar soup was great, and they served thick sandwiches."
That's what happens when a new restaurant serves a pleasing and economical midday meal.
In this case, the place that had people talking was Benjamin's, a spacious bistro decorated with golf memorabilia. It opened in late December, offering inventive sandwiches, most priced at $5, and the popular cheddar cheese soup, which costs $3.95. (By the way, the restaurant is named for one of the owners, Warren Benjamin Minton.)
The golden-yellow soup, almost thick enough to be a dip, may be brought to your table by Benjamin's pleasant host, Peter Hunt. It's served in a hollowed-out six-inch round of Boston brown bread, on a platter surrounded with slices of brown bread and marble rye.
What's the secret of the thick and tangy soup?
 "Cheddar, milk and smoked ham are among the ingredients we use," said Mr. Hunt, reciting his answer in name, rank and serial number cadence.
A diner quizzed him about detecting the taste of jalapenos.
"That's all I can say," he said. "It's the chef's secret." And then, with a smile, he went to attend to other customers.
But the savory soup is no secret in Middletown, where diners at Benjamin's enjoy a bowl when the days are damp and chilly (and even when they aren't.) For business people, it's a satisfying way to take a break from the phones and computers. For shoppers, it's a place to catch a second wind before resuming their errands. And for golfers, it's a place to entertain visions of warm weather and under-par scores on the local golf courses. JOE BRESCIA
 BENJAMIN'S, 776 Route 35 South, Middletown. (908) 706-5993. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 8 A.M. to 7 P.M.; Saturdays and Sundays, 7 A.M. to 6 P.M.

HEADLINE: FUNDS WATCH;
Popularity Contests for Contrarians

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
What's hot and what's not? And why should stock market investors care?
Study after study has shown that people who put their money in the less-popular sectors of the market tend to do better than those who follow the hordes. That isn't surprising: contrarian investing is a longstanding strategy. 
 Latest to review the ugly-duckling theory are analysts at Morningstar Inc., the Chicago fund researchers. In a study conducted in January 1996, they found that buying the least-popular fund categories at the beginning of each year, and selling the most popular ones, improved investors' odds. The least-popular equity funds, chosen by cash flow, beat the average equity fund over the next one, two and three years 79 percent of the time from 1987 through 1994 and beat the most-popular funds 92 percent of the time.
At the beginning of this year, Morningstar updated its study by using its new fund categories, which are based on the funds' holdings, not on their objectives. Looking at the cash flow from 1987 through 1995, it found that the unpopular fund categories still won, beating the average equity fund in 19 of 24 time periods and whipping the popular funds 22 of the 24 times.
This year, betting on the underdogs meant owning funds in the utilities, communications and Latin America categories, the three most unpopular on Morningstar's latest list. The most popular categories were real estate, diversified emerging markets and mid-cap growth.
While it may seem logical to buy the most aggressive funds in unpopular categories, Susan Paluch, the managing editor of the Morningstar Investor newsletter, argues otherwise.
"More aggressive funds naturally catch a larger rebound, but if their area doesn't recover immediately, they're digging out of a bigger hole," she wrote in reporting on the popularity contest in the newsletter's January issue.
She recommends utilities funds like Fidelity Utilities and Lindner Utility that have less exposure than others to United States interest rates and to deregulation. The Fidelity fund concentrates on energy and services areas and likes the Baby Bells over rate-sensitive electric utilities, while Lindner Utility holds many cable television and satellite communications stocks. For investors willing to take more risk, Ms. Paluch recommends Franklin Utilities.
Among communications funds, she says Flag Investors Telephone Income is most conservative, Fidelity Select Multimedia more daring. But the best option, she said, is the T. Rowe Price closed-end fund, New Age Media, which sells at a small discount.
Similarly, two closed-end Latin America funds are trading at deep discounts: Latin America Equity and Emerging Markets Telecommunications.
Another option, for people who prefer mutual funds, is Scudder Latin America, which Ms. Paluch says is "by far the category's best risk-adjusted performer."
 
Fewer Money Funds Waiving Expenses
Fewer taxable money market funds are waiving expenses to bolster their yields. Only 57.9 percent of 801 taxable money funds did so during the last quarter of 1996, down from 61.2 percent during the comparable period a year earlier.
Three funds waived all expenses in the period, and, not surprisingly, they were among the highest yielders, according to IBC's Money Fund Expense Report.
They were the E-Fund, with a yield of 5.76 percent; Olde Premium Plus, 5.53 percent, and Strategist Money Market, 5.39 percent.
The most expensive fund was John Hancock Money Market Fund/class B shares, which charged its investors 2.08 percent of assets annually.
 
New Name for Omni
Berger Associates of Denver, has purchased the $36 million Omni Investment fund and renamed it the Berger Small Cap Value fund. Bob Perkins, who started the fund in 1987, will continue managing it.
Over the 12 months through Feb. 21, Omni gained 28.5 percent, compared with an average of 15.4 percent for all small-company funds, according to Morningstar. It rose 18 percent a year for the five years ended then, compared with 13.7 percent for its peers. Over the last decade, Omni rose 12.6 percent a year versus 11.9 percent for its peers.
The Berger fund assesses no sales charge; the minimum investment is $2,000.

New Managers
J. Rodman Wright, former assistant manager of Pioneer Capital Growth, has taken the reins of the fund from Warren J. Isabelle, who left the firm.
Invesco Small Company Growth, formerly Invesco Emerging Growth, is now managed by Tim Miller, Stacie Cowell and Trent May, who are part of the five-person team managing Invesco Growth and Invesco Dynamics. John Schroer, the former manager, will focus exclusively on health care funds.
 
New Funds
Turner Ultra Large Cap will invest primarily in a diversified portfolio of companies with market capitalizations greater than $10 billion and with earnings growth potential and reasonable valuations.
John Hancock Financial Industries can invest in brokerage firms, insurance companies, asset management firms, finance companies and banks around the world. It seeks companies that have positive earnings outlooks and that sell for reasonable prices. The co-managers are James Schmidt and Thomas Finucane, who also run John Hancock Regional Bank. The maximum initial sales charge is 5 percent.
 
In Brief
Vanguard Trustees' Equity Fund International will be renamed Vanguard International Value Portfolio, and Vanguard Quantitative Portfolios will become Vanguard Growth and Income Portfolio, both effective on April 30.

HEADLINE: A Tale of 2 Economists: Sizing Up the Income Gap

 BODY:
"Like Oil and Water: A Tale of Two Economists," by Louis Uchitelle (Feb. 16), examined the contrasting views of Paul Krugman and Lester Thurow of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, particularly their explanations for the growth of income inequality in the United States. Here are some readers' responses.
 
To the Editor: 
 I graduated from the predecessor of M.I.T.'s Sloan School of Management in 1942. The debate between the two M.I.T. economists is mind-boggling enough to convince me that we are looking at pure chaos -- the kind that generates the weather.
The worlds of meteorology and economics have much in common. The only difference is that the weather has been around long enough to establish a healthy state of chaos. (The world of economics, however, seems to be getting there nicely on its own.)
The world's atmosphere, however, has marvelous self-regulations; indeed, we have done well by sitting out our weather since time immemorial. Perhaps that's why the wisest advice you can get from an economic version of a meteorologist is this: When you invest wisely, sit on your investment. Stick with it!
The world economy is as controllable as the weather and just about as determinable. Professor Thurow? Professor Krugman?

CHARLES EMIL RUCKSTUHL
Groton, Mass., Feb. 15

HEADLINE: ON THE JOB;
Making an Impression Even if You Don't Fit the Mold

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
Office environments usually breed a welcome camaraderie. But once in a while, circumstances dictate that someone finds himself or herself on the outside looking in.
 One day, Joseph H. Zimmerman of Wilmington, Del., looked up and realized he was alone. He had become the lone man in his section of a large pharmaceutical company, where the work involved complex computerized technical searches in medicine and chemistry. Most members of the unit held advanced degrees in science. 
 There was something else, too.
Mr. Zimmerman was not just the only man working with 13 women; he was also the "old man." In his 60's, he was often sought out by the women for advice, particularly emotional and financial.
In this unit, there was a Thursday morning ritual: a meeting over coffee and goodies in a conference room for relaxed talk, unrelated to work. The boss encouraged the meeting. She thought the atmosphere would enable the staff to get to know one another better, leading to improved interaction on the job.
"After a few sessions I stopped attending," writes Mr. Zimmerman, who was married and had three daughters at home. He said the women, whom he described as a "bright and worldly group," would start discussing "food preparation, love lives, recipes, fashion and the latest office gossip."
"Everybody took turns bringing in cookies and cakes they had prepared at home," he said. "I did not feel like baking cookies, and I didn't feel I should ask my wife to prepare goodies for my coffee group."
Birthday celebrations were a particular challenge. "Men just don't give a hoot about birthdays," he said. "Cards had to be bought and signed by everyone with cute little poems or soppy sentiments." And then the recipient was supposed to be surprised at the card and the cake.
"One day my boss came into my office and noted that I hadn't been to Thursday coffee in a while," Mr. Zimmerman continued. "She felt it was important that we have a relaxed bonding experience once a week. Once I told her my complaints, she nodded in understanding and laughingly told me I was excused from Thursday morning coffee time."
He has since retired, but every few months he rejoins his closest co-workers for lunch and a chance to catch up on company gossip.
But, he said, "I don't have to bring any cookies and cake."
Linda A. Teplin says she was something of a novelty in 1975 as one of the few women who served as faculty members at a large university medical school. Though clearly not discriminatory, the school had made few provisions for people like her.
She writes: "There were two washrooms on each floor: 'faculty' and 'ladies.' I never did figure out which one was intended for me."
Then there is David Erickson of Chatham, Mass., an editor with the Adams-Laux Publishing Company, who woke up one day to find himself the only male in his office after the only other man was laid off.
The next day the sign on the men's-room door was covered over.
The new sign said, "Dave's room."
Alice Dayton, 52, who works in Manhattan for Makovsky & Company, a public relations firm, deals with being twice the age of most of her office co-workers by telling "I remember" stories.
Some go this way:
"I remember walking around inside the first computer.
"I remember the first calculator. I was an economist at the fifth-largest corporation in the world. Lots of statistics. To multiply by five, you set the pins and whizzed the handle around five times.
"I remember when you had to crank the telephone to ring the operator.
"I remember before television, plastic bags and pantyhose.
"I remember when you had to squoosh the yellow packet in margarine to give it color.
"I remember rumble seats."
"A couple of years ago, I was a 58-year-old in a high-tech company populated by people my children's age," writes a Massachusetts man who asks that his name be withheld. "I could do E-mail, but that was about it; and my younger colleagues harangued me to use the laptops and other high-tech tools with which they surrounded themselves.
"Finally, I gave in and arranged to take a course in computer fundamentals."
The request was processed through the vice president for human resources, a younger man, and was returned with a note that said: "Approved, but I didn't think old dogs could learn new tricks."
The man replied via E-mail: "Thanks for your approval. I enjoyed your joke. So did my attorney."
Within minutes, the vice president was in the man's office. "He laughingly explained he was kidding, and I laughingly replied that I was, too," the man writes.
"I'm not saying any of that helped my career, but it's two years later, I'm still employed there and still the oldest dog in the pen."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Reading The Mind Of Alan Greenspan

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Phew! At last the Humphrey-Hawkins Congressional testimony is over. I left them as confused as ever, and I have all the freedom of movement I could possibly want. I'll be using that freedom to tighten soon, no matter how much static I get from the "growth at any risk" crowd.
It is a little amazing, even in my 10th year in the job, to see how Wall Street hangs on my every word, yet manages to misinterpret many of them. Having issued three warnings about how stock prices were a bit rich, I threw a concession to the bulls, and they leaped for it as if it were a red cape. And we all know what happens to bulls who go for red capes. 
 "If profit margins continue to rise as Wall Street analysts expect them to," I told the House Banking Committee on Wednesday, "then the market is properly priced as best we can judge on the basis of the level of where interest rates are."
And, I might have added, if the moon is made of green cheese, then there is probably a cow up there somewhere.
What I know, and what everyone ought to know, is that analysts almost always overestimate earnings growth. Which is why stocks almost always seem cheap compared with forecasts. Now, they seem reasonable. And nobody bit on that qualification about interest rates. Did no one remember the hints I've been throwing around about "pre-emptive" action to halt inflation before it appears? I may not be very good at predicting the stock market, but I sure can forecast changes in short-term interest rates.
The Dow rose 93 points on that remark. And they loved it when I said I didn't view monetary policy as a tool to "prick the stock market bubble." That's the whole point. The stock market is not a bubble yet, but it's getting close to being one. I hope something will happen to slow the ascent of prices, or to bring them down gradually. Nobody has ever peacefully deflated a bubble.
I've lived a charmed life as Fed chairman. The 1987 crash came so early in my tenure that no one thought I was to blame. Then I engineered a steep yield curve so that the banks could borrow from depositors cheaply and make good money on two-year Treasuries. That got the banks out of the hole they had dug themselves into with a lot of foolish real estate loans. Now, almost everyone treats me with the kind of respect that other central bankers crave.
But more and more, I find myself thinking about Japan. In the 1980's, when real estate and stock prices were becoming a bubble, its central bank looked at inflation statistics, found them comforting, and did nothing until it was far too late. I won't make that mistake.
Now the Bank of Japan is desperately trying to get that economy moving, but it must deal with a Government too timid to use public money to rescue dying banks. It has pushed interest rates so low that they are financing speculation around the world, even if they haven't done much for Japan's economy. How I wish they would raise rates, or do something to push up the yen and scare the speculators.
Obviously, I can't let stocks be the only thing I watch. I've got two weapons -- my mouth and the Federal funds rate -- and with them I'm supposed to keep watch on economic growth, inflation and the dollar. Pushing up interest rates a bit will be easy. But what do I do if the economy looks a little weak and yet stocks keep soaring? Maybe I keep tightening. I don't think that would bring on a recession. At least I hope it wouldn't.
One thing I'm sure of: if the economy or the stock market crashes on my watch, I'll get the blame. I've got to find a way to make sure that doesn't happen. It would be nice if the stock market would deflate in a nice, gentle fashion. But if it won't, I'll have to find a way to encourage it not to become the kind of a bubble that would ruin my reputation, not to mention the economy.
